reviews.review: Its a park, its free. Take a break from the madness of the city find a bench and relax. Just avoid the folks with doves wanting to take your picture

WOW!!. Difficult to describe this fantastic palace - simply think of the superlatives you know! It it almost overwhelming with gold and treasure - a real feast for the eyes. After being very badly damaged during the war the palace has been painstakingly restored using old photographs for reference. The amber room is absolutely fantastic and we were told by our guide that Germany had contributed several millions to the cost of restoration. In my opinion it's certainly worth visiting with a guide so you don't miss anything important and are given information of this nature which you don't find in guide books. We visited last week and apparently this was the last week of the fountains. I would recommend visiting in October - virtually no queues and although the weather was chilly it wasn't bitterly cold. The grounds are beautiful and an added bonus was watching the tame red squirrels and birds which were everywhere. There is a little market just outside the house where you can buy the usual souvenirs - several of our group bought fur hats at considerably lower prices than the shops in St Petersburg after a little bartering. Don't hesitate to visit, it's very special.

Way too overcrowded and chaotic. Oh dear. Most museums in Russia have strict rules and time frames for tour groups. This is a relatively small palace so, in theory, they want visitors to keep moving through the rooms, no back tracking, no selfie sticks, no flash photography. Apparently the hordes of Chinese tour groups didn't get or adhere to the memo... Inside the palace it was extremely crowded and we were subjected to Chinese visitors continually shoving their way past our group. Hard to appreciate the opulent beauty of the hall of mirrors or amber room with so many people in a smallish space. On a positive note, it was interesting to see how they reconstructed and restored this palace that was nearly destroyed in WWII. The grounds were also very lovely.The sad thing is that despite that October is considered off season, our group waited 30 minutes beyond our scheduled time to enter the palace. Our guide said that on her summer tours at the height of the season they've waited in line for 3 hours just to enter !

Extravagant Luxury. This is a short ride outside St Petersburg. Go early to beat the crowds. If you get there before it opens the grounds are lovely and worth a walk. A band often plays it the gate to keep your busy while waiting. They are fun to watch.This has it all: great halls, lots of gold, mirrors and more mirrors, grand staircases and lovely furnishings.The amber room which is paneled in amber is worth the trip.
Amber Room Plus. The Amber room is a definite highlight but the shear size of the palace and its decorations are stunning to view.
Beautiful. Fabulous Palace and Gardens especially the celebrated Amber room. Preferably go with a guide on prebooked tickets which will reduce waiting times considerably
Another wow. The Romanovs really new how to spend money and this building and its gardens are a must see if you are in St. Petersburg
Brilliant. Another Russian jewel. Stunningly beautiful rooms like the ballroom and the amber room are once in a lifetime experiences.
A must see. If you have very limited time in Saint Petersburg, the Catherine Palace is a place worth visiting. I suggest you go early morning so that it is less crowded.

This palace will not disappoint..... I would highly recommend going on a tour to narrate thru the palace and get a schedule time to go in. The line to wait to get in was over 2 hours that day I went. The surrounding neighborhood was quaint and the back gardens were amazing. The palace it self was limited to a small section as part of it was destroyed and never repaired. It is amazing the care taken into preserving the palace.....so that it can be passed on to enjoy by all.

Worth the Elbows, Pushing & Shoving Crowds. Yes it is worth it--really lovely with several "WOW" moments reminiscent of Versailles : Great Hall & "Amber Room" to name two.
Devout some time (at least equal proportion of time) for a refreshing stroll in the gardens.

Fabulous. Amazing place. We had a guide who explained all the different rooms and artefacts. You need one. Very ornate but beautiful. The amber room is awe inspiring but no photos allowed. You can take them everywhere else. There's a cafe for a sit down. It gets crowded even early on an October day

Wonderful. We did this as part of our 2 day Alla Tours Faberge Museum shore excursion ex Cruise Terminal. Went inside this one instead of the Peterhof. Definitely impressive. Very busy. With a tour guide and only 16 in our group, our experience was much better than normal buses (25-50 people) and doing it alone. Note: A lot of shore excursions do not include this one OR charge a lot more to do so. Alla Tours seemed to get the mix of places, timing and price as best it can be.

Awesome. I thought it rivaled VERSAILLES, but a fellow traveler disagreed! It was truly magnificent. I was especially eager to see THE AMBER ROOM or the recreation of. It was special, but not quite what I expected. No pictures allowed.Since Leningrad [St.P] , 1 in 3 buildings were destroyed in WW2, according to guide, ALL rebuilding after WW2 was done & paid for by Russia,"we're a rich country with gold, silver, etc" except THE HERMITAGE, which Germany helped with,as they looted it.

Garden is natural and elegant. Not like hermitage museum, this place you feel more like a residence.Even it is very luxurious, but you like to live there too. Relax and having a couple servants and friends to walk through the garden and enjoy the afternoon tea in there.We went to the restaurant inside the garden near the lake. Food is fine but atmosphere is great! The restaurant used to be a boat garage.

Worth a visit, but requires guide. The place is a little over crowded on the weekend. Effort is crowd control is not working well. A guide is a must as there are no written guide to the exhibits. Impressive exhibits and garden.
Love the garden more. The garden cost RUB120 and inside the palace costs RUB1,000. I enjoyed the garden in fall season and inside the palace, all are gold.

If Gold is Your Passion. What a magnificent turquoise and gold set of buildings that are beautifully set off by the gardens. A comparison to Verseilles with all the rooms each one outdoing themselves with more gold. Makes you think of the peasants and the contrast of such wealth in that time of residence of the nobility vs the common people.

A spectacular palace. I arranged a tour through Marina Wilson Private Tours. The guide Anna was very well informed. Her knowledge of the history much appreciated. The inside of this Palace including the Amber room should be on a must see list of anyone visiting St Petersburg.

A must see while visiting St Petersburg. This is an incredibly preserved-restored place, espcially considering it was mostly destroyed during WWII. The restored ambiences are beautiful and complete. Definetely worth a visit.

Beautiful. If you visit this place, do it either very early of at about 16-00, it's the least popular time. If you do it in October, you will see the whole palace. They show just a half of it in summer. Don't overestimate the importance of visiting Puskin's lyceum. It's also worth visiting!

Tsarskoe Selo is its name. This was my favourite place during our trip. Considering that it was wrecked by the Nazis and has been completely restored the contents with one exception are original as they were all sent to Siberia! Of course the exception is the Amber Room which has taken 20 years to restore. The rest of the rooms are heavy on gold decor, containing a remarkable collection of Catherine I and Tzarina Elizabeth's artefacts. We had a very knowledgeable guide to show us round. The gardens are also well worth a visit; they were designed by a Scottish architect named Cameron. Can be crowded but well worth a visit.

my 1st suggestion. go to this place with bus, because you can see Pushkin village and it's very nice.the park is very big and beauty, when you buying ticket, ask a map of park. don't miss visiting all places.

You must be fit!. The palace is wonderful. They control the number of people going in to ease the flow.It seems to work well. The whole place is fabulous and well worth the metro and bus from the city.One point to note---- if you have difficulty walking ( like me at the moment) there are absolutely no chances to sit down whatsoever throughout the tour. I asked if I could sit for one minute in the attendant,s chair and she rudely refused.
Marvellous scenery. The whole palace, the wooden floors, the amber room , etc. : incredible & astonishing ! Not to be missed !

Well worth the trip to Tsarskoye Selo. Although the Catherine Palace is a bus or train trip from St. Petersburg, it is definitely worth it! This palace has been amazingly restored, as have its grounds. Tours seem to be mandatory and arriving is quite chaotic, so try and find an English language tour if possible. It's a lot like Versailles, but a lot cheaper! They are still restoring the church and the nearby Alexander Palace, but what you currently see is still great, especially the photographs showing how far the restoration has come since World War II.
Do not miss this. Very impressive Palace and warrants at least a half day to enjoy the surrounds. Suggest a full day. No photographs inside the palace but allowed in the gardens.
Check box for St Petersburg. If you see one palace you see them all. This is true for Catherine Palace. For all the splendor, only the famous Amber Room is worth the visit.

STP Tour. It's an hour to reach this palace. We arrived in early morning and it's rainy. This is a summer palace for Catherine the Great and Tsars. It's huge and was destroyed by the Nazi's during the second world war but has been painstakingly restored continuously ever since. The real highlight was Amber room - a room made entirely of Amber. Outside, you need to walk thru the nice garden with fresh air. Also, do not forgot to listen a a group of young Russian man singing with good voices. buy their CD's. It's worth it.

Disappointing. Another attraction I visited many years ago and finally returned now I can appreciate more of the finer details...The experience began with a wait for tickets outside the palace which lasted a spine aching 3 hours (plus). There is little in the way of seating for those in the queue who need it and no shelter from the elements which inevitably turned wet as we stood in line.Upon reaching the front of the queue you are left to your own devices to fathom which ticket to buy, where from and where to go after purchasing your ticket. I appreciate many will have no difficulty in finding their way, but the process and route is far from obvious for some.Once inside the queuing does not end. Each room must evacuate a number of people before more can be let in. This results in bottle necks which are often clogged further by large tour groups thus making a leisurely stroll through the palace impossible.The palace itself is of course beautiful. The main hall with its gold and mirrors is by far the highlight in my opinion although the workmanship of the amber room must also be admired. The interior is so impressive that it is a shame we couldn't see more of it. After waiting so long to enter the entire route took 1 hour, much of which was spent waiting to enter or leave rooms.The ticket prices are also somewhat steep at 1000RUB (approx. £12) for adults or 500RUB if you are a tax paying resident of the Russian Federation.Upon asking a guard whether this was the norm for summer he confirmed that every day is as busy. My advice would be to visit the palace during its opening hours from September to May if you gave the option and frankly I would give it a miss in July or early August.

Better than Peterhof !. Well, Katherina had a better taste thsn Peter ))) We liked her palace and parks more although both are spectacular ! You can easily spend half a day there, we had a full day triü starting from Newsky Prospect at 11:20.

Spectacular Palace. This spectacular palace is adorned with 'E' all over the place because Catherine is Ekaterina in Russian We knew that crowds would be a problem especially the Chinese tour groups who are new to travel and have not yet learned the concepts of lining up or moving through the building in an orderly group so we booked a private guide with local Alla tours. It is a little more expensive than joining the 'cattle herd' but skips the lines and is well worth it. The palace was largely destroyed by the Nazi's during the second world war but has been painstakingly restored continuously ever since. Much of the furniture and art treasures were saved and hidden in Siberia and gradually returned as restoration continued. Today this is a beautiful palace with Rococo architecture and beautiful colors and gold gilt exterior. Inside are some priceless paintings and antiques and the real highlight a room made entirely of Amber. The original was looted by the Nazi's and in Germany it disappeared. Ten years ago there was enough money to amass 9 tonnes of premium Amber which was hand picked and sorted to get the three tons needed to perfectly recreate the amber room using the old techniques. Fortunately the room was so impressive a 100 years ago there were hundreds and hundreds of photographs for reference. This was the summer palace of Catherine the Great and subsequent Tsars and here, an hour our of town the weather was cooler and the air fresher. I highly recommend a private tour company like Alla for this attraction.

Lack of organisation. The one thing that brought me there was the Amber Room. After entering the palace grounds, I had to wait again to enter the palace itself. After entering the palace, there was a security line after which you could finally enter the palace. Personally, I stuck on the security line: the first time I had to leave my backpack to the cloakroom although its size was within limits according to the signs and the second time because my ticket expired (it is valid 1 hour after its issuance). So, after a 3-hour waiting-in-line I left without actually visiting the palace.It seems that the palace is not an ideal destination for individual visitors. Really, what's the point of waiting after you enter an attraction? I'm really disappointed of the organisation of this place.

Hold your bladder. Warning...Bathroom facilities are severely lacking.Otherwise, this place, this palace, will be as grand as expected. Our visit was extraordinary. Your visit will be extraordinary. The buildings, the grounds, the story. You could stay here for days and just scratch the surface. Throughout our tour we kept hearing about Catherine’s excessive appetite for sex. It is only a legend that she was crushed by a horse. My final thought…..I guess when you rule with an iron fist, while the people starve and live in poverty…you can build grand palaces and live in opulence and luxury. Take note! We were on a Shore Excursion Group tour and we basically just walked right in. So many people were standing around waiting to get in. A tour might be the way to go.

Beautiful palace and surrounds. We thoroughly enjoyed our guided tour through this beautiful palace.....really didn't enjoy the crowds where ever we went throughout. The Amber Room has to be seen to be believed.....incredible opulence. The gardens were very nice but really aren't in the same league as Peterhof.....probably unfair to make a comparison.
Beatiful. Another amazing must-see place to see in St Petersburg, spoilt only by the Chinese who have no manners and don't know how to behave in public

Too much hype. After being driven around the palace like a herd of cattle and fighting through the crowds just to look a little closer at anything, my conclusion is that it is not worth all the effort and expense that so many people have expended.Sure, there is lots of gold and there is an amber room, but really, what we have seen and heard so much about just drove expectations sky high. When faced with the reality, we were quite disappointed. All I can say is that somebody did a damn good PR job on the place!Having said that, one has to see it if one goes to st petersburg, at least to satisfy one's curiosity.

Viewed From Outside. We did not go inside because it was not on our guided tour list of places to visit. We did pass within yards of the palace and the guide gave a running commentary. It is very beautiful building and somehow escaped demolition by the Bolsheviks..

Lovely to look at, just wish you could hold. A wonderful walk through a historic period. Your guide will, of course, be a big difference in how much you enjoy the history of this palace. Ours was very good and kept things fun. Photo ops at every turn, just do not use the flash. And then you have the gardens. Hope you have as nice a day as we did and that your tour schedules enough time to walk through the gardens and lake sides and other buildings. Greens keepers should be getting a special award for the maintenance on this area and we were there late in the summer season.
Quite a palace. A must visit in St Petersburg, don't forget to buy a postcard of Amber Room because you are not allow to take photo in this room

Wow, now this is living!. Guess I didn't realize the wealth the Russian Czars had. And it is all on display in this opulent palace. Room after room of just beautiful gilded walls, lapis and malacite tables. Not to miss.

Amazing and opulent. One of the highlights of St Petersburg is a visit to Catherine's Palace. Lots of wows and admiration, too much opulence of Tzar bygone days. Many beautiful decorated rooms and beautiful ornated ceilings, etc and a replica of the amber room. Well worth a visit, words can't describe as well as one can see with one's own eyes.
Knock your socks off. Be prepared to have your socks knocked off by this amazing Palace. Each room has its own personality, especially the Amber room! This is a must see place.

By far the best palace to see in St Petersburg. The opulence of this palace is unbelievably magnificent. Such beauty inside and out. Guildings, carvings, parquet floors, antiquities are just stunning. The grounds are also lovely. Very busy with tour groups so be patient when going through, and get there early when it opens.
Beautiful comparable to Versailles . Very nicely restored palace with an unique atmosphere. The rebuild amber room gives a good picture of the extravaganza the royals lived in those days.

History Alive. This is another of St Petersburg's best historical/cultural visits. Best visited with a group and guide; guides know the important facts and rooms, take care of ticketing for you, and get you to the group entrance. Allow several hours just to stroll through; photos allowed, but none in the Amber Room - a must see, but with appropriate lines of people. Since it is located outside of St Petersburg, allow w/ traffic at least an hour+ to get there. Lovely gardens on the outside after tour, some benches for the weary. A number of stairs to climb up & down. WC's available at beginning and end of tour. You won't believe the photos from WWII and how this Palace has been restored. Great visit!

Amazing renovation.. The restoration work since destruction by the Germans during World War Two is amazing. The opulence is mind blowing. There are too many rooms to describe, but the reconstructed Amber room is amazing, as is the great hall. Be prepared for large crowds. The gardens are lovely also.

Well restored palace. Lovely palace and gardens but spoiled by the tourists who have to stop to take a selfie in front of every single item and room, and when there are large groups of them this spoils it for everyone. I felt very sorry for the lady looking after the Amber room where so many in one group were taking photos where it is forbidden. They even took photos through the threshold of the room. The group should have been removed and the guide not allowed to work here again as he did nothing to help the situation.

Day at Tsarskoe Selo . Absolutely amazing. From Catherine the Great to the damage in World War II, from the state dining rooms to the Amber Room, from the ball room to the gardens, everything is stunning. Just be prepared to WALK and at quite a pace. The tours are in groups and you have one in front of you and another waiting behind. You are steered on and on and it can be exhausting. As with every site, you're not allowed bottles of water with you and you will need a drink afterwards.

The Blue Palace of St Petersburg . After visiting three palaces in St Petersburg in the space of 2 days, I remember Catherine Palace as the blue palace. It was the first of the three visited and being greeted by the blue painted exterior stuck. The highlight of this summer palace is the meticulously replicated Amber room, the only room where photography is forbidden. The gardens are a nice walk too, with a beautiful pavilion by the lake but it's not as grand as the grounds of Peterhof Palace.

An Imperial Palace At Its Best. Although the Russian people paid dearly for this extravagant palace (which apparently was built and destroyed several times until the Czarina was satisfied with it), it is a wonder. Especially the Amber Room, which although is a restoration of the original, is breath-taking. Don't miss it. We took a private tour, which ensured we did not stand on line. Our guide also took us to a cute coffeehouse, which we never would have found without him. Souvenirs should be bought out of town, so this is a good as place as any to buy the usual mementos.

Amazing - worth the trip!. If you have an extra day to fit a trip up to Pushkin this is definitely worth it. Many tour agencies offer tours, all you need is a half day or even around 6 hours to see Pavlovsk Palace as well.Can get busy with tour groups as well, but easy to navigate for independent travelers as well. Don't forget to put the little booties provided on your feet!
Beautiful. Extremely popular,lots of tour groups but well worth a visit to this lavishly restored opulent palace nestled in manicured grounds.The Amber room is jaw dropping.
Baroque palace. Baroque palace, shows the opulence that existed in the Russia of the czars .Rebuilt after its destruction during WWII is now one of the great attractions of visitors St . Petersburg

The best in St. Petersburg.. This is the best place to visit in St. Petersburg. It is so so beautiful. The outside is amazing with the blue and golden colors. The rooms inside are breathtaking. The welcome was given by a band of old gents that played and danced. Wonderful!

Incredible Restored Masterpiece. This palace was originally constructed in the 18th century, looted and pretty much destroyed by the Nazis during WW2, but in the intervening 70 years has been painstakingly restored to its former magnificent glory. there is still plenty of work to do in the interior, but there is plenty to see, all of which is wonderful. When we visited it was quite crowded with long lines to get in, but definitely worthwhile. the exterior is ornate with a largely blue, white and gold color scheme, plenty of statues and carvings, some gilded included the gilded domed chapel. The interior is exquisite, with many differently themed rooms, all restored to their original condition with looted artwork brought back home wherever possible. The amber room is simply extraordinary, although it had to be reconstructed entirely from scratch using surviving designs since the original decor was stolen and never found. Part of the lure of this palace for me was the fascinating ongoing long term restoration work, started during the communist era and continuing to this day. One hallway contains photos and information about the destruction caused by the Nazis and it's just amazing that the palace has been so wonderfully restored. Beautiful. The formal gardens are also worth a gentle stroll.

Wow!. Just beyond belief! Opulent, stunning, gilded, all the superlatives! But very very busy so not really time to stand about and enjoy the splendours of the Palace - many tours all following each other round. Nevertheless it is a 'must see' destination. The gardens are beautiful and worth a visit too

Visit to Catherine's palace. Even more incredibly beautiful than Peterhof ( palace of Peter the Great). With Peterhof, this palace is a must see. The palace, adjoining buildings and the grounds are extremely well maintained and presented. Over the top magnificence truly displaying the gradeur of royalty's life in the Czarist period. Not to be missed.

Awesome place. It was really a beauty.One of the sites you really dont want to miss.Best with a tour in which you can get to know the history of the place better.Dont forget to spend some time in the park too . You can have a pretty long walk and enjoy the view .

A beautiful palace with a high entry fee and lots of tour groups. . We took a mini bus from the end of the blue metro which was fairly easy. On arrival we were surprised by how much the entrance fee had increased from 600 to 1000 roubles as well as 120 for the park entrance. It is not as spectacular as the Hermitage and there is not as much to see. However, we did love the Amber Room which was spectacular. It loses its attraction with the number of tour groups even in the latter part of September. The gardens and outer buildings are lovely but each building had an additional entrance fee.

Unbelievable. This is a true trip back in time to an era when the use of the word spectacular can not be used enough. It is beautifully preserved and open to the public. Another St. Petersburg not to be missed place.

Breathtaking. What can you say about the most wonderful building. Just breath-taking in its grandeur, but more amazing is how well and beautifully it has been restored after WW2 and the destruction. Leningrad (as it used to be known) was held under siege for over 3 years and virtually demolished and the population starved. The Palace was just amazing, room after room of gold, glass, silks and ambers

must see!. if you are going anywhere for history and grandeur in st Petersburg you must go here! the whole place is amazing,i literally walked from room to room saying wow,each room was more amazing than the last!!

Beautiful. When we went, the guide mentioned that the palace was recently repainted. It definitely made the building much more impressive. Again, there was quite a line-up to enter the palace. There were "monitors" in each of the rooms waving fans to tell you to move into the next room so the next group can enter.I was happy that you were allowed to take photos (without flash), all except the "amber room". Not sure why that is the case. Again, maybe it's to increase revenues by having to buy the photos. After all, the palace is a recreation.Grounds surrounding palace are not as impressive as the Peterhof. I would definitely recommend a professional guide to explain each of the rooms and to highlight certain items in each of the rooms

Incredible Palace. This was not available on most of the tours we found in St. Petersburg, but it was well worth the visit. The palace is a masterpiece. The Amber Room did not disappoint. Every room was more breathtaking than the last. The large ballroom of mirrors (the Throne Room) was like a Versailles.

Mouth watering gorgeous. This is a real must to visit, allow plenty of time and you will take time to just stand in awe. have been three times and still find new objects to stand and admire. A true gem.

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. The Catherine's Palace is very alike all Czar Palaces, extremely sumptuous and rich of amazing pieces of art like furniture, tapestries and paints. Once you get inside you are immediately captured from the impressive staircase which leads you on the first floor and from that point you'll start your tour through the palace's rooms. The most impressive one is the room having all its walls completely covered by pieces of amber and that one is without any doubt the apotheosis of wealth. After the palace tour you can enjoy a nice walk through the beautiful garden which surrounds the palace and if you like you can enjoy the visit of others pavilions along with a relaxing walk around the lake.

Simply breathtaking. The interiors of the Palace rival Versailles, gauche by today's standards but stunning nonetheless. We were the first group to arrive to had the palace to ourselves - simply breathtaking. An absolute must for any visitor to St Petersburg. Allow time to visit the gardens, they too are magnificent.

Puts Versailles to (somewhat) shame. Wow, wow, wow!!! We visited Catherine's Palace and the gardens as part of a full day tour to the Peterhof and this Palace. It's a tough call, and there is no doubt that the gardens at the Peterhof are much more impressive, but if you only have time for one, I would visit Catherine's Palace over the Peterhof. To clarify, the gardens at Catherine's Palace certainly can hold up on their own; in fact, there's more variety here than at the Peterhof as there's a French style garden, an English style garden and an Italian style garden, not to mention the huge expanse of woods in front of the palace where Empress Elizabeth enjoyed hunting. However, there is no doubt that the interior of Catherine's Palace put every palace I've seen in the world, and that includes Versailles, to shame. This was opulence at its greatest and shows how the tsars, at their zenith, lived in the most abundant of surroundings. We seemed to go from a grand room, to a grander room, to an even grander room and so on and every room seemed to have more gold leaf, more opulence, more riches. It's just overwhelming. The Amber room was impressive, but it's not a large room and did not impress us as much as the grand salons where the tsars and tsarinas would hold balls, meet heads of state, etc. I can see how a visitor, in those days, would stand in awe of the riches and power of Russia's rulers by just entering one of these rooms. I should also note that there is a very beautiful loggia on a small hilltop where Catherine the Great enjoyed walking during rain. The view of the palace and the gardens from there are just stunning. If you go to St. Petersburg, do try to visit both the Peterhof and Catherine's Palace, but for me, Catherine's Palace was the clear winner.

Magnificent park and grounds, amber room is a must see. This park is huge. Consists of two parts: regular park where everything is kept up and trimmed and the rest of the park. One can walk for hours. There are statues and buildings all over. Also a pond with gondolas rides. We had a couple of days in Pushkin and stayed in the hotel next to the park and palace, so we took advantage of the free hours (after 7 pm in the summer). Walked for two hours and it was still daylight. Catherine's palace is nice, but inside only two rooms really matter: amber room (no photography by the way in the room) and the great "gold" hall. There are several more rooms, but if you really like to see the interiors of the imperial summer palaces - go to Petehoff (the palace there is much more restored). But just remember that amber room is unique and only in Catherine's palace.

Famous for the amber room. This palace is only partially restored from being looted and burned in the 2nd world war. The public rooms are all redone and quite beautiful. The amber room with with the walls all covered with Amber has been recreated and restored after over 30 years of research and work. The grounds are also delightful. Like all palaces there are loads of tourists that make a visit somewhat stifling. The great hall, with its gold and mirrors overwhelms your senses. This is another example of how over the top the czars lived. The grounds are wonderful. Like a lot of the tourist places in Russiait is better to go with a private car and guide to tell you what you are seeing and to guide you around the throngs of busses. A highlight for us was visiting the amber workshop on the grounds (an additional fee). We learned about amber and how it is used in decoration and jewelry. You see a lot of amber in Rusdia and it was helpful to become knowledgable about what we were seeing.

Very Nice!. We took the metro blue line to the last stop then the 186 bus to the Palace. Very easy, about 1 hour between the two rides.Worth the effort, nice little village on out skirts of palace. We only did the grounds of the palace and it was great!

FAMOUS FOR ITS AMBER ROOM. Originally built for Catherine the wife of Peter the Great it was redesigned for their daughter Elizabeth by the Imperial architect Rastrelli and the Scottish architect Charles Cameron to rival Versailles. You can take pictures of every room but not the Amber Room now totally reconstructed with amber in every shade of yellow from dusky topaz to bright lemon, enriched with Florentine mosaics. During the Second World War the amber panels were looted by the Nazi's. the Palace is best visited out of the high season when there are queues and in the public rooms there are tourists entering on both sides. In addition because of the volume of visitors the tour is restricted
Most Opulent Palace you have ever seen!. This place is fantastic and shows the Russian aristocracy at the height of their powers. Really, don't miss it!

Simply the best . Not to be missed palace and gardens, I've been twice and it gets better, Amber room is unbelievable,as is rest of the palace,gardens are a pleasure to walk round and photo opportunity is superb

Nice park with a lot of lakes and ponds. A park that unlike other parks in the surrounding palaces (Peterhof, Pushkin) is nature like and not as glamourous. It doesn`t mean that it is less fun to walk around it and enjoy the beauty of nature. We didnt get inside the palace as it was closed. From the outside the palace looks more like a castle then a palace.
Another palace brimming with gold. Opulence galore. Stunning interior as well as huge grounds.Almost overwhelmed by all the gold and paintings and furniture that is of the highest quality.

Jaw dropping Catherine Palace. A must see. Do take advantage of the semi-private tours If you can. This will allow you extra time and less crowds. Although you forget the crowds as you immerse yourself in the splendor of the palace especially the Amber Room! We came back at night to listen to the concert at the Great Hall. Wonderful experience altogether.

A Palace of Opulence. A fantastic palace with beautiful interiors well restored after Hitler all but destroyed it during the war. A credit to the restorers. The grounds are also lovely and compliments the experience.
Great Palace. This palace has been wonderfully restored by Russian craftsman since its looting and destruction in WW2. It is worth seeing for the Amber Room alone.

Absolutely stunning . The park is magnificent with a lot of different buildings around such as Turkish bath , pavilion on the water. The queue to the palace is quite big during season but worth the wait , beautiful rooms and display , specially the amber room, the only bad thing is they allow you to take picture every where except this room beware of the woman dragon if she sees you taking picture they are not kidding .
Magnificent . Another must see St Petersburg attraction. Opulent, elegant and magnificent. Huge crowds, big tour groups and stiff staff are the downers. Grand park.

Catherine's Palace cannot be missed. Spend the extra time to take the road trip from St. Petersburg to tour this marvelous palace. The ballroom is featured in the latest version of the 2016 BBC film War and Peace (based on Leo Tolstoy's novel). The Rooms that have been reconstructed and refurbished are exquisite. You will need a guide for interpretation to get the historical background. Honestly, the opulence is stunning and a testament to revolution. It's no wonder it was so brutal and complete.

Nice. One of the iconic things to see. We did it with a private tour guide and this allowed us to jump the queues which were long.Also got a lot of history that we wouldn't otherwise get. The amber room was the highlite for me.

Gold Room!. What a beautiful way to spend a day! The palace and gardens are jaw-dropping room after room, space after space. Lots of tourists when we went which meant all our pictures had swarms of people but the rooms themselves are impressive - especially the gold ballroom. The extravagant lifestyle of the royal family certainly shows. The grounds were spectacular and wish I had more time to spend there.

Opulent. Beautiful palace and worth a visit. One has to wear foot covers (provided) on the tour to protect the floors. The amber room is phenomenal. Interesting to see how the nobility of the time lived and to learn of some of the history through the guides. The gardens are also stunning and very soothing.

Beautiful palace and gardens. This 200 year old summer residence of the tsars is impressive and the gardens in the massive "back yard" are beautiful and a good walk. If you like gold you'll find plenty of it in this place.

Nice. Really nice and big garden.u can spend 5 hours just in the garden and still enjoy of what u see, but to see inside the palace make sure of the visiting day, othervise after all the way u went u just can enjoy of the garden!

Another essential feature of a visitor experience.. The palace has been extensively restored following the wanton damage conducted by invading German forces in WW2. It is a remarkable display of craft and workmanship but, of course, the majority is reclamation in original style. It gives a good impression of the gross and overbearing style of the Royal court.

Impressive. We had a special tour here in the evening after it was closed to the public arranged by Oceana cruise line. We saw the carriages in the carriage house and then walked through all the rooms with various historical displays. We could even take pictures in the Amber room. Music was played for us at several places and an actress as Catherine gave us a welcome toast in the ball room. We had dinner in another room with more Russian music.
Busy but grand. Well worth seeing especially given the level of restoration undertaken following the damage during the war. Lots of queuing..

Hidden secrets of Tzarskoe selo parks. Excellent place to visit.But, tourists usually not informed about its hidden secrets.There are many parks at Czarskoe selo.Among them not only Catherine palace but also Alexander park and Babolovskiy (Potemkin) parks.At Alexander park you may see Czars armaments museum, Czars zoo remains, world war II memorials, famous Rasputin tomb.At Babolovo park - ruins of Potemkin palace with famous big bath.Use wikimapia app (wikiplaces) to locate those and other places at parks.

Expansive and Gorgeous Grounds with a Stunning Palace. Manicured grounds and ornate building certainly were built to make an impression on the viewer. Fighting the crowd was worth the effort to see the throne room, the amber toom, the state room amd more. We chose to hire a driver and guide through the hotel which turned out to be a great choice. The tour was far more interesting, entertaining, and informative as the building is just huge and the crowd would have made audioguides impossible. Dont miss the grounds. Walk. Look. Appreciate the absolutelu manicured plants and flowers. Simply wonderful. Book early. Consider a guide. Plan ahead as it is well outside town.

Catherine's palace is the 2nd summer palace outside St. Petersburg. It was neat to see the different rooms done in different styles and the beautiful grounds. It is not as beautiful as Peterhof but a close second.
Beautiful. Very large palace! Combination of the palace and the gardens is fascinating! Walking through the gardens is relaxing.
Beautiful. It is great to see all the restauration work done in this palace that was destroyed in the Seconf War. It is a perfect peace of history.
Well worth a visit. Make the effort to view this palace - very well worth the wait to get in especially walking around the gardens

Palace deluxe. Can't believe size of this palace. You could live there and not ever see other residents.!! Amber room is one of main attractions. Need to purchase tickets ahead of time and having group to attend is a plus as you get to go in seperate entrance and not stand in line. Time is valuable when visiting place like St Petersburg with so many places to visit and you don't want to waste time standing in long lines. Our group was entering various rooms through what was servant entrances. Worth price to hire travel company.

Outer edge of St . Petersburg. It was raining the day I went, so didn't see the gardens. I went at 4pm, as it is open until 8pm and no queue and only a handful of people there. As more rooms are opened, it will be better. The amber room was great, although no photos are allowed. On exit you can see the destruction through the war. Such a shame.

A must for those who love history. We like the Russian history so this was our dream to see the places we had only read about. The Catherine palace was one of them all. When inside you simply lose yourself with history and the beauty of the palace. Also the park is interesting and unlike anything I have seen before. It is a large park with many trees mixed with beautiful bridges, benches and of course many buildings that are interesting to visit. I would definitely recommend to plan spending the full day here if you want to see it all completely.

Long wait to enter but Palace was worth the wait. Even with the guided tour, we have to wait for more than 2.5 hrs to enter. The rooms were decorated in Gold and beautiful. The highlight was the Amber room but for us Gold room was more beautiful than the amber room. The waiting to enter is painful but the palace is worth the visit
Wow. As we passed through the ornate gate, our guide said this was built to impress. Spontaneously, about four in our group said "Wow". That was just the first of many "wows" in this palace.

Wonderful Palace and Gardens. This palace is famed for its Amber Room (which was actually a little disappointing/average, but still fascinating to see). The palace is impressive and worth a visit; and the grounds and gardens are lovely too. Get a guided tour, if possible!

Amazing Park. Skip the palace. The park is amazing. It is huge. You can easily spend 3-4 hours walking there.Near by there is another free park. The Palace is too expensive and too crowded.1000 rubles (special tourist price, local pays half) you spend an hour or more in lines than they rush you through the rooms. The room are nice, but you can afford missing this one.

Got inside after 3.5 h waiting time!. On the museums website there were no tickets in advance for the week of our visit so we went in place and have waited 3 and a half hour to get in. The experience inside was no worth of such long waiting. You must follow the guided tours inside, you must also wait on thigh rooms while the previous group finishes. If you are not really into the kitschy interiors with golden decor then just visit the park and see the palace from outside

Lovely park but very crowded palace. First you have to pay to go into the park, but you could spend hours there as it is so large. Other attractions in the park require more tickets. You have to pay for another ticket to the Palace and the queues are very long necessitating crowd control all the way round. Having said that we enjoyed our visit and the photographs at the end of the devastation caused throughout the war showed just how much renovation has been carried out.

A must to see. So much beauty and the Amber room WOW. During our tour of the Palace we walked through a stunning gallery of gala rooms where balls, receptions, and official dinners took place. You can almost imagine it. We saw a very interesting collection of furniture and peaces of art, which belonged to the Royal family. But our biggest point of interest is of course the world famous Amber Room. A room, where the whole surface of the walls is covered with natural amber. This interior is a must to see After visiting the Palace we had a walk around the beautiful gardens.

Beautiful. Amazing palace and a testament to the devoted Russians who have lovingly restored the palace to its formal glory after it was destroyed during the Second World War. A must for all - especially the Amber room. I loved it.

Unbelievably beautiful. This place is more than special - it is almost unbelievably beautiful. We hired a guide and it was well worth the money. Know the visit will take maybe 1.5hours. There are some stairs and there are very few places to sit so train for this one. Having said that, know it was the highlight of my visit to St. Petersburg, Russia. Not to stop here would be a big mistake.

Ghosts of times past,. The restoration of this is impressive when viewed in the context of the photographs taken after the war. Such a beautiful place with a deep and wonderful historyThe amber room, fully restored after the original disappeared , is an absolute wonder. We felt privileged to have such such a wonder.

Jaw dropping-ly beautiful but try to go with an arranged tour. Just when you think you can't utter another 'wow', you enter yet another room with something new to marvel at. This has everything in excess and whilst we might ponder on the rights and wrongs of the resourcing and purposes for building, it is undeniably breathtaking. For overseas visitors, I would strongly advise going with a tour group to help avoid the queues and get the benefit of a guide's knowledge - even if this is to the annoyance of other visitors! I don't have time to visit the extensive parklands, but what I was able to see looked well cared with more treasures.
A tremendous and beautiful palace!. Absolutely gorgeous palace. Full of a rich history of Catherine the Great. Beautiful gardens and fountains. A fabulous place to go for a 2-hour tour.

Go with an Tour Group, Magnificent, Wonderful People. Iw as part of a tour group from a cruise ship and they did a special show of band music and dancing for us, really grand. The palace is magnificently decorated and restored, and if the weather is right it's just magic. The staff is friendly and helpful. One of the best museum-palaces I've ever been in, of many!

The number one palace in St Petersburg. No need to visit more than one palace in St Petersburg , and if you can - choose this one, especially if you have a guide that can help you skip the line and arrange a comfortable ride to Pushkin, like we had.The palace is absolutely marvelous, and the amber room is something you will probably see once in a lifetime . The gardens of the palace are huge, we saw only about a quarter of them, mainly the English gardens, which are like a piece of heaven. Could spend there 4 hours if we had more time.

Simply Magnificent!. Remarkable craftsmanship in a truly stunning palace. Lines can be very long in the summer; thankfully we had a private tour via Ulko Tours and walked right in. It's worth reading some history before you go so you can appreciate the people and importance surround this place. Visitors can take photos and video but NOT in the Amber Room.

A must see. A palace with both grandeur and delicacy as shown by its decor. Each room has its own theme and colour scheme and was decorated with portraits of the royal family or other art pieces. The Amber Room is amazing but so are the other parts of the palace. Do not miss the gardens. Although the gardens do not have the size and scale of Peter's Grand Palace, the lake, the forest and the English style garden create a sense of serenity. Also remember to visit the white gallery building to the right of the Catherine Palace (after you have completed the visit of its interior) to see the sculptures of the philosophers.

Astonishing Amber Room. Sainte Catherine Palace (Tsarkoye Selo State Museum)7 Sadovaya Street, Pushkin, St. Petersburg 196601Small queue to buy the tickets to the park entrance The park is huge and beautiful - in a sunny day we took really magnificent pictures)there was a big queue to enter in the palace hall and buy the palace entrance tkts. It took us 1h30min to get inside. The entry of people is controlled and is released only for a certain amount at intervals of 15 minutes.You can take your meal to make a picnic after the visit to the palace in one of the park very nice places. There are several pavilions to visit if you have time. Leave your backpack in the clock room.Search in GMaps the best way to go from your hotel. My husband and I went by subway to Kupchino station.Take the underground passage to the other side of the street to take a Marshrutka number K-342 or K-286 . People are very friendly but if you need some information it is better to ask the young people which speak a little English.The blue and white castle facade with golden domes is stunning.There are different entrances and different routes for individual visitors and guided tours.The must see amber mosaic in Amber Room is impressive. Also do not miss:- The Hall of Light ceiling;- The blue and white stove in White Dining Room;- The charming Green Dining Room;- The blue-and-white painted-silk wallpaper and the superb ceiling in the Blue Drawing Room;- The painted-silk wallpaper in the Chinese Blue Drawing Room.As it is too crowded the security of the rooms do not let you stop to see the details, especially in the amber room that is the most popular. There are so many beautiful things to see that I did not realize how long it took but I think the circuit is seen in 15 minutes which is the time interval that they allow groups entry in the museum. So my husband and I made the circuit again, just admiring the most interesting places like the amber room.
Part of 2 day TJTravel tour. Very interesting as another palace to visit. Must see Amber room in this palace but only if you know th estory
Tourist. There is no place in the world which can fit in the same sentence with this palace. The rooms inside are gorgeous. Take a day of and visit Tsarskoe Selo!

Catherine's Palace with the spectacular amber room. We took a guided tour with a local guide service, Best Guides with whom we were very satisfied. They didn't get us in early, but it was a much shorter line for tour groups. It was crowded especially in the famous "Amber Room". The gift shop was very nice with some different amber jewelry than the other museum shops. The tour including there and back takes approx. 4-5 hrs.

What a beautiful place. I was with a group of 14 and a leader on a trip to St. Petersburg and other destinations. The palace was beautiful, one room after another. I was there in August 2016 and the crowds were not too bad. It is a must see. It was a bright sunny day and the gardens were also beautiful.

Beautifully restored and worth the trip outside St. Petersburg. We went on a day that the palace is normally closed but they opened in the morning for a few tour guides. This is defiantly the way to go. No fighting crowds or rushing through rooms. You are allowed to take pictures in all the rooms EXCEPT the Amber room, which is the most spectacular one. The park is less stunning than the grand palace park but still a nice place to walk on a sunny day, which we did not have.

overcrowded and not pleasant to visit. This is a wonderful palace but the organization is so bad that I would not recommend anyone visiting. Too much waiting and pushing and once inside there is only one way out - my freind had a terrible headache with all the crushing and she just had to wait it out. The actual palace is amazing but go see something else.
Nice place. I was with a cruise ship excursion. As you can expect during summer, the place is crowded with many large tour groups and you are shuffled through each room.

Another amazing palace!. Spending 3 days in St Petersburg, touring some amazing buildings gives a brief insight into the incredibly privileged lifestyle lived by the Russian nobility. Their lifestyle was a complete contrast to the abject poverty suffered by the peasants.This is an incredibly ornate and highly gilded building which has large windows which make the most of the natural light, especially on the gloriously sunny day when we visited. It can get very busy and tour groups are moved briskly from one room to the next which doesn't always allow enough time to enjoy each room fully. The Amber room is interesting and well restored, it's a shame the original was stripped by the Nazis who also nearly destroyed the whole palace. The explanation about the restoration of the palace is very interesting.Don't miss it.
Just gorgeous!. A gorgeous palace and park. A must see place! Although it took several hours to get in, it's worth it.

Absolutely Stunning!. Lines can be long, so try to see this by using a tour company like SPB tours. Tour companies have special access so the wait time to get in isn't as bad. Once inside, it was a whirlwind tour as we were in a bit of a rush to get back to our ship. The place was so absolutely stunning. I literally gasped when we entered the dining room - it was that beautiful. The Amber room is a room that is actually covered almost every inch in amber stones. All too beautiful for words.

Ornate Palace with reconstructed Amber Room. Our visit to Catherine Palace was the highlight of our St Petersburg trip. Many of the state rooms on the first floor are golden, in that they are filled with gilded plasterwork and highlighted with mirrors and chandeliers. Then there is the Amber Room, reconstructed after the original was taken by the Nazis, but still breathtaking. Much of the palace has been reconstructed after damage in the war years, and there is a photographic display on the lower ground floor showing the extent of the damage which was severe. The park is also beautiful although not as ornate as the parks and fountains of Peterhof.

Beautiful place currently in restoration mode. The outside is done and they are slowly restoring the inside rooms. It is very typical of European palaces but if you arrange a good guide, it is well worth a visit. The listening devices may also do a good job but we did not use those - we had a private guide. Few signs have English translations and you cannot take photographs in some rooms. I can't be certain but our guide implied we paid more for our tickets which included being allowed to take photos.They have a small restaurant and gift shop too. It can be very crowded so you can wait to get in and then wait as you go from room to room as they control the flow.

Beautiful palace and gardens. The Catherine Palace is one of the most important buildings in St. Petersburg history. If you have some days you should definitely visit it. But be not surprised that this is an absolute tourist place. After visiting the palace you can still take the time and visit the gardens. These are very beautiful and you can escape the tourist groups for a while.

Not to be missed. We were very lucky to have a private tour and were treated like VIPs. I would definitely recommend visiting this way as the ticket queues are ridiculously long. We didn't have to wait at all and were kept separate from the rest of the visitors so the whole experience was very pleasant with no hassle. The palace is vast & extremely beautiful. We only got to visit a part of it which took just over an hour. The Amber room is the highlight but all of the rooms are very special in their own way. A truly spectacular place.

Stunning. The opulence of the Catherine Palace explains why there was a revolution. The rooms were breath taking. Our group were lucky enough to be there early which mean that it was comparatively uncrowded while we were there and we were able to appreciate the beauty of it all.Don't forget to look down at the floors as well as around.

another georgous site around St Petersburg. One cannot but be overwhelmed by the many beuatiful palaces of the former Tsars. This is another example, especially given that it was nearly burned down by the Germans in World War II. The palace itself is breathtaking and the gardens lovely. The Amber Room is unique, though many other rooms were more striking in my opinion. Also nice to get outside of St Petersburg to see some off the suburbs. The trip out there also crosses numerous interesting monuments and buildings of 20th century Russia.
A Must do. Another must to visit especially the Amber room, it must be seen to be believed, the whole room has been recreated after the Germans looted it in WW2.

Great - unless the crowd in the palace. They do not give you any time to really enjoy the atmosphere in the different rooms. The crowd is hanled like a flock of sheeps - room in and room out. However, the park is a great experience, you can spend hours in admiring it.

Wow, did they live well!. This is somewhat like the Palace at Versailles but has its own charm. The soft pastel colour of the main building is welcoming on the eye. The rooms are grand. The use of natural light is first rate. The amber room memorable and the agate rooms worthy of a short visit. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful. One can see why the royals enjoyed being here - so did I!

Both Lovely & Gaudy. The palace is only a short drive from St Petersburg and certainly worth a visit, but come early because, as with many of the sites...it gets crowded. The grounds are lovely and the palace is relatively small - as these things go - and easily walked and enjoyed. The rooms are beautiful, as is the craftsmanship of the furniture...but the color, décor and gilt all combine to feel a tad gaudy and over the top...perhaps well-suited for the time, but a lot to take in. The lead up to the amber room was bigger than its impact...but the story of its loss and restoration is great for history buffs.
Gorgeous. You need to wear free shoe cover before entering, at where they also lent audio guides. Inside is as stunning as the winter palace. Photos are allowed except the amber house.

Overrun by Tourists! Go Early or Late!. The crowds have become so bad that they now have crowd control between rooms!Definitely worth a visit. Recommend a private tour guide to take you from SPB, not buses.

Beautiful. Although a smaller palace this was my favourite. Beautiful gardens and the interior of the palace has been renovated and is quite beautiful. If you are a fan of amber the Amber Room will delight you.

Lovely palace and gardens. A short drive from St Petersburg - early is best as it gets very crowded later in the morning. Beautiful rooms. Impressive furniture. Beautiful and extensive gardens. Ponds and ducks and sparrows. A wonderful summer palace.

Superb. We visited the palace in a tour guided visit. Totally recommended to avoid the first queue. Unfortunately there are more than 15.000 unique visitors per day so better go early. Audio guide mandatory to get the full experience. Superb

Absolutely Gorgeous!. We visited Catherines Palace on a very rainy day in July, but it was worth it! The Palace is beautiful inside and out! The grounds a meticulously kept and the inside rivals the Palace Versailles.... which it was meant to do. Each room is staged to represent the time of Catherine the Great and does so very well. The Great Hall is very reminiscent of the Hall of Mirrors in Versailles. Beautiful and well worth the visit!

Walk in a park. We did not go in the palace as our tour guide suggested to just see the gardens and go to another palace to see the inside. She explained the gardens are the most beautiful at this location. They were fabulous with secret area with spray jet as you walked by and fountains galore. This garden is something I have never seen before and worth your effort to see. Children will love it.

Glamorous and grand!. Catherine Palace is located in Tsar’s village (it's Pushkin town now), one hour drive from St Petersburg. It's a very beautiful palace, with the stunning rebuild legendary Amber Room, definitely worth the visit. (No photo taken at Amber Room.)There are tons of visitors, always long line, I mean hundreds people. Purchased tickets far in advance. It's very crowded inside, you don't get to walk around by yourself. There is a guideline that everybody follows. We had a private tour guide which is great. She took us in front of the "tour group" line (even there were only two of us), she knows where to go. It's a bit intimidating, it's very crowded here and at Hermitage and other famous churches/places in town. It's too bad that Russians are not helpful or friendly, it's hard to find things around. It's great to have a guide.

Pushkin. This is a place that u have to see if u get to Saint Petersburg! Enjoy the park and when you get into the palace u will see what an amazing thing the Russian renovators, artists, engineer and curators did to bring back this palace from ruins after the second world war. When you will get into the amber chamber be prepared to soak as much beauty as you can in one minute or less. They dont let u spend to much time there. No photos aloud in the chamber.

Gardens were beautiful. We were already in the area, so we decided to visit the gardens (my kids had had enough of palaces). They were really beautiful and certainly worth a walk both through the shaded and unshaded areas.

Worth Seeing for its Brash..... It's difficult to give anything other than a 5 star rating to something in (or in this case near) St Petersburg. In this case the rating reflects only that there are so many more spectacular things to see that I would put this lower on the list. There is a reason Catherine went through something like 5 architects - many aspects of the palace are testaments to bad taste in which self-respecting architects wanted no part, including (imo) the krazy-gluing (or whatever the 19th c. equivalent of that is) of an entire room with amber. On the other hand, the story of that particular room's post-war restoration, and who its benefactor was, is wonderful. The palace is enormous and a monument of extensive and often spectacular plaster work, and an abundance of gilt work. Like everything in the region it is still worth seeing... if only to witness proof that you are definitely too wealthy if you have so many priceless masterworks that you can only display them by slicing them from their frames and using them as wallpaper .... and that doing so may be the best way to foment an eventual revolution from the underclasses.

Opulence in Bulk. This is a tough attraction to review in part because much of it is way off the charts. The Catherine Palace is so ornate that there is virtually nothing to compare it to. It is opulent beyond belief. You will go from one room that is the most opulent you have ever seen to another that puts the one previous to shame. The level of wealth and detail is almost staggering.At the same time, it is a monument to the ravages of the Nazis in World War II and the restoration efforts in the decades that have followed. This palace had gone to one of the greatest in the world to a ruin, to the return of its wonder. The amber room, a marvel, has been lovingly restored.We visited at a time when there were practices going on for a staging of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro". The practices added to the general air of 18th century culture.The Palace is beautiful, and it is a testament to the resilience of the Russian people. It is also astonishingly popular, such that some of the rooms are clogged with groups of tourists. You will want to see this palace, and our advice if you can is not to visit during the busy summer (we could not). Few realize just how wealthy the Romanov Tsars really were and this palace demonstrates not only that their opulence exceeded that of virtually anyone else in the world, but that Russia was able to replicate it again after the vandalism of the retreating Nazis. Remarkable.

Wow at every turn!. This is worth a trip out of St Petersburg for sure. Everywhere we went there was a wow moment. The ballroom where they filmed recent War and Peace sparkles as it should and the Amber Room is breathtaking.
stunning. The whole palace is amazing, the Amber room is amazing, as is the parks surrounding the palace. Went on a wet day and still loved the gardens.

A must see in St Petersburg. On a recent Viking Ocean cruise, on their new small ship, we had a choice of several optional tours during our two days in St Petersburg. Based on recommendations from friends who had been there before, we chose the Catherine Palace and Park tour. The palace has been almost completely restored to its original glory and is amazing in its beauty and ostentation. The Viking tour gets there before it opens, so the crowd was not nearly as large as the one at the Hermatage. Our guide was native Russian and had been to the grounds as a boy when it was much less developed. The grounds around the palace are extensive and equally impressive. We enjoyed this more than our Hermatage tour, partly because the Heratage was so crowded.

Beautiful Place - Horrible Organization. We took a guided tour from St Petersburg to Catherine Palace, knowing that by doing it on our own we were limited as to entry times. It seems they changed the procedures, no more timed entries for tours, so we waited in line for 2 1/2 hours to get in line - being with a group and guide made no difference. It was absurd! Yes, the place is magnificent, the Amber room is really something special, but 2 1/2 hours? We heard from several guides that they changed the entry procedures in May 2016, without informing anyone. Would never ever think of going again in the summer.

A must see on a visit to St. Petersburg. This palace is outside of St. Petersburg in Pushkin, but it should not be missed. It is impressive just driving up to the white, gold and easter egg blue grandeur building. We arrived with a small tour group on a Saturday morning. The crowds were huge! I would strongly recommend you take a tour to make sure you get in. We were with TJ tours out of St. Petersburg. This palace is nothing short of amazing, with large rooms of white walls trimmed in gold everywhere. There are beautiful wood floors, and heating furnaces covered with Delft tiles. Be sure to admire the lovely ceilings. What I cannot forget is the famous amber room. The walls are made of panels of small pieces of amber. The way the light hits the amber is just spectacular. No photos are allowed. I imagine a postcard of it could be purchased.Perhaps a better time to visit would be later in the fall to avoid the crowds of people.
Very beautiful and worth a visit. This was a short trip outside of St. Petersburg but very much worth it. It is a very beautiful palace and the gardens are lovely as well.

Spectacularly . Only way to describe it. Best advice is to go via an organised trip as queues are horrendous for individuals. Tour guides have a different entry point and so miss some of the longer queues. Still some queuing but well worth it for the sights you see . You walk the way of visitors to The Palace as in Catherine's day. The Empress wanted people to be in awe and they most truly must have been.

60 minute time limit of ticket. Particularly for those who have booked entrance tickets to the palace online, please be careful that the ticket is valid only for 60 minutes from the issue time printed on the ticket.As such ticket holders may use the group entrance to enter into the palace area where it is beautiful and sometimes there is no one there (good photo chance!), it is very tempting to spend time taking pictures there while forgetting the clock is ticking.Since everyone have to be at the entrance gate to scan the ticket barcode within 60 minutes, and there is a long queue again in front of the gate and no one knows how long to be kept waiting, people like me would easily fail to meet the time limit.I was lucky that a staff was so kind that he took me to a counter where visitors rent audio guide player for re-activating my ticket. So if you are running out of time, please try asking for help at the audio guide counter.

nice. Crowded but a nice tour seeing some of the art work and history of early Russia, the Palace was worth it they make you check your coat and put little covers over your shoes this takes a little time and then they have minders in every room making sure you behave ha ha all the attractions in Russia seem to have these folks like they don't trust anyone, ha ha but worth the visit.

Mixed feelings. After having to wait in line for over an hour to get to the ticket office and paying a hefty 1000 rubels (€15), you can't help but feeling a little elated when you can finally start your actual visit of the palace. And they do have some amazing and strikingly beautiful rooms. In the most special room it is not allowed to take pictures however, which is a serious downside in my book. More importantly, the tour is over within an hour as only a small portion of the palace can be visited. I find it very hard to show enthousiasm when waiting in line takes longer than the actual visit, and being charged over the top. The park around the palace was nice enough, and easily worth the entry price of about €2.

Magnificent Restoration. A great restoration job has been done at the palace, especially the Amber Room. However, from the black and white pictures of the original, we can see that the present is not as glamorous as the past.

And Another. Visited here the day after visit to Peterhof and yet more Russian Royal splendour and excess. The blue colour of the external walls is something to admire and inside there is room after room of treasures. The route round is dictated by lay-out and again like other palaces can be crowded, especially at areas like the cloakroom and toilets. As with other palaces coats and larger bags must be checked in and also the fetching brown paper overshoes are required!! With the attached Pushkin school added the palace is a larger building than when occupied by the Royals. Again there is a garden to wander through and admire although not as extensive or opulent as the Peterhof. Photgraphy is allowed inside with the exception of the Amber Room. Another jaw dropping experience of Royal design and decor.

Great to be there on a sunny day. I must say that you will see a phenomenal park which is a real gem among many around the world. Walking in the park was so enjoyable! Plus you should visit the Catherine palace. The facade and the interior are amazing! Also it is a popular and crowded place so buy the ticket online because you will waste too much time waiting in line.

Baroque overload. It's just another grandiose baroque palace worth visiting on a rainy day. Great for those who haven't seen too many baroque palaces in Europe, rather boring to those who have. The place is swarmed by busloads of tourists. The park was nice.

The Amber Room...wow.... So yes, it is crowded. The Russians still have something to learn from the Western nations on how to handle a large volume of tourists at a major attraction.However, it is magnificent. Much of it has been restored due to the damage from WWII, but it was done very, very well. The Amber Room recreation is spectacular and worth the admission by itself. Give yourself lots of time and be prepared to spend most of a day here.

do not waste your time. I really wanted to see “restored” Amber Room, I dragged my fiends there on a rainy weekend.We have spent 1,5 hours in the rain waiting in line.Do not go to this place in the summer.Lines are very long, they do not have “short” program any longer.They only allow you to visit as a part of the tour group which are formed at the entrance.Tour groups are large and fast pacing. There is no time to look around an appreciate the place.Stuff is very rude. If you must go - go closer to the closing time.

Absolutely amazing. My wife and I toured did the after hours tour, which meant there were only forty of us in the museum and did not have any problems with crowds. We could take all the pictures we wanted! We were met at the front by a marching band that escorted us to the entrance. Guards were in 18th c. period uniforms, musicians were playing in various rooms, and in ballroom, we had champagne as we sat to watch ballet dancers. Outside, we were able to watch more ballet in the rear of the palace and then further entertainment outside the gates in a restaurant. Truly memorable.

Amazing outlook. Designed by Rastrelli, th opulent baroque Palace features a gold dome crown and is set on acres of spectacular gardens and parklands... One can enjoy the gilded beauty of the Throne room..

The Amber Room - pictures cannot capture its glory. The highlight of our visit to Catherine Palace is the fabled Amber Room, and the visit to the room was far too short. The shades of amber and the depth that comes from the varies textures and shapes of the stones cannot be captured in pictures. Visit this palace even just for this room.

Gorgeous but demoralizingly DISORGANIZED. Perhaps it is our fault, because we went on a Monday (when the Hermitage is closed) and we did not go as part of a tour group, but -- my goodness -- I have never queued for longer in my life (4+ hrs). I attribute at least half of the queue time to the very poor organization of the ticket-purchasing and visitor-management processes, and I detract two stars from my rating for these eminently correctable problems.I'll leave reviews of the park, the palace and its exhibits for other reviews (apart from saying that you must see the Amber Room) and focus on the nightmarish logistics. I know that no one from the venue will see this, much less act upon it, but at least fellow tourists can brace themselves for the inconvenience.First -- when you get to the place (we took Uber: 1000 rubles and totally worth it -- and I'm cheap!), you buy a 120-ruble ticket to get into the park. Once you get into the park, you immediately get into another queue for access to the palace. Of course there are no signs telling you this (not even in Russian) -- so the seller of park tickets has to repeat the same thing one million times a day.Entry to the palace is managed such that about 125 people are allowed in every 15 minutes. But the queue gets so compressed at the front (5-6 people abreast) that you feel like you're never making progress.Once you get inside the palace, you scramble to join one of just three queues to buy tickets (1000 each, with a 150-ruble supplement if you want the audio guide), crossing paths with other ticket buyers, people exiting, and so forth.Then, once you've bought your ticket, you get in another queue (with people joining it from all sides) to get past the security guards and into the facility.Once you get past the security guards, there is another person managing flow into the exhibits. If you are not part of a tour group you can theoretically enter the exhibit area as you wish, but good luck to you in getting through those crowds!Then once you're among the exhibits (i.e., giant, elegantly furnished rooms with mostly unremarkable artwork on the walls -- except, as noted, the Amber Room), you will be managed for crowd control. But even then, they're not doing a very good job, as there were times when we were alone in a room and then times when we were jam-packed among other visitors.The audio guide, although recommended by Lonely Planet, was honestly WAY TOO WORDY, and it directed us to follow a route through the palace that was not allowed by the crowd managers. As for the wordiness, they should have taken a cue from the National Gallery in London: give a brief (60-second or less) overview and then invite listeners to punch in another number for further detail. Far too often, the most interesting parts of the audio exhibits came after three or four minutes of blather.We were so exhausted by the waiting, the scrums and the queues that we made it through everything in just 75 minutes.Here's what they should do: set up ticket booths outside the palace where you buy a timed ticket. That way, at least you can enjoy the grounds instead of just wasting time queuing.One thing I will say is that everyone was really very nice -- even the security guard who had to disappoint everybody by managing flow so tightly.

For the love of all who visit here, get some sense of organisation and humanity!!. What a wonderful place, it really is. Just so you know, as there's no info in English, here's what it's like (I'm sure the attitude will be 'well, you're in Russia'. Of course. But having spent a good while learning the alphabet and some basic words, many people still chose not to understand and be awkward or rude, or amazingly lovely, so all I'm saying is, I tried, really hard.)Queue for a park ticket.Walk around the park a bit.Queue for the palace - For 3.5 hours if you're lucky. With a 5 year old?!! And we all survived, but I must liken it to some kind of hellish Groundhog Day, but with less happening. Can't you do what other places in the world do and sell timed tickets with the park or have some sense to offer more facilities to us or some trivia to read?! Can't even sit on the gravel!! Beg people behind to hold your place as you empty your bladder. It's been too long to give up now. I can do this. Have about 50 Chinese tourists push in the queue as their guide held their place while they had a great time. Don't threaten to kill them or the people in hats.Get in - go to ticket area. Queue for ticket. Queue to get in.Shouted at. Go back to the ticket hall and put your bag in. Back to entry. Over shoes on. Shouted at. Go back you need an audio guide.Office 5. You need to buy ticket.Queue up for ticket for audio guide.Wait for office 5 lady to come back from loo. Proceed to tour.No info provided as to where the hell to go.Miss half the palace. You dare go back you'll ended up shouted at for the hundredth time today. Do everything you can to not actually kill people. Finally get out having wasted your life today. Great! Cafe closed after all that ordeal.I guess living in areas that support a massive tourism industry incredibly well spoils us. There really aren't that many people it deserves this big let down. There is no need for such an awful ordeal that can easily be prevented by a few simple things like signs. You would imagine at the pace of the queue that one person is inside at a time. No. They are being barged through by the next tour en masse. If you get to peep through a gap in the crowd, all good. It is beautiful and people will always visit. But having a bit of awareness of what you need to do will hopefully help. If you have a prescription for anything that can help you through it, make sure you dose up. Oh, and bring a lunch and a book, prepare for rain and sun and stuff like that. It is a nice place, it is worth a visit, but if you only have a day, probably best go Peterhof (we learnt to not bother with the palaces after this one - but the gardens are better) or somewhere else, as it will all be spent here and to not achieve very much.
Gorgeous Place - Huge Park And Palace. Gorgeous Place - Huge Katherine Park And Palace good for singles and families in every season of the year
Summer Palace. We joined an excursion from our cruise, and went there for a morning. Very nice palace with great restoration work done after WWII, with some originals kept. Pretty place!!!
