Beautiful!. This place is beautiful. Not as crowded as the other palaces in Russia as it is not in St Petersburg proper - it's an hour's drive away from the centre of St Petersburg - Worth going once in your life!

Expect a crowd. We went primarily to see the amber room. Considering the lines and crowds, I don't think I would do it again.
Go with a group and you get pass much of the line. But expect a very slow paced and long waiting process.
It is stunning nonetheless. Just very crowded like every other sight in town.

Oh Yes this is a must see.. The Grandness of this is overwhelming. The history and the grounds are fairy tail like. You can feel the aura of past residents as you walk from room to room. You will be taken in by the Gold and the parkay floors. Try to book with Guide Guru is possible (Anna) We did and she knows her stuff. Many brides were taking their photos here. What a wonderful day.

Beautiful palace in the countryside outside St. Petersburg. Wonderfully ornate palace, so much money was spent on the decorations you must see this for yourself, pictures do not do it justice. We went with a guided tour so do not know entrance fee prices.

Great day tour. A day trip to the Catherine Palace provides an opportunity to travel outside of the city and see the smaller village of Pushkin. And, of course, to see the stunning palace and grounds of the Summer Palace.First, don't ignore the statue of Pushkin and the little chapel and cottage outside the palace grounds. There are vendor stalls there as well, which offer a variety of souvenirs in a relaxed setting (for after your tour).The palace tour is well organized. Bags must be checked at the entrance (restrooms nearby) but cameras are allowed everywhere (no flash) except the Amber room. Only a set number of people are let into each room at one time, so photography is possible and you can see elements unobstructed. Yet the groups move smoothly, with no waits.Of course the palace is overwhelmingly ornate and wondrous, including tables set for elegant suppers and walls covered in hand painted silk. One of the most interesting galleries was near the exit, where photos of the destroyed (during WWII) palace and of restoration work were displayed, with text placards in English. The grounds and grand outbuildings are not to be missed (gardens, bath house, lake, chapel). Take a traditional carriage ride around the grounds or a horse ride in the Alexander Park (from the Equestrian Center). Or a ferry ride on the lake. Enjoy them at leisure. We were lucky to hear an a cappella group sing in the Lakeside Music Hall, whose acoustics were tremendous.Several cafes are available on site, so make it a full and leisurely and beautiful day.

Catherine Palace and park compares only to Versaille in France.. The decor is so ornate and grand it is almost impossible to describe. It is a true work of art and grandiose. It is easy to see why the peasants revolted against this obscene extravagance.

Don't go on a Monday!. I hadn't realised until we were already queuing, that because all the other museums are closed on Monday, everybody goes to the palace. We arrived at 11.30, half an hour before the doors open for individual visits, then waited for almost 2 hours in the queue, estimated it would have been at least another 90 minutes before we would get in. At that point, we gave up and went for a walk in the beautiful parklands instead. Still lots to see aside from the interior of the palace.
Stunning Palace. This is truly the castle that fairy tales are made from. Of all the palaces that I have been to (and I have been to a lot) I can say that is by far the most beautiful

Another must visit palace in SPB. This palace is in Pushkin, 40minutes drive from SPB. Building is well maintained and they really strict on preserving this palace because lots of decoration and furnish in this palace is prone to damage. The best way to visit this palace is by having tour guide that can explain everything for each room at this palace. There are lots of beautiful rooms and the most famous one is Amber room. The only lack in this palace is the ladies guard in each room, they keep pushing the visitor to move and make visitors can't enjoy rooms.
We had to see the amber room!. Taking an organised tour allows one to skip the endless queues. Apart from the superb amber room, there are around thirty beautifully restored rooms.
Beautiful place. This was part of our SPB tour. Such a beautiful place. I would certainly recommend this as a place to visit while in St Petersburg.

Bravura!. This was the summer residence of the Russian tsars. Catherine I of Russia hired German architect built the original in 1717 for her pleasure. Her daughter, Empress Elizabeth in 1752 replaced it with a much grandiose Palace and completed it in 1756. The 1,066 feet long new Palace astonished her contemporaries. Elizabeth was a big spender: a lot of money, a lot. She used more than 220 pounds of gold just to decorate the Palace. There was a glamorous garden in front of the Palace. Catherine the Great did not edify it in a great deal, as she considered the Palace was a “whipped cream” architecture. Nevertheless, people would still refer it as “Catherine Palace”. The Palace was “abandoned” after her death in 1796. The Germans during World War II intentionally destroyed the Palace. But soon after the War, reconstruction resumed and nearly completed in 2003. Much work still needs to be done. However, on the day we visited, the glory and lavishness of the Palace manifested itself everywhere. What a treasure!

Very Impressive. We took a private tour of Catherine's Palace and were impressed by its elaborate rooms. Of course the restored amber room was so ornate and beautiful we could have spent half a day just admiring its intricacies. We also learned a secret that 5 pieces in the amber room are original but we won't give that info away - you'll just have to visit or research it. The ballroom with its gold leaf ornaments, ceiling murals and inlaid floor were somewhat gaudy but still impressive nonetheless. The furnaces used to heat the palace are all covered in Delft tiles imported from the Netherlands. The gardens feature a park-like setting behind the palace and contain several small buildings including the Little Hermitage which has a mechanical table that lifts from the 1st floor where servants set the table to the 2nd floor where Catherine and guests actually ate - somewhat over the top but innovative. It does get crowded in summer so I recommend going as early in the day as possible.

A Powerful Lady's Place!. The interior is fabulous....well worth the tour inside. What is more interesting is the story of Catherine (not a Russian, by the way)! She would have made a great partner for Henry!

Anything but a summer shack!. The winter palace was mind boggling and this one is not far behind in its beauty and opulence. The Amber Room is worth the visit. The grounds, while not as impressive as Peterhof, are still beautiful on a sunny day.

Amber Room. The one of the most wonderful palace I saw in my life. Specially the amber room. there is amber stones from the bottom to the top, it's just impressive and must to see it. Please note that it's forbidden to take picture at the Amber Room.

A must visit . Catherine the great left a great collection at this place. The art work is amazing specially the Amber room. Don't miss this room the work here is stupendous. We could see only part of this place due to paucity of time. And there were huge crowds just to see this place.

Very very long queue !. The park was great , you can wonder around and walk at the paths and see the lake and the small bridges .it worth and the ticket is cheap 120 rubles.The Catherine Palace is beautiful BUT very small , you can see a few rooms and the tour is about 45' !also the ticket costs 1000 rubles ! For this 45' I was waiting for 4 hours at the queue !In my opinion.if you see all the other sites then you can go here.

Less is more Catherine. Not sure what to say......it was very gold, although I think that was Elizabeth's doing. The original palace is lovely and then they added an unnecessary extension that just ruined it. Go with an organised tour as it's quicker to get in. Nice to visit but I wouldn't queue up for tickets.

I can see why the peasants revolted!. The Russians love their gold gilt (the U.S. version of bedazzling, I suppose). On the the Palace, in the rooms, everywhere! The highlights were the Ballroom (Gilt & Mirrors), Amber Room, the only one in which you're not allowed to photograph not do they have postcards of it. So sad to think the Germans ransacked the building during WW2. The lines outside were at least 2 or 3 hours long and it's very crowded inside - go with a guide (Dancing Bear Tours!).

Pushkin, home of Catherine the Great Summer Palace. Pushkin is a small town or suburb of St. Petersburg in Russia but houses one of the most beautiful palaces in the world. It is really extravagant, and it's rococo grandeur just cannot be described in a few words.It is a must see. Just the entrance through an impressive staircase will make your heart jump.

The Russian equivalent to Versailles. We only visited the exterior and surrounding grounds. Judging by the crowds this is clearly a favourite. The sheer opulence and scale of the building and fountains is a photographer's dream

Crowds. We went in June 2016. Line control was non-existent. This allowed large tour groups to cut ahead in the line. After arriving about 12n, we waited 3 hours in line, scarcely moving, before we gave up. I strongly recommend obtaining the services of a private guide with experience at the palace. They would get you in with little difficulty. We regret not having spent the money for this service.
A beatiful place. Lines are impossible. Stay away on Monday when all museums are closed in SPb and Peterhof. Line for 4-5 hours

Catherine Palace and Garden. Absolutely delightful!Although we only spent a few hours in the gardens, it was a memorable experience. We visited in July, on a sunny afternoon, there were many other families there however due to the vast size of the park it was not over crowded. There are water fountains for children to play in, from the days of Peter the Great, and plenty of benches and picnic areas for the family. A particular favourite would be the chequered water fountain, providing a fantastic background for taking family photos.

Had high expectations, only to be disappointed.. Horrendous wait to get the tickets into the palace. Waited about 3.5 hours when I started queuing at 1130hrs and only got in at 1515hrs and another half an hour to get the tickets and into the palace itself. Tour groups are the ones holding up the lines, so squeeze yourself away from them. Surprised by the amount of rooms we get to visit which is really very little compared to the size of the palace. Amber room was also unimpressive.

Wonderful Trip Into History of Russian Royalty. It is as beautiful as it appears in pictures. We visited the palace with a tour group. It appeared as though you needed to visit with a group and at least someone to describe what you are seeing. I cannot give any information on this. The furnishings and household items give a great insight into how the Russian Royals lived. As with all stories there is good and bad, but the history is rich and amazing. We are so glad we visited.

Definitely worth a visit. I must admit that by the time we got to Catherine's Palace we were somewhat palaced out after the Hermitage & Peterhof. The building was badly damaged during WWII: parts, including the famed Amber Room, have been beautifully restored, whilst other areas are still undergoing restoration so there are relatively few rooms to visit.Even though we got their early as part of a tour group we did have to queue for a while: sensibly, the numbers entering at any one time are controlled so that there isn't horrendous crush inside (the Palace of Versailles in Paris should adopt the same approach as it has just become unbearable to visit). Once you enter you are moved along at a fairly rapid pace by the room attendants but it wasn't horrifically crowded and there was still time to take things in. Unlike in the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles, visitors move along the edges of rooms so that you can see the splendour of the building.I must confess I wasn't bowled over by the Amber Room and to an extent the extensive restoration does detract a bit from the experience although the grandeur and opulence of the original building has been brought back.I didn't have long to stay in the park which is to a broadly French design and what I saw was really quite delightful.You have to wear overshoes as you walk round and can't take in backpacks or large bags or indeed jackets - it is better to go prepared so you don't have to leave things in the cloakrooms.
Stunning. Beautiful palace, very opulent, lots of gold, amber room story quite emotional, a chance to see how the Zars lived.

Catherine Palace and Park, Pushkin. We only spent the morning here which certainly isn't enough time, it's an all day or a couple of days to view this outstanding Palaceonly a few rooms are open due to refurbishment, gets very busy and cannot spend time in each room as so many people visiting.The gardens are glorious it was raining on the morning we were there but you can see how wonderful they are .

Striking place. Stunning is the right word to describe the place. As the palace was badly destroyed during WW2, the restauration of entire building is still not fully completed. However the completed work is incredible, all rooms look authentic, sparkly and ornate, especially The Amber room which costed the fortune to restore.To visit Palace and grounds (600 hectares) a day would be recommended. Also note that palace (like most tourist attractions in St Petersbourough) can be very crowded and take care of pick pocketers.
wow she knew how to live. If you have the time this is a great place.The decor,the gardens and the history.A great example of life at that time.

Lovely place shame about the organisation. The inside of this place is wonderful (though the Amber Room was for me only so so.) but the organisation of the tours was terrible. We waited over an hour outside with no shade (it snowed in July) and would be horrendous in the sun, inside there were way too many people for comfort. Should there be a fire it would be catastrophic. You should go and you should see it (Even though much of it is really less than 20 years old) as it is a stunning expression of wealth and if you have time a walk round Pushkin Village will show you where the next money trap will be restored.
So Beautifull. Walked around the park and palace in total amazement , breathtaking a must if you are visiting St Petersburg

Catherine Palace, Pushkin. The restoration work is incredible. Well worth studying and exploring how the work was done with such authenticity. The amber room is unique and cost a fortune on its own to restore.Another example of wealth and opulence. Wonder what the poor people did?

The beautiful summer palace . Catherine Palace and Park is a stunning residence in the ci of Pushkin. Just the house or grounds would be a full day's visit. The magnificent rooms and the artwork is voluminous. The most stunning room is the Amber room finally restored in 2003. This palace was a partially destroyed in WWII as the Russians held off the Germans invasion. This room was totally dismantled before the war and has been reconstructed as the actually original ambers were never recovered. Moving into the gardens there is 600 hectares. There are flower gardens, terraces and a lakeOutside the garden walls there is the village of Pushkin with many eating establishments and a market full of regional crafts and other wares

Kind of answers the question, "Why was there a revolution?". Like Peterhof and Winter Palace, everything is sparkly and ornate and dripping in gold. Spectacular doesn't begin to describe it. The amber room is a true highlight. Yes, that is a room covered in amber. Crazy crowded, but pretty well organized. To keep us from confusing this palace with all the others, this one is conveniently painted blue. Not to be missed.

Spectacular. A visit to this palace and the gardens is a must if you are in Saint Petersburg Russia. The palace is actually outside the city in the town of Pushkin but it is a short drive from Saint Petersburg. The palace is beautiful inside and out and the gardens are lovely as well. As an overall experience it rivals a visit to the Hermitage.
Another beautiful palace. This is another palace that must be seen. Both inside and out this is a striking site. The grounds are as magnificent as the interior.

Amber Room delight. This palace's main feature, amber room without doubt is extra ordinary from other palaces. Such quantities showed a unique interior & celebrates the beauty of the amber stone. The whole palace has a sense of greatness and majesty. Not to be missed.

Another amazingly large palace. Huge; glorious in its gold; lovely gardens; history by the bucket; a wonderful amber room but for me it was the floors that I remember most. The quality of the marquetry and the patterns made this building unique in my memory. Long, long queues though groups get a timed ticket (more or less adhered to) and go down a different channel in the house to individuals; they meet in the amber room and at some other points but the groups get the rooms with artefacts.

Gardens are wonderful!. Given the very tight group visit schedule to the Palace, the gardens alone make a good option. A little harder to get to - there are English signed mini buses from Moskovskaya Metro stn.

A walk in the Park - The Spendor of Russia. This is a magnificent palace that has been restored to its past splendor. There is no question that this palace exceeds the splendor of Versailles. Must be seen in conjunction with the wonderful gardens and the many fountains.

A semi private evening viewing. Well this was again part of the Princess cruise tour, we started with Vodka and Caviar before entering with musical accompaniment. Then toured the palace and as a special exclusive tour were allowed to photograph in the Amber room, normally not allowed. we than had a champagne musical experience with a string septet and a visit from Catherine II. Then more music and dancing in the courtyard before proceeding to dinner in one of the palace rooms while being entertained by folk musicians and dancers of course including the obligatory Vodka, Champagne and wine with the dinner. Finally got back to the ship at midnight. Another fine example of restoration after the mess the Germans left it in after their retreat.
Must See. Absolutely stunning. Visited wit a guide from MariaRose Tours, young Lyda, who had a lot of good stories about the history of the place.

Unbelievable. After seeing the lavishness of this palace I understand why there was a Russian revolution! The architecture and decor were completely over the top with gold gilding everywhere. If you visit only one palace in St Petersburg, this should be the one. I highly recommend taking a tour so you know what you are seeing. Be forewarned-coats must be checked in the cloakroom and retrieving them is an ordeal.

A beautiful place. We went to St Petersburg on a Princess Baltic cruise and stayed there for 2 days. We had organised the visit with SPB Tours who were absolutely wonderful. Our guide Elena was great, extremely knowledgeable and very open. We did the main attractions in the centre of St Petersburg itself during the first day and we went to Peterhof and Catherine Palace the next day. We went by boat, the weather was gorgeous. We had been told that we could wait for up to 3 hours, even with our tickets, but in fact we only had to queue for 10 minutes ( Elena was very efficient). Catherine Palace is huge and we only saw a little bit of it but it took our breath away. It is so richly decorated, so colourful and the Amber room is incredible, I did not expect it to be used as wallpaper , covering all the walls. It was beautiful. Definitely worth a visit.

Ambar room pays the trip. It is in process of reconstruction which means that very fewthings are actually opened to visit, but the unique ambar room is worth the visit. The palace it self is very nice.Note that there are massive line ups to get in, so i sugest gettibg there before the palace opens, and seriously NOBODY SPEAKS ENGLISH! So make sure you read about it enough in forums cause you wont get any information in there other than audioguides.

More Opulence. One is both in awe of every aspect of the total extravaganze and horrified!How could one group of human beings have so much and yet their fellow countrymen have so little?It happened all round the world,still does,but it doesn't make it right.It is stunning and totally over the top but makes me appreciate the simple beauty in nature.Take an organised trip it makes life a lot easier.

Another contender for best palace in Europe.. This palace complex and surrounding gardens are testimony to the grandeur and the spending power of the royal family in St Petersburg. Each room is a treasure in itself - with the latest completion being the Amber Room, notoriously taken by Nazis last century.

Beautiful! . The palace and the grounds surrounding were beautiful! Architecture inspiring. Decor beautiful. Loved seeing the rooms set up how they would have had them back then. A walk around the grounds is so peaceful and relaxing. Other buildings as well to visit. Worth a trip there!

Beautiful even under the rains. About 20 minutes by Metro from the city center (Red Square), this place is worth the while. We pushed through with the visit amidst the rain and we still enjoyed the walk, though it had to be rushed a bit as the rain was downpouring non-stop. If weather forecast announces rain, better bring a raincoat or an umbrella as we've seen people soaked by the sudden downpour with no nearby refuge to take shelter from the rain because the sprawling lawns are wide. Beautiful anyway

Amber room was amazing. This palace has some very interesting rooms. It was especially interesting to see the dining room set for entertainment. I loved the reproduction of the Amber Room, especially as it played a part in a book I had finished the day before.

Both house and garden are spectacular!. It is well worth the day trip from St Petersburg to visit Catherine's Palace. The gardens themselves are worth it. Spent hours strolling around the gardens and admiring the views of the Palace. In one of the garden houses there was also a singing quartet who sang old Russian songs - very beautiful. The house itself is spectacular - go and visit the Amber Room.

Pack a Lunch and Enjoy the Day!. My husband and I had bought tickets a couple weeks prior to visiting online and we're not part of a tour group. To get to the palace we took the #2 subway line from Nevesky Proskpect to the third from the end line (airport bus connection) and caught the 575 bus located behind the statue of Lenin above ground to Pushkin. It was suprisingly easy to get there this way. Once there we had some trouble figuring out how to get in and which line...not many English speaking people and little sinage or direction.If you have an online ticket you have to go through the arch on the right of the building to a kiosk on the left beside the gate. The booth opens at noon. We exchanged our tickets and were motioned to go through this back gate...although we are pretty sure it was only for groups. We went anyway and blended in with other tourist groups. There was not an English tour so you go in the building and find a kiosk for an audio tour (150 R). I highly recommend this, especially for the minimal price. Once you have bought a ticket for the audio guide you take it to the information desk and they will give the handset to you with a 1000 deposit per. They directed us to another line to get booties on and we again blended into a group. I think we really had a great experience seeing the palace because we weren't with a group and went at our own pace. You still have to follow a Pre determined path but could take as long as we liked. However, I think we probably didn't follow the procedure as intended. This is due to a lack of direction and language barrier. The restored rooms are really lovely but are complete restorations as the palace was in shambles after the war. Many pieces of art and furnature were spared in an evacuation. The amber room is a work of art and worth the visit in itself. Amazing workmanship and cost to recreate it. The grounds and park are lovely as well. You could easily spend an entire day here. We wished we had packed a picnic lunch to enjoy in the park after the tour to avoid exorbent restaurant prices.

Beautiful. We had a group visit here one evening and the setting sun over the palace was beautiful. The building itself is stunning and the interior is exquiste. A highlight of the trip to St Petersburg - not to be missed!

Amazing site long lines. This palace is not as easy to get into as you must wait in a long line to purchase a ticket for the palace - after you purchase a ticket for the park (must pay for park first). The park is large and not all buildings are open so you get a view from the outside. The palace is limited in what you can see but restoration is an ongoing process. The only room where pictures are not allowed is the amber room and yet people still 'sneak' pictures. I enjoyed everything about the visit and was very happy to have a guide that waited in line (over 1.5 hours) to gain entrance into the palace.
The Amber Room is stunning.. Catherine Palace is huge and it is beautiful. It is located next to Pushkin Village and is well worth a full day visit.

A most place to visit!. Don't miss this Palace.
Spend the day in its garden and visit the palace itself. It's has a lot of rooms with looks of the period and original timepieces.

Catherine really knew how to live. We went to the Catherine Palace on a small 4 person tour with Marie Rose tours, which also included a visit to Pavlovsk.Once again, greatly damaged in the war but spectacularly well restored. Masses of people here, and we had to don over-shoes.This Palace has rooms used by various Czars with personal items belonging to them. Plenty of Wow moments.Photography is strictly forbidden in the Amber Room. The original Amber Room was, of course, looted by the Nazis – boxed up and shipped back to Germany and now lost to history. What is here now is a reproduction based on old photographs. If this is what the reproduction looks like, I can scarcely imagine how the original must have looked.This was the favourite home of the Russian Royal Family and it is easy to see why - quite possibly, the MOST beautiful building you will ever enter.There is a gift shop here that showcases amber like nowhere else, including an amber chess set.

Splendid. You will love the palace interior (amber room) and the garden. Can be reached by local train and bus. Best way to visit and easiest way to tour the palace is to travel with a tourist group organised by a local travel company. You will find the travel organisors in the city center or in hotels.Can be difficult at times to buy tickets to tour the palace if a private group.

Study Katherine first. I read a good biography on Katherine the Great before going and it made the experience much better. The palace itself is opulent beyond description. Only negative... the crowds.

Do have a guide!. A magnificent building that oozes history and spectacle, well worth a visit. The Summer Palace, or Catherine's Palace is in the town of Pushkin, which I believe is also called Tsarkoe Selo. It's 20 miles/45 mins by car south of the City. The baroque style building has been restored since WWII bombing and the rooms - especially the ballroom and the amber room, are stunning, with ornate flooring, troupe d'oeil ceiling paintings, mirrors and gold carvings giving a vision of amazing and spectacularly lavish balls in the time of Tsarist wealth and elitism. The gardens are pleasant if not spectacular. We caught the Catherine Palace a cappella singers in the morning pavilion and their short performance in those acoustics was superb - and free (though the CD I then bought was a bit costly, though I hope worthwhile).The big advice though is to go with a guide - not just for the detail of the history, but to dodge the queues! I hear they're less in winter, but in July they are huge - estimated at up to 3 hours - and it was hot when we went. Our guide was great and we side stepped all queues, and were able to enjoy the experience and take-in the history. The were lots of people there - 20,000 a day, allowed in batches of 100 - but that doesn't tarnish the experience as much as you might fear.

Stunning opulence. This was one of the highlights of our 3 day tour of St Petersburg. Despite large crowds on a July day our guide managed to get our small group of 6 people in and around the palace dodging all the queues. The Gold Room and the Amber Room were truly amazing and it was a shame that no photography was allowed in the Amber Room but very good that photographs could be taken elsewhere. Our visit to the Catherine Palace was outstanding and we will remember it for a very long time.
Absolutely Stunning. This palace and park are so gorgeous! The Amber Room was actually smaller than I had imagined, but definitely worth seeing. This palace is amazing!

Awe inspiring and delightful. The Catherine Palace and Park provide a great day out. There is plenty to see in the expansive parkland and if you are lucky you'll be treated to a concert in the Grotto. The interiors are superb, particularly the Amber room. At the very end of the trip are some moving photographs of the devastation wreaked by the Nazis. The restoration of the Palace and Park is a fitting monument to those who died during the War and the dreadful siege of the city.

Magnificent and painstaking restoration. We visited the Catharine Palace on June 8, 2016. The Palace was burned by the Nazis during WWII and has since been meticulously restored over many years from original plans and photos. The venue is crowed but worth it. It is a view into an era that will never be repeated (hopefully). Even if you only have time to view the gardens and the exterior it is still worth the trip to Pushkin City which is where the palace is located

Wonderful palace with the extraordinary Amber room & park. A lovely place to visit and not too busy but had to wait a bit to enter the Amber rooms. However we think even that was quicker as we were in an organized tour. The gardens are exceptionally beautiful too.

Overcrowded. The Palace is magnificent, whether your tastes run to the Baroque or Neo-Classical. The gardens are truly magnificent in an English way. The major problem was over-crowding, especially by what looked like large parties from the cruise ships who behaved like utter yobs. Why get in line and consider that others have come to see this too, when you can push, shove and man-handle others out of the way? There were some photography restrictions (very arbitrary it seemed to me) but most people accept this. So it is very frustrating when some of these ill behaved mobs try every dodge in the book to catch an illicit snap (mostly by impeding the progress of others by standing in doorways, technically outside the forbidden room). Gallery attendants were rather officious (equally arbitrary). The kind of over-crowding and poor manners seem like an accident waiting to happen.

F A B U L O U S. This palace is a wonderfully opulent glimpse into another era and incredible that it is in 'public hands' rather than private - just amazing interiors, but wow is it crowded in the summer.

The opulence of the palace makes the trip worthwhile, but beware of the long lines.. Catherine certainly added an extravagant touch to all places she marked as hers. The facade of the building is magnificent, but the wait time to get into the palace was over an hour, and the tour of the interior was guided and rushed. That being said, the Gold Room and the Amber Room were spectacular!
Awesome!. It was a cold and rainy day when we visited but that didn't take away from the glitter and glitz. Don't miss this destination.

Summer Residence of the Imperial Family. The summer residence of the imperial family is well worth a visit. It's a bit off the beaten path, but worth the side trip. The palace is massive with opulent rooms adorned with gold and filled with original furniture. The gardens are just as fantastic. Don't miss this gem.
Historic Ambiance. This place keeps you stepping back into a different era of Russian monarchy. Must see. Use SPB tours, you wont regret it.

Catherine's Palace. This palace is just dripping with gold, walls, ceilings, passages, you can understand why the peasants revolted when they saw how wealthy the rich were. The gardens are enormous, but the Grotto beside the lake is worth a visit, the acoustics are excellent and the choir will sing for about 10 mins a time, then you must vacate for the next group to enter.

Beautifully restored to 18th C original design. Incredible arbour ways, ponds, and fountains, this park will leave a lasting impression of the beauty within the city surrounding you. Take a coffee break in one of the cafes or kiosk.

Stunning grounds and beautiful restorations. Catherine's palace is a gem, and it shows not only the grandeur of the era, but the continuing commitment to restoration after this palace was virtually destroyed by the Nazis as they abandoned the occupation of it at the end of the war. Guides will point out restoration work that was done and yet also point out some of the areas that escaped the fires and other destruction. The grounds are also well worth wandering around, and like Peterhoff, feel a bit more leisurely than the more regulated pace of tours inside the palace to manage the heavy crowds. I highly recommend including this palace and park in your itinerary.
Great place to spend a half to full day. We took a tour to the palace and park. It is a huge area with much to see. Beautiful gardens with many interesting/surprises.

How can you not go??. Catherine Palace is a must-see for anyone going to St Petersburg. Yes, there are lines and crowds. But once you are in, it is a feast for the eyes. Definitely worth having a tour guide, as the stories are as interesting as the building is opulent. And I found the stories of hiding and storing treasures pre-Nazi invasion, along with the subsequent restoration of the grounds and palace to be fascinating. Can't believe they are still restoring it. And what a job they've done.

Beautiful but Crowded. We were there with a small tour group (16). Even with a prearranged time we had to wait in line for the palace almost two hours due to the huge crowds that day. The grounds are wonderful. The palace is grandly beautiful but was insanely crowded and we did not get to spend near enough time inside.

So incredibly frustrating. From the poorly marked transportation from St. Petersburg to the poorly marked lines at the site, this was the most frustrating part of our trip to Russia. We stood on the wrong line for over an hour only to be told that we needed to move to another line that lasted over 3 hours. From there we were herded into the palace between tour groups. It was hard to see anything and overall, just left me feeling annoyed.Hard to recommend given how poorly organized it was.

St Petersburg. This palace is hugh, very pretty, but has been changed many times. Inside you will find the amber room,plus lots of gold in the other rooms. The rooms are filled with history, too much to take in, on one visit. The wait to get in here, if you are an individual can be very long, up to 3 hours. However as we were on an organised tour we didn't have to wait too long. If you go out of season the wait would be less.

Great Evening at Catherine Palace. We were blessed to see Catherine Palace in a 'private' event. Oceania (cruise line) had arranged to have an evening at the Palace. No visitors were there other than about 60 of us, who first toured the Carriage Museum, seeing a variety of types of carriages. The one that Alexander II was using when he was assassinated was amazing to see, damage and all. Then we walked to the main hall, to the music of a welcoming band. Inside the palace was beautiful and varied. Elizabeth had this built and named it for her mother, Catherine (Peter the Great's 2nd wife.) Elizabeth loved the ornate style so her rooms are lavish and covered with gold. When Catherine the Great followed, she redid some rooms in the neoclassical style. Both are beautiful. Floor to ceiling, you will be awestruck. The gem of the palace is the Amber Room. Like much of the rest of the palace, it is a restoration as opposed to the original, but who cares! Stunningly beautiful. Pictures don't do it justice. We can hope that they recover the original walls that were stolen in the war, but in the meantime, don't miss this! Then we moved through rooms with musicians entertaining us and into a ballroom/hall where a string quartet played and 'recreators' danced for us. Finally, we moved to a side building that would have housed troops or perhaps help, but we saw the less decorated area of the complex. In all, it was a great evening. Even if you have to fight the normal crowds, you will love this!

Great reminder of the golden age of monarchy and despots. Incredibly beautiful, even while undergoing major restoration, Catherine's palace is a reminder of that too much wealth, too much imagination, too many resources and an indomitable will can create. The buildings and grounds are stunning and the art, furniture and other decorations put this on a par with Versailles. What made this visit even more pleasurable was that we used SPB tours who virtually eliminated the waiting and long lines that every one else seemed to experience.

Excessive luxury. Again, two admissions, on for the park, second for the palace, the line for the palace would take you about 3 hours. Some people are pushing themselves forward. Organization there is to be improved, but definitely worth seeing it.
Superb. Another stunning building in this great city - Tour was excellent and the building simply stunning - another must

History at it Best!. This is a must see when visiting St Petersburg. It is a distance from the city but more than worth the trip to see. Lovely preservation of a historical home. Very opulent with gold gilding and tile fireplaces. The story behind this palace is wonderful. It was build for Catherine I second wife of Peter the Great not for Catherine the Great, which most believe. There are not enough words to describe the beauty and feel of this palace. Recommend to anyone who loves history.

Worth the Trip!. My darling and I decided to forego the hassle and lines and joined ULKO tours. We joined the tour through Trip Advisor and paid for it w a card. We were picked up by a nice Mercedes van, a stellar tour guide (Dima) and another English speaking couple. We were whisked through the city (40 minute drive)while Dima told fascinating stories and answered our questions. He got us tickets and we by-passed the throngs of visitors waiting in line. He brought us through the GORGEOUS palace and explained everything. We got to see the newly-restored Amber Room (totally spectacular) amongst many others. We never felt rushed or ignored. I highly recommend the Palace with or without the tour company and would/will return!
Beautiful. Don't miss.. One of the best. Beautiful palace and gardens. Fountains get started at 11:00, nice to watch. Amber room out of the world.

No idea why the serfs did not revolt more often.. Beautiful building and grounds. Each room is impressive for the architecture and the art. I did not find the Amber Room any more impressive than a lot of the others. It was overwhelming. Opulence everywhere you look.

Halls, Walls and Ceilings galore. Loved it.. Really magnificent, inside and out ..... the Amber room in particular should not be missed, I had heard about the history of the amber and seen pictures of the room, but the warmth and depth of the colour, not to mention the detail, has to be seen to give it justice. I felt it was necessary to have a guide to benefit from the tour, though I could have done with going round again to get the info to sink in....
Spectacular. Visited from a cruise ship so time was a bit limited. It is a fantastic place and the Amber Room is fabulous. Best time to avoid lots of tourists would be October.

Beautifull palace, but be there really early to avoid the groups. Arrived at 10.30, but then already there was a huge line of mostly Chinese groups before the entrance to the palace. It opened at 12 noon, but I did not get in until 3pm. The issue is that they only allow precisely 100 people in per 15 minutes. Once you are in, expect anther 10-15 minute wait for the security check. It can be a bit claustrophic. Once you enter the stairs, be prepared for some slalom around groups if you travel by yourself. As in the Hermitage do not get intimated by groups and sometimes fight for your place.There is little time for walking around, because basically you are gently pushed from room to room by the staff. You are are allowed to take pictures everywhere, except for the Amber room.It is easy to get there by bus or bus and metro from the city. It takes you 1-2 hours depending on the route and where you are staying.The entry fee is 1000 roubles, but you need a ticket for the park first.
See the palace, skip the park. St Petersburg has almost unending amount of things to see. If you are short of time its better to see the palace (which is gaudy yet amazing) and skip the park

Catherine's Palace, great place to visit on a rainy day in St. Petes. As you can tell from the title, the weather was not our friend for our visit to Saint Petersburg. Catherine's Palace was a perfect escape for a rainy day. From the Amber Room to the spectacular multi-colored dining rooms, ballrooms, greeting areas with the throne present, this is a place not to be missed on any visit to S.P. Took a short walk to Catherine's favorite small enclosed portico, and we greeted with a 4 voice accapella choir that was marvelous. one of our favorite sight in S.P.

Nice attraction. Try to book a private guide and skip the lines! Really worth seing - some rooms not finished renovating but still great building. Take some time and walk through the park it's really cool.
Wonderful outdoor walk. The building, especially the Amber room, is unique and has been restored with great care and an eye on detail.

Self guided tour of garden. This place is stunning! Absolutely beautiful. We got there in the morning (10am) on a bus and stood in line for a few mins to get tickets to the gardens. The tickets for the palace are bought seperately inside the gardens. Unfortunately the queue had already formed when we arrived and we would had to wait for an hour before they even opened. We never use tours, but in this case I would have used one to be able to skip the lines and get in. However a tour doesnt allow you time to see the whole gardens, like we did. There are many pavilions and statues spread throughout and it is all beautiful. This just gives me a good reason to go back to SP!

Another stunning place to visit in St Petersburg.. Absolutely beautiful both inside and out. Beware in the Amber Room - no photography and if you try (someone in our tour did), beware of the "security guards" (mainly ladies) who will certainly tell you off! If you get a chance to see BBC War and Peace before you visit do as some of it was filmed here. Some of the rooms are breathtaking and certainly worth a visit. Understandably, it gets quite busy so be prepared to wait to get in.

Crowded and long lines, but worth it!. We visited on a rainy day and the lines were quite long, but once inside, the rooms were magnificent. Crowds in the afternoon were pressing and difficult to navigate, so go early in the day.

Nice place fresh air . Very nice place fresh air we rent a cart horse and take a ride around the place was nice and interesting cause it is a big park if by walk, I recommend this for visitors and cost not too much.

Beautiful place worth visiting . Wonderful surroundings an intriguing open space to spend some time in. Cost was 120 to get into the gardens and 1000 into the palace itself. The palace is very beautiful inside. It's being restored so looks great. You can get an English audio guide for another 120 rub. We took one between two and just put the volume up loud. We could hear it fine. Lol. It's a bit of a trek outside of st Petersburg. We took the metro to Kupichina then got a private minibus type taxi there. So cost is less than 100 rub to get there. We were with a local who had done the trip before.

A little hard to enjoy when it's overcrowded. Catherine Palace is located in the town of Pushkin, located outside of St. Petersburg, about an hour’s drive away. The town is sometimes also referred to as Tsarkoye Selo in some guidebooks (in case anyone is confused like I was initially). Anyway, we visited Catherine Palace only to see the opulent but otherwise masterfully restored Amber Room of course. Before you enter, the usual security checks apply and no water is allowed inside (not even bottled water). They will usually request that you leave your outer jackets at the cloak room too, especially if you’re wearing the thick, heavy-set-looking ones; light jackets are permitted. I suggest just placing your jackets inside the cloakroom in any case; imagine queuing all the way to the security checkpoint (queues are never short by the way) only to be told that you can’t go further because of the jacket issue… The entrance is pretty congested with lots of people queueing for the toilets and lots of people trying to store/retrieve their stuff at the cloakroom so be prepared for chaos. The interior of the palace is really beautiful and photography of the palace interior is permitted everywhere except for the Amber Room. I toured the palace in a big group of 30 and we were constantly shooed along by the matronly custodians in every room, and our guide had to talk really fast, so the entire tour felt rushed. Can’t really blame the custodians either, since there were simply too many tourists packed inside the palace and they had to keep ushering groups along to prevent congestion. Don’t expect you’ll have the luxury of time to take in the beauty of the Amber Room. If possible, I suggest touring the palace interior in a small group (maybe 2-3 people at most); the smaller groups might have a wee bit more leeway with the custodians.
wow. Another amazing place, lots to see could have spent a full day but was included amongst a day,s itinerary The Amber room is a must.

Great Park, great Palace. This was an eagerly anticipated tour and it worked out beautifully with the aid of Natalya, our TJ travel guide. The park was extensive and we covered it first. At a quick pace (you don't want to lag behind and miss the description of events) we covered many of the highlights and historical features of the surroundings. Then the Palace was an item in itself. Absolutely a must see.

Worth a visit, Its not just about the Amber Room. Although one of the things the palace is famous for is the Amber Room there is so much more. As you walk around the inside of the palace you travel from one opulent room to another opulent room. What makes it even more amazing is that the silks on the walls and the inlaid wooden floors as well as other parts of the palace have been restored using the original techniques. It is as if it was never damaged during the war.The Amber Room is beautiful, but unlike the rest of the palace you cannot take photos in there. The grounds it stands in are also lovely with the kitchen buildings (you wouldn't know that they are kitchens unless you are told) standing apart from palace.It does get busy and some of the other guides try to push other guides along so theycan their group in a better spot.

Beautiful palace ruined by tourism. The Palace is absolutely stunning both outside and inside. But the massive numbers of tourists visiting this rather small castle with very narrow corridors makes it an agonizing place to visit. Expect a queue for two hours with guided groups just randomly gate crashing the queue somewhere in the middle.Furthermore, when inside of the castle, a massive effort in making the guided tourists occupy just one side of the corridors since it is almost impossible to get around as a single person or as a couple without a guide. This place has massive potential, but I would strongly recommend anyone to keep their distance during summer.
Interesting place - worth a visit. An impressive restoration - the scale is amazing, wonderful workmanship and commitment to detail. Some rooms are still to be completed.

More tsarist extravagance. Toured the palace, Opulent (Suprise ,suprise) Amber room, a slight let down for me, but it was a must see. The park was very enjoyable we walked & walked to the various constructs, really enjoyed the Turkish tower( designed to look derelict) built to commemorate a russian victory over the Ottomans, of which there are quite a few- Seems the Russians thumped on the "sick man of Europe" a multiple times.

Stunning! An insight into how the Czars lived - wow!. Catherine's Summer Palace is stunning. The many rooms are enormous, opulently decorated and furnished. So much gilding, beautiful inlaid wooden floors, marble staircases, Delft tiles, elaborate ceilings, chandeliers. And, of course, the famous Amber Room. Don't miss this palace - it is the best you will ever experience! Surrounding the palace are marvelous grounds, worth taking some time to explore. I recommend taking a tour to see this palace so that you can learn details about its history and importance. Note: Expect crowds.

Magnificent . We went on an organised tour from our cruise ship, we were there early to beat the crowds. Our guide was very knowledgeable and pointed out things that you would probably have missed had we not been on a tour.The Palace is amazing with gold, marble and beautiful painted ceilings in every room. The Amber room is incredible but no photos allowed. The gardens are beautiful with lakes and tree lined avenues, with many beautiful buildings within the grounds. Visiting Catherine's palace was the highlight of our visit to St. Petersburgh and somewhere not to be missed.

A Cant Miss Attraction.. One of the more beautiful attractions of this St. Petersburg area. Both the Palace and the surrounding Park are well worth your time to visit. The Park is expansive and filled with historical pleasures as well as being beautifully tended to.

Spectacular Palace and Historic place. Catherine Palace is without a doubt one of the most spectacular places you could visit and an absolute must see during your visit to St Petersburg. The scale of the this magnificent Palace is incredible with its blue, white and gold facade, the lavishness of the rooms so impressive as renovations continue after extensive damage during WW2. We had a fantastic tour guide who managed to collect our tickets without us having to queue so my advice is to get there early - this is a hugely popular tourist destination and one well worth visiting. Make sure you either have a guide with you so you can hear the interesting history about Catherine wife of Peter the Great.
amazing. fabulous place, amazing history, went with a guide, still had a long wait in the sun, but so worth it
Catherine Palace - Beautiful Gardens. Access to the Park and Palace was included in our SBP Tours package. The beautiful garden and palace was AMAZING!

wheelchair accessible. This was another beautiful palace near St Petersburg (see also The Peterhof) that was wheelchair accessible. I was dreading the stairs and the long hallways before I went but my SPB Tour guide knew just what to do. The Amber Room was stunning!!

Best attraction in St. Petersburg. The palace was beautiful but the gardens are what really make this place amazing. It is too gorgeous to describe on a nice day. Allow yourself plenty of time to enjoy the fountains and a leisurely walk through the park.

Beautifully restored. I visited Catherine's Palace as part of an organized cruise ship tour on a day where Catherine's Palace is closed to the public. Unfortunately, this did not result in less visitors. We arrived relatively early in the day, but were still forced to wait in a lengthy line outside before entering for about 30 minutes in the rain, but were lucky because groups behind us waited 1-2 hours in line in the rain before they got in. They seem to only allow so many people in at a time, but it wasn't really consistent. There is a free forced coat/umbrella check area near the entrance and also a reasonably sized free restroom area. I forget how many rooms you get to visit, but its not many in comparison to the total number in the palace, however, it is enough to get a feel for what it was like for those who stayed there. It was well worth being on an organized tour with a guide in Catherine's Palace. The tour moves a quick pace with pretty much one group allowed in each room at a time. No photos of any kind are allowed in the amber room, but you could easily take photos of it from the adjacent rooms. They've done a nice job restoring this palace over the years. Its got all of the glitz and gold that you might expect.
gorgeous palace!!!. One just steps back in history...beautifully kept and restored palace.. my mind was reverberating with stories about the Tsars ...too interesting!!!

Amazing palace and grounds. There are so many palaces in St. Petersburg and vicinity that it is easy to become complacent and say...oh another palace. This palace is amazingly beautiful, ornate, and home to amazing artifacts of Russian history. It becomes increasingly easy to understand why there was a Russian Revolution when at the same time these palaces were being built and decorated, millions of Russian citizens were suffering and dying in poverty. Lenin made the decision to preserve these palaces to justify the revolution and the tourist benefits from this decision.

Crazy opulent. Another amazing example of Russian opulence. This place is gorgeous - even if you don't appreciate the Baroque style you will still be amazed. The restoration teams have done an incredible job. Small children will be bored. This tour requires lots of walking and standing and there is no where to sit or rest.

Worth the crowds. Catherine’s Palace has had a stunning reconstruction after being almost completely destroyed during the Nazi siege on Leningrad.The crowds were daunting but it was well worth it to see the magnificent Palace that Catherine the Great had built. The gold, mirrors, the Ballroom, the staircases…all have been lovingly restored to their former beauty. A grand place and a must see while in St. Petersburg.

Gold everywhere. Built to rival Versailles, it certainly goes a long way towards that. There is so much gold and mirrors. Opulence. It explains why the Russian people hated the monarchy, and morally it seems very wrong but you have to marvel at the quality of the detail and quality of workmanship. And then you find that much of it is a re-creation, managed by the communist government after the original was destroyed by the Nazis during World War II. They are still restoring parts of the palace, which is extensive and you could walk around for hours. A guide is essential.

A great gift from Peter the Great!. This may have been a gift from Peter the Great to his future wife, but to me, it's a gift to everyone who chooses to visit! This is a grand, artistic, lavishly ornate palace with gold everywhere, enhanced by mirrored walls and ceilings. Numbers of people are controlled for going through the various rooms but that's good as you can get the best views - Amber room especially (no photos allowed in there).

a true gem. The palace and grounds are absolutely stunning. The workmanship in the reconstructed Amber Room is beyond words. I was also on a tour that included the reconstruction area for the Amber Room which was definitely worth doing.

One of the top sights for a St. Petersburg visit. Catherine Palace and grounds are built to an impressive scale. No one camera angle can come close to capturing that. The palace’s golden spires and soft colors catch the sunlight beautifully. If you are staying in St. Petersburg, visiting the Catherine Palace would be a day trip. The trip takes roughly 1-1.5 hours each way to and from the city center. As with other major palaces in and around St. Petersburg, the palace and grounds are divided into separately-ticketed attractions. You may need to walk to an attraction to buy a ticket for it, rather than buying tickets for all the attractions you want to visit in one place. The line to enter the palace was at least two hours long when I visited.

The visit to puskin is worthwhile. The summer palace built for Catherine the first shows the opulence of the royal family during the 18th century when average Russians were just getting by. No wonder there was a Russian revolution. Very interesting visit.

Worse waiting. Got there at 10:30am, huge line to get into the palace, waited for 2 hours ( we took turns to look around). Got inside and forgot everything: just amazing.... Totally worse it. Check little Fan exhibition just few steps from palace.
Unbelievable . This is so over the top, I couldn't believe the opulence. The net Room does not disappoint. A do not miss for tourists in St.Petersburg.

Versailles of Russia. It was called Tsarskoye Sele (“Czars’ Village) until 1910, built by Catherine I, Elizabeth (wife and daughter of Peter the Great) and Catherine the Great.We came with a tour group and waited for about 1 hour to get in. It was not very orderly with people rubbing shoulders. Once we got, it was better. You waited one group to finish before entering each room. Each room was opulent and beautiful in Baroque and Neoclassical style. There was major damage done to Catherine Palace during WWII, about 32 (out of 58) were recreated. The most famous room was Amber Room (unfortunately no photo allowed) which was rebuilt in 2003.Catherine Palace is in Pushkin, about 15 miles S of SPG. You are better off come with tour group to handle all the logistics. It is a must see in St. Petersburg.

An icon of Pushkin. No tourist will go to this suburb unless to see this palace, Again we were there as soon as the palace opened and our guide really knew how to avoid the crowds, she just did not allow us enough time in the gardens, as our tour that we booked from the Disney cruise said that they will allow one hour in the palace, and the second our in the gardens.However, the guide allowed us no more than 15 min in the gardens and was so eager to take us to the souviner shops just outside the palace, and then she was so happy to get us back to the ship earlier as to allow people who booked two tours to rest before the second tour ( I did not like this a bit).In fact I really want to go back to St. pete again to see the attractions better, the problem is that the season with good weather in this city is very short.I guess April to June are the best months to visit this city, with the white-nights in June.

Visiting Catherine Palace and Park.. Like all in old Russian Capital all is "Imperial", big, beautiful and you feel the power of mother Russia.Mr. Putin puts a lot of money to preserve Russian legacy. Like it even more than Saint Petersburg!Palace is full of people, anyway worth to visit (amber room), don't go there on hot days, there is no air conditioning (18 century :) )Park is huge and very green. Worth to visit!

Grandeur Beyond Belief. This was an amazing palace with ornate wood work and amazing hard wood floors. You are allowed to take pictures in every room excluding the amber room. The place is filled with tour groups and they tend to push you through rather quickly, but it is a site to be seen. I personally found the history of the destruction and restoration to be very interesting. Definitely would recommend to a friend. I have seen numerous palaces/castles while living in Germany, but this one was unbelievable.

A Must-See Place. Catherine's Palace is exactly what you'd expect of a building designed and occupied by somebody like Catherine The Great with an amazing opulence. The Amber Room is indeed impressive but so is the whole of the interior whilst the facade is somewhere that is a photographer's delight.

Spectacular, but very crowded.. In conjunction with Peterhoff, Catherine Palace is spectacular. Unfortunately it is a major tourist attraction and very crowded. You are forced to move through the palace like cattle. Worth the discomfort? Yes, once. The park is large and comfortable, even with the crowds. The fountains and water displays are well worth a visit on it's own. Lunch is available in the park.

A must see along with all the other wonderful places in St P.. A lovely place to experience, gold like you won't image, and the Amber Room is just Wow! then when you have walked for what seems like miles taking it all in there's the gardens. Just go.

Must see. From city centre took the metro and local bus, all very easy, took just over an hour. Weather was mixed, heavy rain at times. Que for palace was huge so we focussed on walking the grounds which are amazing; there are numerous other buildings than the main place and you get a feel for the vastness of the estate.This and Peterhof are the two places we visited drug our trip which were outside of St Petersburg and we spent a day at each.

Beyond Amazing!. Hard to describe all the beauty inside and out. A must if you are visiting St. Petersburg! A "summer palace" that Catherine the Great designed. All the rooms are beautiful - a golden treasure - including the Amber room!
Of course its a 5!. Huuuge place with huuuuge crowds! Blows most other European palaces out of the water. The amber room is incredible. Could spend an entire day here.

Not Your Normal Summer Cottage. Opulence beyond what most of us could imagine. Immense palace with huge gilded ballrooms and parlors. It seems that each room attempts to outdo the other in its beauty. It must have served its purpose to impress the 18th century visitors with the power and wealth of the royal owners. Restorations of the palace are spectacular. The Amber Room is especially impressive. My focus was on the ceilings and floors. The inlaid wood flooring was amazing. It now rightfully belongs to all the people of Russia. Definitely a sight to see in St. Petersburg.

Palace of beauty!. Catherine did it up very well! She designed a lot of this palace and made sure to follow through each and every room with the same theme and opulence. Awesome scale and finish work. Sometimes you just had to stand and let your eyes and ears take in the moment in time.

Stunning. The opulence of Catherine's Palace is breathtaking. Photography is permitted except in the Amber Room and the grounds are lovely. Once again we booked a private excursion with guide, it's much easier that way. Do not miss this when visiting St Petersburg.
Beautiful Place. It was really nice. The parks and the palace. It was repaired after World War the second but it is still beautiful. The lake inside the park has a great view for taking photograph.

Beautiful Palace. We visited in July and it was just amazing. The palace is huge and a lot of rooms are open to the public. The Amber Room was especially impressive. Each room you walk in is more grand then the next. It is just an amazing place full of history and interesting stories.

Stunning Interiors. It may not have the water-features of Peterhof, but the gilded interiors of the Palace are exceptional. One of the top attractions in St Petersburg, expect big crowds. The logistics of seeing the rooms are geared around tour groups - where the staff permit each group into a room at a time, so this is probably the easiest way of visiting.

another impressive palace but too many tourists inside at once meant it got hot. couldn't wait to see this palace luckily before the winter palace as the winter palace is the palace to see. This one was like a lot of other palaces I have visited internally except for the amber room which I was underwhelmed by and the hall of mirrors which was fantastic. The grounds were nicely laid out but not as immaculate as UK gardens or Versailles. I think they should spend some of the entrance fees in maintainence

Amazing park, no chance to enter the palace. It is quite hard to plan a visit to enter this palace if you are a single traveler. There isn't enough information on the web and if you aren't in a travel group, you will wait forever in a cue without chance of getting in, unless you have the whole day to wait. When you arrive in the park it is not clear if you can buy the ticket at the counter outside: there you can buy only the ticket for the park. Inside the park the ticket for the palace. The park is so beautiful that you don't even need to be bothered (much) about the long waiting.
Catherine Palace. One can experience the grandeur of a bygone era and be mesmerized by the workmanship, and the materials with which the palace was constructed.

Unbelievable. I can't find the right superlatives to describe the grandeur and majesty of this palace. Each and every room is unique in its way. The decorations are masterwork of art, the wall paintings are beautiful. The golden ornaments and decorations are amazing. The ceilings the floors everything...The amber room can't be described in words one has to see it to believe.The history of this palace is on the one hand full of glory and majesty and on the other hand full of misery and destruction which reached the peak in WW2 when Germany destroyed and plundered this jem.We couldn't see the garden because it rained but from what we did manage to see was most beautiful work of gardening

Stunning Palace and my favourite of our Russian Trip.. The Jewel in the Crown for me. I loved everything about this palace, it is breath-taking in scale and opulence and history. A favourite of the Romanovs. We had booked a guided tour and leaned so much about the building and the history.

Magnificent. Lovely to get out of the city and see this amazing palace. Pretty spectacular, with beautiful gardens and water features..Highly recommend you take a guide as the crowds are also fairly spectacular, and they(the guides) know their way around.

A must!. This is one of the most incredible sites which was almost completely destroyed during the second World War and is being restored to its former glory. It is worth a visit if only to seethe stunning Amber Room.
Feel the history.. We were lucky enough to have our own personal guide who knew her history and made it come to life. Loved it.

Grand breathtaking palace. This palace is breathtaking in its architectural splendour and interior decor. Tells you a lot about the time and money invested by the czars in pursuit of all things beautiful

Unbelievable opulence. This was one of many organised tours on a cruise from Moscow to St. Petersburg. Catherine's Palace was constructed in the 18th century and it surprises me that it only took four years to build according to Wikipedia. Obviously in those days you just needed money and the right architects and builders. Planning permission didn't come into it.Considering the crowds entry was remarkably quick and, once inside, you are kept moving at quite a pace. Over 200 pounds of gold are used inside and out for decoration and this metal is beautifully displayed behind clear protective panels.Of parallel interest are the gardens and fountains outside. Not as glitzy as the fountains at the Bellagio hotel, Las Vegas, but then, I don't think that would be in keeping.There's a large area to visit and we couldn't cover everything we wanted to see in the time available. Lunch was a hastily consumed ice cream on the hoof.This probably could be classified as one of the wonders of the modern world and certainly enhanced our visit to Russia.
Opulence !. Wonderfull and grand!!! The Amber Room just takes your breath away!!! So much history hidden in it's past. Art lovers paradise!!!Not enough words to describe the rooms.
Beautiful gardens with creative fountains . You can visit the palace and gardens. The gardens have numerous fountains that are all unique, none are the same. It is a must while at the palace.

Great day in the country. We enjoyed the visit. We took the metro, and a little bus- no 545 to the Palace. Had a good lunch in the upstairs restaurant by the entrance gate. Spent the rest of the day in the Palace and grounds

Well worth a visit for the grdens alone. Having mobility issues, I was not really interested in a tour of the palace its self and having to deal with the crowds. However the private guide service I was using insisted the palace interior was a must see and arranged to have a wheel chair available for me. Needless to say, dealing with the crowds inside the palace was not an enriching experience. However the grounds and gardens were simply amazing and there is a shuttle service available to take you through the various gardens.
Awesome!. Try to go with a tour or private guide to avoid the long lines - the amber room is an amazing restoration!

Catherine's Beautiful Palace. St Petersburg is overwhelming. We were dazzled by the sights which are some of the grandest in the world. We had beautiful weather which added to the beauty. If you are traveling to many cities, this is the one to focus on for palaces. They are the biggest and the best We were a group of seven ranging in age from 8 to 70 and think this city is the most uniquely constructed and designed for touring.
Amazing Palast. This is an amazing palast with all the different rooms, everyone with a different floor. It is very crowded. Try to be there early if you want to avoid longer ques.

Lots to see. There were 7 cruise ships in port the day we went to Catherine's Palace and made for a hectic entrance. We finally got in after many behind the scenes maneuvering by our tour guides. It was worth the wait once we entered.

A must see. Got to see this amazing place before they let in those queuing from outside. We were a disabled group so they lets us in first. Great to avoid the crowds. Got to see such splendour and never forget it's beauty. I had to transfer from my disability scooter with black wheels to wheelchair with grey wheels but worth every minute.

Incredible, a must visit. I loved his place, it represents all of the opulence of the Russian dynasties. The gold and Amber rooms were impressive, hard to believe this was a real home. It takes about 2 hours to get through it all, but it's so worth it.
Tour of Palace. Not well managed. Germany does a much better job with Newschwanstein Castle (fully automated! with on the second tours every five minutes...no waiting!) Russia, get up to speed!

Magnifisant Palac and Park . We didn't wisit the Palace itself.We only walk along the park and enjoy the Pakace from outside .Better to buy tickets before, otherwise you will lose so much time waiting in line to buy tickets.

Fabulous but Visit early Morning. Definitely a huge recommendation for everybody going to St Petersburg. We went with a guide and walked around for two hours. This is again one of those destinations that is a must see. Although the palace was very crowded.

Well worth the trip. By bus it takes about 1h to get to Pushkin from central St Petersburg, but it's certainly worth it. The spacious palace has been beautifully restored, and even with the usual crowds you can enjoy your visit.

Phenomenal Palace . Catherine the Great 's palace is a must visit . The grandiosity of this edifice is amazing . The interior is very ornate . From the Amber room to the details in the architecture in each room is mind blowing . A large section of the palace was burned down during the Second World War . The stories about how a lot of the artifacts were buried during the war for preservation were very interesting .

Make time to see this ! . This is considered the Summer Palace during the time of Catherine the Great. It is quite elaborate of a sight. The interior is breathtaking and each room even more impressive than the next. Try to visit this early in the day when it's less crowded you will enjoy the trip more. The gardens are lovely and expansive. Make sure you take time to walk in the gardens.

Disappointment. This visit was ruined by poor organization on the part of the operators. We were booked to enter at 3:10 and finally gained entry at 3:50. Regardless of the entry time you have to queue and that means lining up well before the booked time. Not an issue you might suggest but all that time was spent standing in pouring rain being pushed and shoved by other impatient queuers. Once inside the rooms proved interesting but I wish I knew that little seen was older than me with the palace being destroyed in World War 2. I already knew the story of the Amber Room that looked far smaller and less impressive than the photographs I had seen. In fact it looked very plastic to me! All of this was not helped by officious guides with their multitude of rules and moving us on. Equally popular venues elsewhere in Europe seem to manage crowds much better.

Dazzling Tsar's Village and fabled Amber Room. A beautiful palace with gilded domes just like a fairy tale. Restored at great cost and effort after almost royal destruction in the last war, it is now a must see in St Petersburg. The fabled Amber room is recreated and worth a visit.

Arrive before doors open and be near front of line. It is totally understandable why there were so many impoverished people in Russia. The palaces of the rulers were beyond lavish. They are incredible. You must see the amber room. To have been an artist in those days must have been unbelievably challenging and death defying. There are many areas which are not open to the public but it is worth the trip to see the magnificent architecture, especially inside. Awesome

fantastic, majestic, and GOLD.... I cant believe the negative comments, because it was busy.... This is one of the greatest houses I have ever see, despite it being totally rebuilt and decorated after its demise. The palace itself is massive, and each room is different from the previous, and the amber room is the highlight, apart from the amount of gold used... It would be pointless going into too much detail, you just have to see for yourself. The grounds are nice, very walkable, and gardens well laid out.Yes there will be thousands there, but as with all the places in St Petersberg, if you want to see them, you just have to go with the flow. We arrived on a cruise ship, and had a guide, deffinately the best way to see and learn about the palace. you also have to wear little shoe covers on your feet for protection

Very crowded and hot. I know everyone loved this place, and I may have felt differently if I went at a different time. The day we went it was soooo crowded you could barely move, and it was very hot because of that. Also, you feel herded through the palace, you can't see things on your own. The palace itself is stunning and mind-boggling. But touring it was not my favorite.

Catherine's Palace. This is an extraordinary palace. It's HUGE and amazing. It's done in the baroque style which is quite ornate and maybe garish. It should not be missed because it's so unusual and helps explain how the Romanovs thought.

Nice. A big complex, but not as grand as we had hoped. It looks really lovely from the outside and it is actually a nice building, but we were not as impressed with it as we have been with others, both in Russia and other countries. It is not easy to gain entry into the building. We went early morning to get tickets and then had to wait for quite some time, as entry times were staggered, in order to go inside. Apparently large groups can enter much more easily.... The place was extremely crowded, and we were rushed by the staff, to keep moving, so we could not really stay around to gain a good understanding of what we were looking at. The gardens were by far very beautiful and quite impressive. We loved them.

One of the most precious places in Russia. This where Empress Catherina was receiving Rasputin and indulging into her private pleasures.This is also a place where legendary Amber Chamber is. Fully restored and magnificent. Inside the palace one can hardly find a space which is not glittered with gold. So grand and must see while in St.Petersbourg. I would recommend to hire a guide or to be a part of organized group while visiting the Palace and grounds around it.

Wonderful experience. When you consider that this building was left in ruins after WW2, it is nothing short of miraculous that they have managed to restore it to such a degree, this applies to Peterhof and many other buildings too. After you are kitted out in your protective shoe coverings, you start to walk through a series of rooms each magnificently decorated, crystal chandeliers, superb art, silks. A wonder through the gardens is worth while too. Don't tread on the grass though!

Expansive Palace Still Needs Some Renovation. Contrary to Peterhov, this palace and grounds has been less extensively renovated. Perhaps this is because it seems like one of those residences that had add-on upon add-on without consideration to the architectural whole. So, Russia marshaling its dollars focused instead on Peterhof, which was a reasonable decision.Nevertheless, Catherine's Palace and Park are worth a visit on a day trip out to the countryside, but only after one has first fully explored Peterhof Palace and its many gardens. With many beautiful rooms, this palace (unlike Peterhof) allows one to take photographs in the many rooms of varying design and less particular decoration. Grounds, too, are not as extensively cared for as are those at Peterhof.

Horrible queues , swamped with pushy tour groups. Don't go!!!! This was the worst day of our Russian adventure as independent travelers .While saint p has been bad for too many tourists and overcrowding this was simply ridiculous..?we queued for about one and a half hours for nowhere, no signs, no English... Makes you regret being another tourist ticking boxes. Grounds are ok. My advice if you must go pack a picnic and enjoy the grounds or go in wintertime.

Yikes....but beautiful!. My husband and I did not take the advice of many to get there before it opened and we paid the price. We got there about 11:00 am and ended up in line waiting for two hours and that line is a standing line. The huge problem with the line is that you have people that hold places for large groups so when they let people in every 15 mins you see all these people go in and you move up maybe one meter :( stupid! You may also want to figure out how you are getting there and back before you go. We took an Uber there but then it was impossible to get a taxi or uber back to our hotel. They are non-existent that far out. You would think they would be easy to get but nope because everyone comes on huge tour buses. The amber room in the palace was worth the trip.

This is where the amber room is. When you visit and come in from the main entrance you will see how vast this place is .
