You have to wear overshoes when you go inside and you go to the fist floor from a beautiful stair case into a grand ballroom. What takes you is the elegance of the rooms and how they are designed.You then follow a line which takes you through several different rooms which were used for sleeping dining entertaining etc. Again I would just say you must have a guide to understand what you are looking at and the significance of it .

Spectacular Catherine s Palace.. This palace is really spectacular. It is 300 metres long and decorated outside in blue white and gold. There are a fair number of stairs inside but we coped quite well. We are in our mid seventies. All the rooms are spectacular. Sumptuous with their gold decoration. The amber room is quite remarkable. The walls are covered in 3 tons Amber mosaic, I believe. The gardens are natural but lovely. It is good to have a guide if possible. We were there on a rather hot day and we fairly tired afterwards,probably due to our age. But we are so glad we visited here.

Seven Cruise ships at once. We traveled on Oceania Cruises, a relatively small ship with 600 passengers. In the harbor were six other mega giant ships with 2 - 3,000 passengers each, all going to the Winter Place and the Summer Palace at the same time. The traffic from the pier was beyond Los Angeles, it took 1and a 1/2 hours to get to the heart of the city and the same length of time to get back, normally a 30 minute trip. It sucked the enthusiasm out of our visit.

Needs a sixth option on rating to do it justice. Luckily, we were one of the first cruise ship tours to arrive, so it was not too crowded. By the time we left, it felt like half of Russia was there.Highlight had to be the Amber room - words are inadequate to describe it except when you see it you can understand why the 1917 revolution happened.We also visited the amber room renovation workshop- not sure if this is generally open or just for cruise ship tours, but well worth the time to see how the amber is worked.Sadly, we didn't have much time to visit the garden, which would take a whole day in them self.A Highlight was the four guys ( ee photo) entertaining the crowd.

Spectacular!. Like many of the historic places in the St. Petersburg area, Catherine Palace was destroyed by the Nazis, but then the palace was completely restored after WWII. Of interest is that when the Russians knew the Nazis were heading toward the palace, they painstakingly removed all the valuable paintings and shipped them to Siberia until after the war. When Catherine Palace was restored, they were returned once again. This palace is beautiful and it's hard to imagine anyone living here. It's best on a private tour where one can bypass the extremely long lines to get inside.

Do not miss. This is so full of bling one almost needs sunglasses..The amber room is a recreation as the Nazis looted the original and it has never been found. The heating stoves are made of blue and white tiles and are things of great workmanship,would have loved to have seen them in use.The grounds are lovely if you have time to tour them.The only downside is the line for the loos, really could do with more.

A beautiful Palace not to miss!. This Palace is one you would definitely not want to miss. It was mostly destroyed in WWII however the reconstruction, even being new is how it used to be. The Amber room is out of this world.

I was overwhelmed standing outside this magnificent palace.!!. Wow, what an amazing palace. I loved the beautiful blue and gold of the palace. Once inside we visited many of the rooms, my favourites were the ball room full of gold, mirrors and candleabras, then the amazing Amber room. Having our special guide telling us the history of the rooms was wonderful and this was a highlight so we could understand the use and history of each room.

Stunning!. I would say the only downside is that in the summer you could wait several hours to enter this beautiful palace. A beautiful homage to Catherine the great. The surrounding park was as beautiful to me as the palace.

A Treasure. I wanted to see Catherine's palace because I had read so much about her. Once I was there I was amazed by what the Russian people did to preserve the palace from the Nazi's. In my opinion, the palace is as much a tribute to the Russian people as it is to Catherine. The Amber room was beautiful but so was the rest of the palace. There is more walking then the Hermitage, but not overwhelming. It is a must!
Genius Restoration. The palace was almost completely destroyed during the Second World War its restoration to near original is a hell of a successful skilled work

Opulence Plus!. Amazing history, palace and gardens. Enjoyed the drive out to Pushkin. Best to go with a small guided group to avoid queuing and hear the stories of the tsars. Sourced our company through Trip Advisor.
Loved it. Most of the palaces are restored as they were almost entirely destroyed during world War II. They've been beautifully restored and worth a visit.

Beaufifully restored palace. Carefully restored after the Nazis virtually destroyed it during World War II. The famous amber room, although not the original, is a unique sight to behold. It is well worth the trip to Pushkin to see it.

Rebuilt. Destroyed in the war it has been painstakingly rebuilt and is very impressive. It's huge and busy but the route through is one way so you can enjoy each room. Once you have protective slippers on there are stairs. Autocratic leaders had plenty of money so it is decadent beyond you can imagine. The gardens are nice and it has a good gift shop. Don't miss a visit

It may not be original but a very faithfully accurate rebuild.. The palace was largely destroyed by the Nazis, but much of the original artifacts were removed and stored safely away. A stunning sight and well worth a couple of hours visit

May Day at the Palace. Crowded and full of pageantry we visited the Palace on May Day and watching the celebrations was wonderful. The buildings and park are wonderful and the trip out on the boat was exhilarating... Loved it!

Nice, but. . .. OK, it's gorgeous. But, it is almost a complete rebuild, as the original was so badly damaged during WWII.
If you have the time, go. If you're pressed for time, stay with the attractions in St. Petersburg.

Lots of Gold and Glitz. The famous Amber room and a string of other rooms highly decorated and quite beautiful. It has been reconstructed after being largely destroyed by the Germans during WW2. Large gardens complete with baby ducks and musicians.

Grand Imperial Evening of the Tsars!. While cruising the Baltic Sea on Oceania we took a side trip in the evening to this unbelievable palace. We strolled through the rooms on a private tour as we enjoyed flute and spinet music and a great tour guide who explained the history of the palace in each beautiful room. We loved the Amber room and the string quartet while dancers entertained us, then enjoyed a wonderful meal as "gypsies" danced and sang.

Breathtaking. Be sure to save time and energy to stroll the grounds. On the early summer Sunday when I toured, if anything, the area close to the palace was as full of tourists as the Hermitage had been. Of course, the groups of visitors were more spread out here. The main palace (the famous blue and white structure) was commissioned by Catherine I, whose taste ran to Baroque. Catherine the Great, who favored Neoclassical architecture, added a columned pavilion as a wing that balanced the gold-domed imperial church at the other end. Alongside the pavilion was a lovely flower garden, abloom with fragrant roses, for which the blue lupines and yellow and orange marigolds acted as foils. Both Catherines, as well as Elizabeth, had scattered follies and other comparatively small buildings around the grounds, including a performance space for small orchestras and chamber groups. It had three rooms and extraordinary acoustics. A statue of the Enlightenment tsarina, looking grand indeed, dominated the central room. Across the pretty little lake was the Turkish Bath, reportedly built by Catherine the Great to look like a mosque, in celebration of a victory over the Turks.We had been unable to secure tickets to the palace interior, and at any rate, the lines were long, suggesting that the rooms would be packed. However, there was a shop tucked into the ground floor of the palace displaying and selling amber mosaics, jewelry, even tea cups created by the artisans who had created the replicas of the original amber panels used to restore the Amber Room. (The originals were looted during the Nazi occupation, and their location is still unknown.)

SPECTACULAR. Visited this magnificent Palace while on a tour / cruise from Moscow to St Petersburg. We first visited the Hermitage which was magnificent full of incredible art works. The Catherine Palace was a summer residence .. During WW2 is was almost destroyed by the German Army but years of painstaking work have restored it to its former glory.You can only imagine the opulence of the Imperial Court.The gardens are also a must see. Beautifully laid outHighly recommended for every visitor to St Petersburg

What an elegant evening. Upon entering the gold plated gates of this fabulous site, we are greeted with caviar, and vodka. Once we approach the palace, we are serenaded by a military band, and then we are escorted into the palace where champagne is waiting while we sit to listen to a group of five playing classical pieces. Then we have docents enter dressed in period attire, posing as royalties, dancing for our enjoyment. This Palace sits on 1400 acres of gardens and parklands.

Our absolute favorite spot in St. Petersburg. We caught this on an beautiful summer day which helped make it our most memorable stop during our two day tour with Dancing Bear Tours. Make sure to allow extra time to walk around the garden as we wished we had. Easily one of the best Palaces/Gardens in Europe and comparable to Versailles. France
A Must See. This is one of the best tours in St. Petersburg. The palace and the grounds are unbelievable and so beautiful. Plan on a few hours to explore the area.

Another Palace!. We lined up in very cold weather for almost 1 hour. The Russians have a crazy system whereby groups of less than 8 are allowed to jump the line-up and go straight in. We were in a group of 16! Once inside the Palace is stunning but I question the need to spend almost 1 hour driving to Pushkin when there are other sites in St. Petersburg that we didn't see.
Absolutely Beautiful. This is definitely worth the trip. Take a tour with advance ticket admission to avoid the lines. The Amber Room is not to be missed.
not to miss it. the palace and soroundings gardens give us an opportunity to understand the live at that periodi woudnt miss it

Another must see, although only a very limited rooms are open to tourists. The best way to see the palace is by booking your own private tour guide who is knowledgeable of the history. Our tour guide (who only takes US and not Rubles) is very knowledgeable and takes good care of us so we never have to stand in line. On the day of our visit it was pouring so we all got wet and cold. Our tour guide told us it rains all the time in St. Petersburg so it is good to always carry an umbrella. It was unfortunate that we didn't so my husband got sick afterwards, but seeing the beautiful garden is almost worth it. We didn't get to see all of Catherine's jewelry or her private room, but we see quite a lot of. The dutch fireplaces are awesome.

One of our favorite tours. This was one of our favorite tours in St. Petersburg. The palace and grounds were beautiful. We spent about a half day there with lunch. We got there about 20 minutes before it opened...and really did not experience any lines throughout the day. Make sure you hear the tenors perform down by the lake. They were amazing.

Worth the drive . We went as part of a tour group and the palace was closed that day, but they opened it up just for tours. That made the trip extra wonderful because it wasn't crowded at all. The palace is breathtaking inside and out. Outside is more impressive than inside but we're talking only a small percentage better because the whole thing is beautiful. Inside everything is gold and vibrant. I felt like I was stepping into the movie, Anastasia (though she and her family were executed in the adjacent palace- just FYI for any Romanov fans). The amber room is one of the highlights and gardens are a must see. Even on a rainy day like we had they were stunning.

Nice park and palace, but long waiting lines. The park and palace are really nice and good value for money (compared to other sites in St-Petersburg quite cheap). We decided to visit the park in the afternoon. Unfortunately you'll have to wait about 40 mins at the ticket office and a further approximately 1,5 hours in line at the palace entrance if you're unlucky (which we were). This due to the capacity restrictions when visiting the palace. Therefore we decided in the end to only stroll around the park and skip the palace inside. So take this into account when you're planning to visit.

A beautiful place but the queue is horrible. We queued over 3 hours for the park entrance and palace entrance (yes they are separated). I would recommend to take a stroll around the park before queuing for the palace. There were much less people around 5pm when the tours have already left.In addition, we found that it is much more convenient to take the mini bus from the metro than taking the train (both means are listed on the website). The schedule of the train is not frequent, it is over an hour interval.

Absolutely must -see on your Russia Trip. Beautiful grounds with stunning architecture, lush gardens.....simply breathtaking. Plan for several hours or a full day to take in all of the things to do and see.

Stunning evening visit. We were fortunate enough to visit Catherine's Palace in the evening with a cruise tour. We basically had the palace to ourselves (and ~70 other people from the cruise) plus palace "guards", dancers, horsemen and various musicians followed by a dinner in a building next door with another musical group. Simply a stunning evening I will never forget.

Over crowded but must see place. Very long queue which made me wait for two hours to get an entry. huge groups all around I think this was because it the season.Huge palace and it is a much see place in Pushkin near to st.petersburg.buying an audio guide is advised so that you can cruise through the history.the Amber room was stunning.not much rooms to see like winter palace since most of the rooms are still under restoration

Outrageously Opulent!. A "don't miss" in St. Petersburg.This is the home of the original "Amber Room," even if the panels were stolen and missing in history by the Nazi's. Aside from the amazing interiors - which details the family that had multiple generations in the building - (get a great tour guide like those from ULKO tours) - the outside gardens and ponds are pretty inspired.

Jaw -dropping in Grandeur and style. Named After Catherine the great this beautiful baroque palace ,it was the royal family summer palace ,astonishing completed in 1756 on a scale to rival that of Versailles.Elizabeth Catherine mother used 220 lbs of gold to decorate the exterior .The interior are no less spectacular ,Grand Rocco Rastrelli design ,hall of light occupy the full width of the palace (130,000SF),the dinning room so much luxury,don't forget the Amber room it should be called "the eighth wonder of the World " all carved amber with gold leaf and mirror .
Beautiful but frustrating. The lines and waits are quite frustrating, There could be better crowd control. Once you finally get inside you will find extraordinary sights.

Morning visit. This is the most stunning palace. Although we were only there for a morning ( on a Cruise up the Baltic Sea. ) our guide was superb, she spoke excellent English and showed us all that we were allowed to see. Never seen so much gold.!!Despite the late spring there, the garden was also stunning. We were given lunch, which again was impressive, four courses and beautifully cooked.

Beautiful architecture. Go and enjoy it. Wheelchairs must have white/ grey wheels and shoes need protective covers. Amber room is lovely and there's a list to the correct floor but you need to find where it is add is not obvious.
Amazing reconstruction to restore glorious past. Amazing reconstruction to restore glorious past that was ruined in war. It is next to Paris or better

Half day tour in your language is enough!. After spending a whole day on our own at Peterhof, we decided to get a guided tour for Pushkin, however we had left it too late for a private guide and we had to settle for a bus tour, at least it was less than half the price of a private tour. We were told to arrive to pay for the tour with our booking voucher 20mins before time. At this stage it was going to be a minibus tour. By the time it came to 1400 they had sold more tickets and it had turned into a bus tour after all. Luckily my husband had gone to check, when the minibus had not arrived by 1400. Other people were also confused and a number of Russians were taken off the bus as it was to be a tour with an English speaking guide.We were given those headsets and a small box to pick up the voice of our guide. I had the feeling that she did not do this regularly as she spent the whole time anxiously trying to keep track of her flock! We arrived at one point where she had forgotten or not understood to get something for us to be allowed in, it was no wonder that we had trouble fathoming out what we had to do at Peterhof.Once in the grounds there were different routes for the groups to take but we all landed up queueing in a big hall until it was our groups turn to go round.We were allowed to take non flash pictures except in the amber room, although someone I spoke to later said that they had not been allowed to take any pictures!! The rooms were certainly magnificent, but of course once again you were not able to linger if you wished. The amber room was not particularly to my taste, OTT but its restoration after being destroyed in the war was amazing.There was not a lot of time left to visit the gardens, but we did a short tour and then started making our way back to the bus through a street market.I rate the attraction itself as excellent, but because of the crowds and queues the overall experience falls short of this.

Beautiful, but undergoing restoration. Catherine's Palace is a beautiful 18th century building. Unfortunately it was occupied by Germany during World War II. The Germans left the building in shambles when they retreated from Russia. Efforts have been underway to restore the building and the results are most impressive. That being said, very little of the palace (perhaps 6 rooms) is open for viewing. Nonetheless, throngs of people visit. Patience, consequently, is a virtue. The grounds are quite beautiful and peaceful.

Comfort tickets no longer available. On July 27, 2015, I wrote that the solution to the excessively long lines is a high-priced "comfort" ticket at Booth 3. Unfortunately, such tickets are no longer available.

Overcrowded by tour groups, but a highlight of our visit to St Pete. The problem with all the main sights in St Petersburg is the volume of tourists trying to get access to view the beautifully restored buildings. Queues are long and many rooms in the various palaces cannot be seen to full effect because they are so full of people.Huge sums have been spent restoring (beautifully) the rooms, complete with pure gold leaf applied to the ornate columns, friezes and decorations.We visited during a two day cruise ship stop and had booked a small group tour with a local company. But even with local knowledge, early access and a small group it was a struggle to see all we wanted.For a decent chance to properly appreciate everything here, it would be necessary to make an independent visit to St Petersburg outside the cruise ship period and allocate much more time to enjoy this amazing palace. A guide is needed – if travelling independently it would be worth checking if an audio guide is available - it would be a huge advantage to visit at a slower pace. The souvenir shops looked good, with an interesting selection of appropriately local souvenirs – similar shops were at most attractions and also at the cruise ship terminal and prices appeared to be much the same everywhere.

Beautifully rebuilt, see the Amber Room!. Loved this place. Long drive south of the city, but beautifully rebuilt after the Germans blew it up in WW2. Amber room rebuilt and recreated. Exquisite interiors. Reminiscent of Versailles in France, including the mirror room.

Splendid. The palace is as posh as the Russian palaces get. Recommend a guided tour, there are tours in Russian free of charge.The adjacent pavillion with statues of ancient Roman prominent figures provides beautiful sights, too.

Don't miss the park. The palace itself is interesting (the amber room is amazing), but don't miss a stroll around the pond at the nearby park. I don't think people who join a guided-tour from St. Petersburg get to do this as, obviously, they don't have much time with the guide. For that alone, I think it's worth the hassle to go there on your own (we used a public bus parked at the big square next to the Moskovskaya metro station).It's a really beautiful park (we like it better than the one at Peterhof), so don't miss it.

Another master piece. Most romantic and beautiful palaces out of plenty in st petersburg. The usp is the well maintained and groomed parks. The architecture and restoration of the various rooms of the palace to its originality is praiseworthy
ANOTHER BEAUTIFUL PALACE . Another beautiful palace and terrific parkEnjoyed our visit and delighted we arrived early as it soon became pretty busySo much to see and would love to revisit sometime
Blew me away!. The Catherine Palace was an enormous but beautiful place to visit, the craftmanship was awesome and the rebuild after the war was unbelievable. a must visit place.

Amazing splendour. Quite simply stunning. A real eye opener into the lives of the Tsars. I have never seen such opulence - quite staggering. Maybe best to try and go in a quitter time as it can get very busy
Catherine palace or Pushkin park. Most beautiful was the amber room but so is everything else there Gardens are amazing recommend with a tour guide from allaYou will enjoy it better

The Extravagance of the Tsars. I visited Catherine Palace and Park in early May 2016. The Palace has mostly been restored since the German Nazis devastated the Palace and Park in WWII. I think they are still working on restoring the inside of the Palace chapel. In 1711, a large-scale residence began to be built on this site for Catherine I, Peter the Great's wife and later sovereign. Catherine I bequeathed the palace and grounds to her daughter, Elizabeth Petrovna who became the Empress in 1741. She spent a fortune turning the place into a luxurious palace and grounds. The Empress Catherine the Great continued the work to make the palace a palace to behold. There are several aspects of the Palace that are memorable. The white marble Main Staircase is magnificence itself. The double windows provide natural light. The molded ornamentation on the walls, the ceiling paintings by Italians, pieces of marble sculpture on the landings, the vases and the beautiful wall clock make this staircase most impressive. The Great Ballroom is overwhelming with extensive amount of gold gilding in the ornamentation with mirrors on the walls between large glass doors with large glass windows above the doors on two sides of the Ballroom. The inlaid parquet wood floor with star-shaped diverging rays was restored based on the original architect's sketch and made from Russian wood, oak, maple and walnut. It is simply stunning. The hall is heated with furnaces behind the mirrors. The three paintings comprising the ceiling are the Triumph of Russia. It is clearly a place for grand balls. There are three anterooms containing lots of gold gilded carving and ornamentation. The Arabesque Hall (completed 1784) is one of the impressive rooms in the private apartments of Catherine the Great. It has a white, blue and gold color scheme. Next to the ballroom is a dining room with more gold decor, numerous mirrors, and paintings in the ceiling of Greek mythology. There is a long walkway through several rooms with doors covered with gold gilded carvings. The doors are aligned and give the impression of a very long hallway of gold. There are various drawing rooms, dining rooms and a portrait room containing portraits of Empress Elizabeth and Empress Catherine the Great.  One of the most interesting rooms is the Amber Room, considered by some a one of the great treasures of the world, but seems just gaudy to me. The room was produced in 1701-09 with inlaid amber panels sent in 1717 by the Prussian king, Frederick William I, to Peter the Great for the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg and eventually installed in Catherine's Palace. During WWII the room was dismantled by the Nazis and sent to Germany where it disappeared. This reconstruction is reputed to cost $12 million. There is a Green Dining room with green walls decorated with white plaster statues of Romans. It is elegant without all the gold gilt which quickly becomes tedious. Exiting the Palace into Catherine Park is truly calming and pleasant because the park is so green, nicely laid out, understated but elegant in its own way. There are lovely white marble statues throughout the park, shaded walkways, beautiful buildings (including the Cameron Gallery), impressive stairways, a pergola, and a large lake with buildings at various places around the lake. It was lovely to stroll around the park and the lake. Catherine's palace and park are located just a short distance from St. Petersburg but it is clearly a must-see to any visit to St. Petersburg.

over done. This Palace like most of St. Petersburg was leveled by the german army and fighting with the red army . It has been restored and what you see is man made in the 1990 's It you can pay extra about $ 100.00 US per person for VIP entrance ,safes on long lines It can be VERY hot in late June , July , August NO A/C

Gold, Gold, Gold. There was no shortage of gold leaf in this Palace. Each room was almost overly decorated with gold and the furniture was over the top. Once outside you are introduced to a beautiful garden area that is worthy of a stroll. It is worth a visit, just don't make it the main attraction of your tour for a day.

Beautiful gardens....!! . We visited the Catherine Palace in June. The gardens are wonderful, with beautiful ponds, flowers and romantic atmosphere (even a flute player). We have not visited the inside of the palace due to the masses of tourists and the very (!) long waiting queues. If you want to get inside, we recommend to be there very early, otherwise waiting times will be very long.

From the ashes. Burnt out by the Retreating German army during World War 2 this palace has been fully restored and is spectacular. I have never seen so much gold leaf used for decorative reasons - could be called 'bling palace'. The gardens contain a number of smaller buildings and we were fortunate to hear a small choir sing in the summer house which has perfect acoustics - spine tingling experience.

An Unknown Surprise. Yes, you may have heard of the summer and winter palaces, but there is so much to explore in St. Petersburg and this is one of them. Don't miss the sites, but learn the back stories too....
Worth a Visit. The history and the preservation of this Palace is remarkable. Even the town has a sweet history the way they celebrate Pushkin. It was his birthday the day we were there.

Be Prepared to Wait and Huge Crowds. We went to Catherine's Palace at 10:00 am on a Saturday morning and we did not have any trouble getting in because we had a private guide that we hired and she knew the system to get us moving. But that said once inside it was wall to wall people and just trying to get through the crowd was frustrating. It is one of the most beautiful palaces we have ever seen and our guide was able to give us a lot of detail and interesting stories on the palace and Catherine. I don't think I would enjoy it if I had to wait in a long line to get in and then be in a group instead of just the two of us. Yes, it was expensive but some things are worth paying for.

Romantic gardens with many vistas and interesting pavilions to ponder. I feel sorry for the hundreds wilting in the sun, waiting to get in to see the palace. We decided instead to take in only the park. This alone took the whole afternoon. There are many different buildings to look at. The Turkish Bath has it's own little audio tour which was fascinating! Otherwise, the park guide (free folder with admission) contains a small paragraph about each of the buildings. We also overheard a private tour guide in the garden. The kinds of stories he was telling literally brought history alive. If we were to do it again, we would sign up for one of those guides.

Queues and Transportation. Reached at 12PM today and queued for about three hours - 45 mins for the entrance tickets to the Park and then another longer queue in front of Catherine Palace (tickets to Catherine Palace are to be bought inside the Palace). The reasons for such horrendous long waiting hours are other than its popularity, there are many paid persons helping tour groups to queue, so the queue is actually longer than it looks, as each "queuer" will become a group of 30 or more visitors in front of you. My suggestion to individual visitors is probably do the park first, as the queue to Catherine Palace shortens by more than half at about 5PM (plus by that time, the tour groups would have left). Be sure to check the opening hours first. The Palace opens till 8PM on the day I visit (20June2016). My second suggestion is to take the mini buses directly from metro stations to the Park instead of suburban train (both means are listed in Catherine Palace official website), because the suburban train from Vitebsky railway station to Pushkin railway station runs at about 1-hour interval, less frequent than mini buses.

Don't Miss. Skip Peterhof.. There is no need to see both Peterhof and Catherine Palace unless you are a student of Russian art/history/architecture. Catherine Palace is clearly the better of the two. OK, Picture taking is OK. No hydrofoil ride but that's over-rated and that staff is hostile to tourists. It is an hour drive by car to CP. You'll need almost two hours inside after an hour or more in line. In travel season, the lines are huge. Seems like they stretch to Moscow. And if there are e-tickets, there will be a LONG/SLOW line to exchange them for real tickets.My suggestion is to hire a private tour company in St.P to take you to, into and through CP. Yes, this is much more expensive than doing it on your own though beyond the cost of admission will be the travel. With a private tour company, you will be picket up at your hotel, taken there, and probably will not wait in any line. They have their methods. And they know where to find food and the WC with the shortest line. We used Kremlin Tour (bad name as they operate in St.P and do much more than just the K). Yes, they are more expensive than do-it-yourself. But worth the difference many times over. Plus a good English-speaking guide with good knowledge of the place. If a private tour is not in your budget, I seriously suggest you consider saving for another year so it is in your budget. It will be worth it.

Absolutely Unforgettable beauty. Nothing can prepare you for the opulent extravaganza of the reception rooms and the ballroom where war and peace was filmed. Leave a whole day fir this palace so that you can really explore it, and if you are not with a private guide recognise that your u will have to queue to get in.

The palace of Catherine the Great and see its magnificent Amber Room. Formerly known as Tsarskoe Selo, Pushkin is home to one Russia’s grandest royal estates — the Catherine Palace, built in the 1700s as a residence for Catherine I and once called the Palace of Tsarskoe Selo. Originally modest, the palace was remodelled by Catherine’s daughter, Empress Elizabeth, in the mid-1700s, who turned it into the extravagant baroque residence of today.

Lovely. Our first viewing of the decadence of elite Russia. This stunning building is striking the minute you arrive with its blue and white facade. It is here you will find the Amber Room which is the only area you can not photograph. Once outside take a walk through the gardens to the summer house. Quite often in the summer months they have Russia's answer to Il Divo performing her which was very moving. Again because of large crowds be careful of pickpockets and don't take large bags or coats in with you.
Catherine Palace Day tour. Wow Such splendour A must do. I did my tour with Marina WilsonTours. Easy to book online. Too hard to get to on your own.Pay the extra, get a guide, and skip the queues

The Amber Room is AMAZING. We also toured this with an SPB tour guide and they helped us to sort of skip the lines as we were just 4 of us plus the guide. So, no waiting while all the other cruise ship herds were gathering in the lobby. We walked right through a back entrance, found a spot between large tour groups and just enjoyed it. We also walked through a bit of the grounds on the way back to meet the van.

Note the change of Architects style through different parts of the palace. We toured the Catherine Palace & Park. Plus a visit to the martial chamber. The museum covers a 300 year history. Of the 58 halls destroyed during the war years, 32 have been recreated. One of the banquets was described as having over 100 courses per person!!

Definitely worth the trip to Pushkin. First off - prepare yourself for long lines and waiting in line if you go during the summer. This is an extremely popular tourist attraction, but all of the inconveniences are worth it.The palace is just stunning and has been expertly restored after being destroyed during WWII. There is gold EVERYWHERE!Of course, the gem of the palace is the reconstructed Amber Room. That alone is worth the entire trip.

Amazing Opulence. Yes, this is quite the Palace. The grounds are beautiful, the rooms large and luxurious, the gold abounds and the amber room is truly over the top. It is a "must see" as are many of the majestic places in St Petersburg.

Huge palace. This palace was enormous and full of history. The amber room - which is a replica made from pictures as the original room disappeared in WWII. The palace was destroyed in large part by the German army but the Russian government has spent a lot of time and money to restore it. The palace is huge and it got a little tiring at the end - but the rooms are very interesting and very elaborate. Definitely worth a visit.
Nice. Nice palace, quite small but still pretty. Gardens are nice walk. The cloakroom can get full so if it's busy season might get issues I guess.

"Small" Summer Palace.. There is nothing small about this palace. The ballroom was massive and one of the most beautiful rooms I have seen including the Amber Room which is also here. The story and the renovation of this beautiful palace is historical and the photos of the devastation after WWII and what has been done to restore it is miraculous. The gardens here are very simple but also very beautiful. Another must see for any one near St. Petersburg.

We visited the Amber Workshop and saw how they restored the Amber Room. This was a beautiful palace, full of history. Our visit to the amber workshop, which is a separate ticket, however, was a highlight.

Magnificent. When you see this grandeur it is astounding to think about how the 1/4 of 1% in Russia lived. 300 servants to keep this place going, it is truly magnificent. Beautiful place to visit, VERY fascinating and quite beautiful.

The Magnificent Palace. This is the huge summer palace of the Tsarinas Catherine I, Elizabeth and Catherine II "the Great". It contains the awe inspiring Amber Room. There are large gardens, bathhouses and original furnishings.

Amazing!. When you see this palace you can understand why the Czars were overthrown. This place is phenomenal, although a little deceiving from outside - standing outside you can see all of the way through the palace - it is only one room deep in most of the palace. Nevertheless, the Palace is amazing and worth the trip.We did a private tour instead of the cruise excursion because it the cruise excursion on a one day visit would not let you see Catherine's Palace, Peterhof and the Hermitage - you had to choose 2 of the 3. We are glad we opted for a tour that would let us see all 3.

What took them so long?. The size and opulence of this palace are striking, and of course the restored amber room is its jewel. There will be crowds, but the place is well organized. When you see this, though, you wonder why it took until 1917 to have a revolution!

Beautiful palace be sure to see her gardens..... When you are visiting a place this exotic and far from home there are places onemust visit even if a bit redundant. check ahead for times and lines. A guide ishelpful to gain insight into stories and uses. Wear comfortable shoes, bring your own snacks. Will take about 3 hours. Be sure to sit and enjoythe gardens and views just as Catherine and her esteemed guests might have.Yes parts need restoration but still a great historical place.

What a beautiful Palace to visit.. One should never miss this Gorgeous Palace Of Catherine when you visit St.Petersburgh in Russia. This Palace has got Beauty,Character and exitement to feel proud of.

Amazing palace but renovation looking a little tired. All the big palaces are magnificent but this one is not one of the best. It is smaller than some of the others and the renovation was done many years ago. That is obvious. Can also be a big chaotic to get in.

So beautiful!. We prebooked a guided tour through Trip Advisor, and were very pleased that we planned our visit this way. We were picked up from our hotel and were the only people on the tour on that day. Our guide, Katya, was extremely knowledgable and informed us beyond our expectations. I would strongly recommend arranging a visit this way. The Palace is beautiful and is situated in a large park with lakes and lovely walks. The Catherine Palace is definitely worth a visit.
Very well renovated. Stunning palace very well renovated.....Germans destroyed most of it but it was put back to beautiful.

Very impressive palace and grounds. Upon arrival we were greeted by two small bands - one at the coach drop-off point and another at the entrance to the palace, which was a very pleasant way to start to the tour. Bottles of water were not permitted inside the palace (so hide them, although you can reclaim them when leaving) and large bags/ rucksacks should be left in the cloakroom. Footwear covering is provided to protect the flooring. The palace is amazing and the extensive grounds are very well maintained. We were also treated to a short performance by some talented opera singers in the impressive grotto (with good acoustics) overlooking the large lake.

The most impressive Palace we visited. Beautiful restored palace and gardens definitely worth a visit. We saw Catherines and Peters Palaces on the same tour. Focus on the Palace here and the gardens/fountains at Peterhof.

Luxury beyond believe. Dont miss this palace. It is pure madness that someone could have spent so much in gold and gems to decorate a summer residence when the servants were in such conditions. It is unbelievable.

Gold, Glitter, and Glamour. The palace, the 18th century world of Catherine the Great: Over-the-top opulence on a par with the top palaces of Europe. If you are visiting St. Petersburg, you won't want to miss this palace. Good to know: you can take (non-flash) photos inside the place, whereas you cannot at Peterhof. Many people remark on the Amber Room. It is unusual and has a remarkable history. However, I think many other rooms in the palace are more beautiful. Want more from the experience? Read up on Catherine the Great before your visit.

Stunning but crowded.. An amazing building. Despite extensive looting by the Bolsheviks and the Nazis it is still an impressive display. The one down side was the amount of tourist buses. There were cues and crowds, but it was managed effectively. The gardens are lovely as well. Amazing and somewhat sad history, but a shame about the thronging crowds.

Beautiful and Elegant. The palace and the grounds are a must if you are in St. Petersburg. We went with a tour group, so avoided the crowds. We were actually first in the palace and got to take some fabulous photos of the grand staircase with no one there. The grounds are also beautiful. We were there on a lovely spring day. For really great photos, take the ramp up to the building where you have a great overview of the entire garden. The palace has been rebuilt as it was destroyed in WWII. The Amber Room is the highlight, but there are many lovely rooms on view, although you will see only a small part of it.

Avoid the lines!. First of all, expect long lines if you are on your own. It may take up an hour or more to wait in line to buy tickets to the park and then to the palace. The visit to the palace can last for as long as 2 hours if crowded. I would highly recommend to book a tour with a local company, as we did. Did not regret it after we saw a huge line of people waiting under the rain (at temperatures close 40-s in early June) when leaving the Catherine's palace. A walk in the park is recommended, but not a must if you plan on going to Peterhof during your stay in St. Petersburg.

Beautiful but crowded. We visited when it was perfect weather. We had a private tour guide from Guide Guru for the 6 of us which we recommend because she was able to bypass a lot of the lines and crowds. The palace is very beautiful and the grounds were nice to walk around. I suggest buying your tickets early if you don't have a tour guide. She said the line of people waiting for day-of tickets can be hours long.

Beautiful . We've decided to book our tickets online to avoid the long queues at the entrance - what we didn't imagine is that redeem our online booking will be such a hassle! As usual in Russia nobody at the attractions speak English and they are not willing to help forigners visiting their country so embrace yourself with a lot of patience!!We got to the main entrance which is through the park to find out that we can only redeem our online vouchers from 12 to 4pm bare that in mind! The ticket booth for this it's passing the main entrance pretty much at the back of the palace! So apart from all that the park is nice and the palace is beautiful - the ámbar room it's absolutely stunning it worth the hassle!

Such a Beautiful Place to Visit. Designed by Rastrelli, the opulent baroque Palace features a gold dome crown. In it everything is so beautiful and visitors also get to see the Throne Room. Outside the palace, there is a spectacular garden and parkland.We were on a tour of the palace inside out which also included a dance and horse carriage performance on the palace ground. Dinner was also included to dine in the palace quarters and this came with singing by a trio. We really enjoyed ourselves and though it was expensive, it was worth it. Do visit Catherine Palace when you go to St Petersburg.

The palace and grounds make this a must see. Again we are on a two day cruise stay over in St. Petersburg and the Palace was opened for us on this special day. The lack of crowds made it and easy stroll with an eye on all that glitters. The Palace and grounds are worth seeing and being informed about.
Beautiful Majesty and Architecture and Size. Catherine's Palace is a one of a kind enormous regal dwelling place. Huge, majestic, something special to see and experience.
Magnificent. One if the few places you are allowed to take photos indoors in Russia. The inside is as magnificent as the outside. You will need 3 hours to do this place justice.

Do your homework -- or take a tour -- and you'll be well rewarded. Some places are impressive just to look at, but for some you really need to have background information. The Catherine Palace is an amazing gingerbread building with magnificent gardens, exteriors and interiors and you could just walk through it an enjoy it, but you will gain so much more from doing some advance homework or taking a tour. Not only will it help accessing the site (queues can be long and they do try to move you through with military precision) but you really need the information....to understand the history, the destruction, the rebuilding...to appreciate what you are seeing. The State rooms and the porcelain are so impressive, the ceiling frescoes, the Great Hall, well, you need context and background to appreciate it. And there is no way to fully appreciate the rebuilt Amber Room without a knowledge of the history (and ongoing mystery) of the original room. It is a jewel and most definitely worth putting time into learning about it so you can appreciate it. At the very least Google it while you're on your way there!

Worth seeing. Catherine's Palace is definitely worth seeing if you go to St Petersburg, but, go as am organised trip. It is very busy and the queue to get tickets and enter if you go independently is huge. There also aren't many signs or descriptions in English so you will gain a lot from a tour guide. This is the only site I did as a trip and I'm relieved I did that. Much like Peterhof, you have to pay for each building in the gardens which can add up. Not all of the palace is open to the public as it is still being restored after the German's virtually destroyed it during WWII. The Amber Room has been restored and recreated and it is amazing. The Agate Room is still closed. You need several hours to fully explore the palace, grounds and Pushkin, and the crowds slow you down considerably. This is definitely worth the hours trip outside of the city.
Summer Palace. Once again the wealth in the Palace is breathtaking, has to be seen to be believed. Apart from the fabulous interior the gardens are out of this world.

You must see it to believe how extravagant and magnificent this palace is!. No words can describe this palace, you've got to see it to believe it!!! With a ballroom as big as 1,000 sqm, a garden with cherry blossoms flown in from Japan, more than 20 reception rooms, and a room made with Amber stone mosaics, there's nothing like it in the world!
A must. Even when you think you have seen enough palaces and gold leaf, you must see this place. The Amber room alone is worth the visit. Surpasses all other palaces we have seen on St. Petersburg.

Lots of queuing, short time at the attraction . If this is the only palace you intend to see, then go early or at lunch time, because the time spent queuing is greater than while enjoying the museum. It is a beautiful building, but all interiors have been rebuilt. Better idea just to see Pushkin and visit the interior of the summer palace at Peterhof.
palace. It was mind boggling to see such a place and just try to understand how such a beautiful place could be built without the modern equipment we have now. Well worth the long lines to see this.

Catherine Palace. Beautiful palace. Spent a day wandering through the extensive gardens and ponds. Make sure you get clear directions if using public transport, it's efficient, but the bus stop to return to Saint Petersburg, is a little further ahead.

A magnificent palace . I haven't seen a palace decked with more grandeur. The summer palace is bedecked with bright gold and rich red tones. It's also quite close to St. Petersburg and hence a good way to see the Russian countryside. Would recommend this!

Catherine the Great... We enjoyed the gardens, even though they were not as impressive as Peterhof. The Palace was astonishing, just as good as The Hermitage in parts. The historical pictures of damage caused during WWII were very sobering, to think that something so beautiful could be intentionally damaged.

amazing astounding wonderful. What a breathtaking palace. Each room is magnificent. Every angle of every room is beautiful. Each room is displayed to allow you to enjoy the detail of that room. No photos in the amber room but perhaps we wouldn't leave if we were able to take our time and photograph every corner and wall and... This is a well organised tour with people on each door directing the traffic(us) so we had a room to our group alone. The next group waiting for their turn and being made to wait. With this organisation we had time and space to soak up the atmosphere of the rooms. We did have a brilliant guide who loves the building.

Not yet completely restored. This place was destroyed by the Nazis and the restoration continues today. Since we only saw less than 1/2 of the palace, we didn't spend as much time as I had planned. The highlight of the tour is the amber room, which was looted by the Nazis and its contents have not been recovered.We purchased our tickets online. Whether it was necessary or not, I'm not sure. But it did allow us to get in a little earlier than public opening. Even then, we didn't beat the tour buses, and were completely mobbed by tour groups. Like most palaces, there is a nice outdoor garden to walk through.

Tranquil heaven. The palace is beautiful with glorious artworks but the real winner is the garden.There was the multicolour beauty of spring bloom and the shades and shapes of green in the garden which is the ultimate tranquil experience.

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. This palace is partially restored to reflect its original structure. The art and the furnishings in the palace are original and authentic. There is a lot history associated with the palace and it's best to visit with a knowledgeable guide or read about the palace before visiting. Well worth a visit.

A great palace with fine collection of art. I prefer this palace compared to Peterhof Palace. The place is sophisticated, gave me a calming feeling, especially the gardens. It is easily navigated by walking, though we were there during late spring so not a lot of flowers blooming. But still, I love this place, inside and out, except the footpaths were a bit rough, especially in the gardens. Over- all still a lovely place to visit without the crowds who flocked more to the Peterhof fountains.

It's complicated.... We arrived in the suburb of Pushkin by taxi which took around 35 minutes.( I strongly recommend "gettaxi" and order ahead of time)You pay seperately to enter the grounds and then again to enter the palace.The ticket office opens to the public at noon and we stood on line for an hour and a half in the hot sun waiting.Once it opened people pushed and shoved and the overall experience was a bit marred by that.The palace itself is truly beautiful as are the gardens and grounds as well. Enjoy!

Beautiful- amazing how authentic. This was beyond our expectations. The interiors were beautiful, and floors, stones, fabrics- it is amazing to see how fully restored each of these rooms in this beautiful, historical palace have been so carefully recreated.
Worth a visit. If you love palaces and history this is truly wonderful and worth a visit to. We enjoy the stunning grandeur and the history and I would recommend you book a guide beforehand

Beautiful - wear comfortable shoes. I had planned my itinerary to visit Catherine's Palace because guide books recommended it but I wasn't excited about it. When I got there and went inside, I changed my mind. While it is opulent and extravagant for the time it was built, it is nevertheless incredible. It is worth the time to see the details in the building and to understand what life was like at that time. You do have to put these cloth shoe covers over your shoes to walk in the palace. The surrounding gardens are also quite impressive and beautiful to stroll around on a sunny day. Again, there is a lot of walking and there are stairs so if you are traveling with older visitors, keep that in mind. There are not many places to sit down inside but there are plenty in the gardens.
Must see!. Take time to see this. Incredible restoration from the damage done during WWII, takes a lot of time to see it but worth the time.

Magnificent Palace. Visited the summer residence of the Romanovs as part of a private tour (SPB tours), so we were able to skip the long lines and go right inside. The palace was simply stunning and reflects the extravagance of the royal family at that time. Having a knowledgeable guide helped us appreciate the place, and understand the history of the entire family better. Although the Amber room is usually the highlight, the entire palace in itself is breathtaking. A visit here is definitely worth remembering.

smaller than Peterhof but just as beautiful. Spent about four hours inside an out. Inside you basically follow everyone else. The rooms that have been restored, especially the amber room, are truly gorgeous. The only problem is the large tourist groups. I had a personal guide so we were able to slip by them occasionally.The outside is very nice without the fountains of Peterhof. We had a nice day and just strolling around, smelling the Lilacs was great. Overall a great trip.

Worth for Amber room alone. This is a half day trip but worth the time if you have it. The palace has been beautifully restored after being damaged in WWII. The before and after pictures are amazing. The amber room is truly unbelievable.

SHEER OPULENCE. Catherine Palace is one of Russia’s former imperial palaces and summer residence to its tsar’s built on the orders of Catherine I and is now a museum. The sheer beauty of the palace is evident from arrival at the spectacular entry gate.The baroque style palace has a neoclassical interior that exemplifies wealth and extravagance, breathtaking in its beauty and opulence. It is impossible to contemplate the wealth and resources necessary for its construction and the entire building and contents is an overwhelming experience. Treasures abound, spellbinding, and then you arrive in the Amber Room - this room is a highlight of the tour, you will be amazed by the astounding panels. The Gardens are lovely, comprised of 2 parts including the old garden and English Park. The guided tour is somewhat hurried, I could have easily spent a day looking at the building, its treasures and the gardens.

Another great palace to visit. Although I did not get to spend much time in the gardens, I did get to go into the palace. It has treasures and even a gown worn by one of the empresses of Russia. It also has an amber room.

A nice outing in Puskin. A nice park, but it does not rival Peterhof's in terms of glamour. However, at RUB 120 much cheaper to visit the park only when compared to RUB 700 for Peterhof. A good stroll.

Must see the Amber Room. From the entrance to the interiors this palace has been beautifully restored after being almost destroyed during WWII. The Amber room is really something else and sets this palace apart from The Schaumburg in Vienna and versatile in Paris. The Blue, White and Fold colouring is stunning and the gardens although not anywhere near as good as Peterhof are nicely manicured and laid out.

Amazing restoration. An amazing recreation of a palace that was destroyed by the Nazi.Fantastic rooms and such dedication by the Russian cultural people in dedicating their work to the people who originally built this palace. Amazing.

Amazing. From the entry gates to the facade, the grounds are spectacular, then you get inside, and WOW, it goes on and on, and bogles the imagination to grasp the extent, and glory of the Tzars.Do not miss this!

Fantastic restored interior and peaceful gardens. While the Amber Room may be the main draw for the Catherine Palace, there are so many other splendid sights to see too, including the expansive gardens.It is difficult to apprehend that this was reduced to a shell during the Second World War, as it has been so successfully restored.The Amber Room is stunning, but we found it smaller than expected, but the Grand Hall was absolutely huge, with windows on both sides allowing the gilded stucco work to shine brightly.We benefitted from arriving early (as the gates opened), so there were no crowds ahead of us as we moved from room to room.The gardens are very peaceful, with great landscaping, but the thing that caught our attention was the Cameron Gallery, designed by a Scots architect and reminiscent of some designs in Edinburgh's New Town!Overall, a great visit and a great memory.

Catherine Palace and Park. The palace was once Princess Catherine and there are so many beautiful sculptures and paintings in the palace. There is one section which photo and video taking were not allowed. The two rooms are all in gold. It was a very interesting experience.
Must visit!. I liked it even more than The Hermitage, this is my personal opinion. Great Palace, so gorgeous and beautiful. I was there at the end of the winter and was not so crowdy.

Beautiful all year around!. Arrived here around 10:30 am. Beautiful park! Immaculate gardens. Some places, though, require gardeners' attention. Tip for visitors: if you can, take the local train from Vitebsky Railway Station all the way to Pushkin (Tsarskoe Selo). It is much faster than either taking a bus or driving there from downtown.Good restaurants on the grounds.

Magnificent . One of the most breathtaking sights I have ever seen. This magnificent edifice stretches for what seems like miles with gilded statues all along the front. We had already got our tickets but it still took an hour of queuing to gain access. It was worth the wait the interiors are incredible, and the highlight, the amber room is a wonderful sight. A day well spent, with lasting memories.

WOW. Very hard to believe that the Nazis destroyed this site when they evacuated St Petersburg, BUT typical of Nazi behavior.You can see a new Amber room prepare to spend 2-3 hours hereIt is about 30 minutes outside the city proper
A must see . Gorgeous park, lakes, gardens and palace.Dont miss the neoclassic gallery.I took one hour to go inside the palace but it is worth for sure, amassing spaces and imperial scale
Amazing place. Amazing place. A lot of history. Breath taking. Beautifull. Very clean park. Be ready to take a lot of pictures. Love Pushkin.

Tsarine's "summer cabin". Beautifully restored from ruins glorious palace of the russian emperors. It is a bit tricky to get to without an organized excursion, but definitely worth a trip. The amber room is meticulously recrafted now and can be seen (but not photographed). The golden enfilade is breathtaking. Since the palace does not open until noon, if you arrive early, check out the beautiful grounds. There are a few other buildings that deserve a peek - the baths (open only during summer time) and the Hermitage with the table-elevating service. The park is amazing, not to be missed

beautifully restored palace. Occupied by the Nazis in WWII, they left this place a complete wreck. Lucky for us, the Russians have restored much of it. The rooms are gorgeous. For me the jasper room - walls covered in panels of red to gold to brown hued jasper, some carved - is stunning. If you can go in NOT on a tour, but as individuals (we went with an individual guide we had for the day) you will have a nicer experience, as the big groups - like golfers on a crowded day, I suppose - have to keep the groups moving along at a pretty rapid clip to keep from holding each other up. We'd get the rooms to ourselves for a few minutes between groups. Allow some time to walk the grounds if it is not raining. Supposed to take 30 minutes by car from central St. Petersburg - I don't know how else you would get there, but our trip back to town took nearly 2 hours due to construction delays.
Amazing place. We visited this place during our Baltic cruise. It is amazing considering the whole St Petersburg is only 300 years old. This place can match any European palace.

Beautiful. This is a must stop on any visit to St Petersburg. The one thing my wife really wanted to see was the Amber Room and it was outstanding. It's a shame that it is only a reproduction since the original was taken during WWII by the Nazi's. Very well maintained most likely for the tourist money. The Great Hall is filled with gilded carvings, mirrors and a dozen chandeliers.

Marvelous History. The history and intrigue attached to Catherine's Palace was what first interested me. I knew the story of "The Amber Room" and I just had to see it. I was not disappointed. The Amber Room was absolutely stunning. The restorers are doing a wonderful job with the palace restoration.

Gorgeous!. The famed Amber Room is housed in Catherine's palace. Thought not the original (original amber walls were stolen by the Nazis), these mosaic-like walls of amber are certainly a sight to see (sadly no photos allowed). The rest of the palace is just as beautiful and mirrors the Hermitage's style. In a little chapel next to the pond, we listened to singers performing a traditional Russian song - amazing! Their voices sounded like an organ.

Visit Early Part Of Tour. I highly recommend visiting this place early on in your tour itinerary as there are sites better than this. If rated by itself, I would've given it 5 stars but when compared with other sites like Peterhof and Church of the Spilled Blood, I have to down grade this site. If you visit this site early on, you will go from very good to excellent but if you put this in the latter part of your tour, it might feel a bit anti-climactic...
Outstaning. Another must day trip when in Saint Petersburg. Get the feel of imperial Russia. Will take you a full day to visit but worth it!

A very Grand Palace and gardens. This is one of the must sees in St Petersburg. The palace is very grand with amazing decorations.The gardens have amazing fountains and great areas for walking and exploring.Well worth the visit!!
Lovely day. We spent a lovely day here, the gardens are beautiful and peaceful. The palace itself does. It open all the rooms but the ones that are open are spectacular.

Beautiful Palace. Catherine Palace and Park is stunning with old world glamour and elegance. The amber room, with walls and furnishing made entirely out of amber, is stunning and worth a look. The palace is full of beautiful works of art and the grounds are beautiful. The palace is quite large so be prepared to walk.
Gold, gold and more gold!. The opulence of this palace is breathtaking. Fabulous history lesson and make sure you don't miss the Amber room

Ms.. Magnificent palace. Excellent example of Imperial life. Filled with paintings, furniture, and decorative items. Also, location of famous Amber Room. Beautiful gardens. Interesting background information on restoration of palace after WWII.

Finally, The Amber Room. My wife, Lori and I have wanted to see the Amber Room at Catherine's Summer Palace for many years. It came up in conversation with a travelling cousin (Ron) many years earlier and its history intrigued us. We were not disappointed though we knew it was a replica, as the Nazis had done their nasty business there in WW 2. The grandeur of the place and the immaculate condition of the gardens and walkways made it a fantastic outing though it was a little gray (perhaps even more fitting!). A great daytrip from St Petersburg and worth the hour drive. You actually get the cross the frontlines which is historic in itself.
Glitz and glitter. Opulence, glitz and glitter of an over abundance of fancy rich stuff. Lovely to walk through, great eye candy. A real feel of show off of what money could buy while people starved.

Just another baroque style palace. . This is a pretty Palace with a beautiful huge garden but the baroque style is both on new. If you are pressed for time, go to peterhof instead of Pushkin/zsar village. This like many palaces in Russia was restored after near complete destruction in the war

Stunning!. This Palace is impressive from the very start until the end. Make sure you see the black and white photos at the end showing what the Palace looked like after the war. It was lovingly restored to its former glory.The ballroom is especially impressive as is all the gold everywhere. I love the tiled heaters in the rooms.The Amber Room is stunning - the mind boggles at the work that went into it.

Getting there. I visited in early May 2016, catching a train from Vitebsky railway station in central St Petersburg - not the main station but the local station down the right hand side of the main station. The station needed for Catherine Palace is Tsarkoe Selo and any train going to Pavlovsk stops there. The route map shows eight stations from Vitebsky but the train doesn't seem to stop at all of them. The prior station is the distinctively named Kilometre 21. The Palace is walkable from the station - about a mile - but I was able to catch bus no.370 from outside the station. Unfortunately I couldn't work out the right bus to take back on leaving the Palace so ended up walking. The Palace is a 'must' visit. Individual tickets for the grounds are available at the entrance kiosks. For individuals - as opposed to groups - tickets for the Palace are purchased inside the Palace but individuals are not let in to purchase these until noon. The queue starts forming shortly after 10am.

Try to get there early. There was a small brass band at the entrance gate playing Russian classics to amuse the crowds of Japanese tourists waiting to enter the palace ; this is a nice touch and puts everyone in a great mood. We were lucky enough to be able to slip in first before the group which meant that we had the grand Throne room to ourselves for a few minutes ...Wow...never seen opulence like it before ! It's a shame that most of the furniture was lost during the various revolutions and wars as the place seems somewhat bereft , but the amber room is quite something and the gardens are lovely.

Stunning interiors. Wow the opulence and beauty here are incredible . The amber room defies description you have to stand in it and just soak it up!! Gardens are beautiful and very English in style. Absolutely beautiful.

A relaxing day out. Got a taxi here as it was my birthday for a 1000 rubles and walked around the park grounds which were so peaceful full of amazing little spaces, the house tour was quite short and think that some of it was closed but what we did see was a testament to just why there was a revolution here! interesting how after the nazis left in 1944 and tried to burn it to the ground the Russians pulled together to rebuild it, they truly are an amazing race of people. Lots of photos giving the history of the restoration and how it looked when the nazis retreated.

Exeptional richness. This Palace is even more incredible than what you can figure out watching a documentary. You can see the incredible rich interiors that blow your mind away. More incredible is the state in which it was after the war and the community effort that was taken to restore it to its grand state. We were on a guided tour that lasted a few hors but we felt that we did not dedicate enough time to this place; I would spend even a whole day between the palace and the gardens.
Beautiful property. Interesting and well preserved property that is a must see. The gardens are fantastic, although our visit was a few weeks away from everything becoming green!

Amber. We have been alone in the huge Spiegelsaal. Amber room looks very ' plastic' at first site but worth staying and listening to audioguide twice. Groups passed by staying 2 to 3 minutes. We stayed 20 min. and checked every detail. Worth buying a book how they prepared the new room.

Stunning Opulence. We visited as part of an organised tour. The place has been totally restored since the Second World war and it is dazzling, with extensive use of gold leaf and beautiful floors (you have to wear protective slippers). There are many portraits and the ceilings are also highly decorated. The dining tables have been set as if for a banquet and some of the rooms had large decorated stoves as it must have been very cold in winter. The amber room was impressive - I wonder where the original panels are?

Escorted tour tour to Pushkin. An amazing visit to Catherine Palace. The main hall takes your breath away. The ante-rooms and dining rooms are all decorated in different styles which are also very impressive. Our tour guide brought the whole place to life, explaining the 60+ year restoration project which has still not completely finished. Well worth the trip out of the city.

Limited access during peak periods, but still worthwhile. During the peak season, the place tours are segmented do you have to get multiple tickets to see the whole palace. We saw the Golden Gallery which has been beautifully restored. The craftsmanship is excellent. There are pictures to show the extensive damage done by the Nazi occupation and it's outstanding to see the restoration work done.

Golden Residence. Picturesque place, where you can walk around ponds and gardens, the Palace is chic, but too much gold makes it annoying. It is very beautiful in autumn, when trees are of different colours. It's a pleasure to walk around, remembering Pushkin's verses.

Spectacular palace and grounds . The grounds at Catherines palace are almost as beautiful as the palace itself. modelled on other designs around the world complete with a folly and a tuskiah bathhouse the gardens are intricate and a peaceful place to relax. The interior doesn't disappoint with the amazing ballroom and several other themed rooms.

Beautiful!. The palace is beautiful and opulent.... Lavish ... Amber room is something to watch for, different, beautiful... The parks around the palace make for a lovely walk... A must visit when visiting ST Petersburg!!

Wonderful place. Allocate a full day for sightseeing the palace inside and outdoors. The interior is splendid, the amber room is worth visiting no doubt. We've been there in winter. If you can go in summer, you will have a chance to enjoy a park and fountains.
I'd rate it 6 stars were it possible.
what a place. the palace is just one the most amazing collections of russia and kept so beautifully never seen or heard of such a location.

Outstandingly Beauty . We booked a private tour through BA and whilst extravagant at the time we couldn't have made a better choice. Valentina (Tina) was the most knowledgable and interesting guide we have ever had. We were picked up at our Hotel and driven to this exquisite Palace and had a city tour guide on the way. The actual Palace was outstanding and so opulent you could understand the origins of some of the conflict in Russian history. Whilst not quite all restored the accommodation open to the public is awesome and the history behind it and use of the rooms by the likes of Catherine the Great and her husband Peter the Great so interesting. Tina was able to guide us through the history of nearly every piece of furniture which we found fascinating. After the Palace tour we took a leisurely walk around the gardens and in their bleak form given the time of year, still beautiful. The main lake and it's buildings on a clam bright Spring day were spellbinding. A real must if you are St Petersburg.

Grand Estate with Beautiful Gardens. Puskin is a short drive from St. Petersburg and worth the trip to see Catherine's Palace. Just to see the Amber Room is worth the trip. The sheer wealth of this place astounds...one room after another...after another. They are a tribute to the townspeople who helped restore the palace after the war. Save time for the grounds and gardens, we walked and walked...a nice getaway to the countryside.

Magnificent Place to behold. Such a beautiful palace. The gold room and the amber room are something to behold. Definitely worth a visit. I would recommend visiting in the summer if you want to see the beautiful flowers in the park. I went in April and there was still snow on the ground.

Well worth the trip. The Catherine Palace contains the Amber Room, which was all stolen by the Nazis during the War and has been completely replaced. Quite breathtakingly beautiful. The whole Palace is gorgeous and the grounds are large and in Summer must be lovely.

Amazing. Toured out of St Petersburg to view this palace. We were guided around this wonderful palace being provided with lots of historical information. A spectacular sight to see. Well worth the hours drive to get there.

A riveting rebuild of one of the largest palaces of the late l8th Century. This is a fascinating rebuild, exquisitely realised. It is enormous in every sense. Of particular interest is to be able to differentiate between the taste of Catherine the Great and that of Elisabeth which is so very opulent. And, because most of the contentswere saved, to be able to see them replaced in situ and witness the rooms as they must have been.

A master piece of Russia. In an incredible area, you will enjoy, the park, the forest and the gorgeous palace.Take your day, feel a part of it, walk and enjoy the squirels, the birds and the shades of green.

Magnificent !. We took an English speaking guide with us and wow was this worth it. The building is magnificent and the history absolutely fascinating. The Amber room was spectacular. An absolute must if you visit St Petersburg

Stunning palace but the ticketing system could be improved. The palace and gardens lived up to all expectations but the customer experience could be improved. The queuing system was quite disorganised (a shock for British people) and people kept cutting in. The ticket staff do not speak English (which is fair enough, just be prepared). When we finally got to the palace there was an electronic sign saying entry was now closed even though it was not late in the day. We were pretty annoyed so went in anyway and it turned out the sign had been switched on by mistake and the palace was still very much accepting visitors. Overall, quite a stressful visit, but I am still glad I saw the palace.

beautiful palace and grounds - don't miss it. What is astonishing about this palace (and Peterhof but I forgot to say so in the review, sorry!) is that it was rebuilt almost entirely from scratch after its near-total destruction during WW2. Some of my party found this disappointing but there are two sides to everything and it is a feat of some note to have been able to complete such work and has certainly paid off in terms of attracting visitors.The colours of the outside are just stunning and the gardens beautiful. Many of the interior rooms are just exquisite, particularly the famous amber room.Most people combine this, in summer time at least, with Peterhof and its fabulous fountains. We did so, as part of a group tour, and it was a day which was a true highlight for most of us.
Amazing Palace. Amber room incredible to view, only regret is building is a copy of the original but none the less very impressive

old splendour. rainy day so was glad to get into the palace - but has been restored wonderfully after WW2, lots of tourists so you have to keep in line but an amazing sight to see and the grounds are vast and beautiful

Gold all over the place!. If in St. Petersburg the Catherine Palace must be visited. The huge halls and beautifully decorated many rooms are all shining full of gold and the ceilings are often painted by famous artists. The famous Amber Room has now been reproduced and may be visited, though you are not allowed to photograph it. Everything else, however, may be photographed, as long as you are not using flashlights. Go there off-season (in winter or spring). This is the best way to avoid huge queues.

Great place to visit.. The park and Palace was incredible. I would recommend it to all travellers. We have spent in current place full day. If you travel solo, it would be highly recommended to arrive early and purchase tickets for Palace. We have arrived at about 10AM, but purchased tickets only at 11.30 AM, but when we purchased ticked for Palace, there were available tour only at 16.00PM!!! One guide said us to go at tickets office that is located at the entrance in Park (the place that is located almost at the end of Garden street(Садовая ул.)).

Simply Grand!. Built to rival Versailles, located about25 kms from St. Petersburg this palace will transport you into the opulent world of the Tzars. We visited on a freezing winter day in December, checked in our bags and jackets and enjoyed a full the tour of the palace with an english speaking guide who also spoke german and italian. Do not miss the grand hall, the amber room, the theatre, music room and the green dining rooms, they will blow you away. Winter timings are 10 am to 5 pm and from May to Sept 12 pm to 6pm and July August open till 7 pm.The park entrance is free in winter and it's a lovely sight as the lake freezes over. I believe there is an admission fee for the park in summer, Overall a great half day trip in inter - in summer if you want to extend your time and enjoy the park grounds it's well worth it.
Amazing. We were astonished with that place, really the interior is worthy to see it, Jantar room is nice to see it is something special. Also as well during May the park is giant.

Nice trip out of town, gorgeous surroundings. Wonderful day out, Feel like the Tsarina, great park, lots of little hide aways - The Chinese pagoda and the Chesme memorial. Buildings are so beautiful, you will not believe they are real. Some real Imperial beauty to breathe in and take in your memories

Recommend 100%. This Palace gives you the opportunity to see what life was like for the Tsars of Russia until 1917. You can do the Palace by yourself, but I recommend taking a tour (we took a private tour) no lines to wait in.

Golden opulence. As a lover of all things baroque, I seek out buildings from that era... And this is perhaps the most baroque palace I have ever seen. What a stunner! There is gold everywhere, and they have done a beautiful job of restoring the rooms. Definitely get the audio guide if you are not using a personal guide-- the audio is very well done. People have mentioned getting there. It should cost around 1000 roubles by cab, but the metro and bus is easy, and another adventure! Go to Moscovskaya station, exit and follow the signs for the 545 or the 342 Minibus. It's NOT the stop right at the exit. There will be monstrous Soviet building with a park with a statue of Lenin in front of it. The buses are between the building and the statue.

Highly recommended. I visited this place with my sister, and we both really enjoyed it. To get there, we took the metro to moskovskaya, then walked across the square outside to get to the minibus (they left in front of a large building - we took the 342). It was relatively simple. We booked online for this, but we didn't get tickets - we got vouchers to exchange for tickets which we did at the information booth. This was pointless, we should have just bought tickets there as there were no queues when we arrived at 1100.
