But what makes up for everything is the sheer opulence of the place. the very first room is all gold plated. Massive rooms, gilded rooms, amber room, everything was big, and gave a sense of the lives lived by the czars. Doesn't take very long though. Then there is a huge huge garden where you can walk by the lake as well.

Opulucence. Visited this Palace during July, as can be expected there were many tourists, so it was not easy to really see what one wanted to see. I loved the beautiful floors, the artwork, the Delft fireplaces, etc.If I ever have the opportunity to visit this place again, it will not be during the busy summer months!

Unbelievable Magnificence. The beauty of this palace both inside and outside will take your breath away. It is hard to imagine that this much gold even exists. Words cannot do justice to what you will see when walking thru these magnificent rooms. The Amber Room was particularly beautiful and has been restored to its formal glory. During WWII the Nazis dismantled the room and stole all the amber and it has never been recovered. Catherine's Summer Palace is not to be missed when visiting St. Petersburg.

The Magnificent Amber Room. A great Palace with landscaped gardens. The Palace was originally created by Rastrelli but later redesigned by Scottish architect Charles Cameron.The Amber room created in Prussia and gifted to Peter the Great in 1716, looted by Nazi troops during World War II, It took 24 years to recreate the room and to do that they used historical photographs.Wonderful marble staircase designed by Ippolito Monighetti, built in 1860.If you can travel there on your own, with a tour guide you just get to see a portion of the estate.

too crowded. beautiful gardens, beautiful palace but wow everything is so so crowded. the Russian guards also are very mean looking...whats up with that? They built the place for tourist right? so why the attitude?

SPB Tour of Catherine Palace just amazing. Just an amazing place and a wonderful experience highlighting the opulence of a history past. The artwork and outrageously wonderful architecture are a must see experience for anyone travelling to the region

Stunning. Truly the highlight of our visit to St Petersburg. A Palace which has been restored since WWII and which is one breathtaking room after the next. Situated a few miles from St Petersburg in the town of Pushkin it is best to get there as early as possible to avoid the plague of tour groups.Must see the Amber Room..........
PURE OPULENCE. The entire palace, from the gold room to the amber room, is stunning and worth the visit alone. Also, we loved visiting the amber workshop which our guide had arranged.

Walk through opulence to render you speechless. St. Petersburg's palaces are simply amazing and should be part of any visit to this port city. Catherine's Palace is one that merits a visit. Rooms are identified by the colors they were decorated in and gold leaf accents are wall to wall. No wonder the revolution took place with all this richness in contrast to the miserable living condition of the people! We also had the opportunity to buy watercolors from local artists at the entrance, a rare occasion as tour operators tend to promote tourist stores and omit mentioning it as they probably get a kickback from purchases from tourist traps. Mind you, some of these traps offered free vodka and other spirits.
HUGE. You could spend an entire day visiting this Palace and Park but it is well worth the day. Beautiful pieces of art and rooms like you will not see anywhere else in the world.
glourius. The detail and impressive size of the palace was incredible, with so much history, a visual feast to the eyes and the grand scale is impressive

Amazing! should not be missed. It is a fantastic place, should not be missed ,The park was amazing.I have some advice to make your trip perfect , first, it is better to go early because the number of tickets is limited per day. Second, when you buy a ticket you will get an appointment to when you should enter the palace (Cathrine Palace) with the all group whom got the same appointment, for example we bought the ticket at one o'clock and our appointment was at four o'clock. Of course you can spend the waiting time within the park .Third, if you reserve a private tour through the hotel itself which should be four days before you can enter the palace immediately.My only critisizim, is that there is no English language guidance or knowledge on site for people whom are planning the trip on thier own i.e. no tour guid...
Favorite place!. Absolutely gorgeous. There is so much gold everywhere and the park was a delightful place to spend some time. This should be a must see on your tour.

A part of heaven. Actually as it said St. Peter's burg. Is like a open museum in every corner you see beautyful human artifacts,so after a while your eyes habituated to this beauty and do not notice any more,except for if you are a professional artist.For me as a lay person what is impressed me the beautiful garden in this palace ,actually the architecture of the garden harmonize with natural beauty of the land and affected me very much ,I recommend to stay more and explore the garden more than inside the palace ,if I 'd known this before I remain in the garden instead off the palce.

Stunning. Stunningly beautiful and very photogenic! A lot of walking around the gardens but mostly on the flat and well worth the effort. We loved it.TipThere are places to eat next to the gates but if you go just 50yds up the road opposite there is a small Russian cafe that is much, much cheaper and food godd!

Flowers, flowers, flowers..... Just in case your visit coincides with the blossom season, all sorts and kinds of colours will entertain your eye on the background on blue-and-white sky transformed into the same heavenly blue-and-white architecture... full harmony :)

Catherine's Palace with a wheelchair. Awesome! Amber Room was fantastic. We went with a guide from Alla Tours since we had my Mum in a wheelchair with us. We were able to skip the queues and our guide was excellent. Not any more expensive than the coach tours offered by the cruise ship we were on and definitely geared up for coping with a wheelchair user.

Impressive. Yet another beautiful palace, with well maintained exterior and interior. Another must be included on your tour. So many palaces, so many to see, unfortunately in a limited time you can only prioritise. You would need at least two weeks to just see them all!

Impressive!. We arrived early and luckily missed most of the crowds. We were able to stand and really enjoy the amber rooms on both sides. What an amazing room! The restoration efforts and the mystery of what happened the the original panels are intriguing. Google it. Outside go into the music building and try to time it so you can hear a concert or song. The sound is perfect.
Gem. Yes, this was such a wonderful place to visit. I have dreamed of coming to Russia and this did not disappoint.

Beautifully restored grand palace. Beautifully restored palace. Makes Versailles look modest. We booked an evening tour through our cruise boat (Seabourn), when the palace was private. Best money I ever spent. Got to see the rooms without being rushed and had a lovely string quartet (the Rimsky Korsakov quartet) play a concert to us in the grand ballroom. The palace is beautiful and the scale impressive.
Not to be missed. This is yet another "do not miss" Palace. Again, beauty of the exterior is paled by the magnificent interior. What an amazing place to spend a few hours.

Paris in Russia. This was an 8 hour tour with the palace as one of it's parts. Although hurried it was a site to see. It did remind me of the French palaces, just as Catherine wanted. It was spectacular.

Wonderful. . Want to see real opulence in a palace, then this is the place for you. To see this place in its wonderful settings is a must. It is a history lesson in its own right. Just go see. Do the full tour not the half tour.
A must go for palace. Visit the Amber room, it is really fabulous and you wont find it in other palace. Unfortunately, you cant take picture here.

Wow factor. Hard not to use up all your film or memory card when you bring a camera here. It is spectacular. In comparison to Peterhof, this castle is a photographer's dream. Pictures are allowed in all but one of the rooms. Catherine the Great hired an architect to build her a summer palace in 1733. She was known as a relatively fair ruler as these things go, but must have been willing to spend a little money when she felt a whim. Catherine had something like 15,000 dresses on hand. No wonder the peasants eventually got upset.This building was destroyed by the retreating Germans during World War II, but it has been slowly restored to its past glory. They aren't quite done yet, but the Russians did have the original plans and a list of the contents, so this gives you the idea pretty nicely. This is definitely a highlight of any visit to the area.

Russia's Gem. Catherine's Palace is worth the time to get there and view this beautiful structure. This is Catherine's answer to the great palaces of Europe. Take time to see the grounds as well as the lavish interior!

Very interesting and beautiful place. We spent a few hours here and really enjoyed it. Really interesting to find out about her life and the history of the Romanovs. Also the restoration of the palace after the destruction of the Nazis. Would recommend

WHEN IN RUSSIA, GOT TO DO. Went on an excursion from a cruise ship. Thought it very over priced. Unless you obtained your own visa before travelling you could not leave ship so did it for the fact probably never be in Russia again. Fantastc tghe way they could make a place as fine as this all that time ago. MUST DO.

Magnificent!. Another magnificent palace of Catherine the first. Beautiful and impressive palace and beautiful surrounding park. Although not as good as the Hermitage , it's amazing! Original paintings and artifacts and splendid decor. After you do Hermitage it's a must. Go early with a group before it opens to the public. You will avoid the crowds.

Gold galore in Catherine Palace. We visited Catherines Palace as part of a private tour organised by Alla Tours. What a fabulous place that has been completely restored since WW2. We have never seen so much gold and the Amber Room is amazing. Certainly worth going out of St. Petersburg to visit this beautiful Palace.

Don't miss it - Must See. WOW - Put up with the crowds - you must see all of the palace and grounds - Superb. I could not stop taking photo's and have spent a lovely time looking through my photo's and labelling them
Grande. Talking about how grand the palace is you wouldn't be disappointed tho it could get boring after awhile because there are too many treasures.
Old time of Csar. I liked beautiful garden but the style of castle was baroque in fact rococo,in my personal opinion I don't like this style, on the other hand the garden is gorgeous. .

Another must see places that you'll kick yourself later if you miss it while in St. Petersburg. The majesty and beauty of the palace buildings is breathtaking. So much to see and our tour guide Anna from TJ Travels seemed to know everything about everything. She really made the place come alive as she recounted the history of the place, the relationships between the various Czars, Czarinas, Princes and Princesses who lived here throughout Russia's long history. So much artwork and historical artifacts to enjoy and soak in their beauty. Definitely have this on your must-see list of places to visit in St. Petersburg.

Not to be missed, even magnificent, but disorganised chaos!. We arrived early at 9.30am to beat the queues. There are two ticket booths, which open at 10am. Make sure you go to booth 1 as it has 2 serving points. Booth 2 has only one so the queue moves at half the speed. Guess which one we picked! It is so painfully slow, so badly organised and totally inadequate for the number of people wanting to be admitted. Not a good start. The grounds are extensive and impressive, the outside appearance of the palace is fabulous, especially if you are lucky and the sun shines. Though very busy, there is so much space outside you can amble at leisure and enjoy. Inside the palace is completely the opposite, indeed it was a nightmare! You get a timed entrance which becomes a mass of people all trying to squeeze in. You are herded through the various rooms with large tour groups, very little ventilation so the temperature soars. It is so crowded you struggle to really see anything at ground level. The stewards cordon you off into areas of the big rooms to try and segregate the different groups but all that does is confuse where you are supposed to move to next. We ended up missing a complete wing of the palace as we were swept along in the tide of humanity! Yes the palace is magnificent, BUT the experience for us was a nightmare!

An incredible place. We went on an organised tour from our cruise ship in St. Petersburg and had a full morning at the Palace. We were one of the first groups to go in and it was not too crowded for the first hour or so. It definitely pays to arrive early, before the Palace opens to the general public at 11 am. The opulence of the rooms is amazing, particularly as the Palace was so badly damaged by bombing in the war and has had to be restored. The Amber Room is a must to visit.
Fairytale. amazing place, unbelievable that people lived in such opulence, oblivious to the outside world. But amazing what Catherine collected which is good for us now to see,

Go just to see the sheer size of it!. During our Baltic Cruise excursion with Alla tours, we visited Catherine Palace in Pushkin, just a short drive from the city center of St. Petersburg. The little town was beautiful and quaint. The Palace was enormous and the interior tour was very nice. Don't miss the Amber Room!
Don't Miss!. Catherine's palace is great! Magnificent! Elegant! A must see in St. Petersburg. We featured it in our video of St. Petersburg at https://vimeo.com/album/3471788/video/132972070).
History. Crucial for our culture to learn about Catherine the great.. This palace tells us about personages that interfered in History in such way that we feel obliged to learn and inquire.

Amazing..!. When my group visit canceled, I wasnt sure that I can visit the palace on my own,finally visited there on my own , and it was incredible, absolutely a MUST SEE in petersburg. Just check the website to get information & directions. I choose the " moskovskaya metro station then bus 545 to catherine palace" and it was so fine

WOW!. Over the top. Opulent! Decadent! Certainly tops on the list of places to go while in St. Petersburg. Apparently everyone walks through the Amber Room so no need to wonder if you will see it. If you wear big coats or take a bag (other than a small-ish purse), you will be asked to check it in. They are very strict about not touching any displays and there is 'security' in every room. You are not allowed to take pictures in the Amber Room. The grounds are stunning. A must for tourists.
Fabulous. fabulous palace and worth the visit, amazing gardens and fountains and the palace had so much to view,lots of people in the summer so beware of crowds

Beautiful Palace. This palace was not as highly decorated as Peterhoff, but it has the advantage you can take pictures inside. Many paintings and furniture depicting the Czars lives as well grand halls. The gardens are more of a park setting. Has a reconstruction of the original Ambar Room, as the original panels were lost during the war and never found. It is still a must see !! Lines not as long as for Peterhoff.

Yet another lovely palace. Each palace in St. Petersburg is beautifully decorated and this one is beautiful both inside and out. The Amber room is an incredible sight and each tour party is moved on very quickly because of the number of visitors wanting to see all the treasures on display.

plenty of gold, bombastic. Catherines pallacein Pushkin is extravagant, decorated with a lot of golden ornaments, huge halls and splendid rooms. Every piece of furniture, fireplace, floors and ceilings are pure art. The Amber room is really unbelievebly and unearthly beautiful. the restoration work that was started in the times of the soviet union and continues even today is outstanding.

What's not to like about the Hermitage. Although it was crowded, we enjoyed our visit. The museum is huge and is rated as one of the best 5 in the world. We saw any number of Raphaels, Remlrants and even a statue by Michelangelo. This museum is a must for anyone visiting St. Petersburg

Breathtaking!. We did an excursion through our cruise ship called "Evening with the Tsars". Although this was arranged through the cruise ship, it was one of the most memorable experiences in St. Petersburg. We had a private tour, drank champagne in the grand ballroom while actors dressed up like royalty danced and performed, we had a private dinner with traditional food and entertainment (song and dance). Truly the way to experience this beautiful palace.

Not original. Beautifully rebuilt. It is an amazing palace but dont expect a palace that is original. The rooms have been redone but many are just exhibition rooms. Between the Bolshoviks and WWII and the USSR this poor palace has been through a lot. There has been an enormous investment by the country to restore the palace to its origin glory but it is very expensive and there is so much to do in the large facilityAll that being said it is worth the time.

After hours is the best time. Loved this palace, we were allowed in after normal hours so mostly avoided the throngs, so if you can arrange to come in late please do. the orchestra playing the Imperial Suite in prescribed order was fabulous, dinner was great, the dancing stunning. being able to spend time in each room with the musicians adding flavor made it all very awesome.Like the Peterhof palace this palace was leveled during WWII to what you are seeing is mostly a communist era recreation of what it should have looked like. The amber room is dreamy, but expensive, the original is gone, but this recreation gives you a good idea what it would have looked like.

Park over Palace. The Amber Room is the big draw here, and I get it. All the rooms were nice and the palace made for a nice visit. Having toured many palaces and castles though, I would say it's nothing special, especially as most everything notable is a reproduction. If you have the time, it's not a waste, but be wary of making a special effort. If you do go try to get there before the big tour groups or be prepared for sardine-like conditions. What I do give high marks is the exterior and the park. It's beautiful and wonderful to stroll and experience.
Catherine Palace. Absolutely amazing, but so crowded,you can't imagine. Russia is so different from all other places I have visited.

Not worth the tourism torture if you're an independent traveller who doesn't travel en masse.. A bit overrated. Yes, the exterior is impressive. As are many buildings within St. Petersburg. It's very colorful (blue) and ornate. Surrounded by a lovely park. But this isn't Versailles. So you can't begin to compare the two. The interior has been restored so it feels less authentic. Should you take local transport there, which isn't too difficult, you finally arrive to face a huge line of people that gets progressively worse as the day goes on. It moves quite slowly. Mostly because tour groups take precedence and its poorly organized. You might have a tour operator ahead of you or cut the line to end up buying tickets for 25+ people. Which adds to the wait. They should have a booth for tour operators or for those purchasing 10 or more tickets. After that, you have to wait for your allotted time on your ticket. You don't just walk right in. To get the first time slot you should arrive no later than 10AM. Museum opens at 12PM in the summer. Once you finally get in, you're faced with a set of stairs and a narrow corridor blocked my many tour groups. It just doesn't flow. A human traffic jam. On top of all that, you only get to see about 15% or less of the refurbished rooms. It's quite a short exhibition and just down a single corridor within this enormous building. Prior to entering and assessing the size of the building you assume it will take hours. When its actually less than 20 minutes if you're not on a tour and walking through it and perhaps 45 minutes if your stopping to be informed by a guide. Couldn't get out of this palace fast enough. Not a fan of crowd block or being herded along like sheep. If you truly must see this site, I suggest a tour. It might cost more but it will free yourself from having to deal with the 1.5-2+ hour line for tickets and the additional time after that. Groups seem to go through another entrance and have more preferential treatment. As a solo traveler its a bit of a frustrating mess to only actually see little of how the nobility lived. It's mass tourism at its worst.
Amazing. It´s a huge and rich place, very pretty, you must walk a lot, but its worth. The gardens are really nice

Catherine Palace and Grounds. What a Treasure... Amazing ...I can almost imagine how it might have been to be a guest there at the palace. It seems like a movie set ....even more beautiful than you can imagine. Very Impressive!
Catherine Palace. Fabulous , beautiful opulence--eye candy! Catherine was quite 'over the top' on acquiring and flaunting her spectacular stuff!

Amber room.... The amber room was beautiful but the palace is not as grand as some of the other palaces you will see. Nonetheless, it should be visited for the history and significance. The surrounding grounds are lovely and you may get a fun concert out front.
Amazing. This was so gigantic and beautiful. This a must to see on a tour to St. Petersburg. I had no idea the park was so huge and picturesque. The fountains were fantastic.

A MUST!. An extensive palace set in well kept and beautiful natural style gardens and grounds. The amber room (recreacted) is often most mentioned but all the rooms have a Wow factor especially when you see the photographs of the war time damage.A guided tour can be completed in 90 minutes - you will need to give in anything larger than a handbag so pack wisely as there are queues at the cloakroom and you are told to stow bags its not optional. You also have to wear papers slip on covers over shoes - don't wear heels. If you have large feet - mens size 10+ - then take spare covers from the entrance as yours will split as you walk around! House guides are guards of the treasures and take their job seriously so no messing about or you'll be brought sharply in line. Not a great spot for fracious children!If you get a chance walk down to the lakeside and join one of the tours into the small but elegant stables there 3 male singers perform a short folk song without accompaniment - but which will bring tears to the eyes for the sheer beauty of their voices - well worth videoing - have a few notes to tip them. The gardens on a good day can be enjoyed for at least an hour.Plenty of rest rooms inside the palace but these get busy and its easy to loose companions as coridors look similar so agree your meeting spot!
A treasure. The grounds are fantastic there is nothing to dislike all staff we encountered were friendly even though we never spoke each other's language plenty of photos and memories
Catherine Palace and Park. Don't miss if you have the opportunity to visit Russia. What you see inside is probably one of the interesting places I've ever seen. This was a highlight of our trip.

Fabulous unique yet romanovic architectures of the Slavs. Visited back in October 2012, this amazing palace appears to be quite similar to the Winter Palace but the colour seems lighter than the Winter palace. There are of course, fountains on the sides to embellish the beauty of this palace. In the summer, you can see many local Petersburgers here relaxing on the grass on the bench, or by the fountains. Certainly a good way to relax. But of course, better to enjoy in a resort on Hainan Island like what most SMART RUSSIANS DO))

Awesome, go with a guide. You would never know from first look that this buiding was considerably damaged by a fire. Most impressive from outside, you could spend a considerable time just looking at the buiding from the outside. When you go in there is so much to see, rooms, ballroom, art rooms, make sure that your camera is fully charged and there is space on the digital memory.We went with ALLA Tours, so no queues to get tickets and a minimal queue to get in. The tour guide explained everything in the rooms, doing it on your own you would miss so much, even with an audio guide you can't ask questions. If you like art, fancy gardens and impressive buildings then this is the place to go to.

Beautiful palace but there's more to it than the amber room. Frankly amber is not my thing. If I had realised this, while waiting for our allotted time to get in to see the amber room I would of visited the carriage museum located there instead. Do not go to this palace if you are not with a tour or you will line up for ever to get a ticket while watching tour groups bypass you in the queue and you will be really browned off!!

Absolutely beautiful. We visited at night, were welcomed with champagne, caviar and of course vodka. The palace is stunning, we were allowed to take photos as it was a special tour, normally not allowed inside the palace. There was a string quartet and we got to meet ' Catherine'. Highly recommend a visit here.
Good reason to start a revolution!. so beautiful and rich, enough to generate the envy of the starving People. Impressive architecture and magnificient Colors.

Retreat from St. Petersburg. Quite enjoyed the visit. Walking through the palace may take 30 min - 45 min pending commentary. I'd recommend reading up a bit prior to the visit to get some timeline of events and to assist in staging the scene. It's quite dazzling and a lot of eye-candy with the gilded work. The Amber Room is awe-inspiring and I believe the only room with no photos/videos allowed - quite welcome since the onslaught of visitors with cameras up everywhere block great viewing.I'd bought tickets to view the Carriage House. This was interesting and my 7 year old daughter who'd recently seen Cinderella was quite entertained by the types of carriages and winter sleds. It'll take about 20 minutes to walk through/read the placards of the carriage house.If you're in a crunch for time, ensure that you save time for exploring the grounds. This was truly (outside the Amber Room) quite the highlight for me. I enjoyed the park much more than Peterhof - less crowded, more spaced out pavilions and just overall peaceful. I wished I had planned better Of course, the stories of Catherine the Great were amusing and that went through my mind as the guide was tastefully recounting some events.

Catherine Palace & Park- well worth the visit!. The outside of Catherine the Great's Palace was beautiful. When we went inside and started up the staircase the statues and furnishings took your breath away. Every room contained more beautiful treasures to view. There were several Rembrandt paintings on display. I really enjoyed the tour and would highly recommend it. The only downside was the high number of visitors. The park was pretty and musician was playing his violin as we toured the grounds.

Amber room is good. This is a big scale European style palace that Catherine built.It was unfortunately burnt down during the Nazi siege of Leningrad. However it had been mostly restored. The highlight is definitely the unique Amber room wise walls are covered in amber. The main ballroom is a big gilded room which is also quite impressive. It is about a 20 minute car ride out from downtown. There is also a line to get in do you need to plan enough time. It rained when we were there but luckily we wetter already inside.

MUST!. Catherine Palace is a MUST when visiting St. Petersburg.The castle is impressive, amber room is a must, and spend some time walking around the gardens in the park, its great!Cons: - Huge lines to buy tickets; and when you buy your ticket, it automatically sets you up for a specific time to enter the museum (depending on the amount of people there are)... I got there at 10am, bought my ticket at 11:30am due to huge lines, and was set-up to enter the museum up until around 4pm.- they did not offer any english speaking tours, and they had no english headphones (automated tours).
Beatifully restored. A must if you like baroque architectural palaces. Very well restored.....the Amber room is a site to see.....

A disappointing visit................. To visit the Catherine Palace, we hired a car and driver from our hotel for a return journey and a 2 hour wait !!!!!!!!On arriving, we joined one of the ticket queues; after a 3/4 hour wait we were eventually told that entry to the Palace was not available for a further 2 hours.I now estimate that a visit to the Catherine Palace during the busy summer months, allowing for ticket queueing, waiting and tour, requires at least 4 hours.Something we were not told.....so be prepared !!!!!Whilst walking the fine gardens, which include follies,fountains, bridges and lake, is of course fascinating and enjoyable, not to gain entry to the Palace made this visit a real disappointment.

Just Awesome. When you view the palace from the outside it's impressive, the inside is just stunning, from the gold to the painted ceilings and everywhere you look is just amazing, the amber room is something else, unfortunately no photos were allowed to be taken in this room, you were watched like a hawk from the Russian woman who were on duty in each room, step out of line and they were there, apart from that it's a palace that has to be seen.

A must see in St Petersburg. Our private tour guide (K Joy Day Tour) took us there via boat, which is unique experience by itself. The Palace and the park and the numerous fountains are simply beautiful!

A must see. Expansive park grounds to walk around. the sheer size of the Palace tests the limits of your iphone panoramic shots. we bought our tickets from resellers at the gate, paid a small premium to not wait in a long long line. entrance times are specific on tickets, so plan accordingly. summer times the tickets sell out fast.

Amber room is the business. All the rooms are brilliant; the Amber Room is the highlight, without doubt. The park itself is also very smart. This is one of the main highlights of St Petersburg and consequently is very busy during the season. Tip: try to go early in the day and get timed appointments to avoid long queues. Also go with a local guide, who speaks the language. Not only will they get your group to the head of the queue but they will know all about the Palace itself, and make the trip much more interesting as a result.
Opulence. This was an eye opening experience of how the Czars once lived. So much gold & marble- very beautiful.

Opulant Palace. It is difficult to believe that much of Catherine's Palace was destroyed in WWII. The restoration is amazing and one gets a sense of the Palace as it was originally. There is gilt everywhere. the blazing domes of the chapel, the gilt woodwork throughout the Palace - all amazing. The park is lovely with the lake and gardens.

Short drive to see how Catherine the Great entertained. As your drive out of St Petersburg towards the Catherine palace, you will drive by where the citizens of Leningrad/St Petersburg held off the Nazi army during WWII for over 900 days with a loss of life in the city of close to 3 million. Be sure to see the before and after pictures of how the palace was rebuilt to its present condition from near total, senseless destruction. Much of the guilt work domes were financed by wealthy Russian Oligarcs who donated Hugh sums to rebuild the palace to its former glory. Well worth the visi!
Palace. This place is huge and so inviting. The people that guide you and welcome you are so nice. I loved the Delft furnaces. So much art work and rooms to observe.
Summer wonder of Tzars. No visit to St Petersburg is complete without visiting summer Tzars residence. It offers tours, walk through the restored rooms and grounds.

absolutely stunning, a must see. This palace is jaw dropping, and when you find out that it was destroyed by the Nazi's and its works of art saved by the locals, then rebuilt and restored, it becomes even more impressive. The town is cute and clean, the grounds are beautiful... i cannot say enough.

Incredible building and gardens. This place is simply amazing. From gargantuan ornate rooms filled with art to smaller more intimate rooms where Catherine spent personal time - every corner brought a new "WOW!". The Amber Room is worth the trip alone. And to realize how much damage was done during WWII and the labor of love to restore the palace...outstanding. The grounds are beautiful as well.

A huge window to an extraordinary past. We were blessed with perfect weather and, arriving early were just about first through the doors, so we had the best possible exposure to the extraordinary opulence that constitutes the formal rooms of the Catherine Palace. Such magnificence against the extreme hardships that must often have been faced by the average Russian is absolutely mind blowing - and yet, in the private rooms, there are surprising touches of austerity. Definitely an absolute MUST DO for any visitor to Russia, and if you can get there really, really early in the morning (we had to wait for the gates to be opened) it's well worth it to walk into the great, empty, gilt and gold ballroom with the early morning sunlight streaming through the windows and the extraordinary beautiful parquet flooring.
A must see. Impressive built with Versailles in mind but not as classy very gaudy but a must see. Beautiful gardens
A MUST SEE!. This place was beyond amazing. If you are in St. Petersburg you should make an effort to see this..It was spectacular in every way.
Russia's Wonderful history. Some of the most beautiful rooms of the rein of the Russia Czars. Catherine spared to cost in making this a world showcase.

My favorite czars palace . This palace is amazing and makes all other palaces seem shabby. Catherine loved gilt and everything gold and chandeliers too plus the amber room makes this palace over the top. It was destroyed after world war 2 and is still being worked on to this day. Nice drive out to see from town. Also nice gardens to walk around in. The czars had it all here in their summer palace.

Huge but park not worth visiting. The palace was well worth a visit and we were lucky the crowds were very light so we could wander and get a feel for the place. Our guide gave lots of info. I could have done with a lot less time in the grounds and spent more time at Peterhof, our next stop.We had a lovely lunch there with entertainment, part of our ship's tour.

"Imagine being the lucky Princess!!. Wow, where does one start? This palace is a must see if visiting St. Petersburg. The best way is with a guide to only begin to appreciate everything you will see. Similar to going to the Hermitage, you will not be able to see everything in one visit. But do go and enjoy whatever you can and however much time you can devote. While you are looking at all the detail and all the simply beautiful workmanship, art and the amount of gold used throughout, know that all of this palace had to be restored after WWII. The palace was first built in the 1700's, and added to and changed, etc. through all those years, but during the 2nd World War, the Nazi's had taken over and left everything in ruins, after having ravaged it. Since the mid 1940's the palace has been restored, but only about half of it has been completed. There is still much more to be done. Everything had to be restored from photographs previously taken. Thanks to photography, anyone who appreciates photography and it's importance, can understand all that. So, if you can visit St. Petersburg, put it at the top of your list. The palace is in a nearby town called Pushkin, about a half hour drive from St. Petersburg. You can take pictures throughout, only not in one special room, which is the Amber room. That's fine, because you will be happy with all the rest. Enjoy!

Worth Taking the Tour. I took the Ecclectica English speaking tour to Catherine Palace. It cost a little more but was well worth it. The palace and grounds are quite stunning. We got to see all the available rooms including the amber room and had their history and function described in clear English. The guide was an academic historian who spoke English and some French and knew his stuff. The Ecclectica box office (cassa) is on Nevsky Prospect just outside the metro station. Don't be fobbed off by other tour operators who say there are no English tours.

Catherines Palace. This palace took my breath away The amber room was just ....awesome Palace was very crowded but the guides took turns in each room This place was just so jaw dropping A must on your bucket list

Gorgeous building and gardens. Just breathtaking. The building is beautiful both inside and out and the many rooms will not leave you disappointed. Many different styles and colours. The amber room is of course the most stunning of them all. Restored and sumptuous, so rich and warm. We walked through the gardens and in the pavilion by the lake there were 4 singers who sang the most wonderful Russian acapella songs. We ended up buying a couple of their CDs. This was part of a tour with a guide, which was very helpful, as we visited not only here but also Pavlovsk and the Peterhof gardens. You will need at least 2 hours here, 3 would be better. Like with all Russian palaces and museums, you will be expected to hand in your coats and big bags at the cloakroom. You will also be given overshoes to prevent the original floors fro getting damaged. There are plenty of toilets/bathrooms.
Awesome. Just really crowded it was hard to see everything and extremely long waiting lines for the bathroom.

Beautiful Restoration of the Amber Room.. Worth the drive out to this palace, the one preferred by the final Romanov family and easy to see why. Destroyed by the Nazi's in WWII, but much is renovated and still continuing. An amazing Amber room that must have cost millions. Still used often today by Putin for meetings and summits.

What a palace. The interior is amazing. As usual there are crowds of people in organised groups that allow guides to get everyone to where they want to be. There was a feeling of school trip as we walked down a corridor of rooms that displayed different functions. This felt rushed but was essential to get to the reconstructed Amber room.I especially enjoyed the large room of light. Large windows, with mirrors and fascinating ceiling and stunning floor. There would have been millions of candles used and I could I aged the effect.
Catherine palace. Beautiful palace so decadent. Excellent info tour guide so obliging there is nothing did likeable driver most helpful
Great palace. Beautiful building with many open rooms. You can't take pictures in the Amber room, but I snapped a few

Spectacular Opulence!. Breathtaking interior- chandeliers, paintings, sculpture and the colours! Amber Room was just so rich. As no photos are allowed in this room. one can buy a book with excellent pictures of the Amber Room from their bookshop. Amazing gardens, worth walking around.

Lovely place. We had to have a booked trip and guide due to the visa requirements in Russia.You are allowed to take photos inside except the Amber room, which gives a much better feel to the trip and we were not as rushed as we were in Peterhof: Grand Palace and gardens.The amber room is truly a site to see and a most enjoyable visit. We had a walk around the grounds but always with the guide. We paid £38.75 each for a coach trip from the cruise terminal so not a bad price for what we saw.

Stunning. Absolutely loved this. We got their (in a party) early & waiting for gates to open. We were serenaded by a couple of town bands, who were both funny & entertaining. Once inside, the house and gardens are simply stunning. Massive, richly decorated & appointed. You would not believe how devastated the place was at the end of the war, and the Russians have done a simply fantastic job in restoring it to its former glory. The rooms are huge, richly decorated with gold-leaf covered carvings, fantastic chandeliers, mirrors, great works of art, fabulous views. There is the usual irritating Russian habit of the curators of each room trying to hurry you along all the time, but aside from that, the place is wonderful. You could spend many hours wandering round the grounds, which are dotted with beautiful smaller buildings, ponds, lakes, flower-beds & stunning vistas. An absolute highlight.

A baroque marvel.. This palace is situated south of the city in Tsarkoye Selo and it is well worth a visit. It was built by Catherine the Great and is set in a beautiful park. The exterior is as fine as the interior, which features the famous reconstructed amber room. My advice is to combine this visit with Peterhof. A private guide will help avoid long lines. Visits have a set time.

Wonderful St.Petersburg.We enjoyed the palaces,gardens and lovely fountains.Tasted the Vodka in the chilly climate of St. Liked the sightseeing and dislike nothing as we took an organised excursion with Aventura Travel.We also like the musuems and boat trips to have a view of the attractions in the city

Fantastic. What an amazing Palace. Completely OTT but it works and the Amber room lives up to the hype! We had thought the Hermitage was special but I think the Catherine Palace was spectacular and it a must do in St Petersburg.

A piece of Russian history not to be missed. The Catherine Palace is often referred to as the "Russian Versailles". It stands as a monument not only to the 18th Century Romanov's; but to the Russians who restored it after it was nearly leveled by the Nazi invaders during the Siege of Lenningrad. Allow yourself at least four hours to tour the Catherine Palace and park. Also, hire a private guide who can obtain queue jump tickets or you shall spend most of your time in long, Soviet style queues of tourists for many hours.

Magnificent!. Can walk the grounds forever, and never get tired of it. A spectacular palace would be a worthy stop by itself, but having this park with all of its pavilions open up to you is always magical, and brings out new features every time we come here. Kids love it here, and it's open until 11PM in the summer time, so don't miss it!
Beautiful and Decorative!. Another very beautiful Russian Palace. You need plenty of time to walk through and appreciate it! It is huge, but well worth the visit if you enjoy palaces etc.

A MUST see when visiting St. Petersburg.. A Russian imitation of Versailles but not identical. Although it doesn't hold a candle to Versailles, especially the gardens, it's architectural grandure can stand alone. The guided Russian Orthodox dome feature is unique and it's baby blue facade gives it a fairy princess romantic feel. Inside, the over-the-top decor is predicable and justifies the revolutions just like at Versailles, however, the [reconstructed] Amber Room is surprisingly breath taking. Absolutely worth the trek out to Pushkin while in St. Petersburg.
stunning. Home of the famous "amber room", which for me, was not the best part....the whole thing is amazing -- as are most of St Petersburg. I recommend using a private tour guide.

Beautiful. Just go, the Palace is amazing as most can tell and say but just visit the gardens at ease and just try to travel in time. Try to also understand the love of the Russian people for their land as they began to reconstruct even before WWII was over

While we were only on a two day trip we had a city tour and a river boat trip, Catherine Palace is a place you just have. Catherine Palace is a residence that you could lose yourself in for hours . StPetersburg is a facinating city of the rich and the poor
Great. what can you say, wonderful place to visit. The Amber room is of course very popular, but lots of other great things to see.

Go for the gardens. Catherine Palace is very beautiful. The gardens were more interesting to me as I was not impressed with the staff inside the building. I was not told that checking your bag was a MUST, I thought it was just an option. I did not feel comfortable checking my bag with a building so full of people (very crowded!!) So I missed out on the amber room thanks to the security guard who practically yelled at me. The line was much to long even if I did want to check my bag and go back in. So I went to the gardens instead which were very nice.

A place of exceptional beauty. An absolutely stunning and exceptionally beautiful place to visit. The art,decor and the history of the palace was a joy to behold. Would highly recommend any visitor to St Petersburgh to take the time to visit.
Visit for a whole day.. Magnificent palace and fascinating park. Get luck with weather and enjoy walking through the park, looking at statues, flower beds, trees and other old attractions.

Breathtaking!. This palace was breathtaking. This history is fascinating but the fact that the palace had been occupied by the Nazi's during World War II and then restored after the Nazi's bombed the palace when they left is amazing. This is a must see.

Beautiful palace. This palace was wrecked by the Nazis during the siege of Leningrad (now St. Petersburg). However, it has now been beautifully restored with gold-leaf everywhere. The Amber room is a work of art and there is a corridor showing the restoration work. In the gardens, not as many fountains as Peterhof but still well worth a visit.

A glimpse of the Tsarist past. The Catherine Palace is an absolutely over the top experience. Beautifully restored after the devastation of WWII, the palace gives a hint to what it must have been like to have everything. From dazzling ballrooms to intimate dining rooms to exquisite bedrooms, as our guide put it "if it looks like gold, it is gold." And man is there a lot of gold! Don't overlook the beautiful inlaid floors and the fabulous gardens. Go early in the morning to avoid the worst of the crowds. There are also a lot of steps to climb, but really worth it.

A Russian 'Versailles'. On a slightly smaller scale but the beauty and influence of Versailles is unmistakable. However its location right on the river is spectacular and the ride back to St. Petersburg by hydrofoil was a blast.

Impressive. You are not allowed to take photographs of the Amber Room, so you MUST come to see this in person. It is very moving to stop and look at the photographs of the reconstruction that was necessary after all the damage done during WW II. Such dedication!

Enjoyed this place. We went by public bus, which we caught at 10:00. Got there about 11:00 and had a 15 mins walk to the palace. There were very long queues but we joined in and after 90 mins got a 15:30 entry ticket. We persevered as we had declined the long wait at Peterhof and given the palace a miss there, so wanted to see this one.We had thought that this was a very long wait, but the time in the gardens actually passed quite quickly. They are very different to the Peterhof ones - less formal with individual attractions - none mind-blowing like at Versailles - but attractive all the same.We were a bit apprehensive as we lined up at our allocated time discovering that the 20-minute groupings just meant that you were herded into the large entry area with the previous group that had not yet entered the palace.However, once in the palace, the tour groups separated into little bunches and as individual tourists, we were left to ourselves. We actually tagged along with an English-speaking group for a while and then just wandered through on our own. It was not the sardine-packed experience we has in Versailles. Enjoyed the whole day.

Baroque at its Best. This palace was stunning and well worth the excursion outside the city limits of St. Petersburg. The only drawback is that it is one of the most popular tourist destinations with crowds to prove it.

A Place of Serenity. I said to fellow world travelers that this should be called 'Mary's Palace and Park'. I enjoyed it that much! As an adult it wasn't difficult for me to slip into the imagination of a child and feel this place was my very own. In hindsight, I should have purchased my tickets online, but it was worth the wait as I enjoyed the Park tremendously. I walked for hours in the park and despite the huge crowds of people this land is so sprawling I actually found myself alone on the grounds without another human in sight. Every detail of the Palace is perfect. I would definitely recommend a visit. Plan it as an 'all day' outing or you will find yourself rushed as it took me about an hour and a half to ride the metro to catch the mini bus to the Palace and Park - and that is one way! Enjoy!

What a Palace!!. For this American I was in awe of this beautiful Palace and Park. If visiting St Petersburg, I would highly recommend! It is a little ways off the main tourist sites but a very reasonable cab fare away. One tip, find a friendly cab driver who will charge you what a local would pay and you will find it very reasonable.

If you like gold, go.. Incredibly ornamental and gold-laden rooms full of the splendour that was Tsarist life in the 17 and 1800s. The famous amber room is here as are many many other incredibly beautiful pieces of art and furniture. To be honest it can all be a bit much for someone that doesn't like gold and opulence but it's certainly worth seeing as part of your visit to St. Petersburg. The glory of days gone by.

Wow!!!!!!!!!. This place far exceeded my expectations. It truly is the Versailles of St. Petersburg. The amount of gold decor and carved trim in the palace is staggering. This is the kind of place where you want a guide (we used SPB Tours), rather than walking through the place yourself. Pay the money, learn a lot more, and be amazed.
Catherine Palace. Beautiful, well worth the drive and fighting the crowds. Highly recommend. This is a must-see, definitely an A list excursion.
magnificient. Over the top opulence, breathtaking, i was expecting it to be beautiful but it delivered more. The only downside CROWDS

Stunning palace, atrocious organization, miserable experience. The palace is stunning, however the huge crowds and atrocious organization make for a miserable experience.Timed group reservations are not honored. The visit begins with a long wait in line under the sun just to get into the building, way past your scheduled visit time. The line is chaotic and unsupervised with tens of people cutting in, leading to constant shouting matches and arguments. Once inside the door, there's another long line for the turnstiles. Once finally inside the palace, you are herded like cattle from one room to the next, with a long wait in between the first few rooms; all while being constantly hit and elbowed by other visitors. The little time allotted and huge crowds make it impossible to take more than a very quick look at each room.Not recommended unless substantial improvements are made.
Breathtaking. I was expecting to be amazed but it was more than amazing. While waiting to enter a band played to the crowd.
Amazing... Beautiful palace, well restored and because we went with TJ Travel the whole visit to the palace with return by Hydrofoil was excellent

Wow!. We arrived in St. Petersburg on a cruise ship and booked a tour (through the cruiseline) of Catherine and Peterhof Palaces. We traveled with my mother who had her heart set on seeing the Amber Room in Catherine's Palace. The palace is what you would expect of the opulence of those days. The Amber Room with panels of amber stones (not the originals) was stunning. Why we were not allowed to take photos in that room was a mystery...perhaps they wanted us to purchase photos from their shop. Each room had a Russian woman to watch over us to make sure we followed their rules. They were like bulldogs if someone stepped out of line...not very hospitable. All in all, it's worth visiting this spectacular place and its gorgeous gardens and ponds.

Endless beauty and history. A lavish imperial palace. You will see exquisit floors, illuminating mirrors, gilded carvings, amazing celinging paintings, and detailed amber mosaics. Along with a varied selection of furniture treasures. And that is just the inside. Another magnificent site to see!

Sparkles inside and out. Pushkin Palace was a gift from Peter I to his wife Catherine in 1710. What a gift! Rooms are magnificently decorated and the Amber room is a highlight. Outside gardens are worth a stroll as well.
Glitter & Gold. Amazing, but a bit overwhelming. A must see is the Amber Room. Expect crowds, lots of crowds, both worth it.
Amazing. The palace was amazing all gold and the treasures in it, Worth a visit. The decorations were beautiful, another place that is steeped in history in Russia.
dazzlling. An amazing display of obscene wealth. Provided interesting insigh into royal opulence and life style
Go just go. look by this point you may be thinking I've seen a lot of places/parks combo do i really want to go. you do, believe me just go.

Palace. it was beautiful and an exciting piece of history. We went on a tour with our Cruise ships excursion. It was a little rainy I can remember but it did not detract from the beauty and history of this palace.
palace review. Beautiful palace that was lovely to walk through. not much to the grounds, but worth seeing. decorations on the walls, and things to see made it worthwhile.

Stunning!. We visited Catherine's Palace on a two day tour while in St. Petersburg. The Palace is spectacular. The Amber Room is unbelievable. Although you have to drive a ways outside St. Petersburg to get to Catherine's Palace, it is well worth your time to do so. We were not disappointed in our visit. There is a great gift shop inside, however, our tour did not allow time to shop here.

Amber room worth a visit. Beautiful palace. Very crowded and long lines to get inside. Not well organized, and can make you feel chaotic. Join a private tour with an experienced tour guide, it is worth every penny and save time on waiting in lines.

A MUST SEE..Glorious. Grand, opulent, but lots of light so very airy too. Amber room fabulous,,particularly when accompanied by an excellent storyteller (this applied to the whole Palace).. We were so fortunate in our guide Elena. A proud heritage especially when we realised the devastating state it was left in after German occupation during the Second World War. The restoration work is superb.
Catherine palace ...must see. Muat see for traveller visting petersburg. But keep in mind to prebook tickets online as we are sadden to here museum tickets sold out.

The Amber Room. I can assume that most tourists visiting St. Petersburg wish to visit the "Amber Room" a copy of the original room which went missing during the 2nd World War. The Palace and Park are magnificent examples of exotic cultures. One requires at least half a day (weather permitting) to appreciate this splendour.

Amazing!. Just returned after spending the morning here with my wife, 2 friends and a guide. The interior of the palace is filled with magnificent decorations displayed in a long series of rooms. The number of beautiful light fixtures, mirrors and gold trim is amazing. The Amber Room alone is worth the trip. The gardens are stunning and very peaceful, with small ponds, small palaces and several pavilions. The Palace is in Pushkin, about 1 hour from St. Petersburg. If possible, go early to avoid rush hour traffic and crowds of tourists

Read their WEBSITE!. Ok - they changed the rules - and my Lonely Planet Guidebook - Version 2015 didn't know. Be aware and plan ahead.The crowds are amazing, the line ups endless - and you must first line up to get a timed ticket for entering the Palace. When we arrived at noon - they were giving out tickets for 5:00 PM. And this was relatively off season.As far as I could tell - other than paying for a tour - your best choice is to arrive early - say 9:00 AM. Your timed entrance should be no later than noon - and you can enjoy coffee in the surroundings while you wait.It might be better in the long run to just opt for a tour and be done with it.Check their Website! I'll bet pennies that by the time you read this - the rules will have changed again.Flux - the fun part of adventure travel.

It meets all the requirements for a great palace. You have probably read all the adjectives used to describe this wonderful palace. They are all accurate! This is a real "showstopper" of a tour--well worth the time it takes to get to Russia.The requirements for a great palace are: big structure, great design, beautiful outside and inside, great art and antiques, wonderful stories abut the inhabitants, historical significance, attractive grounds, and "over the top" display of wealth. It meets all of these with ease!We did this on our first day on St. Petersburg--it set the tone (and high expectations) for the remainder of the tour!
Impressive inside and outside, definitely a must.. Impressive architecture, very well preserved and restored, famous amber chamber, wonderful furniture.

Inside and outside it is spectacular. This was a day to remember - from the excellent brass group entertaining us as we waited at the gates to the awe inspiring grandeur of the exterior and interior of the palace. The history of the destruction of the palace during the WW2 occupation by Germany is very moving but to have restored it to such a high standard is a huge credit to Russian authorities. Could not be faulted.

Breathtaking. Just an amazing place to visit. Hard to take in everything,...it would really take hours to do it justice but if you are hard pressed for time you really must see the Amber Room! It was included in our SPB tour and our guide Maria did a good job explaining all the key points

Great Palace - still being renovated. A great and truly opulent palace, which has undergone considerable renovation - which is still underway. Great location in a quiet village a train ride outside of St Petersburg.

Prachtig en enorm! . Very crowded around the palace main. Tour groups don't seem to get past the palace into the garden area. There is an alternative entrance further down from the main entrance, not known to tourists, no crowd and used by locals and knowing how to read Russian is helpful can get you better deals. There is also a very nice little restaurant directly next to this entrance which serves traditional Russian food, pancakes, Russian beer, home made fruit punch, kaas. Food is dirt cheap and the same quality as any other fancy but restaurant, without any frills. As this is an area only known to locals Russian you need to place your order by speaking Russian. Add a sign of respect, learn some Russian! My advice to any tourist thinking of visiting Russia (saint Petersburg) is to learn the Cyrillic alphabet which will allow one to read menus, street names and stray away from the tourist traps. THE most interesting sights and eating can be enjoyed outside tourist areas where the knowing Russian is essential. Do learn some Russian phrases, it can open many doors.
Beautiful palace and outdoor area. We did not go inside the palace, but the outdoor area is beautiful. A great park atmosphere. Beautiful building and lovely fountains and greenspace to walk around.

Awesome Visit to Catherine Palace. This visit went far beyond my wildest expectations. The treasures and opulence of the Palace are stunningly beautiful. The fabulous painted ceilings, astonishing art works, fine china plus the golden decorations are almost too much to take in! However the Amber Room steals the show - truly jaw dropping. Outside there are the golden tower domes as well as golden statues. Be aware that it is incredibly busy and we were taken round quite hurriedly.

Simply Stunning. Visiting Catherine's Palace is a must. We went on a private tour & it was worth every penny (rouble!) to do so. The sheer opulence & also craftsmanship of this palace was amazing. Yes, there were loads of large tourist groups there, but our guide was able to ensure we got through everything with ease & once we had been through the palace we then wandered around the fabulous gardens & walked around the lake soaking up the ambiance of the place - fabulous afternoon.

Don't waste your time. we have been to Hermitage and Peterhof. Both were good. But if you have seen both don't even bother with Catherins palace. It is more of the same. Unless you go by an arranged tour you are in a lot of trouble for very little to see.The only thing that is different here is the Amber room. That is worth going for.But most foreigner unfriendly major tourist site we have come across. No information booth easily accessible. There is one. But to find it you will need guidance. Nobody speaks anything other than Russian. Most signage is in Russian. Free audio guide is Russian. And for every smallest entrance you have to pay. Better spend your time doing something else. Unless you must see the Amber room.
A Must. We did it with SPB Tours and it was amazing to see and tour a must do.. It was easy walking but such beautiful garden and entrance to the Castle. A place is a must for pictures.

For history and queues lovers. Love history? You gotta love these queues. For those who wondering - there are no online ticket sale. You either go with a tour guide or get ready for miserable experience in the queues. Long story short - avoid.
Fabulous!. Loved it! Highly recommend visiting the Palace if you are in St. Petersburg. DenRus Tours Rock and guide Lana rock!
A must see.. Ornately opulent both inside and out. This is a must see in St. Petersburg and a guide is essential to gain any type of understanding of the historic significance.

Stunning inside and out. The palace and grounds are stunning - be sure to include it on your itinerary. If you have time, take time to explore the adjacent park - absolutely beautiful. Be prepared for a crowd inside on cruise days - there is a linear path through the palace and we moved at a snail's pace constrained by huge crowds ahead and behind us.

Wonderful place. Honestly, if someone wants to build me a palace some day I want it modeled on the Catherine Palace! Loved this place - makes me sad to think that it was burnt down by the Nazi's and marvel at the skill involved in rebuilding it. Tips: arrive early in the morning - when you buy your ticket (which we queued for almost an hour to do) you are given a time at which you can go into the palace. For us this was four hours after we purchased our ticket. Which was fine because we wandered around the town, had lunch and visited the park. But if you don't fancy doing that you should try and get there early.Tip no. 2: The museums in St. Petersburg are closed on a Monday so if you want to avoid the huge crowds (which we experienced) you should probably choose a different day of the week.Tip no. 3: Beware of the shoe coverings - someone slipped and fell on the wooden floors while we were there. I'll keep my opinions as to the concept of putting the preservation of floors before people to myself....Tip no. 4: If you are not a Russian speaker expect to be awkwardly walking around with a tour guide who you can't understand - as far as I could tell tours in English aren't provided. Luckily I had my own personal interpreter to translate :)
Watch out Marie Antoinette!. Catherine I of Russia's summer palace. It's a sumptuous resident surrounded by a glorious park. Very lavish living to be for sure!

Simply Beautiful. It is worth travelling to Pushkin to see this amazing palace and gardens. The floors are still original so you have to wear protective booties over shoes. The size of the palace is stunning and the gardens just as impressive.
A Look at the Life of the Empress. Catherine Palace if full of incredible riches, history, and a glimpse into how Catherine lived - very well indeed!

A gilded palace. This palace was beautiful with all its paintings and gold but at the same time ostentatious. The Amber room was breathtaking. It's hard to take in the sumptuousness of this place when there were people starving outside of its walls.
Must-see place around St Petersburg. If you're in the area, this palace is a must-see. Check out your guidebooks why to go here, or go to a similar place in the area: Peterhof.

An evening tour should be better. I visited the palace in the evening as part of an excursion organized by Princess Cruise. The visit consisted of three parts - a tour of the palace, music and dancing performance, and a Russian dinner. The best part remained the tour of the palace, which contained so much treasure to admire and appreciate. The palace by then was already closed to other tourists and we, in individual groups of about 25, walked through the different rooms in leisure. The performance was fine but too short to be of any significance. The worst part was the dinner. It was a 4-course dinner, with wine and vodka included. The food however was the usual European dishes, and fell far short of what I expected to be a Russian dinner. On the whole, the evening was an enjoying one and recommended. But be sure to have some food before jumping into the coach as dinner did not begin until about 10.30 pm

Stunning. We adored the whole complex, this huge park full of various pavillions, but I want especially recommend to visit Catherine Palace (price not included into the entrance price, so,once you arrive try to buy first the ticket to the palace, precise the time of entering - since there are so many visitors they give you some time gap to be able to enter) Maybe, it's the most stunning palace out of all suburban palaces around the city. You will be definitely astonished by the incredible Golden Hall, the opulent decoration of the other halls, and of course the reconstructed Amber Chamber is worth being visited (attention, it's the only chamber where they ask you not to take pictures). If you don't speak Russian, we recommend to take an english audio guide

Stunning, must-do experience. We paid an eye-wateringly large sum for a tour arranged through our travel company, but it was the highlight of our visit. Private tours are tightly timed, but the crowds were tolerable, even in June and photography is allowed, except in the Amber Room. Yes, it's a reconstruction, but it's a work of art as a whole, which should be preserved and valued just as the original. Photographs showing the war-time destruction remind of the skill and costs of the restoration. The outside of the building is beautiful, with lakes and other smaller buildings, including the chapel where there is a regular short vocal performance, a stunning finish to our tour. Why a 4 rating? You really have to use a tour guide, or suffer the ill-signed exterior ticket offices. The time available inside the building is short, but the gardens warrant some time as well, hence my recommendation of 2-3 hours.

Simply Stunning!. This is a must visit if coming to St Petersburg. Opulent and gaudy at times it is stunning. Steeped in History the whole Palace and grounds are fascinating. We only did a relatively swift tour and I would like to go back and spend a more leisurely time walking the grounds and exploring the many rooms given more time. Beautiful!
Breathtakingly beautiful. The size, the architecture, the interiors, the colors... Everything about this palace is amazingly beautiful. It is worth spending the day here as the park is also lovely.
Fantastic. One of the most wonderful trips I have taken. Enjoyed enough to start planning a return visit next year.
Catherines Palace. Opulent and quite gaudy, but interesting to visit. I would recommend this to anyone visiting Russia because it is par the g=the great history of the coutnry.

Catherine Palace. The palace has a stunning Aqua facade and is adorned with gold and white ornaments. There was the beautiful Throne room, State dining room, Blue drawing room and Gallery. The French garden with its geometric designs and Great pond was just spectacular.
Beautiful palace. A must visit in St Petersburg. It's a pity we could not take pictures in the magnificent Amber Room.

So beautiful. Absolutely dazzled with all the gold. And the Amber room, wow!
Advice: It can really get crowded, so watch your valuables while taking pictures/videos. Also avoid the hottest month as it can get stuffy with crowds.
Incredible. No wonder why the peasants revolted.. What were they thinking…. From one room to another. Very crowded. If you visit St Petersburg, you have to come here. People not nice…

Lots of gold!!!. A must to see I believe since you are there!, The garden is well kept and all the states are well painted with gold!! All shiny
I,like the time we were there all the tulips were blossoming and that was also very nice to see!! But if you are running short of time then maybe you can miss this garden!!

Crowded but definitely a Must See. You'll see lots of "Wow's" when reading reviews of Catherine's Palace and it definitely deserves that description. As part of a tour group, we dutifully herded through the rooms, while being watched by stern-faced women who ensure you stay in line plus keep moving. The crowds here are immense, however, you'll still get a good look at the paintings, furniture, decor and slightly fading grandeur of this amazing Palace. You'll see so much that you may want to take an abundance of pictures just so you can sit and enjoy them in comfort at home. Hint: If you are in a group do not lose your companions as you will have a difficult time finding them again in the crowds.

Very glad I went, wish we knew what the restoration cost?. I was more impressed with the main mirrored room than the Amber room, but then I love mirrors, take time to look at the photographs of the destruction that took place! The restoration is simply superb. Long queues I am afraid but some free wifi.
Huge gardens, probably not one for the children

Such opulence!. Clearly Catherine never heard the adage: Less is more. In her world, MORE is more. Grand rooms are adorned with frescos, jewels, gold leaf, intargia, mirrors, delft and intricate inlaid wood floors. The gardens are vast and beautiful. This palace is magnificent and worth a visit.

Catherine's palace. The only thing we wished we had enough of is more time! The palace shows the opulence of the royalty at the time. As you go from one room to the next you see more art and more gold! It's not just the gold, it's the art, it's the building itself. It would probably cost billions to reproduce it today. The outside gardens and fountains are something to behold. This was one of the highlights of our tour.

WOW!!. She went over the top copying European palaces! Her hall of mirrors tops Versailles! Amber room is something to behold. What the Russians accomplished in remaking this palace from the ruins that the Nazis left it in is a true testament to the people's devotion to their history & culture. Not to miss!!

Extremely impressive restoration work done. The beauty and opulence of the palaces and grounds are simply amazing. The craftsmanship and work done to restore the WW11 damage is outstanding . Very thrilling to be able to go back 250 years and visit the Romanoff's lifestyle.

WOW. We visited the palace whilst on a Baltic cruise and the whole time we spent at this place I personally was astounded at the shear grandular of the whole palace including the grounds , The tour was a cruise organised one and was very well planned I personally don't go for churches and places like this but as you don't go to Russia every day I thought why not and I must say I was gob smacked , gold everywhere , architecture, paintings , wooden floors etc just amazing I can't explain how it looks so go yourself you will not be disappointed,
good but busy. This palace is amazing but it's crowded - like everything else in St Petersburg! Don't let it deter you, but go in prepared.

Out of this world. This palace is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen! The richness and display of gold is unbelievable. The display of riches reinstated after the second world wars distraction by the German 900 days of siege of St Petrsburg is beyond the imagination.

Simply Stunning. I have read about the siege of Leningrad and how this historic landmark was looted and destroyed by the German Army. I am amazed at the wonderful job that the Russians have accomplished restoring this palace to its original beauty! This palace is absolutely breathtaking from the first time you see it through the trees! There is a lot of walking involved so wear comfortable shoes. I only wish that we could see more of the living areas so we could appreciate how the royalty actually lived. We see more of the assembly halls and the visitor's halls but little furniture. Be sure you spend some time in the extensive gardens. It was a beautiful day and walking through the shaded paths and viewing the various lakes and bathhouses was very relaxing. Also, there were musicians and singers everywhere! What a wonderful trip and a great opportunity!
must see. A wonderful building, opulence at it's highest! You really can't miss this place!! Very busy but loads to see. As impressive as al the photos suggest.

Beautiful. I always wondered about Catherine's Palace and the Amber room. It was an amazing experience to visit here, and learn of the history - not only the original history but the WWII history causing it to be rebuilt after the war.

A Must See Attraction!. The palace is spectacular and a must see in St. Petersburg. The rooms are reflective of the time period and grandeur of the royal family. The gardens are remarkable as well and are kept trim, neat, and lush. Don't buy the coffee from the coffee cart outside the palace. A small 2 oz. cup was $3! I think she made up the price while we were waiting there.

Very impressive. How can one describe a palace so grand that it defies description.When touring the grounds and all of the rooms available one can only be awestruck by the wealth of the royalty that built and lived in this kind of luxury while the peasants were literally starving.

Try to get Early Opening Access Tour. We were fortunate to pick a tour on our Silversea cruise that arranged early opening at Catherine's Palace , lunch at a traditional Russian log barn with entertainment and a couple of hours in the Hermitage.Early opening made the trip to Catherine's Palace a magical experience as we were not rushed and jostled by people walking across the courtyard with only our own bus companions allowed for the taking of decent Photos without arms , legs and hair of others obstructing the view. You could hear the guide explain special features in various rooms and gave us time to linger longer exploring the beautiful gardens - it was only starting to get crowded as we left the Palace precinct - highly recommended beautiful palace and gardens both worth exploring

Absolutely Stunning. Catherine Palace and Park is stunning. The grounds are as beautiful as any in the world, and the buildings match the grandeur. Each room is breathtaking -- the ceilings, the molding, the walls, the floors. And everything is covered in GOLD! Amazing.

St. Petersburg, May15. A must see on your trip to St. Petersburg. Besides the wait, the only downer was the time and crowds. Every room of the palace was enchanting and exciting to visit. The gardens should be walked and if permitted, take your time..

Palace and Garderns. The building is a truly magnigicent structure whilst the interior is filled with period decoration, paintings and furniture, The Great Hall, The Amber Room, The Cameron Galery,The great staircase,is just peep of what is there to see

A most impressive palace.. The palace, and the surrounding park are really impressive, and most important is the reconstruction effort after the war. The fountain designer was hired from France, therefore the fountains are the same caliber as those in Versailles.

The other half of the Romanov experience. The Catherine palace is the summer palace of the Romanovs, which despite its name was actually beautified by the czarina Elizabeth, then used by Catherine the Great. It was destroyed utterly in WWII after being occupied by the Nazis and the Amber room looted, but since then has been completely restored with modern materials. The Amber room now has 400 colors of Amber adorning the walls. An appreciation of the imperial glory of Russia would not be complete without seeing the Catherine palace soon after seeing the winter palace in St Petersburg. TIP: it opens at 10 and is like the Versailles of Russia. Go early or book early. I would get a guide from St Petersburg for the whole trip to Pushkin, as there are other sites to visit.

Beautiful. So much to see, the gardens are spectacular . The fountains are beautiful and lots of them ! I would have loved more time here but there is so much to see in Saint Petersburg .A very impressive place to visit.

Some tips on how to get there. It is of course an unmissable attraction and many visitors would say it is more beautiful than Versailles, if not as large. There are very many visitors everyday all day as you would expect but because of the way they organise things, the crowd is not overwhelming. This means however that you cannot visit before noon unless you are with a tour group. And you cannot visit the park before you visit the palace. You can save some time also by buying tickets online in advance.Getting there is easy as the mashrutkis are well used to tourists. Go to Moskovskaya metro station which is NOT to be confused with Moskovskaya railway station. After exiting the station look for big statue of Lenin in a big square, go behind Lenin. among others, mashrutkis numbers 342, 545 go to Pushkin. They have a big sign in the window saying Pushkin but it's in cyrillic if you are not sure just ask the driver "Pushkin?". Chances are the driver would shout "pushkin!" at anyone walking near his bus that looks like a tourist. Hop on the bus, pay the driver the flat fare which is posted inside the bus. It will be fairly obvious when to get off, or just ask the driver. He won't know hardly any English but he knows where most tourists want to get off.If you go in the morning, a good plan would be to go beyond Pushkin and get off at Pavlovtsk where you can spend the morning wandering around the palace and park there. Get back on the same bus to go to Catherine palace for noon or later.
Superb. Superb rebuild despite the lack of furniture (used as fuel by the occupying forces in the Battle of Leningrad). Marred only by the crowds of tourists and the miserable attitude of the staff.

Wow, what opulence!!. One cannot believe the opulence in this Palace. First of all the place is huge, the building seems to go on forever! Each room is adorned in gold, gold and more gold, even the minarets outside are gold domed. You have to wear "medical style booties" over your shoes to preserve the floor.
