All the lighting is chandelier form with candles (don't forget this was before electricity). She used candles, mirrors and gold to achieve the over the top effect in all the rooms of the palace. It's jaw dropping …… a must see!!!
As advertised, a classic. Nice tour, not too crowded and a spectacular place to spend 2 hours. Worth doing the tour and amazing views all over he place

Luxurious and beautiful. This park is well-groomed and shining, there you can see luxury and glitter of the Russian empire. It's big so you can easily spend the whole day walking around there. The palace is to my mind one of the most beautiful St.P. suburbian palaces. There is the famous Amber chamber.Note, you should buy two separate tickets to the park and to the palace. When booking offices are closed, in summer it is after 7 pm, you can enter the park free of charge. The park is open till 11 pm. May be it's the best time to see the park if you are not going to visit the museum, cause in summer it is always crowded and there are big lines to the booking offices.

Worth a visit. This is one of the worlds best museums - and its story is also amazing. - the staff are very helpful under trying conditions as many Chinese tour groups disregard instructions and insist on taking pictures in rooms where it is not allowed - but this is a problem everywhere so I won't dwell on Chiniese Tour groups except to say that they are a handful and the staff did their best under very trying circumstances to control them - it makes it unenjoyable when there is one rule for all but one group constantly disobeys, are so loud and make it uncomfortable for everyone else in the room, place or Restruant - the staff do their best to make everyone comfortable - I hope they can stay that way :). They must all be saints!This is a must and you need to see it and hear it's story of survivalOn a 1 to 10 scale of world museums - this is a 8

Elegant to the core!. Just standing in this palace was like living in Russia in 1915, when Alexandra Feodorvna was alive and throwing grand balls, I recommend this place for curious people, and people who love fine art!

Magic but tricky getting there and back. We think the best of the palaces and second best of the parks (Peterhof for the parks). The metro to get half way there was straightforward so long as you counted the stops along the way (few signs and no one speaking English). Next stage by taxi-bus - difficult to find the bus which took about an hour to get to the palace. Coming back, again it was difficult finding the bus but we got there in the end!

An over the top gold encrusted palace.. The palace was magnificent both from the outside, where the gold statues of Atlas supporting the building had been painted over because the Tsarina considered it too bright and the huge interiors where the gold was not spared. You will see the antechambers, throne room ,dining rooms and smaller more intimate reception and living rooms. A must when visiting St Petersburg.

Wonderful and lots to see. Catherine's Palace was 1 of the stops on our 2 day private tour in May/15 with TJ Travel in May /15. Wonderful visit to the palace. The Amber room had to be re-created in recent years to replace missing amber. Visitors put on cloth booties over their shoes so as not to damage the floors. A little slippery but ok. The Palace is a little way out of the city (less than an hour) . Take 2 cameras - lots of pictures to take. The view of the palace from the outside is stupendous - it is so huge. Our tour guide, Anna, was so informative - we could not have asked for better. We were on a private tour which we booked ourselves by contacting TJ Travel. Sometimes travellers to St. Petersburg are not aware that they either have to book a private tour,go on the ship tour, or apply for their own visas to visit Russia. With a private tour, or ship tour, you are on a blanket visa.
Not to be missed. Easy to get to by train, though probably essential to book a tour in the busy season - the only way to guarantee entry to the palace. The garden is impressive.

100% Go Here. If you're on a cruise of in St. Petersburg, this then should be on your list of places to go. It's a 40 minutes bus ride away from the central districts on a tour, but the time in traduce is worth it to see the stunning golden ornamentations that permeate the interior of the palace. Reconstructed after World War II, the rooms in the palace are unique in their decoration, filled with delft-blue fixtures, walls of amber, and portraits of old Russian Royalty. The lines will get long in the afternoon, so make sure to get their early!

Always wanted to visit and it did not disappoint. Catherine Palace is one place I have always wanted to visit and I was not disappointed. You can stand at one end of the palace and look down a very ornate corridor 1 kilometre long, with gold leaf all the way.The Amber Room is something you must see, it is so interesting.The gardens are set up in 2 styles. Formal on one side and open landscape, the other. With man made lakes and islands.

ARE YOUR CAMERAS READY?. This is a huge place. Make sure you hit the water closet (toilets) before hitting the walk at Catherine's Palace (with the Amber Room) and the long walk in the Tsar's Village. We saw this on the second day tour due to some museums being closed on certain days. Make sure you check your schedules. The rooms are overwhelming! Get your video cameras and cameras ready!
Don't Miss It. More impressive, I thought, than Versailles but not as big. Beautiful inside and out. Fantastic, well-maintained gardens and grounds. A must see while in St Pete.
Truely Remarkable!. It is hard to fathom the incredible wealth that was concentrated in the Aristocracy of Russia. It is hard to imagine the type of parties that must have occurred here.
WOW. Oh my! I was speechless. The decoration of the huge rooms and the ballrooms in gold. I do not have any words to describe only "wow"! It has to be seen. I have seen but i want to visit it again.

Don't miss it!. No visit to St. Petersburg would be complete without a trip to the Catherine Palace at Pushkin. The Palace is almost unbelievably beautiful. The restoration work on this palace is amazing. The Amber Room will leave you breathless.
The Rich & Famous. It is beyond belief that such grandeur could be created over many years just to satisfy the whims of an individual. The rift between the rich & poor must have been enormous
Summer Palace. So much rich history, combined with exquisite detailing. The work done to restore what World War II damaged is amazing. It is rather mind blowing what the 14 carat gold is!!

WOW!. this was just amazing! The gold all over the palace, the beautiful furniture pieces, the ostentatious decor - a true picture of royalty. We toured with ALLA Tours and enjoyed individual attention from our knowledgeable guide.
Amazing Indulgence. What extravagance under one roof. Wow is all I can say, it is a beautiful place but not sure if all this was really needed.

Amazing palace - better than Versaille!. The interior of this palace is, in my opinion, more spectacular than Versaille. It is amazing and - at least when we were there - the crowds were very manageable. Don't miss it.

Supberb attraction. This was a highlight of our trip - phenomenal Catherine's Palace. Conceived by Peter the Great for his wife Catherine I (not "the Great") and completed in 1756, the structure is a massive half mile in circumference. Its baroque Grand Hall, known as the "Hall of Light" for its gold covered candlesticks, mirrors and filigree, measures 130,000 square feet (3 acres)! A must see

Unless you are prebooked with a tourist party AVOID THIS LIKE THE PLAGUE. If you are as daft as we were, thinking you do not need a guide and you can just go there yourself and enjoy it, you will not have the chance of enjoying this beautiful palace and grounds. It takes up to two hours to get there going on the Metro to Moskovskaya then walking out some distance to the right to catch a slow bus. If you also plan to have an evening out in St P that same day, then forget it. We arrived at 11:45 and the ticket lady said 'twelve o'clock'. Unfortunately the ticket showed we could enter the Palace only after 14:00, which was too late for us as we were going to a concert the same evening in St P so we ended up having a nice walk in the park then giving away our tickets to some lucky Russians in the ticket queue as we left. Frankly there is not enough adequate information for tourists who just arrive innocently there expecting to visit the palace. Surprising, because in general St P is splendid or English speaking tourists.. ONLY TAKE THIS TRIP WITH A GUIDED TOUR otherwise you are at the mercy of the unexpected. Most people going there were Russians. I would have loved to see the last residence of Tsar Nicholas II, the other palace there, called the Alexander Palace, far more interesting for a british monarchist following the 'family history', however although this appears in the local photographic guide it is sorely and disappointingly under represented on the ground. By the time we had had to wait around and there was nobody to tell us how long the tour takes inside the palace, we had to leave feeling pretty depressed and useless back to St P and did not even see that palace.

picture perfect and so much history here!. We were on a cruise so took the tour through princess for this and peterhopf palace. We took a lot of pictures and had lunch on the grounds. It was very beautiful and at lunch there was a short show of singers who pulled people up to dance with them. The food was okay, not too heavy and traditional Russian. But there were a lot of us and we were crammed tight with one extra person on our table of 13! I think we got to see a little more because we were with this tour. There were some more grounds but we had to leave. The palace is astoundingly beautiful!
Amber room is the highlight of my trip!. try NOT to be in a tour, and go self guided with audio tour.. then you can spend as much time as you wish inside... especially the amber room.
Nice walk. The Amber room what can you say about something so impressive, that alone is worth the trip. The grounds are very nice and a great walk around the lake
Wealth beyond belief - staggering. . So worth a visit and tour. You have never seen more gold leaf in your life. Fascinating history. Immense palace and gardens. Loved it!

Catherine Palace. We had two-days in St. Petersburg and this was well worth the time! The palace is beautiful and our guide (Alla Tours) provided so much history that the rooms seemed to come to life!

A jewelry box. Definitely a womans house. Very grand palace. A lot of gold, more mirrors, paintings of men, and an amber room. It is about 1200-1300 by taxi, 30 minutes from the city in Pushkin. The gardens open about 10, the palace opens at 12. Your tickets are for a set time time. A tip, all Russian museums start at the toilets.

Beatiful beyond imagination. We used "Best Guides" tour company in St. Petersburg. They took care of our travel visa! This place is unimaginably beautiful. I wish we had more time to sit back and soak it in!

Nice palace but really far from the city center. This is a very nice palace, as many other palaces built in the same period, many of the rooms are painted gold with lots of artifacts, sculptures and paintings . However, having been to Peterhof and Hermitage, this palace is just another palace to me. It's so far away from the city and the public transportation to this place is so complicated, i wouldn't recommend people going.Don't take me wrong, it's still a very beautiful palace.

disappointing after the Winter Palace. For a trip out of St Petersburg, we preferred Peterhof to Catherine Palace. It is very impressive but unfortunately very little of the interior is original as there was a great amount of damage during WW2.

opulence and amber. Beautiful, opulent, gilded, intricate inlaid wood floors, antique furniture and clocks. And...the Amber room. The room is about 25X25 ft. 3 walls are panels of intricate amber art work. Originally a gift from the King of Prussia to Peter the Great. The amber gives the room a sunny feel with the light shinning in from the windows on the 4th wall, probably a welcome sight in wet and dreary St petersburg. Although this is not the original, as it disappeared in WWII, it is a true copy and took 20 years to recreate. Parts of this palace were destroyed in WWII, but have been restored. Understandable it was very crowded, but really you must see Catherines palace. It was about an hours bus ride from St Petersburg

Catherine Palace and Park- A striking beauty that blows your mind. Catherine Palace is a Rococo palace located in the town of Tsarskoye Selo (Pushkin), 25 km southeast of St. Petersburg, Russia. It was the summer residence of the Russian tsars.The beauty of this place with golden halls, statues, beautiful park and the lake will completely blow your mind, besides you will be able to see the infamous Amber Room that was completely recreated in 2003. It was originally constructed in the 18th century in Prussia, the Amber Room disappeared during World War II. Before the room was lost, it was considered an "Eighth Wonder of the World".I was really impressed with the golden ballroom of the Palace as well as Park itself. I also purchased souvenirs: an amber ring as well as tin soldiers of world war I for my husband on the small market next to the Palace before going back to the bus. Little tip- it's cheaper to buy on this market rather then in the Palace itself. Excursion lasted 6 hours and we travelled by bus from Saint Petersburg and back. I booked it in advance through Ecletica Tour.
Shine bright. It is magnificant, each room is so beautiful. The amber room is out of this world.The shops are expensive and they mostly sell amber stuff.
Got to see it to believe it. Awesome and very elegant. What luxury in one place. Excellent decorations, furniture and chandeliers to mention some of what you will see.Do not miss it
Catherine Palace, just beautiful. A great place to visit, very pretty inside and out. Be prepared to place items in the cloak room such as backpacks, large bags, umbrellas and coats.

Innovation of 17th century - Bricks & tiles heater. 40 mins from the centre of St. Petersburg lies the grandeur of the Pushkin Catherine Palace.Greeted by a military band playing live music, we walked into the summer residence of Russian Tsars. I loved the fact that even though the facade was covered in gold, because it was painted in blue, it didn't look as glitzy as many of the other palaces. This 17th century palace was named Pushkin after a nobleman of that era. I especially liked the grand halls, where many famous dinner parties have taken place. The one structure that looked out of place was the heater - the blue tiles over the glitzy golden decoration in every room suggested that they were there for a good reason. Wood was burnt in the furnace and the brick and tiles reflected the heat and warmed the entire room - a great way to keep warm in the cold winters for Catherine I and other royalty.The amber room is no doubt the highlight. Almost everything was covered in amber. Although the original set was stolen during the World War II, they were later restored.The garden was cozy with a pavillion and a pond, however not as grand as many other palaces. We were told that Catherine I preferred to keep it simple as she could enjoy the many fountains in the Peterhof palace.

Spend a Beautiful Day Here. Catherine Palace is not quite as beautiful as Peterhoff, but it does have the flamboyantly Rococo Amber Room and a beautiful surrounding park. It is a pleasant walk around the lake, where there is an exquisite Turkish bath at the far end, and the Admiralty buildings on the south side which house a restaurant and a bakery. There are interesting pavilions in the park and you will want to read-up on them and plan your visit so you don't miss anything.

Another Must See in St Petersburg. when visiting St Petersburg, there are several palaces, churches and museums that are must sees and this is definitely one of them. It has a long stunning facade adorned in light blue gold and white. Interior staterooms include the grand throne room, state dining room, the amber room (no pictures), the blue drawing room and much more. After the interior tour, explore the vast gardens, pavilions and lake. If you are lucky you will be serenaded by a Russian quartet or other musical group. Place does get very crowded so arrive early.

Lovely details. Well worth the stop. Very detailed work inside in each of the rooms displaying art and ornate craftsmanship. Only complaint is that you are not allowed to take any photos in the amber room; apparently they do not trust that tourists will turn off the flash on the cameras and will ruin the amber... Still very pretty to experience though.

A must do if you are in St Petersburg. Unbelievable to think that this was how the Russian royal family lived. This is a palace on a grand scale that just got more extravagant as you went from one room to the next. And an amazing job of restoration since the inside was destroyed during the revolution. Amber room is a worko of art in its own right.
Amazing well worth a visit. Worth the journey.A beautiful Palace in lovely gardens.We went on the trip with Alla tours.The fountains and gardens were wonderful.

Another must do. We did this tour as a couple with a guide. Travel time by car from central St Petersburg about 45-50 minutes. Bigger groups are managed at entry to avoid total chaos at coat and bag checks plus control the number of people in rooms at any one time. As a result, large groups must wait their turn whereas small parties can go in much quicker. I imagine having a private guide is a great time saver in summer. The other advantage of a small group is being able to slot between and around some of the bigger groups as you travel through the palace rooms. Tour groups are constantly jostling each other for photos. You need to make a decision between a comfortable time effective experience and the extra expense of your own guide. Majority of rooms are lavishly decorated in gold and with original or replica pieces of furniture from the period. We spent around 1.25-1.5 hours inside the palace then a similar time casually strolling the gardens while viewing the lake and numerous buildings. Many large groups may only spend a short time in the gardens, mostly at the upper level. If planning to go self guided, check specified entry times for individuals as we were told there are specific time slots for tour groups and local and foreign visitors on their own. Overall need to allow at least 5 hours for travel and sightseeing.

Beautiful Palace. This was an impressive palace. So much gold gilded walls in every room. The palace also had a large park and gardens. We saw some singers perform inside one of the buildings on the palace grounds. Unfortunately the gardens weren't in bloom yet, but I can only imagine they will be beautiful. We ate at the restaurant at the palace and got to sample champagne, vodka and caviar. The palace is outside the city in the town of Pushkin. It was nice to see some of the Russian countryside. We even saw on the way back Vladimir Putin's summer home.

Lots of History, needs to be Preserved. This is one among many palaces in St Petersburg and is a real tourist spot. Crowds/tours abound and the rooms are sparsely furnished. After view many of them, it becomes repetitive. The carriage that Catherine rode in on the way to her marriage is remarkably preserved, sits in a room in the palace yet looks small in relation to the size of this hall!Security is poor, little babushka ladies in their kerchiefs and housedresses sit in the corners of each room to make sure you stay within the lanes of traffic (strung with normal string). Shooing tourists into the center of the lanes when you get too close to the edge

Go in the Spring!. My favorite part of the palace and park was the park. We were there early May and the trees were just leafing out. The walk through the park was wonderful. The palace is 'cosy' or feels that way since many rooms, including the church, are yet to be restored and open to the public.

Beautiful Palace and Park. This palace is just beautiful the gold Baroque rooms are stunning and the workmanship is fantastic, it is really amazing the amount of history attached to these buildings, it is such a beautiful place it has to be seen I cannot really describe the beauty of the buildings. We topped our visit off with a carriage ride around the park it's just the best way to get a view of have lovely the whole place is and what is more we had sunshine all through our visit
Lavish Palace. We really enjoyed waling through the palace. The gold is everywhere. It is really just what you imaging when you think of a palace.
Wow!. Such an amazing place to visit. Very much enjoyed the opportunity to see this wonderful site and I can appreciate why the Russians are so proud of this marvel.

Amazing. This is such an amazing building and to be able to see the history here now is mind blowing .
What a fantastic experience

Great spot to stroll and relax. This historic place is a wonderful spot to enjoy a lovely sunny day which is a bit rare in st petersburg as I hear only about 40 days per year meet that bill but apparently I had gotten several during my stay here. It is near the winter palAce and was laid out with care and has beautiful vistas to appreciate. Lovely spot to go.

Imperial Elegance at its best. My first introduction to the Catherine Palace was when I read a book on the Tsars of Russia. It was just after the fall of communism and the world in particular my generation were being introduced to the architectural beauties that lay behind the Iron Curtin for more than 70 years. I was captivated by this picture of this massive blue building with gold tops glistening in the white snow. I made it my ambition to one day visit this place and see it for myself. And that I did! I have been to the Catherine Palace twice in three years and both times it has never failed to blow me away. Whether it be the golden onion domes of the Palace church that greets you as walk towards the complex or the striking blue and gold facade with its imposing statues that mystically lift the palace up from the ground - this Palace will not disappoint. The gardens are immaculate and contain some stunning buildings, bridges and lakes that are scattered throughout. The Hermitage Building and the Turkish Bathhouse were my favorites. The interior of the palace suffered some damage during the second World War including the removal of the famous Amber Room. However, this room has been restored and you are left breathless as you marvel at the intricate detail and fine craftsmanship.The one thing I loved about the Catherine Palace was that the crowds were not as big as they are for places like Versailles or Neuschwanstein. This allowed a little bit of breathing space and created a relaxed visit. Getting to the Palace is easy. We caught a bus from outside the University in St Petersburg. Getting back to the main city is a little trickier if your Russian is not that good. I would suggest getting the Train from Pushkin back into the main city. I would suggest that you double check with your hotel concierge in regards to the best way to get to the palace. I have to say that although I love Versailles, the Catherine Palace is the most amazing Palace I have ever been to and really showcased Imperial Elegance at its best!
Nice. The palace is great and must visit for tourists. Entry tickets are to be purchased to enter this Palace.

Not so good experience. Visited the palace and park today - long q's to buy tickets - entry into the palace is time based and I had to "kill" 2:30 before I was allowed entry only to be informed there no English audio guides - so walked through a couple of rooms with lots of gold..... extremely boring and not at all what I expected - would not recommended you go all the way out there if you have limited time in St P

“Two Day Highlights of St. Petersburg”. Catherine's Palace is magnificent and a MUST for any visitor to St. Petersburg. The interior is dazzling and allow as much time as possible to view this splendid building. Considering that it was bombed in the war and has been rebuilt in the original style is amazing. The Amber Room was only completed in 2003 - it was destroyed and it's whereabouts have never been found. The amount of gold used to decorate the palace is unbelievable - I've never seen anything like it before and I've been to a lot of ornate buildings in different countries. A full day could easily be spent here but a minimum of 2 - 3 hours.

Awe inspiring!. What a gorgeous and tragic place. Gorgeous in that renovations and recreation has enabled future generations to get a glimpse of the opulence the royalty lived with daily. There are gilded mirrors, painted ceilings, recreated dining areas and so much more. The tragedy of the loss of the originals is heartbreaking. There were quite a few tour groups going through when I was there. Since it wasn't peak season I can only imagine that it must get quite crowded during that time. I was very warm walking through, they have a coat and bag check if you are cold natured like me you will b just fine without covering. You can take photos in all but the Amber Room, which is quite stunning. The grounds are amazing and there were several wedding parties there for pictures. You can also pay to have your picture taken with a couple dressed in period garments. You and the royal couple, how fun is that! There is a lot to c and a lot of walking so wear comfy shoes.

Bling by the bucket load. When you see the fabulous wealth on show in this place you really do understand why there was a revolution. The amber room is really over the top and on a sunny day you really will be dazzled by the mirrors and light. There is a good cafe near the road

Great palace area. It is very interesting to visit the palace area of Russia Empire, where also the great poet has lived where also is his lyceum
There is also the nice Amber Chamber which the Germans have brought 1940`s and
where Mr Schröder has helped in restauration
You can easily bay a tour in front of Gastiny Dvor :1200 Rubl/ 5 hours

Good, but not as good as Peterhof. Definitely worth your time, if you have the time. If you have to choose between the Peterhof and Catherine, Peterhof is much more impressive. There are better buildings to visit inside St Petersburg itself as well - the Stroganov and Sheremetev. Not difficult to get to Catherine using the metro line to Moskovskaya Metro Station, then taking a minivan/bus 342 or 545 to the Palace (about 35 Rubles for the minivan). Our hotel advertised this trip at 3,000 Rubles. Gardens are nice.

Imperial style palace!. It's one of the must sees if you are in St.Petersburg. Catherine Palace in Tsarskoye Selo is one of the most beautiful Royal residences in the world, believed by some to house the eighth wonder of the world - famous Amber room bedecked with authentic Russian amber from floor to ceiling. The opulent golden layering in every hall will quite astonish you.It's a very popular destination and therefore in summer it's crowded. If you an independent tourist it's probably better to come after 15.00, though you should know that they stop letting people in at 16.45. It closes at 18.00.The best time to come is Monday, when Catherine palace is open until 21.00 (they stop letting people in at 18.45)Closed on Monday and the last Tuesday of each month (except for summer period)
Go with a guide. Opulence to spare. The trip out there from St. P. affords a great view of the suburbs and Soviet style housing blocks. Huge does not describe. go with a guide if you can.

Wonderful ........ The wonderful interior is quite incredible particularly when you see pictures of the devastation that was left in the war years. The restoration work is amazing and it is well worth the visit. We left St Petersburg at 9am to do the Palace before taking the 3.55pm plane to London and the timings worked very well. The gardens are not in full bloom, obviously in April, but you can imagine how glorious it would be later in the year with the rose beds.

Delightful excursion. We visited Tsarskoye Selo with a guide, only an hour's drive from St Pete and well worth the trip. The palace is beautiful and a stroll in the gardens and on the lake (frozen in March) gave us a sense of what it was to live in this capital in the countryside.

Grand, in the absolute meaning of the word. All i can say is Grand, it was the most spectacular palace i have ever seen.If you want to know who the Tzars were you will see it here.If you want to know the meaning of the grandure you will see it here.If you want to know how the elite of the elite in the world lived you will see it here

Extravagant. Catherine Palace and Park is located in the picturesque and quiet city of Pushkin, about 30 minutes from St Petersburg. The blue and white facade of the palace is adorned with gold details. There is an entrance fee for the palace/museum. Before ascending the stairs, you are required to put on a shoe cover, to protect the floor of the palace. Once set, you then visit the large ballroom and other smaller rooms like dining halls, drawing rooms with gold as the predominant decor. Each and every room dazzles with extravagance. Photography is allowed except at the Amber Room, a drawing room decorated with gold and amber. Outside the Palace is a relaxing park with a big pond and landscaped gardens. This place is worth a visit for the opulence of the palace and the history associated with it.

Visit in april 2015. we visit in sunny day even the weather was 5 celsus :) . it is around 45-60 minutes from moskoyevski train station . we get minibüs ( i remember 565 ) and paid 35 ruble / pp. you again pass the Petersburg airport and it is in a small town. it has very big garden with frozen lakes and pools . the outside worths to see and also isnde the palace is nice area . it is around 2 hours you finish the visit. there is restaurant with russiand food but i didint try . ourside the palace , there was a shopping square with stands and kaffes and eating points.

Blustery Day but Beautiful Grounds. We had a wonderful private art historian guide who took us through the Palace and grounds on a cold blustery day. The guilded rooms and furnishings and of course The Amber Rooms were spectacular. We were so glad we had someone to shepherd us through the palace avoiding crowds and really getting to understand all of the historical significances of the palace. Do not miss it. A good stop on your way into the city from the airport.

Imperial taste. We don't know how to go and we decided call a taxi by hotel staff... well done it was very cold and not so expensive ( Official taxi company 1145 Rubles - Less than 20€ ) from Kazan Cathedral ( center ) about 40 Km.
Amazing building with the top in Ambra room
Back cheaper with small bus and metro
Park. Probably better visited in June or October so that you get the trees and plants in bloom or the colours of Autumn.

Beautiful palace. Hard to get there because it is located in the outskirts of city but DEFINITELY worth a visit.
The interior is to die for; magnificent, grand, artistic, baroque style. Love the concept of the chimneys and beautiful tiles.
And of course, the famous amber room is in this palace as well!

Great side trip especially on a Monday. If you are in St Petersburg on a Monday, many of the museums will be closed but not the Catherine Palace. It is well worth the 45 minute trip to the quiet town of Pushkin and the Catherine Palace and park. Be warned, there are a lot of tour groups who come here but it is still a great place to visit. The quality of the gift shops are high so this is a great place to buy good quality souvenirs.
Impressive. Place U must to see, nice and very impressive. Big palace with nice rooms and wide park. cca 25 km from city in Puskhin city.

Far from the city but it worths!!!. We took the public transportation to get there!!! Pushkin Village is a magic place full of Palaces!!! Its really interesting!!!If you can afford it, take a tour guide with you to explain you all about this small village 1h from St. Petersburg!! We got the headset tour guide which is also an option and take our own walk in the Palace. The Amber room is the top spot in the Palace!! Take some time to walk around in the gardens close to the lake, you can do some nice pictures there!

^_^ great great palace and beautiful gardens!!!. oh, gosh! Can't imagine how people had been living in so huge palaces centuries ago) You even do'nt know how many room has your house) And these gardens..!!! It could be great to have an own one to relax there before and after work ;)
golden trims. The palace is beautiful. The details of the doorways (trims are highlighted in gold) is truly eye catching. Catherine must have thrown some awesome party with that huge ballroom!

A very feminin place. Not only because of the colors, soft, pastell, but also because of the small, cosy rooms, as when compared to the winter palass. And the ball hall, just amazing, rows of windows on each side, looking out to the garden on both sides, simply fantastic. The amber room, you say? Well, that is nice too, but I was more impressed by the row of "small" golden rooms. and the garden and its many buidings, simply like a dream. It makes you realize the Romanov family made more beautiful buildings than any other dynasty in the history of mankind (correct me if I am wrong, but not after you have seen all the palasses in St Peteresburg, St Petershof and Pavlov)

Top Palace to see. It was such an amazing and a beautiful place that I really liked. Architecture impressed me the most I took over 50 pictures there, if you ever get a chance to go there then don't miss your chance!

Beautiful Palace and grounds. An amazing story of reconstruction and restoration after being almost totally destroyed in the war. The rooms in the palace are amazing! Even the floors are works of art. The grounds are beautiful, with lots to see as well. We were lucky in being between large groups, so we got a great view of each room.

Summer Palace. A very elegant structure very well preserved. At least the reception rooms, the living rooms and the dining rooms we were permitted to see since many rooms were closed for renovations. Highlight of the palace the Amber Room! (photos not allowed).According to our guide in these palaces bedrooms are not shown since they were quite simple and small in order to be warm. Surrounded by a vast park which should be delightful to walk through in Autumn!

One of the most beautiful palaces in the world!. This small Swedish nobleman's mansion was presented to Peter I and his wife Catherine Alexeevna in June 13, 1710. In the reign of Elizabeth, the ‘Tsarskoye Selo’ (Tsar’s village) was regarded as the imperial residence. Later, Catherine I rebuilt this modest palace under the direction of architect Rastrelli into a luxurious summer residence. In 1808, the residence increased in size and was proclaimed a town. During the Second World War the Throne Room and several buildings of the palace were badly damaged and looted, many treasures and artworks disappeared, like the famous Amber Room. Nowadays, the Catherine Palace and the surrounding park look as if time has stood still, due to considerable investments in its reconstruction. With the opening after the reconstruction the palace again hit all its splendor with the recreated Amber Room, the Throne Room, Ballroom and Arabesque Hall.

This is a Definite Must-Do. The palace is about 40 kilometres from the city but well worth the drive. It is almost indescribable. The place consists of room after room of amazingly beautiful furniture, paintings, ceiling, chandeliers, wallpaper. We were told that they used more that 100 kilograms of gold in this palace so everything that can be gilded is. The amber room is beyond description - make sure to find out some of the history of the room. Also, you are not allowed to take pictures in the room and there are very stern guards watching to make sure you do not even try.The grounds are equally spectacular - full of manicured lawns, trees, bushes, rose gardens, flower beds, statues and fountains. In one corner of the park, we discovered a little cottage where a group of men sing beautiful songs in an acoustically superior room. The sound was amazing. A wonderful place to visit.

Lovely - perfect visit on way to airport. Very grand, but with only 12 rooms open. The Amber room is jaw dropping! Undergoing renovations, so not for anyone with mobility issues as you need to be able to walk up two flights of stairs. Also, very crowded (this was off season on at Saturday) and very hot inside.

Don't miss a visit here!. Catherine Palace is in Pushkin about 16miles South of St.Petersburg. Best to get a taxi as it's so much quicker and not that expensive. The Palce is wonderful - in fact quite breath-taking inside. Worth going there just to see the famous Amber Room - recently restored at enormous expense!

Wonderful dinner and tour at the Palace. We were on a Baltic cruise with a two night stay in St Petersburg. We had the chance to have dinner and tour the palace one of those nights. It was a fantastic evening. We toured the carriage house, where there were some amazingly elaborate carriages. We also toured the house and because we were a smaller private group, we were allowed to stay in the Amber room as long as we wanted and we were able to take pictures. Normally you have to do a slow shuffle through the palace rooms. (You are not allowed to stop, so the guide tells you to slowly shuffle along or one of the russian guards will yell at you!) There was a guard in the room with us, but she couldn't stop us from taking pictures. It was very apparent she didn't like what we were allowed to do. It was a wonderful opportunity to tour the palace without all the crowds.

Catherine 1st was Peter's 2nd wife, Elizabeth 1st was his daughter & Catherine 11 was Elizabeth's daughter in Law.. I am sure that these 3 Empresses would love to cue up with the other tourists to see what their Palace looks like today, because none of them ever saw it finished. And for 3 years the German solders in WW 2 did their up most to turn it into ashes; as did the fire in 1820. This should be called the 'Restoration Palace', for work continues today - the 'original' shape of the main staircase, for example, has yet to be built.Only a humble 325 metres long I just love the combination of light blue, dark blue, white and gold - it works beautifully; especially if you throw in 5 onion domes.Many, many Serfs died when building this, for they worked 24 - 7, to finish, - and torch-light at night is not the best to stop workers falling from high scaffolding. While I was taking in the Grand Hall, Peter the Great and Cathrine (in costume dress) approached me for a photo for 10 rubles, - they both looked so handsome I agreed - and now if you air-brush me out - I have a terrific photo. However, there are many empty rooms here!Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.
Catherine. This impressive building inside and out. With its impressive amber room. The palace should be on everyone's list when visiting St. Petersburg.

Possibly the best palace in the world - visit EARLY!. The Catherine Palace is an essential stop if you are visiting St Petersburg. There is only one time to go and that is EARLY to beat the crowds. We visited in February 2013 which is not peak season and were the first to enter with our private guide (very worthwhile if you are visiting Catherine Palace - we used Polina Volkova). We had the pleasure of being the first into many of the rooms so got some amazing photos. Eventually the crowd streams through and even in February you will find it crowded by mid-morning.The amber room is impressive, but it was the history shared by our guide that really made this an amazing visit. The palace was almost totally destroyed by the Germans in WW2 and there are some interesting photos from the time. For example, the Germans having taken Catherine Palace taking their own tourist shots, the palace after it was destroyed (no roof, walls blown apart, artwork looted or ruined), and even a photo of a bomb the size of a small truck meant to detonate after they left but which didn't go off.The destruction of Catherine Palace lead to a major restoration effort. At the time, there were limited people with the skills or experience to do the work. This resulted in the education and development of people in restoration work to the point St Petersburg is now renown for its skills in this field.The parklands are wonderful to stroll through, particularly in the beautiful snow. Allow plenty of time and this was a better place to visit that Peterhof if you are there in winter as Peterhof's fountains are all closed down.I've seen palaces throughout Europe (England, Spain, France, Italy) and nothing compares to Catherine Palace.
A very clean and large park. Really enjoyed the palace and park. The grounds were immaculate and gorgeous. Palace was in the original form. Tour guide followed me into the men's room. Would go again.

Amber chamber is more talked about that really is. We went there intrigued by legend of the 'amber chamber'. Looks cool in the picutures in the Internet. However, when you see it 'live' it may be not so impressive. Considering time to get there may be not the best decision if you are short of days.
Wow. Opulence, opulence and yet more opulence! The Amber Room is rightly world famous and totally unique. A delightful place to visit and highly recommended.

The Amber Room is worth the wait. This palace is grand. It was a delight to go through many rooms and finally see the Amber Room. It is a sad page of history that it had to be reconstructed, but I am glad to see what they have done.

A wonderful life experience !! Best palaces in the world, impressive !. a really nice place where you can see what power could achieve at that time, and all the world's best architecture at the time being applied in Catherine's palace. I advise to rent a car to go because it takes less time and is less costly. negative points: when i visited it was under reform and some rooms were not available to visit and the people inside do not speak English. Also since it was winter, the park was not as nice as in summer...

Palace by the Lake. In the UK we think that Buckingham Palace is impressive, the Catherine Palace makes it look like a weekend cottage !!!!A lot of Russian people and general tourist visit so is a bit crowded , the rooms are vast , and you see more gold on the walls , ceilings etc , and when you consider that it was destroyed and rebuilt after the 2nd World War to as it was before it is amazing, lots of newly weds use the rooms , stair cases for wedding photo's trying to hide the plastic over shoes you have to wear to protect the floors , the main room is still used for concerts and is about 300 foot long by a 150 feet wide, and a ceiling height of about 70 feet , which is painted with angels and cherubs , I gather that Elton John used the room for a concert and the piano had to be airlifted and come via the roof , with the ceiling painting rolled back at a cost of £1 million pounds for a 100 people to hear the concert.

Beautifully reconstructed.. This palace is a beautiful place to visit for an afternoon. The main ballroom is the highlight reminding me of the hall of mirrors at versaille except that it is newly restored and looks the way it would have in Catherine's eyes. I was there in winter and did not get much time to roam the gardens because of the cold, but can see how this would be a main attraction. The whole town is very quaint and only a short drive from St. Petersburg. It is well worth the visit.

france. Have you been to the french parks? this one is 10 times better. The palace is the best I have ever been to. Amber room worth seeing. It is not allowed to take any pictures in the room be careful. In the corner of the park next to the exit theres is a little cottage where choir sings songs. Ask your guide to visit it, it is amazing!

Tsarskoje Selo (the Village of The Tschar ). The city is called Pushkin where this Tchar's summer palace is located. It is 24 km from St. Petersburgh. There are actually two palaces, Catherina's Palace ( the turquise color ) and Alexander's Palace ( the brown one ). The Romanov Tschar Nikolai's family were taken fron this Palace to Jekateringburg and murdered there. Anyway the Catherinas palace is 300 m long and worth seeing. The Amber room is beautiful. This was winter time and there were no queues. On the other hand because of winter the beautiful garden was covered by snow.

Russian Emperor's Summer Residence. Massive construction which was destroyed during the 2nd. world war.Re-construction is on going and the Amber room is absolutely unique.Main ballroom has been beautifully decorated in Russian baroque style.

Worth the extra detour there & 4 € entrance fee. Beautiful palace and park. Well worth the extra detour there and the 4 € entrance fee. (Approx 15 minutes from the Airport). Bring your camera and prepare to take wonderful pictures with fulness of gold.

Catherine's Palace. The Amber room is a must! The entier palace is beautiful. You will need at least half day here. Pictures are allowed inside, which is a great plus! Only Amber room , no pics allowed.

Stunning Palace. A must to see, especially the Amber Room. We visted in perfect weather conditions with deep snow, blue skies and sunshine. The inside is fabulous but so is the parkland around it. We even had a troika ride around the estate. Everyone's dream of the Russia of Dr Shivago!
Worth the drive to get there. Out near Pushkin town the palace has been fully restored and is just wonderful. I would allow at least two hours to get through it.

Jewel box. Pushkin is at 2-3 hours drive from Petersburg.This is the most beautiful palace i have every visited. It was the summer residence of the Russian Tsars. It has rich lavish interiors all in Gold. Remarkable craftsmanship. More than 100 kilograms of gold were used in this palace. Walls, ceilings, furniture, doors and windows are all remarkable. It's tells the tale of the glorious and rich past of Russian monarch. The palace is moderately big. It has cathedral within. Also the parks surrounding the palace are beautiful full of trees, statues and roses.This palace was destroyed during world war 2 by Germans. Russians have put in a great deal to restore their heritage. It's a must to visit place. Make sure to find time to visit this Palace when ever you Visit St. Petersburg.We visited during summers i.e in June. The weather is weird, if you are out in sun it's burning hot and as you are in shade its really cool. Also we got pick pocketed during our visit and lost nearly all our money. :( So be cautious.

Stunning. We toured this Palace in the summer, and it was not too crowded. We began our tour by putting on shoe covers. That's when we knew we were going to see something magnificent! I must say that I have never seen anything like it!! The rooms were fabulous. The furniture was amazing, and the architecture was superb. Of course, the amber room was just simply beyond describable. The blue delft heaters were exquisite. The gardens were absolutely marvelous. It is so sprawling that it is pretty hard to take it all in. There was a band playing at the entrance when we arrived, and a flute player in the gardens where we ended the tour, a delightful touch. There were several weddings going on, and that was a pleasant sight. Visiting Catherine's Palace is a must on a visit to St Petersburg. Be prepared for being overwhelmed. It will take several hours to just hit the high points. Be sure to take some time to sit on a bench for a few minutes and just absorb the lovely surroundings. There were some carts serving drinks and snacks when we were there.

Beautiful. Room after room of amazingly beautiful sights. Gold everywhere. Stately design. Floors of beautifully inlaid woods. The whole palace was breathtaking. The Russians have done an excellent job of renovating and refurbishing this historic palace. Do not miss this.

So much Gold!. A fantastic venue that gives a real sense of the fashions of the time. The interior is kept in magnificent repair considering the quantity of visitors. They must have cornered the market in gold leaf. Very beautiful. The park is wonderful to stroll through

Go directly to the Alexander Palace. This was the favorite of the last czar and his family. There were no lines even when I visited in May. The Catherine Palace is impressive but not so personal as the Alexander Palace. I saw the Amber Room but thought it rather dreary. There is a pleasant cafeteria in the basement. And don't pass up the opportunity of a stroll in the wonderful gardens, for which there is no admission charge.

Beautiful Palace. As part of our two day tour, we visited Catherine's Palace and Park. Upon entry we walked in front of the palace and enjoyed the view. But once inside, I was blown away. The gold room was overwhelming. Walls of mirrors and window and gold everywhere. This woman lived in style. Our tour guide was great in giving us the history of this woman and the palace. We spent about 2 hours here.
Great Palace. When you walk around the palace, it is as if you were in the old times. Everything is preserved and well cared. Very beautiful.

I can only imagine how spectacular it is in the summer. This was fantastic to see even in the winter, despite it being difficult to navigate around the lake. I'm almost kicking myself for wanting to experience Russian winter because this would have probably been my number 1 favourite place if I came here in the summer.

A must. St Petersburg is one of the most beautiful cities in the world. Catherine the Great was a wonderful contributor to the arts and culture in Russia and this Palace is a testament to her. The gardens are spectacular and well maintained. Located about 40 mins out of St Petersburg, we had a tour guide with us, so they drove us there. So not sure how convenient the transport system is.

Amber Room. absolutely worth the day trip, but go on a guided tour in order to avoid the long wait lines. Intriguing history from both before and after WW2, after which it has been beautifully restored.

Worth it to see. I'd heard a lot about the Catherine's Palace, before I visited it. Bacause of that my expectation was huge. Well after it, I was a little bit disappointed, but still I think it is something you should to visit, when you are in St. Petersburg. The most impressive for me was Golden Room and the park! Grand Hall was ok, but it was too empty. Amber room was just maybe not my cup of tea. There is also few other chambers to see.

The Amber Room!!. This palace is situated in one of the most gorgeous areas in St. Petersburg (ok, its in the suburbs, so what!)If you miss this place during your visit to St. Petersburg, it's a real pity. I found the Amber Room living upto the hype. Unfortunately, no photos are allowed in this room.

excellent visit. Catherine Palace is the best place to visit if you come to saint petersburg, i recommand the visit of the palace, the rooms are beautifull and of course the visit of amber room is the TOP of the visit

Gorgeous Catherine's Review. My wife and I visited the gorgeous Catherine's Palace which is the most lavish palace we had ever visited. We enjoyed looking at the gold-plated fountains as well as the beautiful landscaped gardens. Also, we explored the luxurious palace with gold-covered doors and panels. After visiting the Amber Room with its walls covered with amber, we can say that the palace was really stupendous and simply worth visiting in Russia.

Beautiful Palace,. We visited the place in July 2014. The weather was beautiful( unlike the usual St Petersburg weather). This made the visit even more enjoyable. On the way we see Tsarkoye sell, place were Pushkin was born. Then you walk into the Summer palace. There was a Russian band playing music in the front of the palace. Restoration was proceeding in the outer facade, which detracted us from the beauty of the palace.Which still did look very imposing and beautiful. Inside of the palace, the staircases were just absolutely stunning! The whole palace was bombed and destroyed by the Nazis and has been painstakingly restired( there are pictures of how the palace looked). Reminded me of the Windsor palace. There are many rooms , bedrooms, dining rooms,etc. definitely worth the visit to see how the Tsars used to live.The garden is also very beautiful and a nice walk! For shopping: the museum stores were very good. Cheaper stuff is sold outside in stalls,

A Winter's Tale. The wonderful reviews of this superb palace have already said it all. It really is stunning. However, I found enchantment in the extensive park and gardens. Under deep snow, they took on a magical quality. My walk took me to frozen lakes and streams, bare trees and local people out sledding with their children. The rawness of the scene was spectacular. Don't miss this.

Make sure you are there for the Fountain Display. Very crowded for the Fountain turn on but get there early to get a good vantage point, you do not want to miss it, grounds are very extensive so leave plenty of time to explore
Very Impressive. The Architecture was eye catching,the colours on a drab day was enlightening .Very impressive outlay and a place to put on your must visit list.

Russian Splendour. I visited Catherine Palace and Park on a half-day excursion from the St Petersburg cruise port. It takes an hour by coach to reach the town of Pushkin. While on the way to the Palace, we were supplied with 'whisperers', portable radio receivers and eraphones whereby we could listen in to our guide's commentary once inside the building. The palace is splendid. We were supplied with slip-on plastic over-shoes to save wear on the palace fllors. The artworks and interior decoration of the palace rooms were stunning. Better yet the walk in the park afterwards viewing the lakes and pavilions.

Catherine Palace and Park. A very impressive Palace, the facade is almost 1,000 ft. long with white columns and ornate gold moldings. A striking example of Russian Baroque architecture. From the Portrait Hall to the Amber Room, the paintings on the ceilings; you just become enthralled, over the gold walls, just when you thought it couldn't get any better; the sight is unreal!The gardens that surround the Palace are actually an English garden and the old garden. Beautiful gardens to walk and enjoy the sights!Don't miss the Catherine Palace and Park; you will love it!Jon Lefeber

Opulent, Amazing, Stunning.....Superb!. You will be amazed as you wander among some of the worlds most prized and priceless works of art. The palace is wow...the grounds about the palace are also perfect. Many people come each day to visit and to be amazed at the riches that are housed here and to hear the history of Peter The Great and Catherine who are so important to the story of the aristocracy of the Russian people and its rulers.Come to this place and, if you can, have a guide with you and you will be shown the most important rooms and their treasures with explanations that piece together the historic past of these Russian Aristocrats.

Palace and Garden. Part of our organised tours and this place did not disappoint despite the freezing weather. Lovely university town not too far from St Petersburg, able to get there by public transport if necessary.Palace was a mini Versailles and was busy with tour groups but not many ventured into the beautiful gardens.Great in winter but would be amazing when all flowers blooming.Worth seeing.

Out of the city and worth it. The Palace itself is a memorable place, and allows a peek into the decadent and excesses of the Romanovs. Once inside you can wander at your leisure and marvel at the entire scene. The day we were there we spent 3+ hours [the morning] inside and the afternoon [also about 3 hours] in the gardens and perusing the "craft" stands on the periphery. Public transproartatio to/fro centre is relatively easy.

Must-do!. Are prepared for a good walking form the parking area to the palace? Are you prepared for the lines? Here is my suggestion: try to avoid going there in the winter time. Make sure when you go either there is short lines or if you can by any "fast-pass" entrance.

A palace indeed. I was in St. Petersburg for a business trip and had the weekend to myself before returning to US. I hired a private guide with a car to visit Pushkin and Peterhof in a day. I'm glad I did because I don't know if I would be able to do both places on my own. The palace is well preserved and the Amber room is indeed stunning.
Spectular. Easy to get to by local bus ststem off metro line. Check that all aspects are open somedays its only the grounds. Thake a picnic lunch and loose yourself in the massive grounds.

Beautiful in all seasons. The place is charming any seaon of the year. Makes sense to come for the Catherine Palace visit and have a walk in the adjecent parks. To get there independent travelers can either take a shared taxi (called marshrutka) or hire a taxi. If you can come there on working Mondays (see link for schedule below) and plan to visit the palace around 7:00pm. This is the only way to avoid lines in the peak season.http://eng.tzar.ru/info/price

Favorite places. Love it in all seasons. The walk around the park is a must, feeding ducks and other birds, enjoying its beauty and meditating. Visit the Amber room at the palace and bask in its glow, quite unforgettable. Of course, read up in advance on the history of the place--you'll get much more out of this visit.

A day in the country.. To reach the Summer Palace of Catherine the First means a long drive out of St Petersburg. A guided bus tour is a good way to go. The drive shows the industrial outskirts of the city, then some quite lovely countryside. Entering the park, you first go through the Egyptian gates, which seem out of place. The town is small and quietly residential. Entering the palace grounds you go through the gold covered main gates and pass the gold onion tops of the chapel. An enormous amount of restoration has been done both inside and outside the buildings. Damage from the war was extensive, but you can hardly see it. Everything that can be gilded is and it is almost overwhelming. We were greeted outside by a small marching brass band, and later, while touring the extensive gardens and park, also were treated to a group of five men singing Russian folk songs. The grandeur is over the top and it is hard to believe anyone could live like this. Well worth the visit to experience the history, see the Amber Room, and stroll the gardens. My visit was in August, so it was hot. Not much available as far as refreshments and the outdoor vendor wanted rubles, not Euros. There is a small outdoor market on the way out. Expect to spend a few hours here.

Long, cold line. We hired a private car to take us to Pushkin - nice drive, but were not able to buy tickets far in advance (online), so we stood in a very cold outside line for 45 minutes. The cafe is simple, but full of wholesome (sandwiches/pastries) choices to accompany tea/coffee. Gift shops were reasonably priced. Gardens were open, but chilly wind prevented too much exploration outside.

Sumptuous palace!. I went to the castle alone in a very cold day. It was good because it was empty. The palace is very beautiful, mainly inside, the restoration done was amazing! The richest of details impresses. Go for a walk on the gardens, even during the winter, it has an amazing energy. Must see in St. Petersburg.

What a Smart, Sophisticated Woman With Money Can Do.... Did she have a bucket list of artists and paintings or did the buyers she sent out all over Europe simply buy what they thought their Queen would approve of? She covered the many wall of her palace with all forms of art; from clocks and knights armor to paintings and statues. And where the walls were bare she covered them with silk or polished sheets of amethyst (It is hard not to cringe when you think of the poverty of the common people during those days).

Don't miss the Amber Room. The ticket booths may be confusing. You need to buy two tickets, one for the park and one for the palace. Many Russians like to spend the day in the beautiful park, so admissions are separate. There were several couples having wedding photos taken in the park.There is a small lake in the park and sculpture, so it is a great place to have a walk. There is a small pavilion with art on display, so don't miss that one as it is not usually mentioned in travel writings. There was a lovely display of ceramics when I was there in Sept. 2014. Read up on the story of the Amber Room before you go. It was stolen by the Nazis and very little was ever recovered. A local workshop reconstructed it. You can't take photos of the Amber Room, but the museum sells a small booklet. You can take photos in the rest of the museum, but I don't remember if you need to pay extra for permission.The palace is not very large, but is about 25 km out of town. I got there easily on a minibus. Bring along a flyer or picture from your guidebook to show the driver where you are going. He will tell you when your stop arrives--you can't see the palace from the minibus, but it is just around the corner from the stop--easy to find. The bus stop to return is just across the street from the one where you arrived. It makes a very pleasant day viewing art and gardens.

Best Guides tours and Larisha the perfect hosts for this tour. Pushkin and the palaces (Catherine's and ALexander) are both worth visiting. The grandeur of the firts and the historical background of the seconf, makes this excursion a MUST. We booked the tour with Best Guides and our host was Larisha, such a nice lady. On our way back to St. Petersburg we even got more than we expected. Larisha took us to visit a wonderfull church and even showed us a souvenir shop which was quite cheaper that the ones in the centre
Another must see. Catherine was a very powerful and expensive women with a lot of good taste. You need to visit in order to understand
Shows how Russia cares about it´s past. Great palace in a lovely town. the rooms are incredibly well restored and it proves how Russians take good care of their history. Impossible to miss.

Another Palace. This was Catherine the Great's home. It's located in Pushkin. The russian government has done a heck of a job restoring it. It was built in the mid 1700s. It is situated within an attractive park and gardens. It's know world-wide for its "Amber Room". The original amber panels were stolen by the Nazis and never recovered after the War. It took 12 years and many millions to restore it.You could never say that the Romanovs had a hard life after visiting their palaces.

Perfect park!. One of the best parks I've ever been, high recommended for everyone travelling to in St Petersburg. Take minibus from Kupchino Metro station, and it takes about 45 min - 1 hour. A MUST visit!

A MUST WHEN VISITING ST PETERSBURG. If I had just one palace to visit in the environs of St Petersburg, I would be torn between Peterhof and here. I think this would win. This is a very lavish palace with rooms on a very grand scale. The Amber Room is unbelievable. we went on a Sunday morning in early October and although not the main tourist season it was crowded. A member of our party insusted on also doing the Agate (or Jasper) Rooms, so our tour of the palace was at a gallop. This is not to be recommended as it deserves to be taken at leisure. Although not as grand as the main palace, the Agate Rooms were fascinating and worth seeing - but not at the expense of racing round the palace. The grounds are also worthy or a wonder, so do not go at break-neck speed (I covered three palaces in one day!)

Don't miss it. Really interesting to see the various rooms of the Palace (especially the Amber Room) as well as the pictures in the basement area that depict the desolate state of the complex after the War.
very nice palace. very nice palace in very good condition. very big park around 300 hectares including lake and some buildings.

Beautiful Palace. Beautiful palace but if you visit it within a day of touring the Hermitage you will not want to visit another museum or palace for at least a week.It has even more exquisite gold, amber and oil paintings---one more beautiful then the last but how can you absorb it all in a short period of time because they do keep you moving from one room to the next.

Memorable Experience. Took a special evening tour, including a visit to the reconstructed Amber Room, a concert in the ballroom and a special dinner with Russian Folk Music entertainment, that will stay in my mind forever. I was transported to the splendor of a by-gone era with champagne, ballet and great food.

Cruise to St Petersburg. St Petersburg was the highlight and only overnight stop on our cruise to Russia from Tilbury, London.We paid £146 each for a full day trip to St Catherine's Palace, lunch and an afternoon visit to the Hermitage Museum.We were welcomed by 3 musicians which was a nice touch then had to wait a while and queue to enter as several excursions arrived at the same time.Another queue while we left our coats in the cloakroom as you could not enter with coats and large bags.You also had to put on thin overshoes to protect the flooring.The Palace was a study in conspicuous consumption, 1000 rooms for one unmarried woman.Our tour guide insisted we stayed together and we all had headphones so we could hear her information.We were not allowed to take photos in the Amber room.We had a short walk outside as it was trying to snow with low temperatures around freezing.The fountains are turned off for the winter.We were booked into a lunch stop nearby with several others groups and had a 3 course Traditional Russian meal with beetroot featuring in every course with a chicken main.Then the common stop at a souvenir shop with free vodka and coffee.Finally the drive back to the city with lots of traffic queues.The area around the Palace is apparently a desirable to live being in the countryside with a good climate for Russia.Worth a visit to see how the Tsars lived, slightly spoilt by the scaffolding repairing the building following the Nazi burning of the Palace in WW2 .

Summer relax place - Pushkin. State museum and park in Pushkin is a great place to refresh yourself from the city. It is conviniently located only 30 min from Moskovskaya metro station (buses №286, 287, 299, 342, 347а, 545, 545а ), where you can admire the fountains and old-fashioned Lenin pedestrian monument. The best jewel of this museum and park is definitely mysterious The Amber Room, impressive and amazing history masterpiece, an unforgettable experience. And the Park itself, calm place with bluish in colour Catherine Palace, where you can get great photo opportunities to splurge on.Walking in Tsarskoe Selo in winter also seems to be great, not so cold as you can imagine, you can see winter fun ,mulled wine, sleigh rides etc...Price for Amber room around 10 USD, The park 3 USD, free in winter

Bring time, patience and money. After you paid a horrendous entrance fee for the park ONLY, you form file ! Since the palace is being renovated, only apprx. six rooms can be visited. Therefore they let in only approx. 100 people at a time !We waited three hours outside in the park !! Then treated like cattle into the palace, another file for the fee paying.......Then another file for the check for weapons....then like cattle again driven through these six rooms, including the AMBER ROOM, This room is beautiful, but smaller than anticipated, 50 people inside don't improve the space....I don't regret it, because I wanted so badly to see the AMBER ROOM !Would I do it again, knowing before about the waiting time ? I doubt it.....Peterhof Palace was much nicer !

All that GOLD!!!. Named after Catherine the 1st Tasteful blue & white faccades great gardens, grand vistas, tasteful use of marble inside , Guilded gold domes of the palace, the portrait hall & picture gallery make this all one memorable palace. The Great Hall so named as it spans the ENTIRE floor so you have commanding views from any window you choose to look out of. VERY full of tourists so be there as early as you can
Blue and gold. Now my favourite colours. And in the sunshine, Sooo photogenic. Take some time to stroll through the park which, although lots of people still seems peaceful Don't forget the camera.

Blue and White Splendor. Prepare to be dazzled by the sheer magnitude of the palace and the grounds. Your jaw will drop at the furniture, decorative arts, sculpture and artwork on view throughout the palace. Enjoy walking around outdoors and taking photos of the palace.

Wow factor, do not miss this palace. I was lucky enough to visit this palace at the end of Sept when it was relatively quite no big crowds to speak of.The palace from out side is stunning with well laid out gardens and the palace decorated with gold gilt statues also the gold gate across the court yard but inside it just has the wow factor all the rooms are highly decorated especially the Great hall you can spend quite a time just looking at the ceiling painting,the Anterooms and of course the Amber room there are over twenty rooms to visit in all and you will not be disappointed.The Russians must take a lot of credit the way this palace has been restored after the state it was left in after W11 just look at the before and after pictures on the internet.

A Must See for the Interior. This palace is beautiful inside and out. Peterhof's ground are more spectacular. Catherine's interior is unbelievable - the ballroom, amber room and dining areas - wow. Please see internet photos that show Catherine's Palace in 1944 after the Nazi's destroyed and looted it. The interior then and now is amazing.

Jaw dropping interior.. I think this is definitely top of my visit list for St Petersburg---lovely park area with a definite atmosphere---seeing it in autumn with the trees various shades of golden yellows and browns was a bonus.The interior just had the wow factor in every room---literally dripping with ornate gold decor and the history of the family that lived there totally fascinating.
Beuatiful. Wow, You should go given the chance. Alla Tours was great, the guide was very knowledgeable and informative.
Lovely place to visit. Very nice palace and gardens. Would suggest to give enough time to visit the gardens. The tour of the palace is very tightly managed for time.

All credit to amazing restoration. This palace is well worth a visit. When you realise it was destroyed almost completely by the invading Germans, you can't help but marvel at the way the entire building has been restored to its original grandeur. The Amber Room is amazing and the gardens are beautiful too. Catherine the Great loved baroque architecture so it's a "pretty" palace that will have you clicking away with your camera. However, no photos are permitted inside.
catherine palace. The gardens here are to die for. I loved the fountain display. The palace was outstanding. The stoies the guide told us were fantastic.

Impressive baroque palace. This palace is where Empress Catherine the Great lived & died. Designed by Italian architect Bartolomeo Rastrelli. The most impressive rooms is the Amber room (eight wonder of the world) Here no photography is allowed. The palace was almost totally destroyed during the war, but has risen like a phoenix from the ashes due to extensive restoration work

A Walk through tim....... Amazing walk through history within these walls. Take a look at the restoration and rescue process in the basement of this palace during WWII. It is just incredible. We hired a car to take us out to the palace and return. It was very convenient. Our hotel organized it.....

Now I know why she was Catherine the Great. Catherine's Palace is atonishing and the Amber room is one of those places that when you see it you cannot believe it. How they could restore this palace is beyond comprehension. Make sure to take a walk over to the lake and see Catherine's study--You know she had many lovers!

Smithsonian Tour - 1977. Still the Soviet Union. "The Olden Days." Our group was treated like VIP's - the most well-educated, articulate and enthusiastic tour guides. The palace was breathtakingly beautiful - restored to perfection - bright, glittering with gold, white, and pale turquoise. It was such a contrast to the (what was then) shoddy construction of so many other buildings. The artwork it contained was very different from the Soviet Realism which was then the only style approved by the state.An experience I'll never forget!

Outstanding -even in the rain!. We visited the palace on a trip from our cruise ship which was docked in St Petersburg. The journey was quite quick and the tour was very well organised although the queue to enter meant that we got rather wet in a heavy shower.The process for entering is rather slow (although I think that we were fast-tracked) and the numbers in the queue were phenomenal, although it did not feel crowded inside the spectacular rooms. We loved the whole visit and were very impressed with the mirrored ballroom and the ceilings were wonderful! Go if you can!

The Rediscovered Jewel of St. Petersburg. Of all the marvelous places to visit in St Petersburg, this was our favorite. It is a short trip out of the city, and not as famous nor grand as Peterhof, it is a magnificent palace. The curators did an amazing job in bringing Catherine's Palace back to it's former glory, after the destruction of war. Be sure to take at least half day to go out and enjoy the palace and grounds.

An All Day-Should Not Miss!. It is not easy to get to Catherine Palace and Park. It took two metros, one bus, one taxi (running late) and a train to go back and forth from St Petersburg. And of course Cyrillic will make it a challenge, but its definitely worth it. The park is amazingly big and worth spending half a day seeing and walking it. I would pack a lunch and just take my time next time. I can imagine the Tsar, Catherine, and/or the royal family strolling these beautiful gardens.... completely worthy of a monarchy. The Hermitage is the poor sister and completely did not impress me. If we could only move the Rubens, Van Dyks and the Rembrandts to this grandiose palace! The tour only covers a wing but please spend the 400 rubles for this. It is truly amazing and it does have that homey feeling that is missing at the Hermitage. Get up early and make your way to this place, take your time and spend the day here.

Monument and Park Heaven. The park grounds and the Palace are absolutely beautiful!!! The Great Pond is not to be missed. This palace was often visited by the great poet, Alexander Pushkin, for inspiration. Once you visit the Palace, you will understand why............

Catherines Palace. From the Amber room to the beautiful gardens you can't help but be dazzled by scale and extravagance of Catherine palace. Even the quirky brass band that greet you as you queue to get in make the whole place a wonderful experience. Even more impressive is the fact that most of it was destroyed during the Second World War. The renovation work is simply stunning.

Overwhelming.. Just too much to take in the beauty of the collection and the gardens and wáter features. It is somewhere you must make time for whenm visiting the city. It's a bit of a way from the city though.

Fantastic!. Recommend visiting this palace on a cool or rainy day because of the proportion of indoor touring that takes place. This palace is very similar to Versailles, but, of course, has history, paintings/artwork, and furniture relating to Russia or that have a Russian flavor and thus is nowhere near being a copycat. Went with an independent tour guide Michael Nougmanov (pochtatravel@gmail.com) whom I used during both my Saint Petersburg visits. Added to the experience.

Empress Catherine's II Palace. Whilst on a cruise of the Baltic in 2008 to St Petersburg we toured Catherine's Palace which was painted in blue to match her eyes. Similar to Peterhof's Palace, was spectacular with all it's grand golden features with mirrors. There was the dining room and also the great hall not forgetting the best room of all was the amber room, totally magnificent. This was followed by the grand gardens of monuments, bridges and a lake. We had visited 2 palaces in a day that will be remembered forever.

Amber room was disappointing. Sure the whole place is ornate, shinny and totally interesting but the Amber Room was a little less than I expected. Sure got to do it but enjoy the other areas as well as the famous room.

Still amazing!. This was my 3rd visit to Catherine Palace. It never fails to amaze me - the sheer size and opulence is breathtaking. Definitely one of the highlights (along with Peterhof) of any visit to St. Petersburg.

Catherine Palace. This Palace is magnificent its no wonder the revolution came about....nevertheless super huge palace and gardens. The rooms are equally unique and very Russian,especially Amber Room and the Dinning Rooms And the Great Hall.
Such opulence. Beautiful, but holy cow! The haves and the have nots. A must see. Loved the boat ride over to the palace and the grounds were so pretty.

A Park to be Remembered. The gardens were just beautiful and so well kept. We were lucky to have sunshine on our visit which made the pictures just beautiful. Catherine's Palace was so well fitted for such an important person in the history of Russia.

Opulence overload. Having wandered through the halls and rooms of catherines palace< it is easy to see why the Bolsheviks revolted> the amount of gold leaf and the overall opulence along with the furniture< artwork etc reflects a time where the super rich took their god like existence to be their right< even though the general populace might have been starving> fully restored after having been badly damaged by occupying German army in WWII during the seige of St Petersburg it is a museum that is a must when visiting St Petersburg just be aware that the staff can be very abrupt _ this seemed to be a general trait of most Russians in any sort of authorative role even the toilet attendants
Hard to Believe. a chance to see and wonder at how the haves lived and enjoyed a much better life style. Takes one`s breath away.

Catherine's Palace. The palace is a top attraction. It is very large and the grounds are very beautiful. We also got to see an "Amber room" where they do some of the restoring. You need to put on protective footwear (slippers) to walk the interior, to preserve the floors due to the dust and dirt from the grounds. (kind of a "red"dust and dirt surrounding the palace.)

Beautiful palace and gardens. A beautiful, opulent palace with amazing gardens to spend some time relaxing in. The palace is filled with ornate room after ornate room. The famous Amber Room is here - or at least a full exact replica of the original which was stolen by the nazis. Portraits & other artworks. Mahogany, Chinese silk, marble - the opulence is constant.
