A fascinating place to spend a day (or just half a day), and fascinating learning Catherine's story.
Gold & More Gold. A beautiful building with an amazing interior. One amazingly opulent gilt & white room after another plus an exact [real amber] reconstruction of the famous Amber Room.

Like Eating Icing All Day. Now I think I understand Bauhaus. It's a reaction. This really deepened my understanding of the royal lifestyle in Tsarist Russia. The Amber Room was a little underwhelming, but the rest of the fricasees and foofaws more than made up for it.Beautiful grounds we wish we had more time to tour. Lots of walking and stairs, hard floors, I was glad we went after lunch and were somewhat rested and full. We definitely walked it off!

Great gardens. The extensive gardens are great for a stroll. The interiors of the palace, on the other hand, are not that impressive, albeit the famous "amber room".On a sunny day the stroll in the park is particularly pleasant, allowing great pictures.

Beautiful interiors. Very pretty palace. Lots of gold gold and gold! The Amber room was quite amazing too. Too bad we can't take any photos inside. Take a stroll at the gardens outside. It's very peaceful and relaxing.
Gold Gold Gold. Absolutely fantastic! No wonder there was a revolution!!! Don't want to see another chandelier or a pinch of Gold Leaf for a LONG time

If visiting 1 palace, let this be it!. Firstly let me state I am not a palace person and secondly I was unsure of using public transport, but I am really glad that I did both! The palace is decadent to say the least! There were certainly two extremes living in Russia. The upkeep must be phenomenal but it gives a glimpse into the original manner in which this class lived.

Loved It!. This magnificent Palace and it's grounds is simply breathtaking. When in Pushkin this is a MUST-SEE without a doubt. The Rococo architecture both interior and exterior astounds. Do take your time and stroll the grounds. Check out events and highlights and exhibitions before you visit. If you're lucky there might just be one waiting for you. Plan to have at least half a day for this visit.Highly Recommended!!

So Much For So Few. Caviar and champagne awaited us on the lawn and musicians played classical music in the background as we strolled the grand gardens. Inside the palace, a uniformed guard posed for photos with palace guests in front of the marble staircase. Our shoes covered in slip covers, our eyes feasted on priceless gilded gold, and amber riches in route to the ballroom, a mirrored version of France's Versailles, with dancers moving to the music of a string quartet. What an enchanted evening! If possible, take a night tour.

Beautiful palace. After visiting here, it's easy to understand why the peasants revolted! Very busy but we were well entertained by musicians playing outside while we waited in the (very long) queue. One visit is not enough.

Queues. A lot of queues here, even with our guide trying to use his contacts. After a bit we were in and it is worth seeing, and do not forget to take a stroll round the gardens.
There is the usual restoration work going on and when all this is finished it will be very impressive.

Wish I could have had a horse to ride the grounds. Beautiful, opulent, fabulous grounds. How could any one dynasty have had such a grand place? The Amber room was a fine attraction and no photos were allowed. Once again, lots of stairs for those walking the grounds.
Oppulence unparallelled. As one of my raveling companions noted, "no wonder there was a revolution". Ballrooms, dining areas, drawing rooms, the Great Hall--all magnificent.

Palace interior lavishly gilded. The outlook of the Palace does not speak for the opulent finish inside. Mainly painted in blue and white, the ornamental mouldings and atlantes on the exterior wall of the Palace were in wood colour (tan). If they had been gilded, the Palace would have taken on a much more monarchic air. Having said that, once you enter the staterooms inside, you would be blinded by the overwhelming use of gilded mouldings, caryatids and pilasters which reflected the extravagance of Empress Elizabeth, the daughter of Peter the Great and his wife Catherine (whom the palace was named ), who was said to have commissioned the renovations to rival the Versailles in the seventeenth century and resulted in what it is today. There were so much to see, mural paintings on the ceiling of the 1,000 square meters lavishly gilded Great Hall (there were two models dressed up in historic gowns in this room for tourists to take photos with for a fee), the decidely different Green Dining Room, many drawing rooms and studies (I was particularly impressed with the finely crafted antique roll up desks and the blue and white tile stoves) and of course the legendary Amber Room. I learnt that the Amber room was completed in 1770 but was dismantled and taken out of the country by German troops in 1941. Recreation was only commissioned in 1982 and was completed and reopened in 2003 after 20 years work. Noted that photography is not allowed in this room only but one could take a long shot through the door way before you enter the room. The garden of this Palace however was far less impressive than the Peterhof Palace.

Do not miss. The colours and gilt of the statues are a must to be seen. We went on a tour with a Russian company We walked through the grounds beautiful statues and flowers, the fountains were in full flow and beautiful.inside the palace the rooms are all different but each just as appealing,the pictures and furniture opulent and make it har to believe they were ever used.
Catherine's beautiful Palace. So glad to finally see this palace, which has been on our bucket list. Some remodeling currently, some packaging, but still breathtaking.

A nice walk. If you wait 6pm (if I remember well) the entrance to the park is free - and what a park! Very well maintained, and along your walk you will be able to see some very pretty little buildings. I had the chance to have the perfect weather with a clear blue sky therefore the colours offered by the palace and the park were unforgettable.

The Russian Versailles.. The Palace is about an hour from the city but it has to be seen. It is interesting to see Peter the Great's triumphant golden shrillness contrasting Catherine's more subdued style.

Catherine Palace. We joined a local tour and Catherine Palace is one of the attractions we saw. Weather wasn't good during our two days at St. Petersburg. Lining up in front of the main entrance with rain wasn't quite fun. However we were quite impressed with the decoration and amazing details and forgot about the rain.We heard about the Amber Room a lot. Perhaps it was because we heard so much and we were expecting more out of it, we were not as impressed with the turn out. We all knew it's a rebuild from the original. But we didn't get a WOW factor out of this room.Overall it's still an impressive palace. This is also a must see attraction.

Impressive and expansive!. The inside of the palace is amazing and extraordinary - did not spare any cost to show off what they have. It is sad to see how the royal family lives when compared to the populace. I can understand why the revolution started ...

Too amazing to be true you might think!. This is a really a beautiful Palace and Park ensemble and well worth visiting and spending time on the long walk around the park. Long tourist queues but well worth the wait.

More "gold" than I have ever seen. What an amazing Palace! You will be dazzled by the ornate gold interior decoration throughout the Palace, and the enormous size.
We recommend this excursion for any St. Petersburg visitor.

Well worth a visit. I wanted to visit the summer palace to have a day outside of St.P and make a comparison with the Winter Palace / hermitage museum. Much of the architecture is the same as both were designed by Rastrelli.Due to the destruction caused during the war, much of the interior is actually restored according to the original design and decor complete with stunning gold leaf. It is very busy there and you have to be guided - there is no independent wandering around. We had a private guide with timed entry so no queuing!The Amber Room is one of the highlights - stunning!
Catherine Palace and Park.. This was one of the prettier Palaces we visited whilst in StPetersberg, the gardens were magnificent and beautifully kept.
Fairy tale. On our two day tour of St Petersburg we saw several palaces but this is a beautiful one. We were impressed with the palace and would recommend it on any agenda.
A must see!. Glad we made it to this amazing place!! Had a friend who drove us there, it is outside St. Petersburg. Definitely worth a visit.
Wonderful experience. One of the highlights of our visit to SPB.on organised tour is the preferable way to see this facility as the lineup is quite extensive
My Favorite Place in St Petersburg. This palace took my breath away. Both the outside and the inside were beautiful. I will never forget this beauty.

takes your breath away. Yes--this is another "must see" in St Petersburg. You cannot believe it until you see it. The gold leaf decor, room after room. Magnificent and not to be missed if you can visit.

Well worth a visit.. There is an odd booking system, whereby tour groups and Russians go in 10 am to 12 noon, at the front and foreigners go in 12 noon to 2 pm, around the back. We tried to book a group ticket with a tour guide, the day before we wanted to go and were told that they had sold out!! So the Petro Palace Hotel concierge kindly arranged for us to go with one of their English speaking tour guides and hire one of their cars for 4 hours. The Palace is about ½ hr drive from St Petersburg. You have to pay to go into the gardens and get a ticket and then show your ticket to be allowed entry into the Palace. The queue at 12 noon was quite long but had all but gone by 1 pm. You have to wear paper slip-ons over your shoes. The Palace was very elaborate and ornate with much gold leaf and the Amber Room (copied from the original which was stolen) was very impressive. Our tour guide Irina was excellent company and very informative.
triple gold. I have never seen so much gold in one location incredible a feast for the senses that I wil never forget I can now understand why there was a revolution

St. Petersburg--One of the World's Most Beautiful Cities. We loved St. Petersburg. People were friendly, the city was beautifully restored, the pride of the people was apparent in the cleanliness of this city. The amber room in Catherine's Palace was the enticement to tour the palace and park. It is like a fairy tale. The detail the restorers undertook to bring this palace back to its glory is amazing. Fortunately to pay for the gold, amber, paintings, and more, this place is open to the public. No longer a place just for nobility, the palace is open to all and often holds public events. The guides describe the history so well and with great pride. If you go to Russia, do not miss it.
Wow!,. Gold leaf everywhere. The opulence of this Palace was incredible. The rooms where restored to their original use. This palace is about a 1/2 hour outside of the city but well worth the trip.

Upmanship. Very lovely, gold blinds you as everything is gilded, and clearly, Catherine wanted to outdo the French, and I think she succeeded. The gardens were lovely and taking the time to stroll about is worthwhile. It's helpful that one is guided through the place, but one visits a miniscule part of the palace. I would have liked to see more.

hard to imagine such opulance. So much gold! It gives a really good insight into the life of the Tsar's. Be prepared to wear funny little hospital type slippers over your shoes and be surrounded by many others who want see what you want to see. It is absolutely awesome I almost gave myself whiplash trying to see it all. Take a guide!

Fantastic. From the outside it is amazing and the inside continues on the same theme. The Amber Room is obviously the highlight of the Palace but every room is exquisite, highly decorated with gold and very opulent.

Nice palace to contemplate. This place along with Peterhof was a glimpse into the lifestyle of the russian royalties. What an extravagant lifestyle this must have been. So much wealth concentrated into the hands of a few.

Restored portion stunning!. Much of the Palace was destroyed in World War II. The rooms that have been restored are surprisingly opulent. The Amber Room was breathtaking, and the workmanship amazing. We had the pleasure of hearing a string quartet in the ballroom of the Palace, which was a real treat. Great insight into the day-to-day life of the royalty.
St Catherine's palace. Like all palaces, it is amazing and they call it "small" but it was pretty big to me. Lots of color. Take a few minutes and walk the grounds. Very relaxing.
Amazing. The Amber room stunning the gold everywhere the whole palace was amazing got to be seen to be believed
beautiful garden. like the beautiful garden, especially the fountains at 11am. Also the amber room is amazing. no air condition inside

Amazing. The vastness of the place and the grandeur is truly amazing..
the interiors and all that tonnage of gold they used for the gilding
The Amber room must be a "one off"....
wonderful site. The Germans trashed it and the Russians are gradually beautifully restoring the opulent place. It is more than worth the trip out to see it.
Incredible. The restoration of the palace, especially the Amber Room, is magnificent. We wished we had had more time here.
Blew Us Away. The interior of the palace is amazing. Well worth the visit. It does leave little doubt as to the causes of the revolution though.

Splendid. We visited Catherine Palace and Amber Workshop while on a cruise holiday. The building is magnificent and the Amber room is something to behold (it was rather smaller than I thought) , the workmanship in creating these panels and pictures is remarkable..Visiting the workshop after gave further insight into working with amber and we were given a few small samples as a memento.

My wife's favorite place in St. Petersburg. My wife and I spent seven days in St. Petersburg. Our hotel arranged a private guide to take us to the Palace. It was worth the price. We already had tickets. Consequently we could avoid the lines and got into the palace without waiting. Once inside you are overcome with both the beauty of the palace and exorbitance of the tzars. The famous Amber Room leaves one speechless and the grounds are a special place to be.

Very good, you do need to enjoy visiting Stately Homes in the UK.. Very good, an amazing Ball Room. You do need to like walking around Stately Homes eg in the UK as its room after room of antique furniture, paintings etc.

Beautiful Reproduction. The Catherine Palace was originally built in the mid-18th century for Tzarina Elizabeth who named it the Catherine Palace in Honor of her mother. It was left in ruins and looted because of Nazi occupation in WW II. The restoration work began almost immediately after the war. I was especially excited about viewing the famous "Amber Room", a room made of amber panels backed with gold leaf and mirrors. Created in the 18th century, it was looted by Nazi Germany and disappeared after World War II. In 1979, efforts were undertaken to rebuild the Amber Room. In 2003, after decades of work by Russian craftsmen and financed by donations from Germany, the reconstructed Amber Room was opened in the Catherine Palace. The palace was beautiful, but it is almost totally a reproduction. The new paint and heavy gold leaf did mimic the old original walls and finishes, but everything was bright and garish. Even the Amber room seemed shiny and modern. Scattered around, there were some authentic old paintings, furniture and porcelain that had been purchased for the palace from auctions and antique shops.

Another Beautiful Museum. This tour was interesting. It was a one way walk throught it. Tour after tour filing through. Very well preserved. This was badly damaged during WWII and looted. The most amazing part was the reconstructed "Amber Room". The "room" was stolen by Gremany and has never been found. It has been completely put back together, from pictures, and is awesome.

Royal oppulence which led to 1917 revolution!. Restored Amber Room is definitely the highlight of the palace tour. Gold-leaf gilded rooms with finely handcrafted figurines may have been a major factor in Russian revolt, bringing home the wide disparity in lifestyles and status between the ruling and working classes.
a walk in the park. it would take too long to describe but on your visit to St Petersburg this is a must. don't forget your camera
Catherine Palace & Park. Huge palace. Learned a lot of pre-revolution Russian history by visiting the palaces in St. Petersburg.

Amazing!. We stood in the pouring rain waiting to get into Catherine's Palace, hoping it would be worth it -well, it certainly was. We moved through the palace with one jaw dropping room after another. The amber room was certainly the highlight of the tour. It was of course crowded,, however you still get to see everything it just takes patience. It is really hard to believe that people lived this way.

another magnificent Russian palace. Visiting the palaces in the Saint Petersburg area leaves one reeling in a state of sensory overload. Our excursion to the Catherine Palace was sandwiched in between the Hermitage and the Pushkin Palace so it's hard to keep each one unique in your mind. However, I remember that the rooms of the Catherine Palace were absolutely exquisite, elaborate, and ornate, even more impressive than the Hermitage. The Amber Room was unbelievable and unique. The gardens were relatively simple, but lovely and peaceful. The crowds waiting to get in the palace were unreal. A practical hint: if one bathroom has a long line, look for another. One ladies' room had the longest line I have ever seen in my life, but our guide led us to another facility just down the hall with no line at all!
The opulence.... Very crowded like the other attractions. But overall an interesting experience. Since we only had two days here, I would have skipped this and spent more time in the city.

Another must see.. A really beautiful Palace. Gold everywhere. Like a lot of the sites in St Petersburg there is so much to see and not enough time to linger. Our guide was very informative and being asmall group it was easy to hear what she was saying. We alsohad ear pieces which were especially helpful when we were walking in the Park.
Can't be missed. Wonderful experience, learned allot and enjoyed the beauty. Naturally, everyone dislikes the crowds.

Magnificent. Breathtaking palace with beautiful art pieces, amazing decorations, a grandeur of architecture. The garden is also very pretty, and tranquil. If you can, book a connoisseur tour and visit the palace before the opening time to avoid the crowd, and come after closing time for a classical quartet performance at the golden hall, imperial chamber dance hosted by "Catherine de Great" herself at the hall and in the garden, and then end the day with a wonderful dinner accompanied by Russian folk group performance.

Amazing Catherine's Palace. At first glance you think that the Catherine in the name is Catherine the Great but it is actually Catherine I, wife of Peter the Great who began the building with Elizabeth and Catherine II adding to it. It is wonderful both inside and out. We felt like it tops Versailles, esp. the interior.

Stunning. We visited as part of our two day cruise ship stop in St Petersburg. This was everything we hoped for both inside the palace and the gardens. The magnificent and opulence of this is staggering. For me the most amazing thing is that there wasn't a revolution by the have-nots much earlier.

A extravagant orgy of gold.. Russian rich and aristocrats liked to impress the world with their wealth. But Catherines Palace passes them all. Wow! Elisabeth, daughter of Peter the Great gave instructions to maximize the amount of gold.... and she got her way. Its not really beautiful beautiful but it sure is showy!
Catherine's Palace. A must-see while in St. Petersburg. It is awe-inspiring. The Amber Room is amazing! The grounds are beautiful as well.

You'll be blown away. The beauty and opulence of palace exterior is exceeded by the interior. It was really something to see how royalty, in this case Catherine, lived in the 18th and 19th century. Palace was lovingly restored to its rightful state, still a few more rooms to go.

Wanting to meet Catherine. Well this Lady was certainly a property manager ... And the art collected was amazing ... But it was the elegance of the palaces that kept me more on my feet than the art... If you take a tour they point the important pieces to you if not they might all look the same depending how much art Davy you are , but don't worry the grandeur of the palaces are enough , enjoy

Catherine the Great made her dreams come true!. This palace was restored about 8 years ago to its' former glory. The French Clocks were amazing! The amber room has been reconstructed to its' original splendor, the original having been stolen by the Germans in WWII. You walk into a jewel case...but no photos allowed. You can buy them however.

Beautiful and historic. Get there early as we were, at opening, but were still behind 200+ people. This is another example of how the rich lived and adorned themselves in Russia. The palace is beautiful and shows the various rooms showing the history. The amber room is a must see. It is funny, the one area not yet ornately decorated shows the actual dress, and parts of their history which are nice to see.

Stunning. My husband visited Catherine's Palace with a private guide. This site is definitely worth the visit. It is amazing to see the splendour. Our guide gave us insight into the different styles attributable to Empress Elizabeth and then later Catherine the Great. The history, the wealth and splendour is everywhere here.
Palace was amazing. Gorgeous palace, rooms were amazing, the gold ballroom was spectacular. The amber room was lovely. The outside domes were absolutely gorgeous. Gardens that we seen were beautiful
Unbelievable. This was part of our SPB Tours in St. Petersburg, Russia. You see these places in pictures but nothing can compare to see these places in real time. Unbeliveable...

Brilliant. Unmissable. Another wonderful palace in an extraordinary city. Overwhelming opulence. It should not be missed. If weather is kind, grab a hydrofoil back to City centre to avoid dreary road trip of about an hour

Worth the ride. Restoration is complete, or almost complete. Definitely worth a trip. Inside the palace as well as the gardens are just spectacular. Don't miss the Amber Room. But, my favorite part was the photos on the wall in a small, nondescript hall on our way out of the palace to the gardens. Here, they had pictures of the palace before the renovations took place. They were remarkable to see after seeing all of the restored areas.

Long awaiting line but worth to wait!. I visited this palace in summer time in Russia. So I spend almost an hour in awaiting line. Exterior and interior of the palace is very romantic, glamorous and elegant. I love the Cameron Gallery where full of bronze busts of philisophers, poet and ancient heroes and the lake beside gallery where a lot of bunches to sit and enjoy the view and happy moment with your beloved people.

Wow factor !. We took the tour to Pushkin and I finally found a place that shows how I was meant to live . Catherine's Palace is amazingly beautiful and decadent . It explains a lot of the reasons for the " average citizens" to start a Revolution . The place is huge, beyond beautiful and a great piece of history that deserves to be restored . The gardens are tremendous , gorgeous and so very neatly kept . There are bath houses in the garden , with pools in front of them . The gardens would be a lovely, peaceful place to just stroll or sit and relax . On entering the Palace, you are requested to put on cloth slippers like the type that are used in hospitals , to protect the floors . There are a few gift shops to purchase souvenirs if you would like to do that . There is a band of 4 men in military uniform outside the Palace to entertain while you wait for your group to enter . They are both talented and hilarious . It would be impossible to even begin to calculate the historical value of this Palace . Loved it !!!

Amazing. We toured the Catherine Palace along with our NCL organised excursion. it was good that we went with them as we did not have to wait for much time to get inside the palace. The palace gives a great idea to the time of Catherine and Peter the great. The amber room built for Catherine is just awesome. No photography is allowed inside this room but you can buy a ticket for a camera for rest of the palace which costs USD 5. The remaining rooms portray great architecture and is worth a visit. The palace is located outside Saint Petersburg in Pushkin village.

Feels like a theme park. This place is like a theme park, from the gates you enter through, to the brass band playing as you wait to go in the front door, to the crazy tiled stoves/fireplaces, the mirrored ballroom, the mosaic-like amber room (remember NO PHOTOS allowed in this room,), to the ornate manicured gardens. Catherine lived an opulent life indeed. Check out the family portraits - I'm no looker, but at least I try to avoid photos!
Wow!. Cathrine Palace and Park was beautiful. The Amber Room was awesome, the dining room set for a meal was unbelievable, the mirrored and gold decor of several rooms, OMG; it was beyond grand!

Plenty of lovers, plenty of Palaces. St. Petersburg is a city of churches and palaces - it seems every time Catherine the Great took a new lover, she built him a palace. Nonetheless, Catherine Palace rates second only to Peter's Palace for spectacular beauty (and loads of portraits of the Romanoffs).

A walk in the beautiful gardens!. The fountains and gardens of this palace are not to be missed. Be sure to spend a leisurely amount of time walking the grounds and taking pictures of this amazing place.

Gorgeous but mobbed and disorganized. We arranged for a cab to take us to the palace and wait for what we expected to be a two hour visit. Entrance to the gorgeous palace grounds was a breeze and we foolishly expected the same at the palace.The first sight of the blue and gold palace is breathtaking even though the front facade is under refurbishment.The signs are all in Russian making it difficult to understand how to proceed. An English speaking tourist showed us the line to get in which was long but didn' t appear too daunting. After a few minutes it became clear that the line didn't seem to move except sporadically and in very short bursts. We learned later that tour groups, of which there are many and use a different entrance, take precedence over individuals. After an interminable wait of almost two hours we were admitted, only to stand on line again to purchase tickets. Inside the palace rooms are stunning but so packed with tour groups that it is extremely difficult to actually see anything.If you go, I strongly suggest joining a tour group or hiring a private guide to avoid the lines. Go as late in the day as possible to avoid the crowds and allow yourself at least 2-3 hours inside plus and hour for the grounds.

Outstanding. Plan this visit carefully! You need a good tour company to get you in before the crowds. And you need to know what you want to see! Unless you will be in St. Petersburg for a few years, you will not be able to see everything. Excellent museum.

Add to your bucket list now.. Amazing, gorgeous, breath taking.....what everyone else says. GO! The amber room was gawdy, but still a site to see. So much wonderful art. I wish our tour here was longer.

St Catherine's Palace. You have to book your tickets at least 48 hours in advance so it is not an attraction that you can do at the spur of the moment. We went with a tour but it receives thousands of visitors a day so can be a bit of a crush, particularly if you are just a couple of people but it is the way I would have preferred to do it as it seemed rushed with the tour. The palace is really beautiful and on the day we went there were entertainers to welcome us as we queued to get in. You have a set appointment time to enter the gates but may still have to wait to gain entrance to the actual palace but it is well worth it. Much like Verssailles, it is opulent and stunning in every aspect, both inside and out. You are allowed to take photos in all but the Amber room but you can purchase postcards of this room fairly cheaply. An excellent day out.

Of course, you cannot miss this. If you go to this palace and know a bit about Catherine the Great, you will begin to feel as though you have been transported back in time. Also, you will want to read the book of the same title which is a current book and covers so much of Russian history.

Wow for sure. Oh my goodness , this place was a total wow !! The riches that are displayed are beyond beautiful . Before we got into the Palace, we were entertained by a group of 4 musicians playing out front ( for tips ) . They were great and very funny. They were playing, and suddenly they lightfootedly moved in unison to the left and then back to the right . The Palace was a little warm inside , having no A/C of course , but it was tolerable because windows were opened to let some air inside . Wonderful place to see, mind blowing wealth on display , and great historical value . The Gardens are huge, grand , fabulous, and extremely well kept . A definite must see !

Beautiful, barely accessible for the physically challenged & no one seems to care about that. Beautiful, iconic, a must-see! Happily, photos are allowed inside the palace, unlike at Peterhof - which you also must see. The amber room is stunning - sadly though, no photos allowed in this room. I definitely recommend going with a tour with a Russian guide to help you navigate through, read the signs, tell you where to go. You must stop in the little house in the garden by the lake where the singers gather, the acapella group. The building is acoustically perfect, you will be blown away! And if you are physically disabled in any way, be ready for a tough time. Traveling abroad for someone who uses a walker or wheelchair is difficult, no kidding, but it was particularly difficult in St. Petersburg and other cities in the Baltic that we visited. Staff are unsmiling and unwelcoming, but we got used to that in Russia. Carry on, enjoy, soak in the beauty and the history.

Beyond Beautiful. St. Petersburg, in general, was a wonderful surprise and our tour of Catherine's Palace was spectacular. As part of a Crystal Cruise tour, we had access when the palace was closed to the public which permitted us to have an amazing tour. The palace was so beautiful and the amber room took my breath away. Being permitted to take photographs throughout with the exception of in the amber room was a bonus. We learned a lot about St. Petersburg during this tour that was totally new.
Another glorious palace. Stunning gold leaf, amber and chandeliers by the dozen. As with the Hermitage, this is a very popular place and therefore you have to contend with many other visitors.
Great catherine palace. a very beautiful palace with a nice view and everything. very similar to versailles in paris but smaller. enjoyed it!!

Opulence at its finest. We came on a SilverSea-arranged tour and really enjoyed the grandeur and the immense scale of the palace and grounds. The restoration work is incredible, both inside and out. Some say it is on a par with Versailles, though I cannot make the comparison from personal experience. The fountains are spectacular. This is a must-see if you are in St Petersburg.

Beautiful and Opulent. The palace is huge with many rooms. There is lots of easy walking. The art works are astounding and the sheer scale of the palace and the extravagant wealth required to build it are amazing.

Same as Tsarskoe Selo. This is listed twice but under different names but very fascinating and I highly recommend visiting it especially the Amber room!! Check out what there's say about Tsarskoe Selo to learn more about Catherine's Palace.

Fabulous. What can I say. Such opulence. Gold gold and more gold. Each room is adorned with gold reliefs,mirrors,cherubs,sculptures. The history of the palace is very interesting.
The gardens are absolutely beautiful fountains everywhere. Small buildings with more Opulance. The vista and gold statues in front of the palace were breathtaking.

Very impressive tour. This is a spectacular estate and palace.The amber room was unbelievable. Do not miss this one while you are in Saint Petersburg. Try to go with a private guide to miss the lines and all the tourist.

The best of St. Petersburg's outer areas. Pushkin compares favourably vs. Peterhof and Pavlovsk in terms of the sheer beauty of what you can see. The Catherine Palace and Park (dually listed as the Tsarskoye Selo here) is one of the standout attractions of the city. It's got an absolutely wonderful lake with some beautiful historical landmarks around it - altogether, an hour-long stroll around it in the summer is very hard to beat in terms of enjoyment of a park. The palace itself is also a great landmark. So if you're only in StP for a weekend, this is the one place you want to take a mini-trip for.

Perfect place for a day trip. Perfect place for a day trip to escape city and just to enjoy nature with beautiful architecture. Palace is amazing. Park is clean and really big, if you are lucky with weather you can spend there all day walking and enjoying it.
A Summer palace worth a visit.. This is a spectacular estate and palace. I preferred Peterhof as the fountains or more unusual but this palace is just behind it.

Must See. We loved this site, but don't think I would tackle without the wonderful service of our private guide from Alex's Tours. She moved us through lines and ques throughout the complex. It is an amazing place and got the full appreciation of it with Ludmila's commentary along the way.

Breathtaking spectacle. If one is interested seeing true opulence, if one wants to know where the riches of Russia went and what "Russified European culture" means - then the Catherine Palace (the onetime Tsarskoye Selo) is the place to visit. Meticulously restored, it exudes imperial grandeur!
Catharine Palace. This palace has been restored to its original beauty and opulence. The furnishings and decor reflect the opulence of the Czarina's world. Very impressive tour.

Another “Must See”. Try to go with a private guided tour as the lines can be long and daunting. It will be interesting to hear the guide`s stories as there is a lot of history around this place. You can buy the tour at the Nevsky prospect opposite Zinger house (approx. 1300 RUB including transportation, guide and entrance ticket to the palace). Catherine Palace is opulent and the Amber Room is absolutely stunning. Gardens are beautiful. Great place to spend a day.

EXTRAVAGANT. This castle was completely rebuilt as is was before it was burned during WW II including a room entirely paneled in amber. It is breath-taking to see the gold decorations as well as the silk wallpaper and all the extravagant furnishings. The formal gardens were also worth seeing

Stunning and Unique. Catherine palace is Russia's Versailles and it does share a common opulence and grandeur. The exterior is it's most attractive feature. The interior is much like most palaces of the era with lots of gold leaf and ornate carvings. The "Amber room" is its most popular and worth seeing. The best time to tour is early in the morning before the large crowds arrive around 10 am. After that, like all tourist attractions anywhere in the world, the crowds become a distraction. Outside the palace are lots of street vendors with lots of "tourist" gifts for sell. They readily take euros and are far less aggressive as those in other parts of Europe. My favorite part of our tour was lunch in the cafe in one of the outer buildings on the property.
not a country cottage!. The stories surrounding this palace enhance a beautiful setting and stunning exterior and interior. Definitely a must see!
Lovely grounds and palace. Take the trip to the countryside to see this pretty palace. Very large and unique, and quite stunning to say the least.

Crowded, not quite tourist ready. We were told that 20,000 people visit this site each day and it looked like the facility was overwhelmed. There were long queues to get into the palace and few benches. When a group of us sat down on the steps, two different security guards came along to chase us off, in Russian.Personally, I didn't care for the Palace. There was an excessive amount of gold lead covering every surface to the extent that it looked tacky. The Amber Room was the main attraction and it was definitely something different, the walls and every surface covered in amber. The gardens were attractive and well maintained. This site has been compared to Versailles but it doesn't match it, I'm afraid.

Beautifully well restored Palce and grounds. This is another "Must See" is St Petersburg. It ornate interior has been painstakingly restored to its former glory after the ravages of German occupation in 1943 left as a burnt out shell. The Jade room is a world beater.

Opulent, huge palace. Catherine Palace was more opulent than Peterhof Palace. Larger too. The archways of gold, the amber room. All beautiful. The gardens are not as amazing as Peterhof but it's all relative. They were beautiful regardless. Pictures are allowed here except as noted like the Amber Room.

See this Palace with its Impressive Architecture and Interior. The Catherine Palace, 25 km south of St. Petersburg, in Tsarskoe Selo, is is a Rococo edifice with opulent interiors, famous for its amber room. If visiting the palace during the busy summer months, try to go with a private guided tour as the lines can be long and daunting. The Catherine park is a nice place to take a leisurely stroll as well. If possible, try to visit the nearby Alexander Palace where Tsar Nicholas II and Tsarina Alexandra lived with their family. The Catherine Palace ranks among the top attractions of St. Petersburg and its environs, so if you have a chance to visit, do go.
Beautiful. Again, wear comfortable shoes and clothes and walk as much as you can in order to see the most before you are very tired. Worth it.

"It's good to be king" (or queen). The building (completely reconstructed) and the grounds are over the top. Apparently the royals went there only a couple of moths per year. It gives one some sense of why common folk were attracted to revolution.
a nice place to spend the day. They lived in style, the Romononovs. Great rooms, great art. A must see. it contrasts with the apartments near by

What an amazing museum!. This palace is also a must see. The rooms in the Palace are so elaborate. Such wealth at the top and this palace displays it all. Be sure to have a guide to explain all the rooms, etc. about the Palace. It is truly amazing!

A great royal residence. The place offers a lot to see. What spoils the view is constant reconstruction of the palace (some years ago one part was under reconstruction and now the central part is again being renovated, so I have never seen the palace in its full glory) and the fact that all the canals are green from some river plants. Only the main pond is clear. Still, the pavillions, the bridges and the lawns are very impressive. The price for the park is not high.

Beautiful. We did this as a tour and it was worth every penny of the 4000 roubles we paid. We were planned for 5 hours but it was nearer 7! We travelled an hour out of the historical district and got so much history explained and then the palace and gardens are stunning. Do walk around the lake. You can take pics inside the palace which was good (except the amber room).

Terrible experience. Maybe it's because we went in August, which is peak tourist season in St Petersburg, but this was a miserable experience. I should say at the outset that the rooms in the palace are stunning, and the grounds are nice enough. But the overall experience that is created by the inefficiency of the entry system basically ruined our day. First, there's a long line to buy a ticket to enter the grounds around the palace. Once inside, visitors are treated to yet another line to buy tickets for the palace itself. Here, expect a 2 hour wait. This line is completely chaotic, with groups of people regularly cutting in ahead of you. We counted about 100 people cutting in. The ticket handlers do nothing about this and seem happy to let people regulate themselves, which leads to obvious unrest. Once inside the palace, you have to wait in line to see each room and are hearded like cattle from one room to the next. There are so many tour groups that it's hard to enjoy a room before being asked to move on. There's fewer rooms than you'd think, so before you know it you're back outside feeling robbed, depressed, and likely very hungry. Naturally, there are no food options anywhere other than an atrocious little cafe on the palace grounds. The highlight of the day was the taxi ride home.

Don't miss before and after photos. When the Germans retreated after the seige of Leningrad, they completely destroyed Catherine's Palace, razing it to the ground leaving only bits of a hollow shell behind. Russian archivists documented much of the interior prior to World War II and the palace has been under reconstruction pretty much since. In one of the hallways, you can see photos of the immense destruction which will make you marvel at the restoration that has been completed so far. I asked our guide what the Russian people thought of so much money being spent on restoring the palace to it's former glory and she said they are quite proud to see it done. Of course I was asking someone born and raised in St. Petersburg which is a showcase of Russian grandeur and wealth and very much meant to impress tourists. Unbelievably oppulent now and still not as opulent as it was in it's crowing glory days. One room has walls covered in hand-painted Chinese silk, another is completely made of amber. There is a great deal of marble, beautiful parquet flooring and chinoiserie along with a great deal of gilt. Quite amazing. The gardens are pretty but much more low key than those at Peterhof.

A must see if you go to St. Petersburg!. Versailles has nothing on Catherine's Palace, from which it was designed. Especially poignant are the photos near the end of the tour witnessing the complete and utter destruction wrought by Hitler's forces and the renovation which continues until today.
Beautiful Palace. Catherine Palace is right up there with Peterhof! The tour is great, and there are lots of artifacts to look at. The opulence is indescribable. If you get the chance, GO!!

Display of wealth and power. Very impressive rooms and palace gardens. - Getting there is a pain (unless you enjoy the train ride experience)Recommendation: you must reserve online in advance, otherwise you have no chance.

Gorgeous and not to be missed; Amber Room is WOW. Catherine Palace, aka Great Palace of Starskoye Selo, is a stunningly beautiful palace. It was under renovation in August 2014 (as is most everything else), but you will be amazed by the powder blue and white exterior, gold domes and beauty within. Once inside, you will be led, room by room thorough the palace, one room being more beautiful than the last. There are cascading corridors and arches, mirrored walls, stone, gold and beauty abound. HINT: You will not be allowed to take photos in the AMBER ROOM. They say that this is because of potential damage to the amber, but the truth is people just stay there and clog up the movement through the palace. That, in and of itself, is worth the trip here. Be prepared to be WOWED.

Beautiful Palace!. This is one of many beautiful palaces that the Russian Tzars and Tzarinas has built to surpass other European monarchs. It is beautiful from the outside and from the inside, although some of the external ornaments are made from some clay, that has to be redone evey few years. The rooms, the furnishings and everything else are grand and, of course, the breathtaking Amber room is the highlight of this palace. The photography is strictly forbidden in this room and it seems that there are several attendants of various ages mingling with tourists and making sure no one takes pictures! A must visit in St Petersburg!

A Russian Treasure..... The previous reviews really say it all. Hard to believe this was destroyed and now rebuilt in the same splendor as in the time of Catherine. Each room offers stunning things to see--so much gold everywhere. The Amber room just amazing. Was told it was redone at a cost of 12 million dollars. Viking guided tour with headset a great way to get history and explanations of what we were viewing--helped me focus on one thing at a time.
spectacular palace. We visited this palace on a tour group. we enjoyed it too much. very interesting, nice architectural building and full of Russian history. Amber room was amazing. Great.!

Compared to other sites not quite as enjoyable. This place, one of several on our TJ Tours itinerary, was extremely busy. We arrived before official opening time, along with every other tour company, cruise ship excursion etc and had to queue for about 30 minutes just as it started to pour with rain. Once inside there were people everywhere, so progress around the palace was very slow, and a bit rushed, with other tour groups pressing in behind, palace guides encouraging everyone to keep moving, but the sheer volume of people made this difficult. Not recommended if you don't like crowds, What we did get to see was impressive, but a bit samey, but does highlight why there was a revolution, the sheer opulence is both amazing but also sometimes was over the top.

Quite a trip from the city, but worth the time.. A beautiful palace expertly reconstructed after being nearly destroyed by retreating NAZI soldiers. Be sure to see the pictures in the basement of the reconstruction effort. As with many attractions in the St. Petersburg area, lines can be very long (an hour or more) if you are not in a tour group. If your time is limited, consider a tour.

Beautiful grounds and palace. Uncrowded leisurely walk around the grounds and then a look inside to satisfy all the "furniture castle" members of our group.Thought it was interesting to know how many staff was required to keep a place like this going in its glory days.

Gold even on the outside. This is a beautiful gold gilded palace. Even the outside is gilded in pure gold. Inside there is room after room of magnificent ballrooms and various treasures. Absolutely stunning. There are some people dressed in period costumes inside. You can take non flash pictures everywhere but the Amber Room because amber is very sensitive. The Amber room has all the walls covered in amber. The Nazi troops carried away some of the amber which disappeared in 1945 so it had to be recreated.The palace is surrounded by gardens. We were on a tour so we only got to see the inside. There is a large gilded gate at the entrance . This palace is a must see.
good to see. the palace was destroyed during world war 2th,but they repaired this palace for decades and now you see a nice palace with pretty gardens and lakes.

She knew how to live!. Just like the Peterhoff, but slightly smaller, this palace is spectacular. Gold, beautiful architecture and gardens it is just eye candy. Reconstruction work on this palace is complete (an amazing job considering how it was almost totally destroyed). The rooms are so well laid out and decorated with art and furniture of the time. This is a palace where you do not want to miss a thing during the tour; the floors, ceilings and walls are one work of art after another. We are so blessed to have had an opportunity to visit. Amazing!

Beautiful. The palace is magnificent. We had to battle the crowds, but it was well worth the bother.
I'm really happy to see the restorations going on. Our guide was full of history and beautiful stories to match the charming decor. Pictures can't truly describe the opulence of the palace.

Top notch, worth every penny. One of the most impressive palaces I have ever seen. And I have seen over 80 so far!We were part of an exclusive VIP-"after public hours"-tour, with Vodka/caviar reception, marching band, exclusive small group tour and ending with classical concert, dinner and folklore dance show. A little more expensive then the standard ticket, but what an experience! Always enough space and time to see the magnificent AMBER room and all the other fantastic exhibits. The architecture is great. In my opinion Catherine Palace comes out on top when comparing to Versailles in Paris or Schoenbrunn Palace in Vienna.

WONDERFUL. It paid to have a small private tour because we got a behind the scenes of the amber room visit and avoided the crowds. To say that this was magnificent is a real understatement. And to think that Peter did not even like it!
Interesting. We had a tour through SPB tours. Our group was led by a charming, knowledgeable native of St. Petersburg. The palace was very interesting to visit.

Inspiring, but….. So the Amber Room is on everybody's bucket list, and the reconstruction has been well done. The only reason I didn't give the palace five stars is that we were there on a blisteringly hot day when half the cruise ships in the Baltic had sent a tour there. On a less rushed, cooler day this would have been a true highlight. Still, no matter what, don't miss it!

Restored Beautifully. We visited the Palace on a beautiful day in July. It is such a beautiful Palace....so well restored after it was destroyed during WWII. The stories of how various artifacts were saved and restored are very interesting. The Amber Room is particularly interesting. Be sure to visit the gift shop and check out the various amber pieces available there.

Catherine Palace. I know I shouldn't say it but as my daughter said " bit over the top". The history is great and we are lucky that they rebuilt the Amber Room for us to see but some of the other rooms all look the same.

Words Cannot Do It Justice. One must see this palace...and, I agree that when going, it is best to arrange with your hotel a guide that can get you in and around the lines. The palace is not air conditioned and it gets rather hot and stuffy on warm days, so arrange your tickets 3 weeks or more in advance during the height of the summer to get morning hours. Be certain to check the photographs of the palace as it looked after the WWII destruction. It is a miracle that it was able to be reconstructed.

Guide essential - expect crowds, go early. The palace is expressive, especially the amber room. Make sure to get a good guide - the history of every room really makes it come alive. It is very crowded, rather go early. The grounds are also lovely.
Wow! Massive, beautiful palace. I could live here! Love all the rooms that were decorated by color. Lots of gold! Breathtaking! Be sure to visit!

Very Beautiful. We were here as part of a tour. No question that this palace is very beautiful and spacious. However, to be a bit objective, on the outside, it seems that a lot of it appears the same design and color, rather than have different styles, colors - in other words, more imagination!Stiill, it is beautiful and nicely restored after all the damage from WWII - photos showing it are in the basement. We didn't spend a lot of time walking along the gardens, so can't comment on that.The amber room is a Must See, after everything that's been written about it, and it did not disappoint, even though some of it are replicas. I don't know WHY photography was not allowed in this room only.

Beautiful beyond words. i was here as part of a private tour, from an Oceania cruise. This is beautiful and ornate, filled with lovely furniture and art work. The amber room is amazing. The basement has an exhibit showing the devastation after WWII, and the palace is basically a complete reconstruction. But, it's worth every minute.
Catherine Palace and Park. The grounds alone take ones breath away. One would just love to slowly meander through these gardens and let everything slowly settle in.

Must See. Beautiful palace restored after heavy damage from WWII. I took some photos that showed how much damage it had. The famous amber room is a complete restore - only one panel left from the original, rest has gone missing after German troops took it away. The park is beautiful, we didn't anticipate it was such a huge place, so didn't visit much of the park portion due to time constraint. Suggest you spend a good 4 hours strolling the ground.

Amber Room = saving grace!. This facility is billed as Russia's Versailles; it doesn't measure up to that comparison. Our visit timed with the G-20 conference and the palace was used to host some of the state dinners and meetings. The attempt to spruce it up fell short in some areas; the exterior was repainted and the "gold" exterior décor was painted a brown mustard color which didn't create a noble effect. The mirrored hall is attractive, the gardens are beautiful and the Amber Room is breath-taking. Overall it was worthwhile.

Beautiful decadence. This Palace has the wow factor. There were audible gasps when we entered the great hall. But every room was stunning. To fully appreciate it you need a guide who can tell you information such as the Story of the Russian 'Delft' stoves.Curiously, though lovely, with an interesting story, the Amber Room was smaller than we expected and not the most memorable room.A fun Russian band entertained us waiting to get in & a male choir sang to us in one of the garden pavilions which used to be Catherine the Great's bath house-which had great acoustics.A MUST SEE.

Amazing inside and outside. This was originally a show palace for Catherine the Great to impress visitors to Russia. Sadly, there was extensive damage to the palace during WWII (pictures of this are in the lower level), but work has been done to restore the palace. The floors and ceilings alone are breathtaking. This is the palace with the amber room in which everything (walls, picture frames, mirror frames, etc.) is made of amber. The artisans who rebuilt this room after the original panels were "lost" after the war certainly did themselves proud. There are long lines to get in, but a small band was playing music while we waited - they even played music from Swan Lake and "danced" like the four swans. As with most of the old buildings in St. Petersburg, there's no air conditioning and few restroom facilities, so be prepared for that. We were there on a 90 degree day, so the mass of humanity made it particularly stuffy, but I still enjoyed everything about it.

Go visit! Beautiful!. We went to Catherine Palace as part of a tour organized by our cruise ship, and am so happy we did. So much to see and learn, it is gorgeous inside, and the Amber room is beautiful. It is 45 minutes from the old town, but definitely worth going to if you have the means of transportation and time.
Beautiful palace. Loved it. Took a tour that was offered by our hotel. It is about a 40 minute ride from center of town. A must see if you visit St. Petersburg.

Beautiful Summer Palace. On our recent cruise of the Baltic, St. Petersburg was one of our ports of call. One tour offered was to Catherine's Palace, the former summer palace of the Russian czars. It was at one time occupied by the Nazis and subsequently nearly destroyed. Thankfully, major portions of this beautiful building have been restored and it is now available for tours. It is a VERY POPULAR tourist destination, so be prepared for lots of people and long lines. It seems like there are two different entrances and one never knows (nor can choose) which one will be assigned. Our tour guide told us that both were similar and allowed one to see the exact same number of restored rooms; just slightly different. The highlight of the tour (and why the lines are long and slow) is the Amber Room. During WWII, the room was "lost" (of course, the rumor was that the Nazis had something to do with this). In any case, after many years of reconstruction work funded by the German government, in 2003 the room was reopened. Absolutely no pictures are allowed in here, but people want to stand and gaze at it for hours. This is why the lines slow down. As one moves through the various rooms, one gets a real sense of what it was like to come to a palace...to be overwhelmed by opulence. Our guide told us that that was the main purpose of this palace; not necessarily to live there (the royal family actually preferred another palace for that) but to entertain and amaze people. The grounds also include extensive gardens, although we did not have time to go through them. We were also quite amused to be greeted not once but twice by mini brass bands. The second one (right outside the entrance) was a great amusement and made the waiting time go by quicker. This group is larger than the first and quite entertaining. They played the dance of the swans from "Swan Lake" and even moved the line of players left and right in the manner the dancers do in the ballet during this number. It was great!
Summer Palace. One of the most beautiful palace you will ever see. Parquet floors, amber room. many beautifully decorated rooms. Another example of opulence fo the time.
Lovely palace. lovely palace and nice garden. Though the palace was repainted in a too "new" color, it is still a marvelous place to visit.

One hour south of St P. We went on a Russian tour from Kazan Cathedral (R1500) as the English ones were twice the price. The guide spoke no English but thankfully a man on the tour spoke fluent English and told us the essentials - like where and what time to meet for the bus back!! I understand you can go individually by public transport but in July it is very busy. being in a group, we went in the back entrance, went through with a Russian speaking guide, and a special roped off route from all the crowds who also had to queue for access.Later we had time to explore the grounds on our own and go to Alexander Palace.

Amber Room and so much more. Every room we walked into was stunning to look at, even the parquet floors were breath taking. World class craftmanship, gold gilding everywhere, just majestic to look at!

I loved this palace. This palace makes me go back in history. Each room is covered with information and details. It is a beautiful and well rebuilt palace. I enjoyed the ballroom and the ambar chamber, they make you understand the power and beauty of the place. The gardens are also very pretty and conserved.

Terrific. We visited with a guide which we appreciated. We were able to make our way through the crowd as our guide new all the shortcuts.The palace was a real masterpiece and the finish inside with all the gold was unbelievable. Although visiting early the crowd was overwhelming. The gardens were also enjoyable and well worth taking the time to visit.
Tsars Nobility. every thing shows willingness of Tsars to Nobility , wide saloons , rooms with numerous gild facilities ,... it is too beautiful but same as Hermitage too crowded,....

Outside the city centre, but magic!. This great palace is located a bit outside the city centre, so you have to expect some traffic to go and return, but it is worth of it. The palace is very elegant in Baroque Style, and the garden surrounding it include a little lake shaped as the Black sea.

Spectacular. Beautifully restored, this Palace is truly spectacular. The mirrored ballroom is beautiful including the floors of ornate timber design. The Amber room is a masterpiece. The gardens are lovely and all are well maintained. Must have been lovely living there. The only negative were the crowds and groups run on a tight schedule unfortunately. I would suggest don't go in peak season as the lines are long.

Gold, luxury and Amber.. Every superlative you have heard about this place does not do it justice. You really have to see it yourself to believe the wealth that Czars had. Wait until you see the Amber room.

Too much?. Never too much! For a peak into a decadent history and to appreciate the post-war efforts to restore this beautiful building, take the opportunity to visit this palace! The gardens are lovely and the rooms open for public viewing will simply take your breath away. Most visitors come with groups or have guides: we tried to do it on our own and felt swept-away by larger groups. We speak no Russian and there was very little help available in English. If you are timid, you might want to arrange a guide.

Lovely gardens and palace. We visited the palace and gardens with a guide and were very impressed. The gardens are very beautiful and a lovely place to walk around - we just needed more time! The palace is spectacular - it is interesting to see the original baroque design (Elizabeth) compared to the classical style in a few of the rooms and extensions favoured by Catherine. Given the extent of the damage in WWII the restoration is amazing.We wished we had organised a longer tour and taken in Alexander Palace which is nearby so I would suggest that visitors do that if they can.

Beautiful house. Catherine Palace is very large and ornate and there's a lot of walking involved. The worst bit is, if there are a lot of groups, you get held up waiting to view the Amber Room (no photographs!). Once past this point, everything speeds up. Incredible to see the Amber Room although it was a bit disappointing as the photographs of it glamorise it. However, the furniture & fittings are well worth seeing. There's even a Wedgewood room.

"It's good to be the king!". Or the czarina in this case.. A beautiful and very nicely restored palace. As soon as you enter the rooms your eyes will open wide simply because of their splendor. An absolute must-see.
BREATHTAKING. Prepare to spend a lot of time here, we were limited to 3 hours and it wasnt near enough. I took over 200 photos and was blown away with the beauty and opulence.

Gorgeous!. Loved the Catherine Palace! Downside - tremendous crowds but our Russian guide did a great job of shepherding us through the crowds. Such a beautiful palace and grounds - loved the amber room recreation. Definitely a high point of our Russian visit.

Absolutely beautiful. Far nicer than Peterhof we think. Did organised tour. Far better than trying to go on own. Rooms are exquisite and photographs allowed apart from gorgeous Amber Room. Grounds are exquisite. You have to put little overshoes over your shoes in Peterhof and Catherine Palace.

A breathtaking masterpiece. Externally beautiful, with classic gold leaf onion domes. Inside spectacular rooms lavishly furnished. Beautiful paintings. Then their is the famous Amber Room. this room alone is worth the visit. The gardens are excellent but not as spectacular as the interior.Special overshoes have to be worn inside and are provided free of charge. Photography is allowed inside except in the Amber Room, and staff enforce this. What I did was to go into the next room and take a wide angle picture of the room.Again, another very busy sight.

So detailed and beautiful. Since the moment I got off the tour bus I felt something strong. Everything is so well cared, there are gorgeous gardens, the front of the building is really beautiful. Inside you can't stop taking photos and even then you'll probably miss some details. The building was partly destroyed by a big fire long ago, but there's no trace of it. Taking photos in some rooms is forbidden, take it mentally. :)After the building visit, you're gonna walk through a garden maze, toward a nice place by a pond, where 4 men sing beautifully.Amazing place, very very beautiful, must go!

Beautiful palace - but go as part of a group tour - and don't forget your camera. We visited St Petersburg on a cruise and visited the palace as part of a 2 day tour. We had to stand in line for a while before we were allowed in. It was very very busy with group tours and the groups were given priority over individual visitors - so if you try to go it alone, you may wait in line all day and not get in!The place was mindblowingly opulent even though the restoration is still a work in progress. Everywhere you turn there are the most fabulous chandeliers and gilt work. We took loads of photos as thankfully they didn't object to photography.We went in July and it was very hot - we soon discovered that Catherine's treasures did not include air conditioning!We did a whirlwind tour of the building and then explored the grounds for a while - absolutely fabulous. Whether your interest is history, architecture, art - or you just like to see how the other half lived, this is definitely worth a visit - and a good guide can bring it all to life!

Overwhelming buildings and parks. Be prepared for hours of walking with very few opportunities to rest your feet. Only a fraction of the palace has been restored after its destruction, but the rooms that we visited gave a good indication of the enormous amounts of money spent on this palace in its time. When visiting this place, you can only wonder that it took the russian people 150 years to rebel against the excesses of the tzar family.

What a surprise!. Just when I thought I'd seen it all at the Hermitage we were brought here. The amber room is incredible, such amazing restoration when you read about who most of it was destroyed by fire too. Well worth the trip.

Catherine's Palace totally OTT but worth seeing. Gold gold and more gold but a very interesting tour and well worth seeing!! The wealth of that era is so evident. I do think that a trip to St Petersburg wont be complete without seeing Catherine's Palace.

Makes you realise how the privaliged lived. Certainly a very richly decorated building which is part of the whole Hermitage 'group' of buildings. Worth going on a canal trip as well so that you can see the whole set up from inside and out.

All that glitters. You have heard the expression, "all that glitters is not gold." This palace is the exception. It is all gold. In fairness, this was the last stop on a 2 day whirlwind tour of this great city and frankly we were searching equally for the gold and the finish line. That said, this compares favorably to many palaces we have toured in Europe over the years. Its elegance is definitely not understated. A pessimist might say it is gaudy with some degree of accuracy. Unfortunately the anticipation of the ship's horn prevented more than a bus window view of the grounds to my regret.

Opulent. Unfortunately the day we visited was cool and rainy and from the time we got off the bus until we entered the palace, one hour had passed. You are very area of the control of the Russian authorities. We were not allowed to keep our jackets on so had to go to a coat check and then we had to go to another area to cover our shoes. Be prepared for massive crowds. The gold leaf decoration and the different beautiful woods on the floor are magnificent and opulent and not to be missed although I couldn't help feeling the contrast with how ordinary Russian people seem to live. We didn't spend much time in the gardens because of the rain and there didn't seem to be many colours only green but it was early June so perhaps there wasn't too must growing or planted yet.

top attraction. about an hours drive from the port but well worth the trip the palace is stunning so interesting and the gardens are lovely i would certainly recomend this to anybody visiting st petersburg

Catherine's Palace - don't miss the Amber Room!. Originally built as a modest two story summer home for Catherine - wife of Peter the Great, the palace was expanded tremendously by her daughter the Empress Elizabeth. Now it's an unbelievable, over-the-top building with something wonderful to experience in every room. The grounds are also extensive and have smaller summer "follies" to visit; surprising vistas every direction you turn. If possible, try to get there first thing to be in line when it opens. There were military men playing music when we arrived (before the gates opened) and being amongst the first in made for a less crowded experience - well worth getting up early. Although we didn't have a chance to explore the town of Pushkin (where the palace is located), it looks like it might be worth a stroll as well.
A palace of Gold. They are still doing restoration on the exterior, but the interior has rooms of gold leaf and amber. Beautiful!!!
Going through Russia. This was a palace for Catherine 1. Built for the wife of Peter the Great, the palace is surrounded by magnificent gardens. All of this is from the Czarist era.

Amber Room is a highlight. The palace is very much worth a visit. We engaged a tour guide with car to help make the journey and entrance easier and we were pleased we did, as it was raining the day that we visited.The palace buildings are impressive and the grounds are very lovely including the small "hermitage" . Once inside the palace, the state rooms are impressive and the Amber room was truly spectacular.

Worth The Long Drive. We visited the Tsars Village as part of our 2 day tour of St Petersburg. It is a good hours drive from the town centre but it is worth the journey. Following a major fire much of the building has been reconstructed, and renovation is still taking place. As you approach, the palace appears as an imposing but colourful structure with pretty gold onion dome on the roof. Through the entrance gates and you are in a huge courtyard with the palace on one side and the gardens on the other. Great photo opportunities.Inside there are shops and toilets if you need them There were many tour groups here so had to queue to get into the main palace. On entry you have to put some stylish green covers over your shoes. You then follow a set route through the various rooms of the palace, waiting for the group in front to move on. Many of the old rooms are spectacularly ornate, and the main attraction, the Amber Room, was unusual. It was not rushed and we had plenty of time to hear all about the history of this amazing palace.We would love to explored the grounds further but had to get back into the city. It is worth a visit, but recommend that you go with a guide to fully appreciate what you are seeing.

A beautiful palace and gardens, I loved some of the smaller grotto's. Home of the world famous amber room, I actually didn't like the amber room, but loved every other room and the gardens. I loved the gold room, which leads to the never ending corridor, you feel like you are looking into two mirrors and seeing a never ending reflection. I loved the transition from the gilted rooms to some of the newer styles. I loved the furniture and the stories that went with them. Some of the pictures at the end of the tour that show the extent of damage to the palace before the renovation are quite shocking, it's really unbelievable to think it's the same place. In one of the little grotto's in the gardens there was a 4 man group who sang like a choir, the acoustics of the building made it sound like there were hundreds of men singing. It was a truly beautiful moment. I did love this palace but if I had limited time on my itinerary and I wasn't hoping to see the amber room, I would choose the Peterhof gardens or the Faberge museum over this palace. Those were my favourite parts of my overall tour.
Excellent. This is a wonderfull palace to visit and when you see the restoration that has took place since the last war you will be impressed. Go.

Amazing .........but not as good as Peterhof (in my opinion). Amber room is truly outstanding as is the amazing mirrored hall - Jaw droppingly amazing. As with my other reviews - use a guide, get there early, and you'll be able to take some amazing pictures and indulge in looking at some amazing artefacts from such an amazing time in history. I'm not particularly interested in history but the guide kept my attention and just as I was getting bored of seeing any more rooms..........they finished. Really brought Russian history alive into a way that is understood. Gardens were ok but not as good as Peterhof. You can't take long coats or large into palace so either leave them behind or be prepared for the scrum on the way out

Take a break. As wonderful as St Petersburg is, make time to get out of the city to visit this site. The palace is simply ( well maybe a bit ornate) lovely. Make a day of the journey and spend time in the park as well. It will be well worth your time.

"Grand Evening of the Tsars", indeed. During a recent visit to St. Petersburg, we wanted to see Catherine's Palace in Pushkin. When we signed up for a tour of that name (above) through our cruise operator, I wondered if it would be worth it. Well, what an unbelievable evening it was. It began about 8PM. We started with a wonderful, spirited outdoor performance by the palace guard's brass band, then were ushered inside the palace for a tour. After donning shoe covers to protect the parquet floors, our small group got to tour a number of rooms in the palace while a harpsichordist and flutist in period dress played in the background. The artwork, gilt, and grandeur in the palace is indescribable. I won't even try. The evening continued with a string quartet playing Rimsky-Korsakov in the ballroom while actors portraying Catherine and her consort were in attendance with us all. The guests sipped glasses of champagne as we watched a pair of dancers in period attire dance a pas de deux to the chamber music. Following the performance, "Catherine and her consort" left by royal horse-drawn carriage. Dinner followed. It was quite a regal experience!

Magnificent decor. This one so out of the.city but we hired a private guide, Boris Leostrin at leostrinebo@yahoo.com to take us there. He got the tickets in advance. We cut to the front of the lines. He was knowledgeable and passionate about his cultural heritage. You must see this palace above all other palaces in St. Petersburg or you will see only the ordinary.
Beautiful Ground. Could do with more flowery garden and ornament plants.The big ground seems a bit bare, need more imagination on how to make this garden more beautiful.
A must see!. Well worth a visit, even though there will most likely be a ton of people. The rooms are unbelievable.

Must See. The Palace is beautiful and wonderfully restored. Amazing to see the Amer Room and a replica of a dress of EMpres catherine. The mirrored hall was based on Versailles and is breathtaking. Every room is fabulous. Sadly our tour (organised by oru cruise ship) had to wait an hour outside to get in as other tour guides & parties overtook ours!!!! So we never saw the gardens despite them being part of the tour. I suggest you take a private tour you organise yourself online before you go to ST Petersburg. A friend did and had no queues. They also supply your visa.

Nice break from the city.. Came during a weekend around noon. The queue for the palace was considerable due to tour groups. Luckily there is a lot to see and do on the very big territory. We wandered around and saw the whole park. When we came back to the palace there was almost no queue. Although even then there were a lot of people in the guided tour. Very informative guide and stunning palace interiors. Overall a great day out. My advice, dont be tempted to go for the palace first, wander and let the queue die down.

Not to Miss. Yes it is very crowded in July but we read the reviews in TA before and therefore went on a private tour that was arranged by the wonderful Anna at the Domina Prestige Hotel. It was a very good idea: no lines, a car from the hotel and back + a lot of explanations and information about History, Art and whatever you can think of about the Palace and other attractions in St. Petersburg , All of this from our guide Ludmila + a bonus of a visit to St. Nicolas Church. Due to Ludmila we had a wonderful and enlightening experience in the Palace. She also guided us through the crowds and we were not detained so much which was a relief. We highly recommend to go there on a tour.

Catherine Palace for the day. A lovely place to visit. It has been substantially rebuilt since the Germans occupied it in WW2. Both the inside of the building and the gardens are beautiful. Would rate it slightly behind the Peterhof but should definitely not to be missed.
Beautiful. An iconic sight but jam packed with tourists. It is still worthy though. The boat ride over was to be tolerated and not a highlight, but interesting with all the different people.

#3 must see in St Pete, read why. #1 is Spilled Blood (5star) #2 Hermitage (2star but a must) Catherine's Palace should be your number three on your to do list. Building looks to be in the process of being renovated, which is much needed. There are wonderful works of art within its rooms. The rooms, furniture and decorations are amazing. Amber room is superb. Amazing to see the pictures at the end of the tour of how much of the place was destroyed by the Nazis. It can be crowed and the bathroom situation is horrible. Please beware and use restroom before getting there if at all possible.

Being herded like cattle through marvellous surroundings. I visited Catherine Palace in the summer of 2014 as an individual tourist. No organised group, no bus transfer, I simply took the train from central Petersburg to the town, a bus from the railway station to the park entrance, and queued for a ticvket for myself. And that's where the bad experience starts...The place is extremely crowded. I understand that everyone else there is just a tourist like me who wants to see the same place as me, and that the management is not responsible for the large number of visitors, but this review is about my experience, not about attributing blame to anybody, so I guess it legitimately affects the review. Essentially, you queue for something like 15 minutes to get a ticket to the park, and once inside, you'd have to queue again, for at least another 45 minutes, to get a ticket to the palace (you cannot get into the palace or even the palace ticket booth without entering the park first, for which you need a park ticket). Both times, you queue in the blistering sun, without anything around to give you shade. Prices are not extremely high, but considerable (120 roubles for the park ticket, 400 roubles for the palace). Inside the palace, the assembly line experience continues. You are herded from one crowded room into another, and even if you don't join a tour the wardens will ask you to move on if you stay in a room for too long. The tour takes, I hear from Tripadvisor (I didn't take it myself) only about twenty minutes, but even if you stroll around on your own it won't take much longer than that.
