Staff, and that applies throughout from ticket clerks over wardens to salespeople etc, are generally rather harsh and unfriendly, most of them speaking only Russian, and even those who do speak English do not seem to include words like “please“, “excuse me“ or “thank you“ in their vocabulary.This is a pity, because the place itself, both the park and the palace, and above all of course the amber room, are marvellously beautiful. The conditions around the visit ruin the experience to a great degree, though.

Gorgeous!. Oh, where do I begin? To know that the palace was all but destroyed by the Nazis, and see it now, I was amazed. Cons: the crowds, but like I have said before in other reviews, what do you expect in the middle of summer in St. Petersburg? It is definitely worth strolling through, and seeing the Grand Hall and the Amber Room, however, the whole palace is beautiful on the inside.
golden palace. We took a bus tour to visit here. Really beautiful palace and garden.

Opulence and Gold Leaf. Outside, the palace looks beautiful with classic lines but inside you are overwhelmed by the amount of gold leaf everywhere. The rooms are opulent in the extreme but elegant for all that.
splended Catherine Palace and park. It is so gold! In the middle of restoring the exterior. very beautiful - the palace as well as the garden.

Gold, Gold, Gold!. Sparkling gold sprinkled all over a pure white palace---against a blue sky. Over 100 kilograms of gold were used to gild the facade and rooftop stutues. This is Rococo design at its superb whimsical elegance. From a historical perspective, one thinks about why royal families met sad ends---considering how the peasantry lived. But what inspiration---humanity's excellence in building, craftsmanship and design.

Spectacular Palace from the Old a world. This stop is a must when visiting Russia. The opulence, grandeur, and style of a world long ago is a spectacle of the time. Russia, the old and the new Russia, should be on your travel itinerary. Visiting in July is their summer but the weather then was not too warm. We visited as part of a Viking River Cruise land tour.

Interesting palace, but WOW in the park!. The palace reminds me a lot of Peterhof, but the Gardens are definitely different. They were the highlight of our visit, and I recommend spending definite time exploring in the park. There is a Hermitage building in the park that was a retreat for the tsars, and fascinating.
Amazing opulence, and spectacular sites.. This was breathtaking --- gold everywhere. The Tsar''s really knew how to live extravagantly... The shear size and setting were amazing.

Impressive Palace, Shame about the guide.. Booked this trip via Thomson Cruises and we had the guide from Hell.The palace itself is magnificent considering the damage done during WW2 and the incredible restoration project that is ongoing. Whilst we were waiting to go in we were entertained by a costumed marching band who were excellent and speeded up what would have been a very boring 30 min wait. They do not allow you to take larger bags round with you but there is a secure coat & bag drop next to the toilets.You have to put on paper overshoes but, be aware, one size does not fit all and one of our party was shouted at for not wearing them properly due to the possible damage to the parquet flooring.There are stairs to enter the main rooms so some areas may not be suitable for those with mobility issues.The rooms themselves are magnificent and it's hard to believe that it was an empty shell within living history. The replica of the Amber room is the only area that does not permit photography but you can video and photo all other areas. When I tried to ask questions about some of the items I was told not to ask question and I feel it was obvious that she did not know anything that did not come from her script. Due to the weather and the attitude of our guide we were unable to experience the gardens and we were rushed through the rooms a lot faster than a lot of our party would have liked as they were slow walkers and wanted to enjoy and absorb as much of the Palace as possible. There is a gift shop which takes Credit cards, Euros, US dollars and Roubles. The toilets inside the palace are free and there are some pay toilets outside that cost €0.50 to use. Would definitely recommend a visit but try and choose your guide carefully.

Tsarskoye Selo. Well worth the travel to see this Palace. I was able to get my ticket on-line and got right in when it opened. The amber room is only a replica of what was originally there. Still, the palace is very impressive. The bathrooms are clean. You can travel to it by taking the marshrutki from the Moskovskaya station. (From the park in the square, situate yourself so that you are behind Lenin and head for those minibuses, just confirm with the driver before you hop on!)

Beautiful Palace architecture. The size of Catherine's Palace amazed us. We were made aware of the architecture of Rastrelli, the Chief Architect, and Charles Cameron, and impressed by the decorative detail of the rooms within. Even more significant was that the palace was badly damaged by war and has been restored. The Amber Room, a magnificent room designed wholly with amber, had to also be restored. To this day, panels stolen by the Nazi's are missing. Palace gardens were extensive with many pavilions along side a lake. A beautiful visit.

Lavish even though redone after WWII. As our tour group waited in line, outside, in the palace's courtyard, which is surrounded with a black and gilt trimmed wrought iron fence and gate, I admired the unique exterior features of this building. Unlike the Winter Palace and Peterhof's Grand Palace, this multiple storied long rectangular building is painted light blue with white trim. Large sculptured red clay figures of Atlas, holding up the world, surround each window. The last czar who lived here with his family was whisked away during the Russian Revolution from these lavish surroundings to Siberia to be executed. After WWII, this palace was a ruin with only 5 original rooms remaining in good condition; 50 other rooms had to be completely redone using photos to do the restoration. Pictures inside show the extensive damage and then comparing those to the finished result, I just marveled at Russian workmanship. The sparkle of the gilt decor in these rooms, like the State rooms, reception hall, dining hall, and sitting rooms stayed with me for some time because it was so ornately done. For example, rooms are accessed through a continuous hall, with doorways in one line. When I looked backwards through these hallways, it seemed like I was seeing the same gilt adorned massive doorway through many mirrors all reflecting the same image. The amber room, a square room which probably is a major attraction for tourists, is much smaller in comparison to the other rectangular rooms and is "wallpapered" from ceiling to floor with Baltic amber tiles. This is just beautifully done and the rich soft amber color complements the gilt decor in nearby rooms. Another room that really impressed me was similar to the Hall of Mirrors in the Versailles Palace with its mirrors reflecting images on the opposite walls, French doors for windows, and many huge sparkling crystal candelabras. In this room, the ornate gilt wood trims on the walls and around the doors are out of this world. Some of the private rooms used by royalty have silk damask on the walls, painted ceilings, royal blue delft corner fireplaces, writing desks with drawers, and upholstered chairs. In one of these rooms, a dining table had been set up for dinner with a white tablecloth and a decorative rope of flowers. A mannequin was shown wearing a dress worn by Catherine in the 1700's (nearby on a wall was a painting of her in the very same style of dress). Signs in English placed discreetly beside a doorway indicated the name of the room, but the rooms were so crowded I missed most of these signs. I was glad our itinerary allowed time (about 1 hr) to visit Catherine's Palace, but we didn't have time to walk in the surrounding gardens. These grounds were visible from the windows in the palace, however, so that had to do. This palace is located 15 miles out of St. Petersburg in Pushkin (about a half hour drive) which appeared to be a very pleasant town as we drove through it with parks alongside the roads and many trees. We had seen Peterhof, the Grand Palace, in the morning which is about a 40 minute drive from Pushkin. With a 1 hr lunch in between, I found that visiting these two palaces outside of St. Petersburg in one day was not tiring as I could rest my feet in the bus while being driven from one place to the next. If you have time for only 1 of these palaces, it is a toss up to which one to go to. Either one will give you a sense of grandeur of the czarists' homes.

Great Palace. This palace is amazing really beautiful and also what they are doing to recover everything that was destroyed after World war 2 is amazing . Important to have a tour guide explaining you and see all the information of how they are restoring every room
Gold, gold and more gold.. If you see nothing else, you must see Catherine's Palace & Park. The renovation of the Amber room is beyond belief.

An amazing display of art and decoration designed to impress. Having been to the Hermitage the day before, we were delighted with the Palace and grounds, and the State Rooms that were open to view in a grand, bowling alley-like row of gilt and art going out into the distance. The Amber Room was a highlight, as was the Ballroom. I was disappointed that the living spaces were closed to public view.

Amber room is breathtaking. Another beautiful and lavish palace. The Amber Room is the highlight even though it is replicated from the original stolen by the Nazis and either destroyed or still missing. A must see while in St Petersburg.

Great experience. Part of our 2 day tour took us here ...it would be difficult to do it on your own as it is quite a way out of the city...well worth the drive. It has been restored to it's original condition and has to be seen to be believed.

Exquisite!. Riches beyond belief behind the walls of this beautiful blue and white palace. We had to don cloth slippers over our shoes to keep them from scratching the inlaid wood floors. Again, as in other sights that day, over-the-topness in every gilded detail. Just breathtaking.

Catherine Palace and Park at Pushkin. Catherine sure knew how to live. The Palace is famous for its Amber Room. A lot of the rooms are gilded in Gold. We had to wait in queue for a long time. There was a lively band which was playing on the grounds. The Palace is so huge that it is difficult to even photograph the whole thing. Worth waiting in the queue to see how magnificent it is.
Ornate and over the top. This is an amazingly beautiful palace. The amber room alone is worth the visit. We have nothing in the US that even comes close.
Wow!. This place is unreal! I can't imagine having a home away from home such as this! Gorgeous Palace and surroundings. Definitely worth the visit.

Gold gold everywhere not a drop to take. Catherine's palace of course you would expect everything to be extremely posh, but as our guide pointed out she was consumed by GOLD, and everything that could be embellished was gilded.It was a bit overwhelming but her love for gold carried thru every room regardless, suggest you wear sunglasses because of the glare ( kidding of course ). The palace grounds were magnificent also.

Amazing. Another amazing building in St Petersburg. The blue and gold really make this place stand out. The gardens are so pristine and beautiful. We only had a short time to visit inside but what we saw was unbelievable - you can understand why there was a revolution! I would recommend visiting here with a tour guide especially if your time is limited as they will show you the important and most interesting parts. This is a must see place when in St Petersburg but be warned the queues can get quite long!

One of the best palaces!. Spent about 5 hours visiting Catherine Palace on a beautiful day. Got there from St. Petersburg by taking the subway, then a local bus. Total transit time to the site was one hour, which was also very easy and cheap. We arrived at the palace around 10 am. Since we didn't have pre-purchased tickets, we looked at the line of people waiting to purchase tickets when the ticket office opened at noon. Since only about 8 people were in line, we took a chance and decided to walk around the grounds to look at the park. Bad decision! We returned at 11:15 am to find that ~50 people were now in the line. That doesn't sound like much, but what we didn't know is each person was holding a place in line for others. For example, the individual in front of us was holding places for 13 others. So at noon the line went from 50 to ~200 in a matter of minutes. It took us until 1:15 pm to get into the palace. So if there is one recommendation, get there early if you aren't on a tour or have tickets...and get in line. The palace tour itself took ~40 minutes, and was well worth the wait. The place is spectacular and unlike the Peterhof Palace, you can take pictures.The only shortcoming the site lacks given the number of people visiting is sufficient dining facilities. We stopped by one restaurant located beside the lake and had an enjoyable lunch, but their overall dining capacity is limited. Visiting Catherine Palace is a great day trip to take from St. Petersburg, well worth the time and money.

Beautiful. Have to see but need to love history, my teens and young adults loved it! the amber room is awesome! The securiety ladies are rude though and so are some other tourist running into you, the place was packed try not to go in june or july too crowed. still the place is beautiful! beware long restroom lines hugh

Grounds are amazing, the palace OK. First tip: Avoid on a Monday when the Hermitage is closed! The masses of cruise tour hordes was overwhelming in the palace (which is really only a copy anyway--the original was destroyed by the Germans in WWII). But the grounds are worth the entire visit. Not the incredible fountains you find at Peterhof, but the gardens and outbuildings are just amazing.

What a Palace.. Catherine Palace is undoubtedly one place to see on a trip to St. Petes. The Palace itself is adorned with majestic paintings and statues. Together with its park, you can stroll for hours enjoying this beauty.

Beautifully restored and a lovely visit to the countryside. This Palace is reasonably located in the countryside about 40 minutes outside the city. We were blessed with superb weather throughout our visit which only highlighted how well restored the palace and grounds to their original condition. The gardens are well worth visiting all the way down to the lake area, bearing in mind that many of those who created the landscape originally worked on Versailles, which is evident as one walks around. Definitely worth the effort to leave the city and make this part of any visit to St Petersburg.

Ornate beyond belief. The gold inside and outside this palace is beyond belief. Although the grounds/courtyard are very modest, the inside of this palace is filled with ornate rooms especially the Amber Room.

Catherines Palace. We were on a guided tour to Catherines Palace and gardens with a Thomson cruise. We were told it was best to visit early morning before the crowds gathered at the gate to enter the grounds. Our tour group were there 9 oclock and there was still a crowd waiting.An orderly group were waiting at the gate when along came an American group straight to the front of the gates as though there was nobody there and expected to be let in .Unfortunatly they were.Once inside the gardens there was another crowd of people waiting to get into the palace. To keep the crowd entertained there was 4 trumpeters play Russian music and dancing. Once inside the rooms are magnificent with gold leaf covering the walls and statues. There is so many people viewing that you just have to go with the flow and move when they move. Then there is the amber room where the whole of the room is covered with pieces of amber.We were told by the guide thet during the war the palace was just about destroyed by the Nazis who laid bombs in the rooms to destroy the place even riding motor bikes in the corridors. Fortunatley over the years it has been restored back to its original splender but how people could live in such opulence when people were dying of starvation outside makes you think does it not. Well worth a visit The gardens and lake are worth a visit if you have time. A lot of the statues were buried in the grounds during the war then dug up afterwards.....

St Catherines Palace. We had a wonderful time in St. Petersburg. Found the Palace to be the most beautiful I have ever seen. Although their were a lot of people we were on a private tour with with a very knowledgeable young lady called Alana who worked for Kurs-Spb. tour operator. very well organised, can highly recommend them. As we were on a private tour we did not have to wait inlong queques, would recommend you do this if in St. Peterburg for a short time. We had 2 days and saw everything we wanted to see. Gail

never again. This is truly a "once in a life-time" experience. If you are not part of one of the hundreds of Tour groups you may as well forget about trying to enjoy the palace as an individual. The wait outside just to again wait inside was in excess of 1 1/2 hours. Once inside you wait again in line to purchase yet again another ticket only to be jammed in between a constant succession of rude tour group operators. There is at best limited English language signage even regarding where to queue for entry. The staff rates second only to the tour operators in rudeness. Suggest buying the DVD or a coffee table book and pretending you were there. It would likely be much more enjoyable.

Catherine's Summer Palace is the Russian Versailles. This palace was a huge place that was large enough to be the full-time home of Catherine the Great. This palace has gone through good and bad times. When Catherine lived here it was a wonderful place for family and entertaining her cousins from the other monarchies of Europe. Then came the revolution and you see why the peasants revolted. She had the gold and they had nothing to eat. Then the Soviet period, followed by World War II. The sad part is that the Nazis lived in it, thus keeping it in good shape, during WWII. However, when they knew they had lost the war, they torched the place. The Russians have rebuilt it, and are re-doing the rooms one by one. They are replacing the gold leaf on the outside of the palace to make it look like it did when Catherine was alive. It is beautiful. On display are photos of how it looked after the Nazis destroyed it. Make sure to take a close look at the Amber Room – with amber panels on the walls. The comment of the other folks on the tour, was that they were trying to get decorating ideas to use at home. Ah, if only.

Good day out but full of tourists!. Very busy early on but thins out by later afternoon so good time to go inside then. As in all of Russia no helpful signs unless you read Russian. You pay for a park ticket - 120 rub per peeson to get in park then you pay once inside the palace itself. Have to wear protective foot mitts. Again why don't people move after getting the miss before trying to balance on one foot trying to get them on. We don't bother with the audio and guide. Wait until you get up the stairs and then push past all the tour groups or spend hours listening to guides drone on and on. The Park is very nice and is probably the best bit. Spent most of the day there waiting for the queue to subside before going into the palace. Beware that there is renovation work going on at the moment so does spoil the outside a bit. Getting there from st.petersberg was an adventure. Used bus then train then bus. From Pushkin station use bus 382 370 371 or 378. Little old lady in kiosk outside station gave us a little piece of paper with this info on - obviously been asked many times before. Tip - use Google maps and it'll give you all buses and train numbers and even the closest bus stops.

Stunning rooms and beautiful gardens. Well worth visiting. Went wi a tour guide which was the best idea as the queues to get in with a normal ticket were crazy long. With the guide we went straight in. Lots of stunning rooms that have been reconstructed after being destroyed in WW2. Including the amber room and some examples of dresses worn by the empresses. Lots of gold leaf here too.
Never miss it. It was fantastic nice and big Do not miss it, Many nice rooms The amber rooms and park where spatacular
Catherine Palace.. Went on private tour with our guide Irina. She was so informative, had all the answers and information. Only way to go, with a private tour. Partner and myself.

Awe inspiring.... This was the summer palace of the Romanov's...Again, to think that this palace was bombed is so painful. The hatred must have been undeniable and intense...The opulence is over the top. The restoration was remarkable, but I feel that there was no way they could duplicate in their truest sense,the original. They did an amazing job, again, I was taken by the photo's of the palace in its bombed out state. The Russians really did lose a lot in the war, they lost the originality of their history. It all had to be re-created, which is terribly sad. So sad for any culture. The gardens were impressive. I would recommend seeing Catherine's palace.

Over the top opulence. Hard to imagine living with such opulence but interesting to see. We took a day tour here - not sure how you'd manage by yourself to get here. LOTS of cruiseships were in port the day we went and the crowd was the largest our guide had seen this year.

WOW!! Don't miss this:. The first stop on the second day of our 2-day shore excursion was Catherine’s Palace and we spent all morning at the palace. Our guide, Alexi, was again fantastic; his command of the English language & his knowledge of the arts & history was extremely helpful. We were thankful he was our guide for both days.This palace is incredible and every room is overwhelming. It is opulent. Let your mind wander so you can visualize how life was if you were part of the aristocratic society and lived in Tsarist Russia. Just like The Hermitage, the palace is a fantastic must-see museum on a par with major museums in other countries; perhaps even better. Please also note that when walking through the palace, everyone has to wear special ‘pull-over’ slippers. This is one of the museums you must visit. Bring a good digital camera with a large memory card and be aware that flash photography is not allowed. Photography is allowed almost everywhere except in the unbelievable amber room.

Amber Workshop was incredible!. We visited as part of a small tour group from Queen Victoria for the St Catherine's Palace & Amber Workshop tour.It was incredible - the Palace is just stunning and the Amber Room so beautiful, faithfully replicated on the original which was stolen. The Amber Workshop was the icing on the cake, loved seeing and hearing how they make the beautiful amber panels.The grounds are incredible as well, we visited on a sunny day and we were just taken aback at how amazing the Palace is. Visit here if you ever go to Russia, you won't be disappointed!

A logistical nightmare for tourists travelling solo. If you want to see it, do yourself a favor and take a guided tour, even if it costs (a lot) more. We tried to get a train from Vitebsky train station, which was a mistake since the station has no signs in English at all and the schedules are unfathomable. We ended up taking a taxi.Once we arrived, we ended up standing in line three times; first for 45 minutes to buy tickets to the gardens, then another hour to buy tickets to the palace, then another half an hour to don footings and enter the palace. We were rushed through in about 15 minutes.There are no brochures and no explanations in English. A guide accompanies the group but speaks only Russian. So do yourself a favor and go the tour guide way.

And it was just a summer palace. An enormous edifice with endless corridors of magnificent banqueting suites etc set in beautiful grounds. And all set in lively gardens. It's not surprising that the poorer people of Russia became a bit envious of the Tsars' extravagence.

Amber room all it should be and more. The tour of the palace was grand. We enjoyed the history and the Amber room. It is beautiful. We took a guide who informed us that one of the sections of the Amber room was orginal. A German doctor during the war saved this section and returned it afterwards. The rooms were made to the periods which added to the feeling of you waiting for a Czar to arrive. My wife who was born in St. Petersburg was extremely happy over the Amber Room and its beauty.Our guide took us on a fast tour of the garden, i would have like to have spend more time there, but the waits in line stopped us.I also appreicate the work and deication of the Russian people for restoring it after the destruction of WW2. The museum had pictures of the palace after its recapture.Our guide was so-so and the wait was long even for the tours. The palace is closed on Tuesday's and we were a Monday group, so more groups then normal were there. Because of this the vendors by 4:00 PM were low on drink and food. Because of the long wait, the sun can be hard on older people, I would suggest in the summer to bring drink with you in case of a My wife and I both enjoyed walking in the footsteps of the Czars. I highly recommend this tour.

Good tour but don't eat here. I would skip the carriage house but the palace is beautiful and the rooms are a wonder of excess.We had a special dinner there and it was less than good. However the entertainment was excellent.
Just beautiful!. The amber room will takwe your breath away, they dont allow pictures in this room, but it is OK in most rooms.

Probably the most impressive of the St Petersburg palaces. We visited with a tour group, with privileged early access (before the crowds arrive) and if you can do this, I strongly recommend it. We were actually the first group to go through, and as we left it was obviously getting a lot busier. The interior is very impressive, almost overbearing with its gilt opulence. Don't miss a walk through the grounds and down to the lake.

Amber Room. Fully restored - so not much is original, but the palace was fearfully trashed in WW2. The Amber Room is a faithful replica - the original is lost - but no less extraordinary and amazing for that. A must see attraction.
Beautiful palace and gardens. Very busy but an absolute must on anyone's itinerary when visiting St Petersburg. The gardens are wonderful and it is a wonderful place to walk and relax.

More opulence. As with many of St. Petersburg's attractions, the palace at Tsarskoe Selo is extravagantly furnished with gilded interiors, a combination of Baroque with Neo-Classical styles. The Amber Room, although a reconstruction after the original was looted by the Nazis, is still a sight to behold, and the Great Hall and Green Dining Room are exquisite. And like with most of the city's venues, be prepared for crowds.
Catherine's Palace & Park. The wealth shown in this palace is overwhelming. And, it's remarkable that the Russian people want to preserve it at tremendous expense. It's truly beautiful!

Russian Oppulence. First of all, be prepared to don adorable protective booties over your shoes, haha! The palace is beautifully adorned with gold and jewels everywhere. The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because it's so crowded that it can be really difficult getting around. We weren't even able to shop in the gift shops there because there were so many people in the hallway we couldn't even get through. Definitely worth it though!

Gold. gold, gold!. What a palace! More than 100k kilograms cover the walls and statuary. The paintings are magnificent! tour takes at least 2-3 hours, and do get a guide! The grounds are beautiful also! Not to be missed!

OMG. Very baroque and ornate. You got to go. The place is amazing .lots of historical paintings, grand rooms, covered in gold, I felt like I was in a fairy tale. The grounds were also very beautiful. We met a couple of guys, one of which had been a few times before, "hello Peter& George . George you where a wealth of information, and with you knowledge of the Russian language ,we arrived from St. Pet ,via train and bus.I would recommend you go as part of an organised trip.please visit, you will not be disappointed.

Over-the-top gorgeous!. This palace is unbelievably gorgeous and extravagant inside and out. We visited with Tailored Tours (see my full review there) and received so much interesting information about this palace!

A smaller copy of the Versailles Palace. While not quite as flash as Versailles, it was still definitely worth the trip. Public transport is good, if a little difficult to navigate if one doesn't have basic Russian (at least to read cyrillic). Fortunately we did and people were very helpful along the way. The Amber Room was a definite highlight and made the whole visit worthwhile. This room alone cost US$11 million to restore. It is sad that so much was damaged and restoration is still under way. Buy tickets in advance on the Internet to avoid a much longer queue at the ordinary ticket booth, as we did. Only problem is you can't predict the weather so we were forced to go in the rain. You can always buy an umbrella from the fellow who walks down the train selling them.
Unforgetable for the whole life. Incredible! A "must"! I went with a private guide from St. Petesburg, is the best way.Don't go by yourself.
Don't miss it. But make sure your tour also takes you inside and not just to the park. Was disappointed that our 2nd visit was only to the grounds.

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. This place is definitely worth a visit - about one hours drive from the city it is set in a spectacular garden with chapels, a grotto, summer house and breakfast pavilion. Get there early to avoid the crowds and get a good guide to help you navigate and understand more from the surroundings - Peter's Walk Guides I can recommend.

Huge amazing grounds, fountains are wonderful!. After taking a hydrofoil boat from across the Hermitage museum, this very interesting boat ride was very interesting, in all the countries I've visited have never been on a hydrofoil (1st time for everything)!Once off the boat the walk up to the Palace is beautiful, the massive grounds and fountains scattered throughout are amazing, just wonderful, this place seems to be on an island all by itself, but just 45 minutes outside of the city center of St Petersburg.The palace itself is massive, and crowds can get quite ridiculous. The palace completely re-done after being destroyed by fire back in WWII, is a little too much in my opinion, all laid out in gold, but the history behind the family and the tragedy behind their deaths are quite interesting; well worth the drive over to check out!

Another world. We had to queue up to get in as there are so many tourists who want to see this palace. Most of the decoration is in the baroque style with lots of gold leaf. There is a model of Catherine the Great in her court dress which shows how impressive the whole place must have been when it was at its height.

Well worth a visit. The inside of the Palace is all gold in every room , get there early in the morning to avoid the crowds , we got there just before they opened and had rooms to ourselves walking round, the gardens are worth a look with lakes and fountains , one of the best places to visit in St Petersburg
Lovely. I did like this but when you see other more stunning buildings I was a little disappointed.Still put it on the must visit list though.

A must see. This place was amazing! It was well worth the 45 min bus ride to Pushkin from St. Petersburg. I would recommend it to anyone who has the chance to go to St. Petersburg. Go with a tour guide, as the history behind the palace is fascinating! I hope you enjoy!

Queue Chaos!!. Getting out to the Catherine Palace on public transport is a challenge in itself but to then encounter the chaos that there is to get in is unbelievable. We joined the end of the queue at just after 11.30am and they only seem to let a certain number in every half hour. There is no queue management so lots of cheeky people just walked further up and pushed in with no one to stop them - very annoying. We eventually got in just before 2pm. As you have to buy tickets at the park entrance for the park why can they not issue timed tickets so you can go and look round the grounds instead of wasting 2 hours in a queue!So we get into the palace and then join another queue for the tickets and after that another queue to actually enter the palace rooms.The rooms in the palace are absolutely stunning and take your breath away. The Amber room is also very special. The palace is amazing but if I had known how long it took to get in I don't know whether I would have bothered.

Catherine Palace - Outstanding. We did not tour the park on this tour - only the palace, which was well worth the time to see. We were amazed by its beautiful construction, the parquet flooring and wonderful/amazing national treasures on display. The special Romanov attire exhibit was truly outstanding and most interesting. I highly recommend this tour site.

Amber room restored. This is a beautiful (to excess) gilded palace. Except for the beautifully restored amber room, gold embellishment is everywhere. The palace is huge; the tour this time did not include some rooms I saw when here in 1994, but others like the amber room were included. The crowd control here was much better than at the Hermitage, with roped off paths to follow (of course, we had a guide as well.) Since the area you can walk are generally on the periphery of the rooms, you are able to get good photographs without people in them. The grounds looked lovely from the windows, but as it was absolutely raining cats and dogs that day, we did not spend much time there.

Stunning architecture with long queue. The Catherine's Palace was very beautiful and the garden very impressive. However be prepared for the long queue both outside and inside. I think the tour guides should educate their clients that they shouldn't be blocking others' way while they were explaining the rooms. I think it was the main reason for the long queue and congestion.

Good choice of shore excursions for family. We visited Catherine's Palace on a guided tour we purchased through our cruise line, and I'm glad we did. Yes, there was a crowd and we had to wait in line to go in, but it wasn't that long a wait and there weren't so many people that we couldn't get beautiful photos without strangers in them. The rooms were impressive and restoration work extensive. Even our 7-yr-old said "Wow!" in the famous Amber Room. Our guide was very informative, including regarding the gold-leafing and Russia's recent ban on smoking in public in addition to all the history ... The day would not have been the same without him. Our half-day visit ended with a 'traditional Russian lunch' on-site, including bread, salad, soup, and main course (described as 'like beef stroganoff except with chicken ... and rice' -- gave us a chuckle but it was good), as well as ice cream and a shot of vodka. Note: Backpacks are not allowed (purses and camera bags ok); there was a coat check but we were advised to leave our bags on the guarded bus instead, which we did without issue.

Talk about excess. In your wildest imagination, you could not create anything more ornate or over the top than reality. Each room is unique and you can't believe anyone really lived here. I think even kids and non history buffs will be amazed.
Unbelievable!!!!!. So much gold. This place is beautiful. It goes on and on with all the gold. Lots of paintings to see.i can't believe people actually lived this way.

Shambolic - a complete disgrace. We arrived at 10am to find that the Palace is only open to groups between 10am and 12 noon. We therefore looked round the gardens and joined the queue for tickets at 11am, a full hour before the palace was due to open to individuals, at which point there were about 100 people in the queue ahead of us. By the time that the Palace opened at 12 noon there were probably more than 1000 people in front of us who had pushed in, many of them in large tour groups. We finally were admitted to the Palace at 1pm, more than three hours after we started queuing. Once inside we were able to buy a ticket relatively quickly, but very little information was available - no English language signage or information, so we really had no idea of what we were looking at for most of the time. It appeared that you were meant to join a group for the tour, but it wasn't explained to us how the system worked, so we saw it mostly on our own. The Amber Room is truly spectacular, but if we had known that we were going to have to spend three hours queuing to see it we probably wouldn't have bothered going.

Big, blue and gold! Beautiful palace!. When you arrive, you are greeting by a band which plays music while you wait. You need to wear shoe covers so as not to damage the parquet floors. The staircase lead to the gold room and there is an amber room and there is a loggia which copies the one at the Vatican! Even the doors between rooms are magnificent. The palace is huge and served as both a residence and a public gathering spot on the outskirts of St. Petersburg...in the country! Opulence does not even describe the gold, the furnishings, the rooms, the tall Delft corner fireplaces, and all the treasures from around the world. It gives you a clear look at what life must have been like in Tsarist Russia when money was no object! Words cannot even describe just how overwhelming each room is!

Full marks for the restoration work. This is what impresses one about this attraction. It looks immaculate from the outside - it looks so well looked after and preserved and then you learn how much work has had to be done to restore this palace. the amber room is breathtaking - i am so cross with myself for not buying a book to remember it by or even a postcard. (Photos are not allowed in this room)
Magnificent. As with all the palaces we visited, this palace is also magnificent with gold stucco work and again magnificent wood floors.
Great sights. Able to go inside of the Palace. Must work has been done to update the place...some areas closed to public. Interesting display of what was seen.

Beautiful Palace. This Palace is very very popular and therefore gets very busy so be prepared to wait and shuffle your way through the main rooms. On arrival you have to put on shoe covers (provided). Up the main staircase and into a great room covered with gold and mirrors. Through several rooms and into the Amber Room where the room is completely covered with Amber. No photos allowed in this room although photography is allowed in the other rooms. Take a walk around the stunning gardens afterwards.

Wonderfully interesting. This building is an interesting mixture of Baroque and Classical style, reflecting the tastes of the three Tsarinas, Catherine I, Anne, and Catherine the Great, who used it. It is lush, luxurious and fascinating, allowing one a glimpse into the life styles of the stupendously rich and glamorous Russian royalty of the time.

Very Luxurious Site. Catherine's Palace is about an hours bus ride from St. Petersburg, but the Palace and Park are well worth the ride. Outside the Palace the gardens are very well manicured and the size of the Palace is amazing. Once inside the Palace each and every room is filled with history and most of the rooms are huge. The Amber Room and the Grand Ballroom are too amazing to be describe. Well worth the trip from St. Petersburg and highly recommended!

St Catherine's Palace, Russia. Such glory. Room after room was gold and marble. Then we reached the amber room. Walls covered in amber. Although not the original amber walls (they were stolen in the war and never recovered), it is still extremely impressive. I think this is a must see. Very interesting history.

Beautiful palace but poor management of admission. The palace and the garden are not to miss, but be prepared to suffer long wait, people jumping the queue, stampede at the entrance turnstile - even if you are with a guided tour. Certainly not something I would recommend for people with young children or the elderly.

Busy, but beautiful. I'm going to echo many of the other viewers here and say that it was chaotically busy. But, don't let that put you off. The palace is well worth the queues and hassle to get in. The Amber Room literally takes your breath away and while there's little information in English (if you're not part of a tour, which we weren't), don't miss the information on how it was rebuilt after the war, which is tucked away in a dark corridor on your way out after you've been through the main rooms. It's absolutely fascinating and a testament to the many people who worked so hard to restore the palace to its former glory.

Those royals must have been incredible wealthy. The palace is incredible. Each room is very different and unique. the rooms are very elaborately decorated and beautiful. The amber room is amazing. At the end of the viewing rooms there are pictures of how the palace looked after the war. The main room was completely destroyed after walking thorough it you will understand the amazing restoration that happened to the palace.

Amazing Palace. Equally s spectacular as Peterhof, with beautiful period furniture, gold trimming in many rooms and the amazing Amber room. External very attractive and constantly maintained with external painting. Well worth a visit.

Busy place but beautiful. We just returned from St. Petersburg & visited Catherine's Palace. It is exquisite with gorgeous grounds & an interesting history. Going with a tour group allows less waiting in line & quicker admission but nevertheless, it is a very busy tourist attraction. Lines are everywhere. There were so many buses it was unbelievable (multiple remote parking areas after drop off) & if one is separated from the group, forget about finding them or the bus. There were no fees for photography, as in some other museums, & all rooms excepting the amber room could be photographed. I would suggest having an emergency contact # for your guide in case of separation. Nevertheless, a fabulous place. We went to Peterhof primarily for the gardens, bath house & outdoor spaces & to Catherine's for the interior primarily, with just a quick trip around the grounds. I would recommend that approach as the architect & design for both Peterhof & Catherine's are the same, so the interiors are not that different. Lovely day! Recommend.
Opulent. Catherine's Palace was incredible. Each room was different and, of course, the Amber room amazing. I would have liked to have spent a whole day here but. alas, we only had a few hours.

Beautiful but chaotic. The long stand waiting in the rain to gain entrance is only brightened by the entertainment provided by the oompah band. Once inside the chaos reigns. People being told to go to the cloakroom and generally causing a crush.The rooms which are open to the public are awesome. The term All that glistens is not gold does not apply here. It really is. The work to rebuild and replace this palace after the devastation caused during the war is still on-going. There are pictures showing the burnt out shell of this building after the war so it is amazing to see what has been accomplished.We had to pay an extra fee in order to be allowed to take pictures inside ($5 or 4 euros) but even so you are still not allowed to take photos in the amber room which is quite jaw dropping - no explanation given. There may have been photos on sale at the souvenir stalls but we were not given any time to shop. Everyone has to put on shoe protectors before entering the grand rooms with their patterned wooden floors. This is another hassle as it is all so crushed.This is a beautiful palace and well worth seeing but the lack of proper organisation as well as no cover for the extremely long queues standing in heavy rain (which must happen often) is very off putting and left us feeling disappointed with this visit.

Over the Top Palace. Beautiful palace surrounded by many gardens and ponds. One can take pictures inside which is a plus. The palace is huge and yellow and inside has many gold rooms. The only negative were long lines and many people. If I was to choose one palace to see in St Petersburg I would go to Peterhoff.

Excellent Attraction. This was a memorable museum despite the crowds. The humble beginnings of this 16 room summer palace which was added to by various czarinas highlights the splendour, power and wealth of the Russian czarist.The daily life of royalty is re enacted by the various rooms and the gardens and statues of philosophers highlights the education and culture. Nearby is Pushkin's park and a statue to him

Wear sunglasses on a sunny day.... To protect your eyes from the gold leaf on every mirror, onion dome and wall decoration. An outstanding collection... Go for baroque! And don't forget the lovely gardens and above-average souvenir vendors

Pearl of the city. Although the Park is far from the city center and lack of convenient transport link , I strongly recommend visitor to Saint Peter burg to spare at least half day to visit the place in particularly the Palace and the famous Amber room. The palace was reconstructed with the concerted effort of the German who bombed and completed destructed the place. Since the Palace was serving the Queen it was in different style and tone from the others serving the King. Amazing architecture with finest finish and craftsmanship. Shall come again in different season .

Long waiting!. Solo much gold, mirrors and amber!!!! Beautiful gardens. It was worth the visit, but we waited more than an hour in line to get in with only 20 people in front (groups appeared to have priority).

Outrages spending of Catherine. We travelled by bus as a group and arrived just before it opened. The waiting time was filled in by the 5piece band. Once inside together with many other bus loads of tourists the wait was well worth it. The luxury and opulance was hard to comprehend. The works of art were a delight. The amber room was a work of art in itself. Unfortunately with such numbers of people in there at the same time it would be worth going solo and spending a whole day to see everything properly.

Palace and Gardens. It is an hours drive across St Petersburg and we arrived in a group at 0800hrs to find the gates locked and entertainment provided by an amusing 5 piece band. We had to wait 40mins before the gates were opened by which time a further 8 coach loads had joined the queue.The wait was rewarded by a very busy crowded one hour tour - quite spectacular .On completion it was confirmed the collection had been totally destroyed in WW2 and restored in the interim years. The gardens were not so enjoyable due to heavy rain.

Magical Palace in Russia. We traveled to Pushkin to visit the lavish 18th century Catherine's Palace which is the summer residence of the Russian Tsars, named for Catherine, widow of Peter the Great. We explored the luxurious palace with gold-covered doors and panels as well as the beautifully landscaped gardens. We visited the Amber Room with its walls covered with dazzling panels of amber, gold leaf and mirrors. It was simply stupendous and simply worth visiting on our Russian trip.

CATHERINE KNEW WHAT SHE WAS DOING. You have to see it to believe it. Six hundred different rooms laden with unprecedented works of art. Ballrooms out of logic and prompt fit for a Tsarina. But she was a Tsarina, although she was more successful from most Tsars.

A Splendid Summer Residence. Even Peter the Great probably won’t image the modest summer residence he gifted to his wife Catherine I would one day be transformed into a grandeur palace by his daughter. The palace is nearly 1km in circumference with blue, white and gold exterior, and the interior is equally breath-taking! Visitors are not allowed to take any photos in the most famous Amber Room for the protection of the fragile amber. The wait outside the entrance was the longest, probably nearly two hours, during our two day’s trip in St. Petersburg, which cut short our time spending inside and we had to rush passing the beautiful gardens in order to visit another site on schedule.

St. Isaac's Cathedral and Square - huge and humble!. One of the largest and most beautiful places of worship in the world! The beautiful altar with the huge stained glass window, icons and decorative pillars leaves you speechless.

Amazing palace. A must see. This is an amazing palace where the ruling family lived. To be able to walk thru their rooms and see how opulent was their lifestyle is from a world that no longer exists. The amber room alone is worth the entrance fee. We were able to tour the amber workshops where they were recreated. Also great photos of how it looked after the nazis were done with it in WW2.

Splendor and Pomp in the court of the Empress. We were a bit leery heading to Russia with the troubles brewing in Ukraine, but after a year of planning e took the plunge. What a great decision! The crowds were way down in numbers with many tours having 50% or more cancelations. We were on a Grand Circle boat, the Rossia, which would normally hold 200 travelers, but had 160 for this trip. The number of crew and service staff remained the same, but there was one fewer Tour Director. This was great for seating in the restaurant and service in general, but I felt sorry for those on other cruises where they cut the staff due to smaller numbers of travelers. Anyway, with the ruble down and the crowds gone it was fantastic. We were able to stroll around Catherine Palace with very few crowds…this was true of the Hermitage, and Peterhof as well. Our guide, Natasha, was not only knowledgable, but really honest about Russians and their thoughts and feelings about the US and Americans as visitors. She discussed the serfs and the human cost of these huge and grand palaces and the cost of repair and reconstruction after the Great Patriotic War, WW II to us. She never sugar coated the Stalin years, but pointed out buildings and remaining successes the era as well as discussing the cost to Russia in human suffering before and after the war. We were also fortunate to hit the best weather possible with 3 days in the 80's, unheard of for May in St. Petersburg. The remainder of the trip was also beyond expectations, with Moscow being a very interesting city, not the industrial backwater I had suspected. The subways were beautiful, clean and pretty easy to navigate with such extensive routes that no place was out of reach. I will say that the traffic was as bad as I have ever seen, topping the goat rope of Quito Ecuador by a slight margin, with 99% of the cars holding a single person. this made the subway even more attractive.If you are considering a Russian trip I highly recommend getting out and doing it! Seldom will a trip top expectations like this one did.

All that glitters is gold!. Amazing palace, stunned by the fresh flowers, the beauty and grandeur of the rooms, the history does not disappoint. Lucked out and heard an amazing vocal group performing in a space near the lake.
a double wow !!!!!. words cannot describe the beauty..you need to go there to feel the beauty of the grandeur that was there

Royal excess. If you want to know why the peasants revolted just visit this palace. There is more gold, rare stones, marble, amber, art and furniture than any 6 royal families deserve. It is a must do stop in St Petersburg. She also had a stable with 200 horses and 400 men to support this seasonal palace !

Catherine Palace is a must see . Catherine Palace is still undergoing major renovation work . To see how the Nazi's destroyed the structure and the amazing authentic reconstruction that has been completed is amazing . The Amber Room is the most famous as well as Grand Hall , Picture Hall and the main staircase . This is a must see attraction when in St Petersburg . Do not miss this .

A Mile of Palace with Pleasant Grounds. Catherine's Palace, tho' restored from rubble, delights the senses. There's nearly a mile of Palace filled with wood inlay furniture, plush furnishings, art works, and, of course, the incredible Amber Room. You eyes will feel blinded by the awesome gilding. Catherine created the grounds on a more human scale than Peter did at Peterhof, so it's peaceful and pleasant to walk in this country setting.
Huge....HUGE....palace. this palace must be as huge as two football fields. there is a lot of walking and very few places to sit...so it is not for the faint of heart.
Opulent-opulent. The opulence of this palace is truly amazing. The Russians have done an amazing job of renovating the palace post war damage.

Talk about gold gilding. The amount of gold gilding from the domes outside to the formal rooms is overwhelming. The richness and wealth displayed in this palace makes you appreciate why there was a revolution. The amber room is truely a work of art.
Another most. You will be mesmerized with this place. St. Petersburg has so many beautiful places, but this one and The Hermitage are the on the top of list.
Blown away. What can I say that's not been said alreadyWe had a wonderful sunny day to explore this place of opulenceEvery room had some different amazing treat to look at Like a huge Pandora's box

BEAUTIFUL PALACE. The Nazis set fire to the Palace & dismantled & stole the amber room as they retreated from Leningrad-at the end of your tour you see how things were before the restoration. The time and money put into the restoration is impressive as are the results. Your eyes are dazzled by the amount of gold leaf, mirrors and Dutch tiled fire places -these are magnificent rooms if slightly over the top,but it works as room follows room. Then you get to the Amber room - a master piece that will mellow with time. The dedication & workmanship of the Russian restorers is to be admired. Good selection of shops at the end of the tour plus excellent bathroom facilities. Made a quick tour of the gardens which are massive with different layouts. Would have like to stay longer but we are on a tour & off we go.

Another great World Heritage discovery. This is another amazing World Heritage building. If you have visited the Versailles in France, this museum has a lots of rooms that ressemble the Versailles. The Grand Hall actually looks like the "Palais de Glace" from Versailles. The paintings, the numerous rooms well decorated with gold, the size of the structure, the beautiful gardens, not to forget the Amber Room... where you are not allowed to take pictures but where you won't believe the beauty and richness of that room. All of the amber panels were actually transferred from the Winter Palace (Hermitage) in 1755 to this Palace. What's even more amazing is that the whole Palace was rebuilt after World War II, by great architects, and based on its original design, using old pictures and photos. In our visit to this Palace with our Cruise Ship (Royal Princess), we got to see many beautiful rooms decorated in Baroque style. With our guided tour, we did not have enough time to visit all of the parks as the site is very big. But if you plan a visit to St. Petersburg, you might want to consider that as there are plenty of things to see in both Catherine's Park and Alexander's Park (over 40 points of attractions not to miss). Although we had seen the Versailles in France, there was something different with that Palace and we were very happy about our visit. There are little boutiques inside the Palace, where you can purchase books, etc. I would recommend you get the Palace and Parks book as a souvenir as it includes a lot of points you may not get a chance to see during your visit. In addition, I had looked elsewhere to see if I could get such a book, and my chances were'nt paying. As well, there is a lot of walking involved and if you or someone travelling with you have limitations, you might find it difficult to visit this place. Not matter what plan you make to visit this place, you will not be disappointed. Booking with a tour might also save you time for the entrance.

Not to be missed!. We could not get on a tour (last minute, early April) so we hired a taxi to take us from St Petersburg, wait at Catherine's Palace and take us to Airport for evening departure. Worked great, be sure to have his cell number and have him show you where he is allowed to pick up.Palace is wonderful, Amber Room is fascinating but no pictures allowed. Enjoyed lunch in the café.
Catherine's Palace. One cannot come to Russia and not see the Amber Room. Absoluteliy incredible restoration of a missing art gem.

She was a Capital B this more than proves it!. OMG Ego run amuck. One of the most opulent Palaces ever built and built by the German Princess that murder her Czar husband, estranged her own sun and met death in a very untimely manner in the grounds of her Palace. Easy to understand why th e Bolsheviks had enough!
What can i say.. The palace and the park gardens are beautiful.We saw them in glorious sunshine in May.To wander around them was fantastic.Very versaille.
Excellent fountains. This magnificent and excellent historic site is so well built with magnificent fountains and gardens, the royals sure have found a real place to enjoy life.
Great Place. Not the most beautiful palace I saw in St. Petersburg, but there are so many. The best part of this palace is the recreated Amber Room, which is absolutely stunning.

While beautiful it was quite frightening. Entrance took longer then expected even though we had a guide with reservations. The crowd there was getting quite unruly as they were upset at the lengthy queue and wait times and starting pushing and shoving. Thank goodness for our guide who did everything she could to keep us safe and get us into the building as quickly as possible

Blue and gold. Amazing palace that is in the process of being refurbished room by room. The gold gilded rooms there are 12 are breathtaking as was the amber room. You cannot help being awestruck as you tour this palace and the grounds!

Stunning grounds. The inside was beautiful and the grounds make this an unforgettable place to visit. Get outside to the fountains before 11 AM because they turn them on at 11 accompanied by music. Take a video if you can so you have the music with these beautiful fountains. You will love a picture of yourself and party in front of the fountain.

Tsarskoye Selo, Russia. About an hour by car or bus from St Petersburg, but a world away, do not miss Tsarskoye Selo (Pushkin) where the last tsar actually made his home. Although considered just a day trip by many, I highly suggest that visitors make this a one-night, two-day visit. It is leafy green in summer, cool and very quiet. Avoid the bus and hire a taxi on line to drive you direct from St Pete's. The cost is about 80 bucks, but worth it. The Catherine Palace, the huge turquoise one, is super, the highlights being the gardens in my view, but do not miss the Alexander Palace a few blocks away. (The highlight of my last visit.) This is where the last Tsar actually lived and in which he and his family were imprisoned. It is being slowly restored and only about 10 rooms are available for viewing, but a visit is rewarding for those interested in the last of the Romanov families and the palace is completely free of a crowd or line! If you can speak Russian, the babushkas who sit dourly guarding each room, are actually bored as hell and will offer you an historian's wealth of info on the palace and family if you ask. They are thrilled to be asked too! And their sour faces transform as they personally guide you through "their" room!Do yourself a favour and spend the night in this provincial city. Book a room at the Catherine Hotel situated on the actual grounds of the Catherine Palace. It is a very, very, simple, small hotel with clean, but by no means five-star rooms. The bathrooms though are European, and once you see Russia you will understand that comment, the staff very friendly with some English, and the bar quite good. But the real reason to stay there is that YOU wake up, look out the window and see the palace and lawn directly outside. It is as if you are a humble guest of the Royal family. Really a delight. The staff can book you a taxi back to St Pete's and is happy to open the bar "off hours" to serve you as you wait. A lovely little place and only about 100 dollars, for two, a night. (Avoid the rather crowded restaurant next door and walk across the little yard to the tiny cafe you can see from the hotel entrance. Here you can enjoy a simple dinner at a reasonable price and the chef will try to fill your requests.)
Opulence and Grandeur at its finest. Lots of gold, mirrors, massive gardens, immaculate fountains. Worth the trip out there but make sure you get a good tour guide.

Dont know where to begin. Just like the Hermitage, each room appears more spectacular than then previous one, and then you get to the Amber Room. Words are almost inadequate to describe the beauty of this chamber.
The beauty is almost sybaritic! An absolute must-see!

Must see. Take 2 hours and enjoy the opulance of past rulers. Although almost destroyed in the war the palace has been faithfully restored to its former glory. As a builder I appreciated the huge scale of the rooms and the great hall is amazing. Very worthwhile seeing.

Beautiful. This castle is absolutely amazing! It is furnished as if a royal family still lives there and at a certain point, the fountains were turned on, giving a spectacular and truly unforgettable performance. A flute player in the garden added to the ambiance. I highly recommend visiting this palace and the gardens.

Ostentatious Vulgar Display of Wealth.. Despite my Title, this place is worth seeing. The Palace where Tsarina Catherine stayed with its Numerous well decorated Rooms. On the Outside, the superbly Manicured Gardens & Lawns are a sight to behold. Nothing like sitting on the banks of the Lake, in complete Solitude & silence. A truly remarkable experience.

Catherine Palace a wow!. When you first come upon the site it truly takes your breath away - from the lush gardens outside to the fountains to the little water canal outside - what a site. A must see if in St. Petersburg!

Lovely Palace. Huge palace with minimal furnishings (due to Nazi's burning the palace to the walls) they recreated the glory of the palace and brought it back to the original details of the palace. The carriage room was our favorite place to see all the decorated carriages dating back to the mid 1700's.

Lots of history at Catherine Palace take a private guide. We took a private guide for our tour of the palace and she was incredibly informed. She was able to tell us the history and inform us of all the facts that were relevant. It was really worth the extra cost to have a personal guided tour with all the knowledge.

A Must When In St. Petersburg. This is a place you just don't want to miss even if your stay in St. Pete is a short one. It took our tour group about an hour to get there, but well worth the time. The Park is beautiful. I am sorry I didn't have time to stroll through it, but I am glad I spent every moment I had in the Palace. The Grand Hall and Amber Room are beyond words as well as the rest of it. Versailles has nothing on Catherine's! Be sure to bring your camera to preserve those memories.

To be Catherine. If you are a Russian History buff, Catherine's Palace is the place to be. So much history, so much Russian furniture, arts and design. The buildings and gardens are magnificent. Especially interesting is the "Amber room" which has been renovated since the war.

A Palace of Opulence and Splendor. This Palace is so very grand and well and truly worth seeing. The Great Hall is amazing. Our Guide told us Elton John once performed there. I know that unfortunately a lot of the baroque architecture of all the palaces we saw will merge in my mind but the Great Hall and the Amber Room of the Catherine Palace stand out and are two rooms I don't think I shall forget. The park land surrounding the Palace is good for a walk and the buildings dotted around are worth seeing. I would highly recommend The Catherine Palace and Park even if you are only on a short visit to SPB.

Beautiful Bewitching Catherine Palace. This really is a beautiful place. The rooms are more amazing and so full of history. The building has been restored beautifully from the damage that occurred during the war.
Perhaps I rated Peterhof as this.. Oops. I described this palace and park under Peterhof. It's great and well worth a trip. It was a cold and windy day so our sojourn in the park was short.
Breathtaking. Impressive beyond messurement - a fantastic example of modern time restoration. The whole place got bombed during WW2 and now it is almost totally back to past glory

St.Catherine's/Pushkin. If ever there was a reason for a revolution, this and the Hermitage would be it. From pauper population, to over the top waste of resources, mostly on a whim, this would it. Garish, and typically Russian architecture, the use of over 1 kilogram of gold leaf to cover a minaret told the story of the profligacy of the Romanovs. Still and all, a trip to Pushkin was well worth the time and effort. The whole experience one never to be forgotten. Much was due to our guide, and her excellent knowledge of her subject, and her excellent English. All questions were answered, and much more information imparted. A must see for any visitor to St. Petersburg. Breathtaking

Too crowded inside and very over the top!. The gardens are pretty but the tour of the palace was a disappointment -- too crowded and too gaudy! It's also a little disappointing that the amber room is a recreation -- not sure what the point is if it's not the original.
Worth the drive. Beautifully preserved and restored, the palace and the gardens are worth seeing.. a nice drive, lots of walking through the gardens...very European as is most of St. Petersburg

a gorgeous residence of the Russian emperors. The guided tour was very interesting and informative. The Amber chamber is a must to see. The park is also very lovely. I was very sad to learn and see on photos that the palace was almost fully destroyed during the nazi's occupation.
Way over the top. If you live baroque and rococo this is for you. There was more gold leaf than you've ever seen! The hall of mirrors was impressive, as were the crowds.

So much to do and see, spend a whole day!. Not only is the town of Pushkin nice to see after the busy city, but this Palace and Park is amazing. Spend the day, take a picnic and enjoy. The grounds are free for everyone and have such wonderful little hidden secrets: picturesque bridges, a mock chinese town, mini pyramid, Greek temple, a dilapidated old church and so many more amazing things to see and explore, and the palace itself if breathtaking. It is here that the Amber Room has been rebuilt after WWII and it's seriously incredible - completely worth paying for entry to the palace. The baroque architecture is fantastic as well, I just can't speak highly enough about it all! Take the metro to Moskovskaya and then get a marshrutka - it's the cheapest way to travel (less than 250 rouble return!)

Fabulous palace!. A stunning palace which is still being restored after the damage done during WW2. Before and after photos are shocking. Fantastic restoration of numerous rooms including the Amber Room.

Catherine Palace and Alexander Palace. If you visit St. Petersburg, do not miss visiting the Catherine Palace approximately one hour outside of the city. Catherine I was the wife of Peter the Great who ruled Russia for two years post his death. This home was originally built as a small summer residence but was later expanded by Catherine's daughter Empress Elizabeth into a palace on a scale to rival Versailles. The Amber Room is incredible as most of all the other rooms are. This palace is definitely a do not miss. We also went to the evening reception at the palace. Though it was expensive, we thoroughly enjoyed the entertainment and the meal and felt it was worth it for the experience.

Yet another great sight in Saint Petersburg..see the Amber Room. We did this attraction with a guide although you can probably get there by public transport if the tourist bureau has it. Generally our experience has shown (we dont read Cyrillic very well ) unless the public transport stops at the front gate better to get a guide or a tour.Anyway our guide was great. There were only two of us plus our guide and he took us through the Palace at a pace that suited us explaining many things we would have missed. He was very truthful about the Palace , it origins, refurbishments , war damage and repairs. This made it very interesting.After that he took us for a walk of the gardens again explaining issues of interest.We really enjoyed what he did and found the personal guided tour good value.There are quite a few tours in Saint Petersburg but our guide Alexander came from ToursByLocal.com. A guided tour had a fixed price so if there is one , two or 6 people the total cost is the same but the cost per person drops with more people ..ie 6 versus 2)I would not recommend a tour with more than 6 people as there is too much information lostI felt the inside area of the Palace was the best. The gardens are good and quite interesting but not as good as PeterHof with its fountains.

Truly magnificent. Loved the grounds, the history, and Amber Room. I have read much about this site, and could not wait to see it. Get there early, plan a good 2-3 hours and avoid the girls in costume who want $7.00 for one picture. I understand a tip but this is very high, and demanding.

I don't know how she had time to bring all this together. A delightful building in a beautiful park, enhanced by bridal parties taking lovely photographs all over the place. It is well organized, with a good cafe and cloakroom, and the amber room is only one of its attractions. I would recommend it as a must see!

Beautiful palace and gardens. Although you can go on an organised trip out to the Palace, which is some distance out of St Petersburg, it is possible to do it yourself too. We took the Metro out to Moskovskaya station and from there there's a selection of minibuses and buses to Tsarskoye Selo. The use of public transport is cheap and transport runs at frequent intervals. The Palace was beautiful, and towards the end of the route through the building there are photographs of the building after it was bombed in the Second World War. Seeing these was a shock as much of the Palace has actually had to be rebuilt rather than just restored, and the work is ongoing. The result is stunning! The grounds are beautiful and well used by Russian wedding parties who use the gardens as a backdrop for photos. It is well worth the trek out of St Petersburg to see the Palace and Park.
WOW!!!. All visitors should make arrangments to visit this palace - just to see the Amber room if nothing eles!

So much beauty in the design and execution.. We have been here twice now and it was amazing both times. The building is a work of art, with its inlayed wood floors, scroll work, and gold leaf. The furniture and furnishings are stunningly beautiful. After the tour, we walked the grounds a bit, but didn’t have time to see enough.Definitely would return, because there’s so much to see, but also to see more of the gardens and grounds.

Out of this world. Luckily we visited on a quiet day when there were not that many tourists around so walked straight in. The palace is out of this world with gold everywhere and the amber room amazing.

Beautiful experience. Traveled with young children, facility to take a pram. Went as part of a tour, but plenty of opportunity to investigate expensive grounds, have a nice team or sit by the sea. An amazing attraction with beautiful fountains would recommend a visit

My favourite among Tsar's residence around Saint-P. The palace is amazing! It's not that big to get tired of it, and it's not that small - so definitely worth a visit. One may find there the Main Hall (100 sq.m. of gold and windows, reflecting in the mirrors), the Amber Chamber (worth a fortune room ALL decorated with amber), example of how they served the royal dinner and many other things.The park meanwhile is very romantic. It's cosy and charming at any time of the year, I love it so much we had a wedding photosession there. Have a look!

Amazing riches. Catherine Palace has been under permanent reconstruction almost since WWII. Now nearing its full past glory, the interiors of the palace ring of royal balls and stately games. A wonderful example of one of the summer royal palaces of the Russian royals.

Stunningly beautiful. Visited as part of a tour. Certain rooms were closed off for refurbishments and the front of the building was being redone in places but this was well hidden with canvases painted to mimic the actual building being put up in front of the scaffolding! Very clever.The rooms were beautiful and fabulously decorated and the grounds were immaculate. The bath houses were closed (I do not know if they are open to the public during the summer) and the statues were covered due to the cold but you could still picture how it would all look once everything was open and flowering! Stunning.

An over the top palace. While I found this interesting to see because of my interest in Catherine, I did start to get bored after seeing one over-the-top room after another. Think gold, marble, gold carvings of angels, gods, kings and queens, statues, dramatic stairways: you have the idea. If you love ornate palaces, you'll enjoy this. Otherwise, you may find this of interest but a little tedious after a while. Glad I saw and probably wouldn't return if I were to come back.

Unbelievable. Most fantastic palace I have ever seen. Never seen so much gold leaf. This is the one place you must see though it is very busy. Would have liked to have seen the gardens with the flowers out as it must be lovely to see.

Breathtaking. This is the most beautiful palace I have ever seen. From the moment you see the splendid blue, white and gold exterior you know you are in for a treat. The amber room is superb (recreated in 1982 after the Germans removed its contents in 1941) and the gold state rooms are absolutely breathtaking with gilded stucco walls and high windows. The gardens are very attractive and there was even a male choir singing in the grounds.
Super!. Its super house in gold! we hane a nice day and good photo! Ekaterina GREAT lady in Russian Imperators

Highlight of our trip to St Petersburg. We spent four days in St Petersburg in March. We took the metro and then the bus to Catherine Palace. Besides the beauty of the palace, the contents were amazing, the Sevres and other porcelain, the floors, ceilings, gilt. The actual palace was restored after the war they did an amazing job. It was great to see that the original contents had been removed and stored safely so they are now back in their original setting. For history buffs, this is a treasure. To see the Romanov crest on the porcelain it somehow sent shivers down the spine. We walked through the park, it was covered in snow and was snowing. It was like a fairy-tale and really beautiful. A real treasure not to be missed

Grand palace. Tips: The amber room is the highlight and it looks really amazing!Dun buy food from the road side stall, the food is horrible!There is good fast food nearby.Minibus is useful to get to the area. Alexandra place is nearby at walking distance.

Opulent. Pretty much everything has already been said about the oh-so-gold palace in other reviews, so I won't tell about that. Renovation made finding the entrance somewhat complicated - especially since it opened at noon and not the 10am that was posted. But they did a good job of line control after noon, which was nice. Make sure to walk the grounds and see the other buildings, especially (in our opinion) the Hermitage.We took the 299 minibus from Moskovskaya metro stop (which we also used for returning from Pavlovsk), which was easy and cheap both going and returning. Hint: take the first stairs on the right when leaving the metro station and cut across to the large building with the buses and vans in front … do *not* go to the stops on the main street. And you can pick up the 299 right from in front of Pavlovsk when returning.

Summer Palace. This is a beautiful complex of buildings in a green setting. The buildings have undergone renovation after being bombed during the World War. It was a pleasure to stroll through the gardens. There was a vocal group performing in the chapel near the lake which I found very romantic.

Its a beautiful palace (obviously) but only go if you have time. No debating how beautiful Catherine Palace is, however, if you are pressed for time (less than 5 days in St. Petersburg), I would strongly advise you consider other options.As far as palaces in St. Petersburg go, I would rank this as the fourth-nicest. Hermitage is far and away the winner in my estimation. Catherine Palace being a trek makes the case for it even less compelling.If you do go, you will probably enjoy yourself, and a nice plus, is the neighbourhood you walk through to get to the palace, has a very nice, local feel. We took the train, and it was rather complicated, but well worth it (rather than taking a taxi).
Gold, gold and more gold. Fabulous experience - particularly spectacular when you see the photos of how the palace was wrecked at the end of the war - what a restoration. Wonderful

Opulent. Hard to get your head around the opulence and excess these people lived in. The ballroom alone is worth seeing. The gardens were shrouded in snow which added to the atmosphere of the place. A must see.

Catherine's Great Palace. The palace and parks are absolutely beautiful, the palace is a vast spread of white and gold. The interior is packed with beautiful rooms each displaying some magnificent pieces of furniture. Photographs can be taken throughout, except for the famous “Amber Room”, (postcards are available). Room after room is absolutely splendid, the Picture Hall is wonderful and the Great Hall is overwhelming. Although the palace was all but destroyed by the german army after the siege of St Petersburg the Russian authorities have faithfully reproduced the original palace.Outside, the gardens are beautifully maintained with many delightful features including The French Garden and The Grotto, and keep a look out for the red squirrels. Guided tours are generally for half a day but it doesn’t seem long enough. We recommend you buy a book e.g “TSARSKOYE SELO” which contains the history and a description of the palace and over a hundred photographs that you would love to have taken.
