Very good audio guide. Thanks to the audio guide, we had the impression to live at the time of Catherine: very well explained and beautifully restored palace! (the external part of the palace was covered for restoration but we enjoy it)

Beautiful, even on a grey winter day!. This is an amazing place, brightly painted and vast in size (and this is just from the outside!). We were greeted by a local brass band playing, despite the cold - so it certainly cheers the spirits! You can see a small statute to Pushkin (as we are in the town bearing his name) and you can see how he is loved due to all the flowers left in memory. The palace inside continues to amaze. St Petersburg is just packed full of incredible art and architecture and here is yet another breathtaking place. The Grand Hall is stunning, all the light from the windows and lights, coupled with incredible ceiling art and marquetry in the vast wooden floor. It can apparently be hired out for weddings too, and Elton John has played at one there - how amazing for those who can afford such luxury! The investment in the restoration work has produced a jewel… ahem… in the Amber Room restoration! The details were amazing, and we were fortunate to be able to spend some real time discovering that room and the rest of the palace as it is fairly quiet in the off season, can be a metre deep in tourists in summer. It is mind boggling to see the picture of the pre war and post war palace and the work down to restore it. As it completely burned out during the war, it is quite amazing to see how wonderfully the place has been rebuilt. Much of the interior was saved for the restoration by transporting effects to Siberia, packaged up by the ladies and children of the house as the men were involved in fighting. Go and admire it!

Such Opulence!. Again, we were there at the right time. It was winter and we walked straight in. I've never in my life seen so much gilded opulence as we saw in the Catherine Palace. The displays of rooms such as the dining rooms really bring to "life" the lifestyle of Catherine the Great and her family. Because there were so few people around we were ushered into parts of the palace not normally open to the public.

Royalty tours. St.Petersburg and its outskirts has a lot to offer when it comes to palaces and grandeur. Although many say that once you have seen the Hermitage everything ceases to amaze you, yet Catherine's Palace ( also known as Tsarskoe Celo ) is worth visiting even if just for the Amber Room - impressive to say the least! . A hint - don't spend a lot of money on organised tours!! take the elektrichka ( urban train ) from Vitebsky Vokzal ( Vitebsky Station - as soon as you exit Pushkin metro station ) and a good guide book to explain the rooms. REMEMBER IF TRAVELLING ALONE - DURING PEAK SEASON AND SCHOOL HOLIDAYS you may be allowed to enter only from 12 ( till 14.00) and again from 16.00 - so plan your time well.

We'll worth the trip. A real 'must see' for any trip to St Petersburg. Wonderful restoration and great setting. The history behind the restoration after WW2 is fascinating. Hire a tour guide to get the most out of a visit to this palace.

Winter night of lights. The palace is worth to be visited by St.Petersburg newcomers. Grand empire style both in the palace and park, beautiful baroque and classical style interiors, famous amber chamber andt etc. Last time I've been in the park March 1 night when they had so clled Nights of Light event. candles along the walkways and crowds of people with the lights in the park impressed me much.

astonishing. We visited this on a day trip from St Petersburg, which is very easy and cheap - metro to Moskovskaya, cross the main road and there are several minibuses which go all the way there, although you see lots of the public housing in the town of Pushkin on the way. Visitors are free to go round on their own. You might want the audioguide as there are hardly any labels in the rooms.On a sunny day in February it all looked gorgeous, both the Catherine Palace itself and the numerous other elegant buildings in the large park. The rooms in the palace have been superbly restored and show a variety of decorative styles from different periods. The care that has been taken is astonishing. We did not see the Cameron Gallery, the agate rooms or the Alexander Palace, which were not open, or some of the outlying buildings in the park but we still spent a happy 4 hours there. The cafe was OK for a snack lunch.

Another wonderful restoration. This is a beautiful palace which available on many tour itineraries. Well worth the effort. Our tour group (Gate 1) gave us just about the right amount of time to see this one.

Very perfectly rebuilt. When you think that this Palace completely burned out during the war, it is quite amazing to see how wonderfully the place has been rebuilt. The Russian Government saved a lot of the interior by transporting furniture and picturers to Siberia. Now everything is back at its original place to be admired.

Great Palace and Grounds. Catherine The Great's palace is amazing. The restoration of all the different types of fabrics and gifts are nothing like I have ever seen. Entire rooms designed in gold! I found that the palace grounds equally matched the beauty of this massive fortress. Long walkways along the waterways to Finland. I did not enjoy the meal that was served in their dining area but it did not take away from the experience.

An amazing restoration. This vast palace gives a real feeling of the grandeur of the Russian Tsarinas. The exterior is bright blue and when it was originally built the detail was adorned with gold leaf. The interior rooms on show also feature lots of gold leaf and the restoration has been painstakingly done and much of the original furniture and fittings have been saved. I thought the most interesting part of the palace was on the way out of the state rooms where the corridor is lined with photos of the saving of artefacts and the restoration of the palace. You can see photos of bare brick walls and roofless state rooms following bombing by the Germans during WW2. A total of 12021 articles were packed up and stored in the cellars of St Isaac's Cathedral to be saved for future generations.The famous Amber room is an example, nobody knows what happened to the original amber panels as there wasn't time to pack them up and remove them to safety before the Germans arrived. However the Germans did pack them up (and everything else of value in the Palace) and took them away and then they disappeared, reputedly destroyed in a fire. The restoration of the amber panels has been done from black and white photographs aided by computerising the amber colours.So, save some time to marvel at the dedication of the restorers!

A Golden Day Out. The sheer opulence is simply stunning. How the Tsars must have lived ! The exterior is very pretty. Inside is out of this world - particularly impressive if you consider it was a near ruin before being painstakingly renovated. Well worth a visit.

Sheer Golden Opulence.. What a Palace! Truly breath-taking. The over dose of sheer opulence is incredible to experience. The detailing in the decor is remarkable and even more so when you see how the building was close to destroyed before being returned to its former glory. Wonderful.

Should definitely be visited !. You want to see the richness, power and luxury ? Then you are at the right place. When you travel to St. Petersburg you really have chance to visit many incredible places at the same time. Catherine Palace is one of them. You need 2-3 hours to travel just a part of it. But for the whole palace may be you need 5-6 days. İts huge inside. Hundreds of room with thousand of antique items. I 100% suggest you to visit this Palaca.

Russian Tsars & Tsarinas inhabited this magnificent building.... Booked a tour via the cruise and it was well worth it ! Second time visiting St. Petersburg but only there for the day, so it was difficult to choose between seeing this palace or taking in the Hermitage. Glad I took the opportunity to see this Palace after reading about Catherine the Great. Interestingly, it's really her Aunt Empress Elizabeth who is largely associated with this palace.Find this on par with Versailles, with the gold glinted doors, chandeliers and mirrors. The artwork seen here is amazing and the grounds of the Palace also worth a look. To protect the floors, you are provided with shoe covering. Doubt that kids would enjoy it much but as any history lover will certainly enjoy it !

Amazing Palace of Catherine the Great. We spent the day visiting the palace and grounds of Catherine the Great at Tsarskoye Selo. It is not to be missed if you visit St. Petersburg, Russia. The interior is unbelievable......gold gilt, exquisite furniture, and the opportunity to imagine how the elite lived in czarist Russia. The palace interior has been beautifully preserved and the exterior is breathtaking.
interesting. Its always interesting to see how royals lived. Catherine lived the "good life" as one can see from her palace. The amber room is a must see.

Magnificent . See how they lived back then in Imperial Russia. The palace is magnificent, the grounds beautiful and the story of the palace amazing. I got lucky and must have been one if only 20 people there. I had the palace almost to myself and the Amber Room I saw alone. To think that this is a mid-20th century reconstruction of a grand palace that was almost destroyed entirely during the Great Patriotic War. A must-see.

Another gem. This is another must see while visiting. Although it is quite a journey from town, it is well worth it. The excess is a bit much at times, but it is really amazing to see. Of course the famous amber room is a sight to behold. Sadly no pictures are allowed. Also that room is absurdly crowded but you have to see it to believe it. Great place to see overall.
Amazing!. This was a great place to visit. We used Cruising Excursions , who provided a great guide and driver and a small group of only 14 people.

Obscene opulence but well worth a look. About an hour from St Petersburg the summer palace of Catherine the great is an amazing example of a stunningly beautiful palace, room after room of jaw dropping beauty, floors, walls and ceilings all get the treatment and I found myself open mouthed on more than several occasions, no more so than by the Amber room, the only room you could not take pictures unfortunately. So if you have half a day to spare get out to the palace nice and early before the inevitable throngs of tourists turn up!

Superb. Well worth visiting and the hydrofoil to get there is different. The palace is stunning and the Amber Room is unique in the world. The gardens are worth visiting in their own right and one should allow plenty of time to traverse the many paths with outstanding flower displays.

Wonderful Palace. We visited the Palace on our second day in St. Petersburg. It was nice to get out of the city and out into the country for a while. We had to park a little ways from the Palace and walk to it. After pushing our way through security, we were in the enormous courtyard in front of the Palace. The building has been restored after its partial destruction in WWII. Once in the building, we checked our jackets so that we wouldn't be too warm in the building, since there is no AC and lots of people. You are allowed to take photos inside without flash, but no photos in the Amber room. The interior was very ornate and lots to see. It was busy but the crowds moved at a reasonable pace. The lobby of the palace held numerous shops selling souvenirs, it was a bit chaotic to get through there with all of the people gathering around.The gardens behind the Palace are well worth a visit. It was quiet and there were not many people. It was good to get a little piece and quiet from the crowds. The area by the lake was nice.

Glitz and glamour. Its grand. So much gold, beautiful rooms, beautiful windows - wish I was invited to high tea or a ball here. The Ambre room is a sight to see. It reminded me of a more lavish Veraisse (but its been a while since I was there - can't spell it either).Definitely worth a look and let your imaginations run wild with imaginings of being a Russian princess.

Stunning. Do not miss this when in St. Petersburg. One of the highlights of our trip. There are so many beautiful palaces and cathedrals, but this one took the cake. A little crowded, be sure to get here early as the large tour groups can be overwhelming.
Worth the trip out of St-Petersburg. Beautiful palace. It's a rebuilt palace as it was destroyed by the war. The amber room by itself is worth the trip.
Incredible. We came on the most incredibly beautiful cold, sunny day with everything sparkling in the snow. The Palace is over the top gold ornateness but the setting is exquisite.

I can see why they revolted!. Worth the drive out here. The gold, the excess, the outsized rooms and gorgeous furnishings. Loved it! The Amber Room is incredible (even though it is "restored"). No photos in the Amber Room, but, lovely postcards for sale at the gift shop.

Incredible Restoration. Terrific opportunity to view history as well as the perseverance to return a war damaged treasure to original elegance The beauty of the palace is wonderful to experience, but the true amazement comes when you view the photos of the damage done to the palace during the war and compare it to the current status.So much of the original beauty has been restored and can be enjoyed by all who are fortunate to visit

A marvelous blend of art, architecture and history. The Catherine Palace is a MUST when visiting St. Petersburg. It is now a re-bult version of the original...having been destroyed by the Nazis during World War II. But, nevertheless, the opulence and art give one a definite feel for what it was like to live during the era of Catherine I.
catherine's palace. It seemed a bit challenging to get there so we had hired a private guide for 1/2 day tour which was a brilliant idea.  A must while you are in St.Petersburg

Gold, Gold and more Gold. The Catherine Palace in Pushkin was the main reason I wanted to visit St. Petersburg. The visit was everything I hoped for and so much more. The palace is sparkling in gold and beautiful works of arts, it's almost too much to take in in one visit. Everything has been restored after WW II, and the restoration work is unbelievable. Visiting in winter means no queues, at times we were alone in the rooms. You feel like a czar yourself.

A luxurious palace. Loved this place! It is so beautiful inside and outside. I really liked how all the rooms have a different style and that there are mannequins wearing dresses etc that are appropriate to the era.This is one of the places where I would recommend to have a guided tour. Apart from being absolutely beautiful, this palace has also a interesting history.

"THE GREAT" PALACE. We went to Pushkin for a half-day tour to Catherine's Palace. WOW! We got there early. Just after it opened in the morning, so it wasn't crowded...YET! We were greeted outside in the courtyard by a band. Upon entering the palace, you knew that you were in a special place. We had to put on booties to protect the floor, and made our way up the stairs to the main ballroom. You could picture in your mind, the grand parties with prestigious guests that would have taken place here. Each room was more opulent than the next. Catherine the Great knew how to live and surrounded herself as such.The highlight of the the palace was the Amber Room. Everything made from Baltic Amber, including the walls.We were on an organized guided tour and had an in-ear microphone for explanation from our guide, which helped. Although we had an early start to the tour and there were originally a lot less people, it got crowded quickly. Seems at times we were shuffled from room to room, without stopping or any explanations.The grounds were manicured and pretty. There are food vendors where you could purchase a soft drink, or a snack.I would definitely recommend a trip to Pushkin, but try and get there early. If you can get an audio explanation to the various rooms, it greatly helps.

Awe-inspiring.. The Peterhof Palace may have the most impressive fountains, but the Catherine Palace was, to me, more sumptuous in every other way. One stunning room after another, with excess upon excess pouring out of every surface. Consider that this palace (like Peterhof) was virtually gutted by the Nazis during WWII, and your jaw will drop still further at the meticulous reconstruction. Group tours dominate (and make movement difficult in places), but a good audioguide is available for the more independent-minded. Be aware that an entry ticket to the grounds is required before you can enter the palace itself. A truly magnificent achievement.
Only problem: you won't know which pictures to select. The entire compound is beyond words, the only problem is selecting the pitures afterwards because everything is great.

You need to go here. Going here is a bit of a hussle, you need to go those shops, like a yellow galleria by Nevsky prospect the day before and book there your tour to go there and so they'll arrange your transport, guide and entrance, don't bother going on your own as far as I could tell; it looked good to take those boats and arrive directly without having to be on the bus for like an hour to get there..but..you are in Russia, you might as well see it. This palace is great as well as Peterhorf, really if you dont have much time to study their story the tour guides are really good and thorough, just look after your bag in the crafts markets outside, I think someone tried to rob me

Catherine the Great's gift to the world. This was the summer residence of the Tsars. A romantic park surrounds the palace. The real treasures are inside the palace - the Gold Ballroom, the Grand Staircase, but especially the Amber Room and it's unique history "the Eighth Wonder of the World"

Impressive. Catherine Palace rivals Versailles in Paris. Pushkin they call it now, but for royal splendor it has more gold leaf than Versailles. It's restored to it's original opulence, and is a major attraction 25 km outside St. Petersburg. Timed tickets for group tours. Ours brought our own English speaking guide. State ballrooms and dining rooms (fully furnished with place settings) go on endlessly. Definitely worth a visit.

Wow!. We went in winter, traveled by train & bus (est an hr traveling time) and q for a good half & hour in the cold before door open... What really upset us off was the tour group who cut our q and planted a group of at least 20 people right before us 15mins just before door open!!! >:(There's a nice garden for you to wonder around overlooking a lake. Perfect for photo taking.Once we are in, the interior are really impressive. All the gold & amber are indeed WOW and the restoration effort put into it are double WOW! The advantage of visiting during off peak means we get to slowly admire the rooms without being rush out by the staff and crowd.

A classical example of baroque architecture. It's a very nice palace to visit during winter or rainy weather. It's a museum of zars' palace interiors, in particular, of Cathrine's epoch. The main thing to admire is sumptuous and rich baroque decoration in gold, massive chandeliers and mirrors. But some of the halls contain the masterpieces of painting. There is a beautiful park near the palace which you can visit in spring, summer and autumn.

Top Marks for bling. If you love glitz and glamour and history, here is another palace you must see. It is a lot to take in within a very short period of time (if you're in a tour group), but the beauty is well worth it!
Amazing. You shouldn't skip this palace, it is a must, it is simply gorgeous! going with a guide will help you understand the history of the place
Good place to visit, if you have the time. Nice palace, nice garden, if you have free time when in Saint Petersburg, go there. You can get there taking a bus from Moskovskaya station.

TSERKOE SELO PALACE. You need to take a taxi to go there - it's about 30-45 mins drive from city centre. The palace is beautiful and has very nice gardens. Also, it is located in a very nice village (today called Pushkin) and is 10 mins drive away from the Pavel palace nearby - also not to be missed!

Unbelievable opulence. This is a must see if you are visiting St Petersburg. We were fortunate enough to have our own private guide who was very knowledgable and spoke perfect English. The palace itself has recently undergone extensive restoration so everything is very 'shiny'. Having said that it gives a brilliant impression of what the palace would have been like. The detail is astounding and clearly shows the wealth of the period. Unbelievable to think the original interior was completely destroyed just after the war. Definitely an example of how the other half lived!
A gorgeous palace.. It was a sight to see in every respect! The opulence, the beauty, the location were astounding. Put on your "must list".

Breathtaking. Opulence, wonderfully restored. I felt I had been transported to a bygone age. Best time to visit in the Winter, our tour guide said the Summer is so busy but you do have the advantage of warm weather to queue.

Breathtaking. Alk that glitters is really gold, well gold leaf anyway.
Startlingly bright spa rich and carefully restored. Check out the pictures of post war destruction and you will appreciate the attention and detail to bring this wonderful historical piece of Russian architecture to life and allow us to all appreciate.

unbelievable wealth. My recommendation is to take a proper tour. The place is extremely crowded and to get to see it all you need to have someone lead the way and explain a bit of what you are seeing. The inlayed floors are to be appreciated as well as the gold, amber and intricate plaster work all throughout the palace. The opulence is sinful but must be seen. The grounds are just as impressive as the palace itself.
Great palace, too hot on summer. It's a beautiful palace, wih great historic items and art. However it lacks of AC, so visits on summer are really hot. But worth it anyway.

Extravagant to say the least. I really enjoyed seeing this palace and what I felt was a monument to Catherine I, Peter the Great's wife who ruled for two years after his death. So seeing this home and its treasures was very special. The home itself is just beyond belief with all of the treasures, gold, paintings, gilt and beauty. Definitely would read the book about Peter the Great and the second book, Catherine the Great by Robert Massie before going to Russia. Helps so much in knowing the players from those centuries.
Wow all that gold. Another palace worth the drive to see.Amazing gardens and scarves to buy.Loved this place and the history.

Beautiful palace in lovely gardens. We made the journey by train and bus which was a little daunting and relied on locals to help us reach the palace. Once there it was worth the effort with such stunning rooms to admire and lovely gardens to wander on even on a grey, wet November afternoon.

Catherine Palace and Park. If you are going to visit Catherine Palace and Park it would be better in summer. In the palace you can see amazing Amber Room and a lot of other wonderful furnitures, and great park doesn't leave you indifferent. On the weekends there is a lot of tourists. I think you should visit this place on the working days

Rich and luxurious russia. We had a tour with a guy who was so amazing and hilarious while telling the stories of Catherine the Great so I would advise you to get a guide while going there. I did not like the attitude of the woman in the palace who was guiding us through the rooms. She was arrogant and nearly called some other visitors uneducated because they were standing not the way she wanted them to stay. It was tippical russian way to treat ordinary people.

The best museum in the world. Catherine's palace for me is one if not the best museum in the world! It looks very simple outside but when you go inside, you will be surprise because of the elegance, lavish and extravagant architecture off all the things inside. Different rooms have different colors and designs. The treasures inside are all priceless coming from different parts of the world where Queen Catherine collected during her reign which showed her love for arts. First time for me to see all the paintings of well known painter all over the world and history like Picasso, Van Gough etc. This is better for me compared to Louvre in Paris

Beautifull but too much. We went here to see one of Russia's most beautiful palaces. It was absolutely amazing, a very pretty building but really, it doesn't surprise me that when people are building things like this, there is going to be a revolution... Gold everywhere
Totally awsome. We had a guide from "great guides" who was very knowledgeable and brought the whole place to life for us.

Great history and and art. Catherine's palace is quite remarkable and it's beauty rivals Versailles. The palace is located outside of St. Petersburg about 40 mins by car. Many of the important rooms have been completely restored, which is amazing because most of the palace was destroyed during WWII. The amber room, which is a one of a kind, is spectacular. The grounds around the palace are also very nice, but they not as we'll done as many European formal gardens.

Beautiful, but crowds and Russian crowd control detracted!. Of course the place is stunningly beautiful, one room surpassing the next in opulence. Furniture, art, ceilings and walls, inlaid wood floors, it is all exquisite. But when you want to just stand there, and slowly turn around to take it all in, one of the guards soon comes up to you to move you along, which is why it is not a five stars for me.
Very impressive. This place is amazing and is a tribute to the Russian people in restoring the palace after the terrible destruction that took place during the Great War (World War 2).

Well worth visiting. We got to and from by metro and bus, so it cost less than a Euro each, starting at Sennya Ploshchad metro station on the blue line southbound, and changing to a small white bus at Moskovskaya (where there is an impressive statue of Lenin on a column). Buses from the same area as the Airport buses so follow the sign for buses to the airport from the Moskoskaya metro. The driver will tell you where to get off.As it was a November weekday there was no crush, and we just walked in, bought a ticket and went round the museum at our own pace. No crowds, normally we were the only people in any one room.It is most impressive, and has many interesting things to see, not least the Amber Room and the Gardens. Unfortunately it suffers from a problem that is difficult to define but common throughout the ex-communist world, in that it is a display of static things from another time ("The past is a foreign country: they do things differently there." - PL Hartley 1953) and so the displays actually give little idea as to what it was like to live and exist in this time and what the people did etc. Where was the Tsarist loo for instance, or the kitchen ? The museum needs to come alive; to project the times and events in a more friendly way, and not just to be a repeat of the photographs in the book. Also the labeling and signage generally is very poor, but again this is not just a problem encountered at this location.I imagine that the gardens would be beautiful in the summer, but in November are a bit bare and colourless.There is a cafe where you can get a cup of tea/coffee and a sandwich; and a cloakroom to leave your bags and overcoats.Overall well worth the visit.

Not as good as the Photos suggest. spent a few hours here at the palace... the outside of the palace is looking drab and tired.... the gold has really faded in areas,,,, the only part which was shining gold was on the roof.... the tour inside was very good.... in areas it has been very well restored as it was destroyed in the war...... the gardens were well kept but all the statues were covered up for winter to protect them from the elements...so if you want to see them don't go in the winter months. there is also a little market outside of the palace if you want to pick up Souvenirs to bring home..... this is about an hours drive from the main city of St Petersburg on the bus.

Spectacular.....and then some. If you were commissioned by a King to design and build the most oppulent palace you could ever conceive, with money as absolutely no object, your finished product would fall way short of what you will find here. Modern design could never even begin to imagine glitz and grandeur side by side on this scale. If it can't be imagined, it can't be described so I'm afraid you will just have to go and see it. I can promise you will not be disappointed and it is worth devoting a day.

I could live without seeing this waste of money. I love to see spectacular things but it strikes me as strange that money was wasted once during the building of this palace (and people were starving) and then they rebuilt it again during the communistic era (and people were starving). We chose not to take a tour and got there by public transport then we got bullied in the queue by tour guides who wanted to get their 'customers' in first despite the fact that we'd waited In the freezing rain for an hour, we started out number 6 in the queue but ended up number 60 because of these forward thinking 'guides' who literally man handled their way in. I've never actually been physically assaulted by anyone in my life, I've travelled all over the world and not been mugged or assaulted! this is a first! and in a country where queueing was a national institution for half of the last century!All said, when we got into the amber room we were alone as the museum attendant held back the group behind us while we soaked in the absolute ridiculous fantasy of the the German gas company who paid for the restoration of this room since it was trashed by the invading Germans in WW II.

Fantastic. The most beautiful Castle on this Earth. It was destroid during the last worldwar, but have been rebuild. All are gold and shining..
Beautiful rooms, some with dinner tables. I recomend to visit outside tourist season, as in the season there are too many visitors, you cannot see anything.
The Amber room is a must. Go and visit!

Awesome Palace. This is a huge and great palace. Another must! But you need the whole day to drive atleast 40 min from St petersburg city and the whole day to appreciate what's inside. Make sure to check the hours of operation, the normally start 12nn for open tours. Its an awesome place!
Oh My Goodness. It's amazing to see how they really lived. Especially because most of the buildings were re-created after being damaged in WW II.

They certainly like Gold Leaf!. Pleasant tour of the restored rooms which are generally stunning. Difficult to realise that it was all rebuilt since 1945.
Raining too much to see the park!

Most beautiful palace.. I have travelled a lot and visited many palaces in Europe and Asia. This one truly is one of the most beautiful palaces in the world. Every room is a masterpiece, made from different precious stones. My favorite is the emerald room, and, of course, the amber room. The amber room is stunning! The combination of all shades of amber, gold, mirrors and light create an effect of a fire. No wonder the entire room was stolen during the WWII. It took many years and tons of money to restore the room, but it was worth it! The outside of the palace is gorgeous too with its park, pond and beautiful blue church with golden domes. Anyone who visits St Petersburg MUST see this place! You can buy a tour on Nevsky Ave (more expensive), or go on your own by taking a commuter train from Baltiysky Station (Балтийский вокзал, get off in Pushkin - less money, but more hassle if you don't speak Russian).

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. To say that Catherine's Palace is too glitzy is to miss the point. The Russian rulers lived in opulence that today cannot be duplicated, by the old (the Breakers in Newport is a poor cousin) or new rich (who are the ones who would like to live like royalty but do not know how to). Russian royalty had palaces that were used as "play grounds", that is, no bedrooms or kitchens, but simply a place to spend the day; palaces to make a stop for lunch, etc. The Kremlin displays solid gold coaches, gowns completely encrusted with jewels, etc. By comparison, Catherine's palace and gardens are beautifully restored, with magnificently decorated rooms. I especially liked the dining table set for (what looked like 50, but I didn't count) with absolutely beautiful dinner ware. To my surprise, there was more than one such room with huge dining table and beautiful dinner service set out. This Palace is smaller than Versailles, but more tasteful and more beautiful (and I do love the French, despite their faults and my laments), although I am not a groupie of the opulence that the Royals enjoyed in France or Russia. We visited with a small tour group of 13 in July, 1998 (despite the date that this site forced me to put it from a list that did not go back to 1998---without it, I could not submit my review), and did not find it as crowded as Florence, Italy, which has the greatest collection of early, high and late Renaissance art that I have seen. The entrance fee for the Palace (if there is one) was included in our trip.

Visit to Catherine Palace and Park. Breathtaking and beautiful - highly recommended visit. The two days in St Petersburg were the highlight of our visit with Trafalgar. The beauty of the Palace was unreal and the history, art, furniture was absolutely magnificent. This trip made a great impression on us and we will always treasure it!

Wonderful Palace!!!. This Palace called Tsarkoe Selo is very big and I think better than Peterhof about the rooms to see inside where the best one is the magnificent Amber room(all made with elaborated amber) but also the dining room and tne big saloon are fantastic!!! There are more rooms to see respect to Peterhof and more interesting I think. From a week has also opnede the visit(only guided so you'll have to wait a lot) of the very nice Khaterina's private apartments where she lived her last days all just renewed.About the park we've seen not at its best because of winter preservation of the fountains but there's a big lake with some beutiful constructions but not comparing to Peterhof that for the gardens is unbeatable!!!

Catherine's place. The beauty and opulence within this palace was almost unbelievable. This was the first place we visited in Russia. The history, the art, the furniture, the grounds were breath taking. There is a nice little tea room for that break. Note there are two lots of toilets. Some near the cloakroom, looooong lines. Walk past the cloakroom and down a long hall there are more, no waiting. The grounds outside were beautiful. No walking on grass however!

Pay this one a visit!. I'm sure you read plenty of times that you have to go here. And it is certainly all true.However, the problem is getting here. There are no signs and as soon as you leave St. Petersburg, nobody even remotely speaks English. So I'll use this review to guide you to the palace, assuming you're visiting St. Petersburg on your on. Btw: Queues seem to be no problem in October.First, you need to get to Vitebskii Station (Metro line 1, Pushkinskaya). Go directly to the platform level, suburban rail tickets are sold in a booth close to platform 3, not in the main ticket hall. If you ask for tickets to "Pushkin", you'll certainly get the correct ones; here, everybody knows where tourists want to go if they come here! Take one of the trains from platform 3 or 4, most of them go to Pushkin (ask if you're unsure).The stop you need to leave the train at is called "Detskoye Selo". Here, nobody speaks English - so unless you speak Russian, you can either take a cab or the bus, which is what we did. The buses in the correct direction leave from the stop the farthest to the right when you leave the station; if you want to play it save, take number 382 and don't be surprised if it's not much more than a large car. The ride is cheap at around 30 Rubles.The closest stop is Sadovaya Ulitsa. However, noone speaks English, so if you want to play it safe, look for a big sort of gate (in dark grey) to your right and get off at Parkovaya Ulitsa. There, you'll certainly feel lost as nothing points into the right direction and every building looks sort of palace-ish. Walk to the big grey gate. If you're lucky and it's off-season, it's open - then you can just enter and cross straight through the park. If not, continue walking along the road right in front of the gate, further away from the bus stop. It's Sadovaya Ulitsa. At its end, you can't miss the palace.I hope that helps - because as I wrote before, you certainly need to go here.

The best Palace to visit. As we had a car and driver for the day we drove out to Catherine Palace to finish up our day. There were eight of us and the car/driver was very reasonable price. Catherine Palace is such a sight to behold. Many rooms of gold opulence, baroque style, mirrors, period furnishings, artwork and other items from times way past. The tour through was breathtaking.

Stunning location - palace and grounds. We were here in late autumn and the leaves were just turning - it was a lovely sunny day and the grounds looked absolutely beautiful. The story behind the restoration work here after the war is amazing - have a look a the before and after pictures - it is hard to believe that alot of the work done here is replicas of the original. We had a guided tour and a knowledgeable guide definitely makes a big difference. A wonderful palace with a fascinating history

Catherine's Palace - The most fabulous night ever. The two days in St. Petersburg were the highlight of our recent Baltic cruise on the Princess Ship Ocean Princess and Catherine's Palace was the highlight of St. Petersburg. We had an exclusive visit on a beautiful night in late July. We entered the gates after seeing the carriage museum and were met by colorfully dressed royal guard musicians. The first look at the palace is absolutely breathtaking. We had a tour of the palace which was very impressive and with only 90 of us there that night it was an exclusive visit that made you feel like you were really visiting at a royal invitation. The Amber Room was definitely a highlight of the visit, it was so beautiful. There was a man in one room playing a flute, in another room a harpsichordist, and the highlight was a concert in the great hall with four musicians and two actors impersonating Catherine the Great (Sophie) and Pushkin. Then they sat down and we were entertained by two dancers who truly were charming and eloquent. Then on leaving the palace we were unespectantly thrilled to see a horse drawn carriage tour around the front of the palace several times and then the charming couple got out and did a waltz. All of this was while the royal musicians played. Afterwards we were treated to a Russian Dinner and Folkloric show in a different part of the palace. The grand finale was an absolutely unbelievable sunset on the palace that made it look like it was on fire as the sun reflected off of the glass windows and the chapel spires. It was an absolutely incredible night, I don't know of any event in all of our travels of the world that left a more exhilarating delightfull impression than this memorable night.
Breathtaking. hard to believe that this palace is a restoration of the original that was completely destroyed in the war. The restorers have done an incredible job.
Catherine's palace. This is a really beautiful place, named not for Catherine the Great but for Catherine 1, the wife of Peter the Great, A highlight is the recreated Amber Room.
Catherine Palace. Nice but I think it was not as good as Peterhof, I will visit again as the garden needs more time to expolre
Worth the trip. Go here rather than Peterhof for a change of pace. Enjoy walking through the park. You may have to wait a long time on weekends to see the inside of the palace

Yet Another Stunning Palace. We were in St. P for three days and by the time we had seen Hermitage, Peterhof, and Catherine Palace, we were pretty well overwhelmed by the gold leaf etc. This is another gorgeous palace and well worth the visit. The amber room is especially remarkable. Catherine Palace is outside of St. P and requires transportation of some kind. Despite my remarks, I'm glad we didn't miss this. By the way, our tour guide says there are better and less expensive places to buy amber if you're interested. Also, amber used to be available in pieces washed up on the beach. No more...now they have to send divers down to dig into the sand to find it. So new amber is more expense. Luckily for me, brown and gold are not my colors.
lovely park. The park was lovely and well kept, but nothing really exciting or different than you would see anywhere else.

little original construction. Due to destruction during the world wars, little original work is present. Most things are reproductions. It is still very interesting and worth a visit, but make sure you have an informative guide so that you know what you are actually looking at.
fantastic. We visited it on a beautiful summer. The garden was outstanding, but what we liked the most was the visit to the Amber room and the inside of the palace

Unforgetable! It is worth the visit. Well the highlite is the amber room which is a work of skill and beauty, there are several other galleries and rooms, each with intricate decoration, and different paintings, it is incredible of the human creativity and talent together and of course huge money resources can produce. The Palace is fantastic!

A magnificent house. To appreciate this house and its rooms one should read on its history specifically on Catherine the Great, before visiting it, then one would truly appreciate how it literally rose from the destruction and ashes of the war and regained its former glory. All still seems new from its restoration - one somehow feels a whiff of paint and gilt when on goes through the rooms but one must ignore these to truly appreciate Catherine's magnificent history and destiny.

Stunning!!!. The palace from inside, outside is simply breathtaking especially the amber room and the ballroom. All the rooms are lavishly decorated. Catherine must have been a great admirer of art and all good things! The gardens around the palace are well laid out and well kept.

Amazing Palace. What a show of wealth!!! We took this tour with an English speaking guide who put us ahead of the crowds (there were long ques!). The place is simply stunning from inside as well as outside. The ballroom and the amber room are superb. Must, must visit.

Absolutely Magnificent - A work of Art!. We visited in late July on a private tour while on a Baltic Cruise (Oceania). Our tour guide Valery from SPB Tours was excellent and maneuvered the crowds well. The history is evidenced here for sure. The Palace was built as a summer retreat for Catherine and 100 kilograms of gold were used to gild the sophisticated stucco façade and numerous statues erected on the roof. In front of the palace is a great formal garden. The interior rooms (especially the amber room), furnishings and gold inlays are way over the top with extravagance. It makes one wander how the aristocracy could live this way when ordinary people starved from lack of food. We enjoyed our visit but found the crowds overwhelming, especially when the fountains were started around 11 am (see photos). Worth seeing if you know that there will be so many people, but it can get a bit tight in the grounds of the Gardens. It is a once in a life time experience to see this magnificent architecture and opulence!

Catherine's Palace. A must see. Beautiful grounds and fabulous museum which is well worth the visit. The fall is a beautiful time to visit and the weather was extremely good. This was my second trip and I'd highly recommend this Palace to any age traveler. It is amazing!

Unimaginable Wealth!. Catherine it seems was never satisfied with anything. This is most apparent in her summer palace that dazzles with gold and crystal and Amber, and countless priceless treasures. A room encrusted with Amber? Really you must see this, it is not to be believed! And make sure you take a tour that includes the "Amber Room" as I am not sure that all tours do. The Palace is one of the jewels of Saint Petersburg and should not to be missed!
Great. This was mind blowing with the amber room a must see. There is so much gold and the paintings were beautiful. This building has been beautifully restored

Amazing opulence and beauty. The exquisite art, the gilded linden wood, the delft blue heating stoves, the porcelain - everything about this palace is stunning. It is well worth the drive to Pushkin to see the beauty of this place and imagine the history that unfolded here.Wear comfortable shoes for walking indoors (they will insist that you put on the shoe covers which are provided) and touring the grounds. You'll want to see as much as you possibly can during your visit.

WOW. I loved our tour of Catherine's Palace and much preferred it to the Hermitage - purely because although it was reasonably crowded, we weren't packed in like sardines. It is about three quarters of an hour from St Petersburg by coach.The palace is sumptuous with many gorgeous rooms. funny having heard so much about the Amber Room, I was a little underwhelmed by it. Some of the other rooms though were just beautiful - light, airy and one could imagine the court enjoying their time there. The grounds of the Palace are vast and simply beautiful. Dotted round the park are numerous pavilions, including one lovely one by the lake in which a male a cappella will sing to you in glorious harmonies - just magic.

Catherine's Summer Palace. Magnificent and charming. The Amber Room impressed many but for us it is a bit over the top, vulgar, however the views from the windows are lovely; the dining settings, and art works are elegant and of great historical interest. It is nice to be there late in the day as there are so few fellow tourists and a stroll in the beautiful gardens reveals Catherine's palatial guest house, lovely lake, sculptures and the odd red squirrel scampering about.
Amazing. Yet another amazing Palace near St Petersberg. One cannot quite believe the lavish decorations and furnishings of the rooms. Take time to visit the gardens and see all the pavilions.
Vast wealth on display. This palace was amazing - bigger and fancier than Versailles- The Russian rulers had tremendous wealth. The grounds were beautiful too - lake and gardens. NIce guided tour.

Beautiful, enormous and visually stunning inside and out. The Palace was even more impressive on a bright sunny warm summer day. The first view of the place is literally breath-taking and stops tourists in their tracks. The amount of wealth on display is beyond belief, and gives rise to thoughts regarding revolution - one can imagine what the peasants who had nothing were thinking when they saw what one family had compared to their own meager circumstances. Room after room of elaborate everything - floors, ceilings, walls, furniture, decorations - many with gold. The Amber room is truly incredible, even though it is mostly a recreation. No pictures allowed in the Amber room, and there are very vigilant guards and matrons in almost every room to keep an eye on people and enforce the rules. Well worth seeing and being patient with the very large international crowds and lines to enter, as well as a moderate drive from St. Petersburg.

My reason for wanting to go to Russia. This was the place I most wanted to see in Russia. It's history really appealed to me and the part I was most wanted to see was the rebuilt Amber Room. I'd seen many photos & footage of it but nothing prepared me for the splendour of this room ... and I don't like Amber but it's effect is amazing. The whole Palace is beautiful. You'll never see anything like the Amber Room anywhere else.

The Amber room is a must see! Unique!. The fanfare in front of the palace was special! Then the richness of the palace rooms.. But the Amber room is totally unique and is a must see! Beautiful, impressive! The gardens are really beautiful, too!

Breathtaking. Catherine's Palace, now with Amber Room open, is a crowning achievement of the restoration of Russian Baroque. If you miss this, and it is a bit outside the city, you have missed the gem of St. Petersburg. Each room you enter will have your jaw drop and take your breath away.

Great grounds,too many tourists and gilt.. Visited the Palace on 9/26 with Viking Tours. Lovely grounds/gardens. Palace is smaller version of the Peterhof with much more gilt...most of us on tour were gilted out by this time, but if you like rococo, this is your spot. Only real negative was as this is a pretty small palace the fact that on a cold day in Sept. it was wall-to-wall with tourists in the mid-afternoon made seeing it much less enjoyable.

Catherine's Palace. A large palace filled with period pieces. Actors were dressed as Catherine and others. They wanted money for pictures taken of them. You move from room to room seeing the displays.

The Blue Palace. The Summer or Catherine Palace is located outside of St-Petersburg but a visit is well worth the short trip. A visit of the interior rooms and art works and the garden are a must. The harmony of the buildings and the grounds is a tribute to the architect and the builders of this magnificent place.

Amazing Palace & Grounds. We visited Catherine Place as part of an Alla Tour. It is a bit outside St Petersburg but well worth the time to walk around the grounds and the Palace itself. Our tour guide did an outstanding job of navigating the crowds so we could get the most out of the time there. It is amazing to see the art, wealth and majesty of the interior building. The exterior is different then the other places in St Petersburg in size and color. If you are going to spend more than a day in St Persburg then I would add this to your must see sites. Because of its distance from the city it would be very difficult to see all the other must see Palaces/Churches/Museums in St Petersburg.

Bling that will wow you. It would be hard to imagine the life of the rich in those days without seeing this site. The men were military minded and lived as though in battle. The women enjoyed their boudoir and had to use their brains to survive. Get there early.
Jaw dropping. The decor is out of this world. Definitely have a guide or audio to lead you through the museum. Flash is not allowed, but if you have PhotoShop, you can fix the pics.

Wonderful palace and part...equal to Peterhof. The amber room is truly unbelievable. It is a recreation of the original, but still a work of art. As all of the famous sites in St. Petersburg, the crowds certainly reduce the impact of the house, but the grounds are truly remarkable.

Park at Catherine Palace. The park is a highlight of the Catherine Palace, though the rooms are beautiful. However, one does not get a real idea of the extent of the palace from the rooms that are on view. I'm waiting for the church renovation to be finished, and would then visit again.I would strongly suggest stepping across the park and visiting the Alexander Palace, from which the last Romanov family was arrested. It has a moving immediacy, unlike the Catherine Palace.

Beautiful, a must see. This was my favourite building in St Petersburg as it had everything. Beauty, Gold, Gardens, Lakes, History, solitude, peace. We walked around the gardens and saw very few people, we heard beautiful voices sing in a lovely building in the garden, the damage caused in the war was devastating and what they have done to restore the Palace is truly astounding. If you have any choice about where to go, please choose this one to visit.

Catherine Palace. A lovely Palace to vist - loved the grounds and surrounding buildings. I did not like a large group who tried to push their way past every other group in the lines and did not go through the procedure of removing their jackets and bags - and got away with it as well.

Beautiful. This is a gorgeous restored palace of Catherine the Great. The rooms are perfect pictures of Russian royalty and have been amazingly restored. The amber room is stunning. The grounds are also absolutely amazing. The old pub restaurant is well worth the stop as you walk across the property and around the lake. It is a marvelous contrast to political life in America to see such opulence from the hands of Catherine the Great. Again, slow down and take your time to take it all in. Plan to spend a half day there and back. It's worth it.

it is a bit to go there, but may be worth it. the palace and park are beautiful. however, if you have limited days in st petersburg, do not prioritize this. if you have seen hermitage and winter palace, then you have seen the bigger and better versions. but that is just my own opinion, of course. there were few rooms open to public, for understandable reasons.

Gorgeous palace. It's a beautiful palace, especially the exterior, and the other buildings and small lake looks gorgeous! It's further from St Petersburg than Peterhof (mainly because the bus to Tsarskoye Selo stops everywhere, while it doesn't do as much with the Peterhof one) so allocate nearly an hour to get there from St Petersburg.

All that glitters. It was exciting to see this beautifully restored palace of Catherine the Great, and well worth the trip out of town. You need a good amount of time to take in all the amazing rooms and features, not to mention the gardens.

Golden Palace - Great Hall, Amber Room and Picture Hall. We have dreamed of visiting St. Petersburg for years. Finally, we were there for two full days. Because we can’t speak or read Russian, we decided to visit this wonderful city with Shore Exclusions’ Exclusive St. Petersburg Two Day Program. Additional benefits to book from this company are they are local and they take care of Russian Visa. We arrived by cruise in the early morning and started our journey around 9:00 am. The port is about 36 km (22 mile) on the south of the St. Petersburg, and it took us 70 minutes to get there. The traffic was incredible; I don’t think I could drive in St. Petersburg although I have driven in many countries (both left and right hand side driving). The local drivers do not have much patience, and they drive however they like.The grand Rococo style Catherine Palace (Russian: Екатерининский дворец) was built for Catherine I by her husband, Peter the Great, in the village of Pushkin in 1717. It exceeds all the other palaces with its massive size and its unique decorations- Blue and white with golden deco. The stunning facade of the palace extends for over 300 m (1000 ft). It was the summer residence of the Russian tsars. We waited in line for about an hour before our group was allowed to enter. All the visitors were asked to wear the shoe cover to protect the floor. First, we went through several “golden” rooms, including the largest state room in the palace - the Great Hall. It is amazing to see such a big hall, 800 m2 (8,600 ft2), with real gold decoration and mirrors. Those large windows and mirrors visually enlarge the hall, while the painted colonnade on the ceiling expands the space upwards. After that we saw the Main Staircase, the stunning Amber Room and the Picture Hall. I never visited a place with so much real gold inside and out. After we exited the Palace, we also had a chance to view some parts of the more than 6 km2 (1,500 acres) of park and gardens around the palace.Photography in the Palace is permitted with no flash and no tripod. You are not allowed to take photos in the Amber Room. We visited there in late June, and it was very crowded. If possible, you should find a less crowded season in order to enjoy all the beauties of the Palace.

Day Trip. Came here with "Best Guides" and glad we did - worth the cost as we got to see it all,and have it explained. Alexander palace and the buildings around the Great Pond were nice add ons. Photos allowed except in Amber Room but nice pictures of it are available on line. This takes about 5 hours!

Catherine Palace in January!. Yes....go to St. Petersburg in January! Bring those little chemical hand warmers....good boots and go! We hired a private tour guide (not very expensive in January) and had a wonderful visit to Catherine Palace. By the time we got there the us was up, haha and we almost had the place to ourselves. Truly magical. Well worth the trip and I hear Peterhof is also fabulous but the day we went it happened to be closed!

You should not miss Catherine Palace. Catherine's Palace is a short distance by car from St Petersburg but so much worth the visit if you have the chance. The palace and grounds are outstanding. However, with that said, if I had time to visit either Catherine's Palace or Peterhof I would probably have to pick Peterhof ... would be a hard choice.

Catherine Palace and Park. The blue Palace! Wow! Built so many years ago and still standing! Such wealth - all that gold! Too much to take in! This place is massive! I liked the beautiful palace church and the park.

A Remarkable Restoration.... Catherine's Palace was completely destroyed by the Nazis in WWII. To get a sense of the immense amount of destruction, be sure to view the photographs on display in the downstairs hallway, just before the exit area. These pictures put into perspective just how amazing the restoration of this palace has been, and is still going on today. The original amber panels in the Amber Room were stolen and never found to this day. Bring a sweater to wear while you are in the palace since everyone is required to check their coats and the rooms are chilly.
no words. there are no words to describe this the palace and park is just wonderful no wonder when we were there there was so many brides and grooms getting their photos taken

beautiful day trip. To Pushkin. If you are travelling independently, plan a little time as it takes a while to get from the center of St. Petersburg to Pushkin and back. Having said that, the trip is not to be missed even if only coming for the 'amber room'. The Palace is wonderful but a shame many people miss the fantastic little and inconspicuous exhibit in the corridor on the way out that shows how much was done to preserve and rebuild the palace after WWII. If you have an extra 45 min. to spare, I would recommend walking to the Alexander Palace for comparison. There, you don't have the crowds because the building is not as spectacular but provides an interesting pendant and contrast.

Oh! The opulence!. Gilded wood, mirrors, exquisite furniture, etc. A feast for the eyes. The outside is beautiful blue with white and it was lovely to stroll through the gardens. You can pick up a tour from the city center very easily.

Incredible Splendour. Mostly destroyed at the end of WW2, the Summer Palace at Pushkin has now been restored to astonishing glory. As you approach, the sheer scale of the pale blue facade is breathtaking, and once inside, the intricate detail of the restoration work gives an insight into the opulent lifestyle of the Tsars. Particulary interesting are the Ballroom and the Amber room. We visited on a particularly sunny September day which also gave us a chance to spend a little time in the attractive gardens from which you get a great view of the southern aspect of the palace.
Don't Miss It. What is not to like? The architecture and art are astounding. A photographer's dream. Obtain a guide and learn the amazing 19th Century history.

A Day in the Life of the Tsar. A short drive out of St Petersburg - Catherine's palace. Largely destroyed during WWII, it has painstakingly restored to much of its former glory. Although we only are allowed into a small part of the palace, it gives you an amazing window into the splendor in which the tsars lived. The Amber Room is truly amazing. I will remember best the amazing ceilings and the gilt columns, requiring sunglasses to prevent blindness. Wotrh the drive.
Extravagant!. If one was to become self indulgent, this was the model to see as our tour guide explained how Catherine loved to spend on things she wanted..and she sure did spend! Over the top!

Beautifully restored, but.... This palace was almost completely destroyed in WW II. The restoration is amazing...and yet sort of Disney like, or movie set like. It is really just a tourist trap as almost nothing is original. Truth be told, some of the Vegas hotels are nicer...and just as fake, yet spectacular.
St Catherine Palace & Park. A world treasure to behold. It has grandeur, it was crafted with human ingenuity.It survived World War 2. Long may it shine.
Opulent. This was another stunning palace with much baroque decoration. The exterior was very eye catching. Well worth a visit.
We got there early and waltzed right around. It takes a good guide to know how to get in and out of these remarkable palaces with style and grace. So pleased with the chance to see these places...
Outstanding beauty!. The interior of the Catherine Palace is unbelievable in its opulence, with so many beautiful rooms. The amber room is spectacular. The restoration of all of it is superb!

Stunning, over the top palace. We went in early winter, so it was quiet and that gave the place a wonderful air of freedom to look at the astonishing, over the top furnishings. No wonder the peasants revolted! The gardens were covered in snow and this gave them a picture postcard effect (in a positive way). A must see.

very very nice & grand. This place is so nice and grand that it is still in use today. My guide told me that President Putin had a G-7 Summit Ball/party here with world leaders. The curators should have a heart attack, with so much protocol, security to contend with and telling world leaders not to touch the displays! Grand as everything was. the ballroom (i attached a panaroma pic) the Amber Room was something else. pity we cant take pics. These were the 2 unique things that makes this place stand out from all other wonderful attractions. Really worth the experience
jaw dropping!. this was my favorite excursion while visiting St Petersburg- an incredible palace- absolutly stunning! Maybe the most beautiful place in the world!!!

Fabulous Restoration. This is a very impressive palace which I loved. The gold leaf restoration is meticulous. It gives an insight into life for the Tsars. The grounds are pretty too. There was nothing to dislike.

Be Dazzled by Gold!. The gold decorations were stunning. Differnt sets of dining table and dining set exhibits lives of opulence and how they welcomed their honorable guests. Everythings clearly demonstrate "the work of (high) arts.

A Must See Attraction. If you can only see one attraction in St. Petersburg, then this is it! Well worth the drive out of the city and the time to explore a national treasure. Remarkable not only for its beauty but for the incredible feat of restoration [Photos on the ground floor when exiting show what the palace looked like after the war]. The park is as magnificent as the palace and should not be missed. The secret to avoiding long lines for admission is to have a private tour prearrange to purchase tickets which then only have to be picked up on arrival - no waiting. Only downside to a visit is the very large number of tour groups who tend to be loud and move as a herd, making it difficult for individual visitors to either get through or to even hear themselves talk to each other. One of the joys of travel!
Amazing. This is well worth booking a tour or the time it takes your tour bus to drive here. The rooms are amazing, as are the grounds.

Dazzling but over the top. This palace is jaw-droppingly over-decorated and rather overpowering with its relentless gilding. I didn't like it as much as some of the other palaces.Empress Elizabeth had several architects working on it, and the lack of an overarching design concept really shows. The palace front is only 4 storeys high but its length goes on forever without any relieving architectual feature. It is impressive nevertheless, and there is a lovely park around it. The profligate way that the Romanov's money was lavished on palaces, but this one especially, makes you understand why there was eventually a revolution!

Very decadent. The Baroque style was VERY evident. It was a magnificent palace and the Amber room, while not the 'eighth wonder', was fascinating. We took a tour that told us that it was Elizabeth that expanded the palace to what it is and not Catherine the Great. A very fun experience.

comfort tour st petersburg. the wow factor is still there,yet another awesome building beautifully painted in lovely grounds. there were four wedding parties visiting the grounds to have photos taken. again the rooms were set out as the period design.

Outstanding. The exterior facade of the Palace on first sight is just amazing, with huge male terracotta figures appearing to shoulder the weight of the entire building. Painted in a pale blue and white, it is quite an imposing structure. As you enter, the staircase is a beautiful flourish of white plasterwork off-set by the colourful arrangement of fresh flowers. Each room that you enter has a "wow" factor, for both sheer size and decoration. The use of gold gilt in every room togehter with the quantity is quite amazing. The Palace houses some wonderful artwork and porcelain amongst its many treasures. The grounds are equally awesome - particularly the lake and the surrounding sculptures. So worth a slow amble around at your leisure.

Beautiful. Both the inside and outside of Catherine Palace were beautiful. The rooms were highly decorated, the floors, walls and lightfittings were so opulant. The grounds were beautifully laid out and very well maintained.

Beautiful. We were very lucky to be able to incorporate an afternoon tour of Catherines Palace and Garden into our trip to St. Petersburg. What a stunning Palace and we enjoyed the experience very much.

Too long a line but the park was great. If you do not buy your ticket before you arrive, you may wait 90 minutes to get into the palace. We quickly bought a ticket for the gardens but they would not sell one for the palace in the same booth and pointed to a horrendous line. We had just seen the Hermitage the day before and passed on the insides of another outrageous display of wealth sucked from the lives of serfs. The gardens were quiet, lovely and a wonder.

Opulent!. Opulent was my attempt of coming up with an adjective to describe this palace. Truly hard to imagine living there. Our guided tour greatly helped in understanding so much about it. Well worth your time!

A Day Well Spent, Can't Wait To Visit Again!!. Catherine Palace and Park is one of the prettiest sites in the St. Petersburg area. For some local flavor, take the train. The old-fashioned wooden benches fill up quickly with locals who are so friendly and they make sure you get off at the right stop. Buying the train ticket is easy even if you don't speak Russian. Hand gestures and pantomime do the trick. You transfer to a bus at the Pushkin train station and voila! You're at the stop for Catherine Palace. A short walk and the beautiful blue color of the palace peaks through the trees, as well as the near-blinding gold trim around the outside of the building. The highlight is the Amber Room, where photos are forbidden, but if you can stealthly use your cellphone camera, you may get a pic or two. All the rooms have been exquisitely restored and the colors and patterns of fabrics are beautifully coordinated. The parquet flooring is also stunning, and each room has a different pattern. The tour makes you wish you could live like a tsar, and you can keep that memory by having your photo taken with a guy and gal dressed up in period costumes.Outside in the gardens, you can forget where you are as you view all the beautiful flower gardens. It's a great way to spend a day, just taking your time and strolling around. There's a small cafe that has reasonable prices (given that they could really rip you off since they're the only game in town. Don't miss this palace. I think it's even nicer and more elegant than Peterhof, and less crowded too.

Beautiful! Stunning example of architecture.. This palace is beautiful! That's the only way to describe it. It is a great example of the architecture of the Russian Empire. I would definitely recommend this if you could get over to Pushkin. There are gardens as well. The Amber Room is stunning. At first, you walk in and it's underwhelming, but then as you stare at the floor, ceiling, furniture, etc. you begin to realize how phenomenal it is.

Catherine the Greats' palace. I have NEVER been rendered speechless at such opulence in my life. Been to various stately homes and palaces, this is the VERY BEST. We had a very good English speaking licensed guide, who 'whipped' us through art galleries and grand rooms, but compensated this with time to gasp in awe when entering the Gold Room.

Catherine the Great. How can anyone live in such a huge, golden palace and not feel guilty? She led a very active life, building small palaces for two of her lovers! Nothing I have seen compares to the wealth displayed here
Wonderful. This palace is excellant and shows the opulence of the time. The grounds are wonderful, and the restoration work after several times of great damage, are certainly a credit to the workers.

A little outside the city. More splendour - if you can take it. This palace is outside the city so there are gardens to wander about as well. Like all Russian museums you will have to put your coat and any backpack in the cloak room (free).

Unbelievably interesting. Visiting this palace gave a great insight into Catherine The Great, a must see, as it isn't something you could imagine in your wildest dreams, learning the history behind each room was most interesting. The palace has been preserved with the utmost care, and is worth a visit.

Awesome. I have to add my superlatives to those of other reviewers. This place is incredible. It is amazing to think that with the amount of gold adorning the place, Catherine ordered the 60 oversized statues of Atlas on the front painted bronze as a cost saving measure. Inside though it is pretty clear she spared no expense. You will walk through one gold adorned room after another each an ostentatious statement about the arrogance of power and privilege. And just when you think you can't bear to look at another gilt edged room, you glide into the amber room and say "oh, wow." No photos allowed in the amber room but non flash allowed everywhere else.Travel tips. Consider a tour group to speed entry which is controlled. Large bags and long coats must be checked but the facility is spacious and the process runs pretty smooth. The place is very crowded. We were there on a Monday afternoon and it was packed but they keep the tour groups moving so despite the crowds you should get to see everything. Definitely a must see and less than an hour drive from downtown St. Pete.If you found this review helpful please click below.

Well worth the visit. Although a total reconstruction because it was destroyed in WWII it is fabulous to see. The amber room is impressive but smaller than I had imagined as a lot of the pictures of the room are infact showing you all 3 walls in a line as if that is just one side of the room. However it is still very impressive and worth the journey out to the palace. It gets very busy and we met a tour guide who didn't like the fact that we 'overtook' her group. The trouble is that some groups were slower to pass through than you wanted to go your self.

Wonderful grounds, the Palace less so. Definitely worth a visit, but I must give a balancing opinion. From what I have read, the Catherine Palace was mostly destroyed in WWII, and what you are seeing is a restoration, and not an inspired one. I have difficulty believing that the original was so monotonous -- now, there is room after nearly identical room, all gold-painted Rococo ornamentation. Considering the lavish variety of the interiors in the Hermitage, the place pales in comparison. Wonderful grounds. Just picking a bit of a bone, go see it anyway.

Amazing but crowded. This place is astonishing and no doubt best viewed at a quiet time if possible. If you can, avoid when too many tours are visiting so you can at least get some idea of the grandeur of the place - otherwise you'll be hustled through with the masses.

A gem just outside St Petersburg. This superb palace is just a few miles outside the city of St Petersburg but it must not be missed by visitors. The palace is open to visitors -- for a fee-- but it is all worthwhile. One cannot but be amazed by the opulence and splendour of the building. Gold is found everywhere... The symbols of Russian power and pre-eminence are on the walls, the ceilings, the doors and were meant to impress visitors to the palace. Catherine the Great was responsible for it all. She was said never to wear the same dress twice and some are on display as are objets d'art, furniture, marvellous wooden floors, paintings, etc. In sections of the palace, all visitors are compelled to wear protective overshoes (free) in order not to scuff the flooring. The surrounding gardens, done in the French style, are totally delightful and not to be missed, just like the ornate gates to the compound. A glimpse into the aristocratic world of old and beautifully preserved today...

Over the TOP. Catherine brought in the best of the best. Almost overwhelming the gold guilding and portraits and abundance of priceless treasures. Another amazing restoration of a beautiful Russian treasure.

Much history and beauty here. Another amazing top ten place to visit in St. Petersburg. Much of it was destroyed in WWII, but has been beautifully restored. The amber room, by itself, is worth the trip. Otherwise known as the the Tsar's Village, it is incredible.

A capella choir worth the trip!. Yes, it's a beautiful palace built by Peter the Great for his second wife, the former friend's servant, Catherine I. She wanted a modest country home (dacha). He built her a palace! Lovely gardens and lakes. But best part (for me) was hearing the a capella male quintet sing Russian songs in a building constructed for a capella singing. Catherine Palace is about an hour from St. Petersburg. Take an English-speaking guide and skip the lines! She also told me exactly where to stand to hear the best acoustics for the a capella (they don't sing there all the time, so we just lucked out!)

A must. There are many adjectives you could use talking about Catherine palace - breathtaking, opulent, stunning......Also the gardens are beautiful, if you´re lucky about the weather. Beneath others you can find there one small palace by Rastrelli, called "Grotto" with lovely inner decorations and quite often music shows. Going inside requires a lot of your patience.....unfortunately I have to say that I have never met such an ignorance as in Russian attitude to tourists....we came to the palace round 10,30 (by train from Vitebsky railway station and then with masrutka bus) and find out that the ticket office is closed and it opens at noon. We asked why? One of the staff told us that you can only go inside at 10AM and than every two hours and between, you´ll have to wait in a row, because otherwise, there´s a risk that you won´t be allowed to get in next visit....So we waited more than hour in a row to get inside - but it definitely worth it! The palace is gorgeous...one part is decorated by Rastrelli matchint the taste of Elisabeth Petrovna, the other is much austere (from the times of Catherine The Great). The amber room is magic. What was the most impressive for me, the exhibition at the end - about restoration works at palace. You just have to admire thousands of people who were able to save the objects from palace and than, after war, restore the palace into this really sparkling look.

russian and majestic. if you go there you will feel the atmosphere of XVIII century in Russia. visit in Petersburg without this palace would be not full. the queue was long, but we spend there not so much time as we thought it might. the main problem was lack of information in english, but this is general problem in Petersburg. luckliy my mom undestands russian so she translated me what our guide said. if you finished visit in Palace, don't think it's over! the gardens are delightful and good place for lunch. there are many paths and places to discover.

Really a beautiful place. Although it's quite long and difficult to reach, it really worths. It's like Versailles: an enormous garden, with a lake and some structures spread around and at the top, the magnificent palace from 16th century. The inside is almost completely visible and it's really amazing. Must see

Worth as much time as you have!. We visited as part of a tour group so we entered early, before individuals. There is a cloak room and large and clean rest rooms. Bring your camera and comfortable walking shoes. If you are on your own you may choose to enter the palace or the Park or both. Check the weather and organize your trip accordingly. The gardens are huge with beautiful allees and lakes, you could easily spend a day just exploring the gardens. You will see young brides with their bridal party. It is a Russian tradition to visit the most beautiful local sites to have pictures taken after the civil wedding ceremony. When we were there we were fortunate that there were singers performing in the Grotto which has wonderful acoustics. I did not see a place to eat but there must be something in the area. The palace will be very crowded but the park will give you a chance to catch your breath and envision what it would have been like in the 18th century to live on such a vast estate. Inside the palace appreciate the elaborate Russian Baroque woodwork - almost totally destroyed during WWII. What you are seeing is all carved wood and our guide explained there was only one carver - a woman who worked for years. Each gilded cherub has a different face. Enjoy the details!

Opulence beyond description. This was an incredible, beautiful and opulent palace. The tours take you through a small part of it because it would take weeks to see it all. There aren't enough words to describe all the beauty contained within. A "must see" if you are near St. Petersburg.
Excellent. Like all the palaces in St Petersburg. It is mindblowing. Not quite as grand as Petershoff but right up there and worth a visit.

St. Petersburg tour. We toured St Petersburg while on a cruise. The Palaces and churches were amazing and at the same time heart breaking to know they were build with such lavishness and expense while the people of Russia lived in poverty. St. Catherine's Palace had many works of art that the average person doesn't see. Please let me forewarn you though. We were very disappointed with the tour group that we used, Den Rus.
