The tour was very rushed , with a harsh tour guide and mediocre lunches. We understand that they tried to cover a lot of places but we found it disappointing that we could not enjoy the sights.

The Amber room alone is worth a visit!. Visited Catherine Palace and Park in August as part of a tour from Viking cruise's "Waterways of the Tsars" trip. Wonderful experience, we arrived there early enough to bypass the crowds, was even able to linger in a few rooms to examine the details. We were welcomed by a band who played some classical tunes to entertain us while we were waiting for the palace to open its doors to us. The opulence is unexpected, the Tsars certainly knew how to live in those days! The highlight for me was the Amber Room, photos and videos do not do it justice ( that is one of the few rooms in the palace that photography is not allowed anyway ), you just have to be there. It's amazing how they managed to recreate it, there are a few panels near the ceiling that are not filled in with amber panels, but you can imagine what the original must have looked. The artistry is spectacular, and even with the crowds mingling in the room, there is a special feel about the room that is so awe inspiring.As mentioned earlier, photography is allowed in most of the rooms in the palace which was nice, the grounds are also very well laid out, but be warned, between the palace and the grounds, there is a lot of walking to do! You also have to leave any backpacks and coats in a cloakroom before you are allowed to tour the palace rooms.

Grandeur, gold, and gilt. If you are looking for an example of the excesses of the Russian Tsars at its very best, you need look no further than Catherine's Palace! We were told that 100 kilograms of gold was used to gild the façade of the palace and the statues on the roof. The gold, set upon the iconic blue and white exterior, is truly stunning. The views of the Chapel with the gold onion domes are spectacularly beautiful.The interior of the Palace is royally opulent. While certainly the Amber Room was special and unique - and we particularly enjoyed it because we had heard its story when we were visiting Berlin, other favorites were The Great Hall, The Grand Staircase, The Portrait Hall and the Picture Hall, The Crimson and Green Rooms, and the Dining Rooms. In room after room, you will see gold that is so bright that you almost feel as though you need sunglasses! Don't forget, though, to look up and down - the ceilings and floors are equally beautiful. The Palace is so large that it is difficult to get a sense of the size of it when you are there - look for an aerial view of it on the internet. That will give you some perspective when you visit. The park was lovely and, even with tourists, seemed quite peaceful. Flowers, trees, sculpture, buildings, pools, bridges, and buildings - the park is landscape architecture at its best.While we traveled to Russia independently, we did choose to take a tour to Catherine's Palace, due to our time schedules. The tour company we used was Eclectica and it was quite good - the guide was excellent with an extensive knowledge of the Palace, Park, and Pushkin and, additionally, his English was excellent. Plus, this particular tour used a small van, rather than a large bus - so there were only 12 of us which made it very easy to hear the guide, ask questions, and have time to spend both on the tour and independently.This is definitely a "must see" in St. Petersburg. Touring the Palace and Park and seeing the grandeur really gives some context and clarity to Russia's history and people.

Spectacular. We were lucky as it was very sunny when we visited. The Palace was spectacular and very ornate. Usual groups of people being herded around, but worth it. Park was glorious but, unfortunately, we did not have enough time to just wander around. There is a music gallery in the grounds, where a group sing Russian folk songs - bit cheesy, but fun to listen to, and you can buy CDs of their music!!!
Beautiful !!. Catherine's Palace was so beautiful !!! It is so big and so visually stunning !! From floor to ceiling there was so many wonderous things to see.

Probably my favourite palace in St Petersburg. This palace was probably my favourite out of all the ones we saw on our 2 day visit. We did a tour with SPB tours. Having a guide in this palace was necessary as nothing was written in English. The rooms were smaller than other palaces but very opulent. The morning tea room was spectacular. Definitely worth a visit.
It good to be Tzar.... Opulent and large, this palace continues to impress as it did many years ago! The Ball Room and Amber Room were pretty cool! Enjoyed the short visit and perspective!

Opulence beyond belief. This baroque palace was the highlight of our two day visit to St Petersburg. The palace was built as the summer palace for Catherine 1 and is located in the famous historical town of Tsarskoe Selo approximately 17 miles south of St Petersburg, approximately one hour's drive. The facade of the palace is magnificent and gives an immediate impression of what to expect inside. We were shown round the palace in groups and were not allowed to linger in the various rooms for very long. The rooms were breathtaking and beautifully furnished. Each room we entered was more magnificent than the previous one. The doors and parquet flooring are works of art and simply outstanding. On entering the amber room it is hard to believe that this is a reconstruction, the original having been stolen during the Second World War. The ballroom is unbelievable with gilded walls, mirrors and the most magnificent chandeliers. The gardens surrounding the palace are well laid out with many attractive features. This is a must for any visitor to St Petersburg.

Don't miss this. Catherine Palace is a must see. From the beautiful parquet floors to the exquisite amber room, architectural details, it is breathtaking. Much of it has been restored, some of it, like the amber room recreated, as there was extensive damage done during WW II. There are very interesting photos showing the extent of the damage and the restoration work done. Much did survive, however, and the grandeur of this palace lives on. The grounds are spectacular with terraces, fountains, and sculptures, beautiful gardens. Could really use more restrooms!

Indescribable - Must see to believe. This palace is amazing. And to think, it was completely restored after World War II almost destroyed it makes it even that more amazing. This is truly a grand palace with grounds to match. It is true, it is very crowded, but well worth the visit. There is not much I can add that hasn't already been written in TripAdvisor. This is a MUST SEE when visiting St. Petersburg/Pushkin

Golden splendour. Wonderful gardens surround this opulent palace. Restoration work continues but a large portion is open for public viewing. Take your camera as photos are allowed with the exception of the Amber Room. Well worth a visit

Wonderful gardens, but the palace is this tour bus heaven....... The grounds are exquisite and well worth lingering in; the only drawbacks are endless ways to part you from your money: trinkets, musicians, snacks & drinks,etc.. I think they should pay us to tour the interior1) It is profoundly vulgar: you can understand why the revolution happened2) There are endless tour us groups. Sometimes you are hurried through rooms, and sometimes you wait, and wait, and wait3) If you like being treated like cattle, this is the place for you

A piece of paradise. I was traveling with my mother and her friend.To get there we took a bus. The bus ride took about 1/2 hour give or take.The entrance fee to the complex is cheap only 100 rubles.The territory of this attraction is huge. We decided to take a walk and look at the nature and only then to go to the palace. There are a lot of lakes and everywhere you can find a bench to sit and enjoy the nature. The squirrels are so friendly and hoping you brought them a tasty nuts.After a two hours we arrived to the palace section, we decided not to visit inside but just to enjoy the gardens. (to enter the palace you have to pay another entrance fee)In one word I can say that you have to visit this place, it just combines so many great things to see and enjoy.

Highlight of a Cruise tour.. We booked the most expensive package of a cruise tour. It was worth it. We got to see all the highlights of St. Petersburg and usually we were the first tour group to see all the highlights. However, Catherine Palace was scheduled for the first night. We only got a hour and a half to change from the day. After a quick shower, we were the first bus on our way to St. Catherines. It is about.an hour away. When we pulled up to the gate and greeted with vodka and canapés. The palace is unbelievable. Inside including the Amber Room, the ballroom, the gardens, the carriage museum was breathtaking. It makes Louis15 from France look like he lived in a shack. The best part was musicians in different part of the palace. It don't want to ruin the wow factor. We finished the night in a room near the castle with dinner and folk musicians. THIS WAS THE HIGHLIGHT OF OUR TOUR. THIS IS A MUST SEE. Everyone talked about this and how lucky we were. The Baltic cruise is physically a lot of walking and long days. If you have a cane, hard time walking, wheelchair....this will be a challenge. Many stairs do not have railings, floors are slippery, streets are cobblestones...not for the faint ......But this part of Russia is beautiful and very interesting. GO.

Breathtaking!. Go for the Amber Room alone. It was amazing how this Palace was restored after the devasting damage of WWII. The pictures of the bombing of the Palace was heartbreaking, but how they were able to bring it back is worth seeing.

Grounds stunning, too crowded inside. This review should be tempered by the fact that we were there high season and on Monday when most of the other attractions are closed. Simply, just too many trying to get inside made it very hot and uncomfortable. We kinda thought the organizers could do better and not seem to be only interested in the money we paid to get in. If we come again we'll definitely try to see the palace interior but will consider the timing of our visit

Catherine Palace and Park, Pushkin, Russia. Beautiful palace and gardens. We had a fabulous tour guide who spoke really well english. Very busy though and you get ushered through the palace quiet quickly, but all the rooms are jawdropingly beautiful, especially the Amber room, there is nothing like it.

highlight of the trip. Words can't do justice to this beautiful place,I could easily have spent a full day there but not possible as so many people are visiting . The amber room was for me, the highlight of the trip.

Beautiful. More awesome than Peterhof to me. Had missed this one on a previous visit so was especially glad to not miss the opportunity this time. Were told Catherine the Great preferred this palace over Peterhof and after seeing it I see why. Definitely worth working it in.

Catherine's Palace, St. Petersburg, Russia. The entire extensive property and grounds were absolutely beautiful. The tour through the palace was very interesting and informative and showed a period that was so elaborate & grand and a bit ostentatious!!! There was a room in the palace where the walls were entirely covered with amber which is like a diamond in Russia. It really was a beautiful and interesting trip.
the time for tourists. very busy but wow that's a lot of gold hard to even imaging the opulence and wealth quite the collection Catherine bjut what did the rest of the people have

Awsome Catherine Palace. One of the highlights of our two day De Luxe SPB Tour. We arrived early on first day with very few people about which was wonderfull. The ambiance hits you before you get in the door and is enhanced as you go through each of many rooms.The attention to detail and quality of workmanship is amazing given so much restoration has taken place. The pieces of furniture, porcelain, floors, paintings and even fireplaces are magnificent.Each room is great in their own right but the whole ambience in the palace is mind blowing and is finished off by the walk in the gardens. All in all a must to see on your itinerary.

A great royal palace. This is one of the great palaces of the Tsar's . If you like major league royal palaces, this is one not to miss. We had some problems with the timed entry tickets, so we spent extra time in the gardens. It was very pleasant. Sitting there for a couple of hours was a nice break and a window into the extent and peacefulness of the gardens.

An absolute must!. Catherine Palace is fabulous - renovated from utter destruction - amazing colours of ice blue and gold present a stunning view on arrival.Our tour including coach travel was approximately £40 with entry and the tour took us from the harbour through St Petersburg to Pushkin viewing the city on the way through. There are many staterooms decorated in gold and white, and the Amber room although not huge is amazing.We went at the end of August and found we were not inundated with with other visitors too much perhaps this being the end of the season. Our guide was very informative and on the outskirts of the city we passed over the hills where the city of St Petersburg or Lenningrad as it was known at the time, was besieged. Highly recommend this trip, beautiful gardens, and if you only have a couple of days in this wonderful city take a half day tour as we did not too tiring and you can see something else for the other half of the day.
Perfect. It is a magnificent place. Worth visiting. Great palce, lovely park. Audio guides in english, you are allowed to take pictures, except the impressive Amber Room.
catherine palace. the city holds an unusual amount of sights worth visiting . the different venues lived up to their pre-trip build up. worth evey minute in the city .

Amber Room visit wonderful!. Although the room has been renovated following a fire, it has been created as it was in Catherine's time. Beautiful! The Palace itself is so opulent, you can just imagine the Royal Family moving through it! Well reconstructed and worth a visit. Enjoy!

Catherine Palace is something that must be seen. Whilst in St Petersburg we took the opportunity to visit Catherine Palace. It has to be seen to be believed. The Palace is approx. 300m long and many of the rooms have gold lining the walls. As you enter the building you are greeted by a 4 piece brass band, just adding to the atmosphere.The reception/dance room, with its gold walls is just fantastic. 1 room using classic paintings as a type of wall paper with all the frames abutting each other. The room with amber, which unfortunately you cannot takes photos, is also spectacular.To really appreciate the building would take about 3 hours, but once you leave the building strolling through the gardens are a must see.Whilst we did this tour in a 1/2 day, I could have stayed all day and still be wanting more.

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. Everything about the palace is spectacular. The place is enormous, and each and every room is breathtaking. The palace was burned during WWII but beautifully restored, and well worth a visit.
A must see, but unpleasantly crowded. I don't think a visit to St. Petersburg can be complete without visiting this palace, but the overcrowded conditions made the experience unpleasant.

Well worth seeing. The Amber room here is lovely and I do not think you will every see so much gold leaf in a Palace! It is an amazing place. At the end you see the photographs of how it was after the war and you cannot believe how they have renovated it so wonderfully. Apparently after the war there was a meeting of architects from around what is now Europe and an English architect apparently said it could never be renovated, how wrong can you be!

Don't miss these fountains. We enjoyed the hydrofoil journey. Don't miss Peterhof it is a spectacular sight, these fountains were built 300 years ago and are gravity fed, unbelievable!! We visited in August 2013 on a very sunny day when the gold glistened. Yes there were crowds round the main fountains but visit the rest of the palace gardens and try the trick fountains. we went across the stepping stones and the fountains caught us out and we got wet, great fun on a hot day. We didn't have time to visit the interior of the palace as we headed off to St Catherine's Palace.

Catherine's Palace. It was gorgeous and sumptuous to view. Can be off putting when you think of people starving in the world and you see rooms dripping with gold. It is truly beautiful. Very glad to have visited. Remarkably when you walk from room to room, you see all this abundance of decor and then in the door jams, you see the room needs repair. Catherine was quite a woman!

absolutely beautiful. The building is so beautiful both inside and outside. Having a guide really helps you understand what you are seeing. Each room is unique. Definitely suggest seeing Catherine Palace.

Impressive restoration from WWII damage. We learned that the entire palace was basically destroied by Natzs before they were defeated in Ruasia. The goverment really made a lot of effort to restore the palace to its original status, which shows its glamorous past.

Fabulous, but go with a guide. It's hard to add anything to the descriptions of other contributors on this amazing blue, white and gold palace, with its fabulous chandeliers (and we don't usually like chandeliers!). Almost all of it is an excellent restoration, the place having been badly damaged and looted by the Nazis (there are many evocative pictures of the wrecked building in a gallery).If you go individually you'll be restricted on times and, I'm told, have to take their guided tour(s) which seem to be just in Russian(?). It will, no doubt, be very busy too.Go with a good guide (see SPB Tours that we used) and you might miss all that, and will certainly get a much better explanation in your own language. In fact, although the palace is ostensibly closed on Tuesdays it seems that SPB (and perhaps a few others?) have rights to take people in; we certainly went in with very few other people there and have photos of long hallways totally empty to prove it. Our group of 15 was the only one in the famed Amber Room (the only place you can't take photos), though I'd have loved to see the Agate Rooms too, which are still being restored (although they apparently weren't looted).To have this place almost to ourselves was a major highlight of our time in St Petersburg, and a real tribute to SPB
Brilliant. Just awesome, beyond belief ,all that gold. Amber room is stunning. Hard to imagine someone once lived there.
Wow. Among all the beautiful buildings, this had so much opulence and gold and beauty. It's a privilege to be able to wander around it.

So beautiful. We went with a local tour guide from White Night and enjoyed it very much. The little bits of knowledge from a knowledgeable guide helps to navigate around this beautiful palace and grounds. It would have been lovely to spend the whole day here but at last, we were on a tight schedule!
Catherine Palace. This amazing blue and gold palace with the beautiful gardens take your breath away. All the gold and mirrors and the Palace church!

A Palace Worth Visiting!. Having lived in France for 5 years, I've seen my share of palaces and castles all throughout Europe. But, St. Catherine's was definitely a surprise! While not to the size of Versailles or many other European castles, the craftsmen work and interior is just as amazing! From the woodwork in the floors, to the Amber room, to the mirrors....there were too many details to catch. We were fortunate to arrive before the gates "officially" opened and were able to have a small private tour throughout the entire palace without crowds.

Simply Stunning. It was a very busy day and the queues were huge - however, once we started on the tour we didn't feel rushed in any way. The view of the shimmering gold as you looked down the corridor might have been mistaken for mirrors but it wasn't. One of the must sees when you visit St Petersburg.

Tribute to a Queen. Beautiful Palace, lovely gardens. We had lunch there and were entertained by a band when entering the palace and whilst we ate, a group of folk singers. The highlight was an impromptu choral quintet singing in one of the out buildings

Gold and more gold!!!! This was one indulgent Queen.. The gold opulence is something to behold. Catherine the Great reigned for a long time but she sure did know how to spend money. Her wardrobe is famous with gowns that were never worn. She had gold covering everything! Room after room of carvings and gold leaf. i've never seen anything like it even at Versailles. This is a must see when in St. Petersburg. Learn the history and the lineage of the royalty, I find it's interesting and it's more fun seeing the art and sculpture when you understand who the different people were.Our private guide was invaluable in describing everything and helping to make sure we saw all the most important and interesting sites with the time we had.

Amber Room - the biggest star. The palace is fully restored including its famous amber room that has been vandalized and looted by nazis during the WWII. in its luxury and decor it overshadows the Winter Palace in the center of St. Petersburg. The interior walls, floors, paintings, furniture, lights - everything looks brand new and shining, covered with gold, blue porcelain, white plaster and polished precious wood. The amber room is an absolute and unique masterpiece. It is a shame there is no photography allowed in the amber room. You will be stunned when you see this room and the entire palace. No words can fully describe this experience.
beautifully restaured. it really looks like a fairy-tale palace. The amber room is magnificent. It is absolutely worth the trip from Sint Petersburg to Pushkin.
Very nice. This was beautiful to see, the grounds are beautiful, the palace is big and beautiful. It takes a fair amount of time. But its worth it.
This is an amazing palace to visit if you to Russia. The place is fantastic, beautiful inside looks like Versailles and the gardens are beautiful. Worth a visit.

Lovely. This palace was wonderful. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was not too crowded. The gold leaf and ornamentation is breathtaking, as is the Amber Room. The history as explained by our guide was fascinating.

St Catherine's Palace. Amazing palace and grounds.Spent hours enjoying the palace and park,very well kept .Tourguide was very informative and knowledgeable about the history of Russiaand Catherine the Great

Worth a visit. Gorgeous Palace, and the last residence of the Russian royalty. The Palace has been painstakingly restored after WWII. You have to see it to appreciate the lifestyle of the Czars. To get in, foreigner's have to walk past the line of waiting Russian's, and purchase tickets inside the Palace. You need to do this before or after lunch, as ticket sellers take a break. But before you can get to the Palace, you have to purchase a ticket to get in to the vast fabulous gardens surrounding the Palace. You can spend hours wondering around this vast estate.

Crowded but nice. When I was there, a lot of the trim was brown and needed gold plating. Still, it was still enjoyable. However, by 9:30 AM it was crawling with tourists. I was with a tour guide--they can get you in sooner. The palace was quite large and had a number of areas w/o air conditioning. So, dress suitably.

Prettier than Peterhof. Beautifully restored after WWII, Catherine Palace is not to be missed! The entire Tsarko Selo is an amazing display of Russian architecture and artifacts. Go before 10:00 am to avoid long lines for entry.
Over-the-top. Consider this: the Communists' workers' paradise spent several $billions to fully restore this palace to its Czarist magnificence during the 1950's. Don't miss it!

My Favorite Place in St. Petersburg. Catherine Palace is unbelievably beautiful! I think the outside is as pretty as the inside. One of my favorite souvenirs is a watercolor picture I purchased outside the palace. It makes me smile every time I look at it and remember the beauty of this place. You can take pictures inside without flash except in the Amber Room. I did manage a picture of it by standing outside the room and shooting in as much as possible. Do not miss this fabulous place.

Opulence. This is one of the worlds finest piece of architecture. Catherine was truly loaded and her extravagance was breathtaking. In a country where almost everyone was a penniless peasant she spent a large fortune on this palace. a specatcle in every way, the grounds too are amazing. Not to be missed.

Beautiful!. The tsars and their families really knew how to live. This place is a fairy tale come true with it's beautiful rooms and grounds. Think it was here we saw Chinese statues. Another place to revisit.
Opulence Overload. If you ever thought you could become blasé about gold gilt covered walks, this is the place. One fabulous room after another. WOW!

A Night (and Day) to Remember. We went on a private tour in the evening where we could take pictures of the Amber Room. And watched players waltz to Tchaikovsky while drinking champagne in the Great Hall. The next day we went with another tour group for a day tour; we learned more but no pictures in the Amber Room. No room like it.

Make sure you double check opening hours. We arrived to the Palace and went to go inside for tickets but they told us it was closed. Even though the opening hours on the website and front door said it would be open. They didn't give us a reason why or tell us anything. One person mentioned that they might open again later so we spend a hour or so walking around the beautiful gardens (which are worth the visit itself!) before heading back to try our luck again. This time it was open and we were able to buy tickets and get in however for some reason we were some of the only ones in there. We didn't mind as at least we got to see it but the whole situation was confusing. Definitely worth a visit as it is an impressive palace.
Ostentatious. If you like gilt you'll like this. Be good if owners catch on to our interest in how the servants lived and serviced such a place

Completely Restored.. Catherines Palace has a lot to see. It is very beautiful with its elaborate colourful decor. However it is even more amazing when you get to the basement and find that it was totally destroyed during the World War 2 and had to be restored to its original glory. There is a room which was covered in Amber which was restored to its original condition. It says a lot about Russian craftsmen who not only created many of these estates and their treasures but who also restored them.

Amazing Place in the Evening. If you go in the evening, you can get a wonderful tour of the palace, watch a concert, see a dance performance, hear wonderful soloists and drink champagne and vodka with characters in period costumes. One of the remarkable sites in St. Petersburg.
Completely over the top ion a Tsarist sort of way!. Very ornate. Lots of rooms to see. Rather crowded at times. The gardens were also nice. good to get a flavour of how the Tsars lived.

Living in style. So happy we didn't book anything for the evening. We were exausted after all the visiting, but a happy exaustion!!
Wish we would have had a 3rd day!!

Catherine and Elizabeth. They had beaufitul taste and obviously the money to get what they wanted.
I found it a bit too much gold to the point that you get tired of it.
Reminded me of Versailles in France.

Amber room is why I went. Loved it, we take a private tour from Best Guides. Beautiful inside, and you can take photos except the Amber Room.
Rocco and classic style mixed, hard to believe it was mostly rubble after WWII.

Makes you feel you are in a fantasy land. Both the palace (the Amber room especially) and the park make you feel as though you are in another time. You can close your eyes and imagine that you are living in the time of the Czars and Emperors of Russia. The only downside is you have very little time to spend in the Amber room as there are thousands of people going through.

The museum is the real gem.. As European gardens go, this one needs more work. I enjoyed the violinist as we walked into the park. They have lovely ponds and I found the separate baths a great idea. After having been to Versailles, it is hard to compare. All gardens pale in grand scale.

Opulent. Hard to believe the opulence and extensive decoration in this palace. The gold cupolas and blue architecture are brilliant. The rooms are furnished with extensive artwork, gold, marble and mirrors. She spared no expense as she declared herself Catherine The Great. Another must see on a visit to St. Petersburg.

Breath-taking!!. A trip to St. Petersburg would not be complete without a trip to Pushkin and Catherines Summer Palace. The drive out of St. Petersburg through the suburbs into the countryside is memorable and the town of Pushkin is lovely. The crowning glory is the palace.So much opulence and over the top beauty, take your time and enjoy each room. The amber room was amazing, which we could have spent more time there. Besides the palace the grounds are unbelievable. We had a beautiful sunny day there and the way the sun glistened off all the golden domes is something we will never forget.
WOW. lots of gold. tells the history of Russia in so many ways. but looks so European. Amber room is beautiful. Restoration is exquisite.

Busy but good. Splendid palace with one room after the other of wonderful things to see, the amber room was a bit overwhelming on this trip did not have time for the gardens but they seem to be worth a visit

More is more. Let's face it. If you make the trip to SPB, you are almost certain to visit Catherine's Palace. Depending on the order in which you visit the many attractions of SPB, you may be pretty well zonked out by the over-the-top excess of Czarist interior design. Regardless, suck it up and soak it in. You could easily spend a day studying each room, but, of course, this is not possible for us mere gawkers. The enormity of the palaces coupled with the arrogant opulence evidenced by the decorations and furnishings is amazing. On one hand, you will be awed. On the other, you will understand why there was a revolution.BTW: the Amber Room really is everything it's cracked up to be. What a pity that the original amber panels were stolen / destroyed / looted by the Nazis.

Unbelievable. It is for me impossible to believe that this had been rebuilt almost from nothing. And to see the Amber room was for me a breath-taking experience and to know they were rebuilt just blows me away. I could have stood in front of the panels for hours taking in the details... the grand hall, and the rest of the restored parts are mind blowing as well!

Beautiful palace but here's my tip. Everyone knows the Catherine Palace is beautiful. However, getting there on a non-organized tour can be challenging, and then once you get there it can be difficult to figure out how to buy tickets for the park and palace. Anyways, this is what my friends and I did: 1) from st. petersburg we hired a taxi for the trip that costed a fixed price of 5200 rubles with return (sounds expensive until you compare it to the price of a tour package to get there, and is cheaper when you split with more people. The taxi waited for us for 3-4 hours to head back to St. Petersburg), 2) you must buy a ticket to enter the park grounds at the park entrance before you can enter the palace. You cannot buy tickets for the palace here. 3) Join the long line of tourists in the middle of the palace and enter into the palace to buy tickets to enter the palace. Buy an audio guide in a booth opposite of the one you bought your palace tickets. 4) Enjoy the palace!

A Fitting Tribute to the Powerful Catherine the Great. The palace rooms are decorated in gold and marble and provide a feast for the eyes. The grand ballroom with its magnificent chandeliers, painted ceiling and wood floors is worth the visit alone. The most incredible part is the restoration of the palace after it was nearly destroyed by the German Army in World War Two. Calculated efforts to store the treasures and photos of the palace in Siberia before the attacks were a stroke of genius. Well worth the effort to visit as early to opening time as possible.

Magnificent!. The exterior of the Palace is lovely, but it is the interior that is just stunning. Opulence & gold gilding everywhere, beautiful grand throne hall & amazing amber room. The grounds are also beautiful & the people in 18 th century costumes just added to the appeal. Don't miss !
Excellent. What a wonderful place to visit. There is so much to see inside the palace that like The Hermitage it cannot all be seen and taken in at one visit. Very popular so be ready for the queue.
breathtaking. Get there early to avoid the queues. Amazing renovation following near destruction during World War II
Impressive. get there early to avoid the queues. Amazing how they have renovated it so well following near destruction during World War II

Catherine Palace. Wonderful place,the Amber room is amazing.The main ballroom is absolutely beautiful.You can imagine what it would be like to have a wedding there.The gardens are also lovely and we were lucky as it was a gorgeous day when we were there.Well worth a visit

Magnificent. This must be one of the most beautiful Palaces and gardens in the world. From the 100 or so kilogrammes of gold adorning the roof and spire to the magnificent interior, this palace is priceless and breath taking. The queues to enter can be very long, and a wait of an hour or more is normal. best to get someone to stand in line while you walk around the gardens or take a coffee in the near-by cafe.
A Really Ornate Palace. The decor here is amazingly ornate and expensive. A worthwhile site and an important figure in history.

Highlight of the trip. Our private tour company (Alla Tours) took us to this palace late in the afternoon, so we were nearly the only group there. It was so amazing to see this grand palace without crowds. They did a phenomenal job of restoring this palace to its original glory. It was breathtaking! A MUST SEE!

My favorite palace. First, just to get it out of the way: the park is lovely. Anywhere you stroll you will like but if possible, try to enter the Music Pavilion and hear the male trio honor us all with a couple of tunes in an acoustically perfect space. OK, the palace: Gaudy as it is (it's Russian after all) I could actually see it as livable. The decor is totally over the top, yet in good taste and comfortable. This is the most feminine palace I saw and seemed the "happiest" instead of trying to be the grandest. Although Empress Catherine I (not "the Great") originally built it, her daughter, Empress Elizabeth did a massive renovation and is responsible for most of the current structure, inside and out. (Most, not all - Catherine the Great and her son and grandson did some stuff too.) The Grand Ballroom will blow you away. The famous Amber Room is here and turned out to be totally different from what I had thought from just media coverage. The workmanship is so much more refined and detailed than I could have ever imagined. Be sure to look at the pictures of what the Nazis did to try to annihilate Catherine Palace and be amazed at what the Russians are restoring. We could learn a thing or two from them about historic preservation. The gift shop is one of the best in Russia - the stuff is very good and not cheap, but it's the real deal. The village of Puskin just outside the gates of the palace is lovely too. All in all, probably my favorite site in northern Russia.

Stunning!. The Palace and grounds were fantastic! The opulence is unbelievable and the Amber Room a true work of art!! The grounds are also stunning. Don't miss the acapella group of men that sing in the one of the small houses on the grounds where the acoustics are perfect and their music is other-worldly and beautiful!!!!

Grandiose and Opulent!. Lovely gorgeous main ballroom, and amber room made this special, a "must see" if you are visiting St Petersburg. Truly opulent and every room takes your breath away, would not have missed this for the world! The park is also lovely great mirror lake and lots to see as well as the views of the palace from the private 'back garden'.......Catherine the Great did not hold back in spending and the whole palace and surrounding grounds demonstrate this!

Impressive opulence..... As you queue to gain entry I have to say its already impressive but then when you enter its all baroque, gold and very very opulent....it takes your breath away as you wander around the palace as to how much money was spent on this originally. Despite having been bombed heavily (you get to see the pictures of this), there has been extensive restoration activity taking place which takes place now and every few years they open up a new room!The Amber room was really impressive and despite being remade given that parts were totally destroyed/stolen it was fantastic to see how all the amber was worked into the room around yet more extensive mirrors.The gardens are also amazing with the mirror lakes.Toilet queues for ladies can be long so its advisable to go as you enter the palace as it takes quite a while to walk around this and the gardens.We then had a lovely traditional Russian lunch with Russian singers and dancers, all in all truly unmissable!
wonderful. the palace of Pushkin is beautiful, huge, full of works of art and a room where everything is made of amber

Interesting history near the city. Definitely worth a visit for both beauty of palace and interesting history. However, not a lot of rooms are open for visitors because the palace is still under repair from WWII. The Amber Room is not to be missed - simp,y amazing. If possible, get a tour guide (the guides there do not give tour in English) - guides also get better access. The grounds are nice, but simple compared to Peterhof. There is a small cafe for a quick/light snack on the first floor. The gift shops are nice and prices relatively reasonable.Don't miss the photos and explanations once you walk down the stairs at the end of the tour.

Fabulous but avoid cafe. Great place to visit. Opulent to a point where its easy to see why the peasants revolted! Mustvsee the Amber Room, but avoid the cafe. Food was terrible and the pickings were slim.

A perfectly rebuilt version of the original. It is a grand palace built as a tribute to herself, Catherine the Great. When you can have your husband the Tsar murdered by your lover so you can become the Tsarina building the originalist have been easy. It is sad that the Germans felt the need to destroy it after the looted it. Pains takenly reproduced it measures up to the grandeur of the original. Even the amber room was redone and does take your breath away. The grounds are worth exploring as well.

Magnificent - full of superfluous decorations. A wonderful palace, were you will admire all the excess in the decoration, all cover with gold (not the real anymore), sculptures, paintings and superfluous architectural details. Creates a wow effect and it’s unbelievable all the details and extravagances in every single room. It’s a must to been seen since there is almost nothing that compares to it.

Impressive but.... VERY similar to Versailles. When first entering the palace you go into a "hall of mirrors" and while the palace is very beautiful, it is extremely disappointed that none of it is original. It was almost completely destroyed in the war so everything you see is a replica including the famed Amber Room. I will admit the amber room is incredible though. Go early because the lines are atrocious.

Very much like Versailles. Catherin's palace is vast and beautiful and has many unique qualities, but, it reminded us very much of Versailles in quite a few places but none so much as the "hall of mirrors" immediately after entering the palace. The palaces was almost completely destroyed during the war so everything you see has been restored or is a replica including the impressive Amber Room which is paneled entirely with carved amber. It truly is a sight. Strongly recommend arriving early as lines are atrocious and be prepared to put booties over your shoes as these must be worn within the palace.
Wow. Catherine the Great really loved the good life. A must see for everyone men included ! Very very Grand and ostentiasous
Interesting. This was a beautiful spot. The palace is still being restored. It was extremely busy the day we visited. I didn't think the Amber room was worth the long wait. The history is amazing.
Jaw dropping. WONDERFUL! Ah....speechless in the face of the gold, mirrors, gardens....AMAZING. I wish that we could have stayed in the palace for a longer visit.

Wow!. Nothing much else to say in my opinion. The Amber room was worth the visit by itself, but add the size and elaborate decorations, and the imagination soars as to the life they led. The work that it must have taken to build this is mind numbing!
An exquisite palace. the ball room and the amber room are something you would never see in the whole world. the palace is also surrounded with massive park and beautiful nature.

A must see. What an amazing palace. So much beauty. The amber room was amazing. I wish we could of spent more time here. It was raining on the day we toured this palace,but it did not distract from its beauty. A must see if you go to St Petersburg.

Christina & Clifford Boonzaier. This palace is absolutely spectacular. We could only stare and admire the beautiful interior, Peter The Great must have loved his wife very much to build her this lovely summer palace.

A must see. When you visit St. Petersburg, be sure to go out to Catherine's Palace in Pushkin (about 40 minutes from St. Petersburg). It is spectacular and huge! There are really two styles inside the palace. The original Roccoco, all gold and gilt and Catherine's preference when she redid it in Neo-Palladian which is much softer and less gaudy. The grounds are also lovely. Well worth a trip.

The Amber Room is like being inside a jewel box. It is worth the visit just to see the reconstructed Amber Room. It is drop dead gorgeous and truly a wonder of craftsmanship. The exterior of this palace is one of my favorites and just stunning in pictures. The ground behind the palace are also quite lovely. The number of palace rooms open to the public aren't as numerous as in other palaces, especially the Hermitage. But still worth the effort. Make the day of seeing this palace in Pushkin, along with Pavel's Palace and Alexander Palace. This palace's gift store has some beautiful, abeitly pricey, matrouska dolls.

Catherine palace. It was a great place to visit. Our guide was excellent and knew just the places to take us to, we organised her thru our hotel Four Seasons, like everything they did it was great. I use a walking stick and at times it was hard going with the crowds but our guide shepard us through

Indeed beautiful, varied and impressive. I wouldn't call it a real "must see", but then again, I don't call anything a must see, depends on taste, but the amber room is one of the most stunning i've ever seen

Masterpiece. This elegant and beautiful palace in the Russian countryside was well worth the trip,traffic & crowds. The baroque design is a masterpiece with the striking blue and gold exterior and of course the gilded statues, mirrors, walls, celiings and frames that line the interior. The history of this palace is beyond belief and the restoration of it is equally unbelievable, especially the Amber Room. The gardens are stylized French style and definitely worth a stroll.

A band greeted us!. That this palace has been so lovingly restored since World War II is a tribute to the human spirit. They are still working on many rooms. A band greeted us and our tour guide took us through the breathtaking palace of Catherine the Great. It’s all amazing. We also had a chance to walk the grounds and a male choir sung to us in the Grotto the acoustics there were unbelievable. A sight truly worth seeing.

Enormous!. The palace is gorgeous inside. The amber room is amazing, even though it's not the original amber. Many of the floors are parquet with intricate patterns of different wood types. Paper booties are required to be worn over your shoes. The artwork and décor are breathtaking.

So good! I recommend 'Russian tour'!. If you prepare for 'Catherine Palace' ,No problem! Russian tour are better than Englishi one. Woman give you a number of bus and take you to the Palace. And take you back to Nevski. The fee including entering fee. Watch out you make sure check about return way. You must confirm the time and place the bus leave.

amber room beauty. lot of glitter/gold reminds one of the glory/opulence of Czars and Romanov family.spend an hour with a guide to make the most of your visit helps understand the history or else it will deem like a pretty golden palace.
Spectatular in Every Way. We thought nothing could rival the grandeur of the Peterhof Palace but here is a destination to be equally enjoyed and loaded with history of the Russian royalty,

Another stunning building. A beautiful building, especially the great hall and amber room. We had a guide who provided us with lots of useful information, i think this made the trip! The gardens were lovely but we went on a very wet day so didn't see it at its best. Quite an expensive trip

Beautiful on every level.. I am very glad to have experienced Catherine Palace for myself as photographs do not do the beautiful architecture justice. The 'Amber rooms' is spectacular and it was interesting to learn more about both the palace, Russian history and 'Baltic Amber' in the process.When you arrive, you will be asked to go through security checks and place special covers over your shoes to preserve some of the flooring.

Magnificent. Totally out of imagination. Extremely extravagant. Never seen anything of this magnificence before. Someone described the Amber room as a wonder in the world. The garden is beautiful. Drawback is too many people. It is a fulfilling but not relaxing experience. You will be pushed around by other tourists. There are two separate lines going into the museum, choose the one with less tour groups.

Definitly worth the wait. Palace interior beautiful recreation of the Tsar palace interior. We loved the unique amber room. The gardens are English formal gardens very well maintained. Must visit after the Hermitage and Summer Palace.
Wonderful. Absolutely must do this if in St. Petersburg. I just could not believe how spectacular it is. Especially the amber room. The gardens are also beautiful.

Catherine Palace St Petersburg. It's difficult to imagine how they managed to renovate this palace, when you see all the photos of how it was after the war. As we arrived, the Catherine Palace band were playing traditional music - a lovely way to be greeted. We arrived very early, so we managed to be one of the first groups through, but even that meant crowds, and a slight wait to get into the palace.When you go, be prepared to be amazed at the opulence and artwork. But don't forget to look down, there is a very good reason that they ask you to wear protective booties, the floors are beautiful as well.

Be sure to visit the Hermitage Palace. We were very impressed with Catherine's Palace and had a wonderful experience walking around the gardens, but found the Hermitage Palace to be a wonderful surprise. Not to be confused with the museum at the Winter Palace, this is a smaller structure at Tsarskoe Selo that has an amazing system of dropping tables and individual plates from the 2nd floor to the 1st floor. A must see!

Restored gem. This palace is by far the most beautiful I've ever seen. You do need to cover your shoes so they don't mark the floors. It was so interesting to see what this palace looked like after the Nazi occupation set it on fire to what it looks like today, mostly restored.

We need another word for wow!. As with the other restored summer palace at Peterhof, this is a magnificent building with beautiful furniture, paintings etc. But nothing can really prepare you for the Amber Room. It's totally amazing. It does get very crowded and we didn't get the chance to visit the gardens but it's a great destination for a day out.

gorgeous ornamentation. Stand in long queue to enter Park (free is only for Russian students), then stand in long queue to enter the Building of Palace, then a long queue to buy tickets to enter Palace, then queue to the interiors. Exhausting! But very beautiful Palace, Amber Room is amazing. There are a lot of wooden furniture, vases, clocks, paintings, porcelain tiles ovens.

The blue palace. The Palace is stunning, The exterior grounds are lavish and manicured with greenery and sculptures, The palace was well done and it is incredible to see how much has been rebuilt since it was badly damaged by bombing during WWII. It was interesting to see the photos taken after the bombing and to see how much has been reconstructed. Prepare to wait for a long time in line and they rush you a bit. So try to take your time. Do not forget to visit the other palace , it is more peaceful and you can enjoy some relax time after visiting Catherine Palace. Plan a whole day,since it's a bit far, but easy to find.

Must walk through the Palace. It is hard to imagine how it looked originally when you see the photos of the destruction from the war. The renovations are extensive and beautifully done! It was good to be a Czar or Czarina!

Like Disney World for adults!. The incredible Catherine's Palace is a must see for any visitor to St. Petersburg. So much to see! The furniture, sculptures, flooring, tableware, art work, etc. The outside of the building is so phenomenal in person.
another amazing feat of gold leaf and over-the-top decor!. a treat for the eyes - this is a beautiful palace! Would prioritize peterhof if only can do one - but definitely try to get to both.

Must visit. Great place and very nice park, can also visit with children over 4 y.o., they will not get too tired, park is huge and great for all ages, kids can run around, ride bikes, feed squirrel... My favorite room in palace was amber room that was restored recently, beautiful room specially on sunny day as amber is lighten by sun through windows...

Worth a visit. It's cheaper and easier to visit here than Peterhof. Both palaces are luxurious and stunning to see. Unfortunately during high season not all rooms are open to visit at Catherine Palace so you may feel like you've missed out if you didn't get the full visit. The cost of the visit is in addition the the entrance fee to the park, which is significantly less than Peterhof's Park.

Astonishing!. Before even arriving in St. Petersburg, it was decided we would pay a visit to the Catherine Palace; it's not something you wanna miss out on!! We took the metro and then a bus; it was all fairly easy but you will want to have someone to write down the name of the palace in Russian for you, it might come in handy. We took bus 342 which was a minivan and we paid the driver directly (35 rubles each). The ride took about 20 minutes and its very easy to spot where you need to get off as there are loads of busses and people standing on the side :) We went on a Wednesday (be aware that it's closed on Tuesdays!) and we arrived at 11:30. They only open at 12:00 for individual visitors and we did not need to wait very long as we were inside at 12:40. You need to pay entrance for the park (otherwise you cannot enter at all) which costs 100 rubles and the entrance to the palace is 350. (Use a student card if you have one, with us it worked! Park is then only 50 and palace 180). Bags larger than 25x25 cm need to be checked in!We didn't book a tour since we usually do things on our own, however, in the end I think this visit is more worth it when you book a group tour! You just get to see MUCH more of the palace inside!! I was a little disappointed with the "quantity", but certainly NOT the quality!! The palace and its surroundings are just breathtaking, simply fantastic!!

Spectacular. This palace is huge and is overwhelming with colour and light. The size is hard to describe- gigantic, enormous making some British Royal Palaces look like garden sheds.The throne room is a wash with glass and gold leaf covering. Definitely worth a visit.
Over the Top. Unbelievable the size of the rooms, the amount of glitzy gold and amazing art. We spent a couple of hours with our guide. Many tourists.
Still under overhaul. Worth the time and very beautiful, especially the gardens and pools. The welcoming band was impressive. Lots if walking.

Catherine Palace and Park. The art, architecture, and the extravagance of this palace and park go way beyond the imagination. The Hall of Mirror's in the Versailles, while awesome in itself, pales by comparison to the gilded gold ballroom in Catherine's Palace. The added touch of characters dressed in costume in the ballroom captures the very essence of the grandeur of the times. Awesome!

Catherine Palace. This palace rivals the Versailles. An amazing glance into the opulence and extravagance of its time. Together walking the Peterhof Gardens and having an extensive visit at Catherine's Palace gave you the essence of what it must have been like there during its day.
Worth the drive. Be sure to take the time to see this sight; there really are no words to sufficiently describe it! Learn some of the history behind the tsars in order to fully appreciate it.
Magical place. We loved our visit to the Palace and the park, souvenirs were cheaper than in the city, I recommend an organized trip, thats how you can miss the enormous queues.

Beautiful, beautiful interiors - don't miss this!. Built to compete with Marie Antoinette, Catherine The Great's palaces (this one and Peterhof) were designed emulate the opulence of Versailles. The designers achieved what they set out to achieve - absolutely breathtaking! The Amber Room was smaller than I'd expected but nonetheless impressive! Staircases and ceilings were baroque overload - simply beautiful!Top tip for wheelchair users:Just about every palace and museum in St Petersburg has the most beautifully restored parquet/inlaid floors and paper slippers/shoe covers are required to be worn by all visitors. Having hired a brand new wheelchair on board The Arcadia, we were (very fortunately) allowed to go around the Palaces because it had new, clean, light coloured wheels. People who had older, black rubber wheels on their chairs were being refused entry. You do not argue with Russian matriarchs working in Museums and Palaces!!! If you plan to visit with a wheelchair, I would highly recommend making some white towelling or cotton wheel covers that can be slipped on to protect the floor from being marked by your wheels.The male staff were very helpful and allowed us to use the goods lift between floors in Peterhof, Catherine Palace and The Hermitage but there is generally little awareness/consideration for the needs of wheelchair users in smaller places and churches. Hope this helps!
A palace of ostentatious wealth.. Stunning, so much richness in the state rooms, furnishings, breathtaking chandeliers, unimaginable wealth.

Catherine the Great. This is one of the world's largest castles and is blue colored. It was interesting to see the different styles of architecture inside since it was completed over a number of years. The gold leaf really sets the building off. It was a highlight of our day.

Wonderful. A lovely palace restored to its former glory after being practically destoyed. The Amber Room is well worth a visit. While waiting for the gates to open we were entertained by a band of musicians, they then entered the courtyard with us when the gates were opened and continued to entertain until we enter the palace. They danced along to their redition of Swan Lake and delighted my husband by playing "Blue Moon" (signature tune for his football club!!). Once inside we wandered from room to room each one spectacular in their own way. I was astonished at the central heating system - huge floor to ceiling furnaces covered with blue and white delft tiles. In the beautiful gardens we wandered round and then our group were ushered into a domed building where a group of men sang "cappella" Russian folk songs.If visiting SPB you must visit at least one palace and Catherine Palace is a good one to choose.

Palaces Galore in Saint Petersburg!. My husband and I had a private guide (which included car service) take us from Saint Petersburg to see Catherine's Palace. We were the only people there who were not part of a much larger group (everyone else was part of one of those tours where they bus you around, 30-ish people), and I highly recommend getting a private guide to see Catherine's Palace. Like Peterhof, there aren't audioguides for you to tour on your own and it's not like each room has a description of the objects being shown. If you're not going with a guide, I don't know what you'd get out of your visit other than having looked at pretty things. Having gone with a guide, it was interesting to learn about the role it had in Russia's history, the painstaking historical renovations done after WW2, and learning more about Catherine the Great. And because we were a group of 3, not a bus of way too many, we were able to go at our own pace and spend a little more time here or go somewhat quicker in other areas. The Amber Room is the main attraction here, and I have to say to me it was rather ugly. I appreciate the detail of the room and how unique it is, but there's a reason Amber rooms aren't more popular (besides the price). Glad to have seen it, but not the best part of the palace in my opinion.The grounds are lovely, but not as interesting to walk around as those in Peterhof. If you're short on time and can only pick Catheirne's Palace or Peterhof, I would recommend Peterhof, but both are definitely worth the price of admission!As a side note, we used St. Petersburg Best Guides for our tour. We had Larisa as our guide and she was great!

Life of Royalty. The Catherine Palace in St. Petersburg, Russia is a must see attraction when you visit this area. It's hard to comprehend how this was built and then reconstructed after its destruction during World War II.
They are not short of a Palace here. Lovely exterior, and even lovelier interior. As you walk through a Palace DRIPPING in gold, bear in mind that this has all been restored since WW2. Unbelievable.
So much gold!. This is really worth a visit as you can look round the rooms which are very ornate. The palace is very large and ver beautiful.

Very oppulent. The inside of the palace is so amazing with almost every surface covered in gilt carvings and paintings. It takes a fair while to travel out to the palace but it is fairly simple getting the metro and the minibus, although you do need to ask about where to get off otherwise you end up a few km away and then travel back on another bus. You also need to guy a ticket to the gardens before you can even line up to buy a ticket for the inside of the palace. Even after waiting an hour to get inside and then line up again to buy a ticket for the palace rooms it was still worth it! The rooms are great and you can wander through at your own pace if you just ignore the tour groupings. Just astounding gold covering everything, and in the loerr floor shows just how much restoration work has been undertaken in this palace as it was almost completely destroyed during the second world war. The gardens themselves are wonderful as well. We started counting the number of brides we saw getting wedding pics taken.

Ever likely they had a revolution. This is one enormous palace with the biggest emfilade in the world, for us of little knowledge that's like looking through multiple doorways along several cricket pitch worth of corridor. Sorry if you are American but its a proper game?The interiors are typically overblown Russian with gilt in abundance, you never saw such opulence it has to be seen to be believed, although just pop down the road and at the Peterhof it's just the same. Restoration post WW2 is a marvel and a tribute to Russian craftsmanship of incredible dedication, if you see the pictures of the destruction (why do that?) and have our benefit down the years of seeing the reconstruction you realise that Russia has a real passion for it's history.The equal majesty lies in the park, the layout is English natural landscape with a little bit of tricky French thrown in, suppose they had to, but the lakes and buildings and structures give you the opportunity to spend a lot of time walking, looking and admiring.We had a double ferry ride to the Admiralty where we were treated to a lovely lunch in a building of Dutch style, good food, good day, good walks and oh yes a marvellous gallery with a line of philosopher busts and gorgeous gardens.The bath houses are also worth a visit, you see just to what extent the little darlings went to pamper themselves.

worth a trip. We took a 5-hour side trip witj Eclectica Tours to Pushkin where the Catherine Palace is. Maybe it is easiest to join the tour than to travel on your own and look around on your own.It is smaller and with less collection compared to the Hermitage but certainly worth visiting.

Gilding. Catherine certainly liked her gilding, very opulent in every room, from here on you recognise her style and influence when you go into the other palaces, gold and flowers everywhere. Stunning.

The finest example of Tsarist excess. This palace is second to none in the elaborate richness and gilded detail one would expect of royalty. After leaving this palace one can't help saying to oneself "it is good to be Tsar".

Another great example of the Czars. Another great example of how the Czars lived...how it was destroyed during the Nazi occupation and has been restored bit by bit over the last 65 years. Thanks goodness for photographs that have been used in the restoration process! The Amber Room is really neat although honestly expected it to be 'more' but still incredible.

Spectacular!. Gold, gold, gold and more gold! The public rooms of this palace are truly spectacular. And when you think it couldn't get any better, there is the famed Amber Room. This palace was almost totally destroyed during WW II, but has been carefully restored to it's former eye popping glory. A true Russian treasure!

Wonderful site. This huge palace in the Rastrelli style is really a must to visit.Even if you can’t access the palace, the gardens and the buildings it encompasses are good for a day trip. If you have some initiative and you don’t want to visit the palace, the cheapest way to get there is taking the metro to Moskovskaya and board the small bus K-45 just behind the huge Lenin statue. It brings you straight to the park/palace.Total cost, including acces to the park, approximately 5 Euro.

Catherine's Palace is Amazing. We visited Catherine's Palace in July 2013. The Amber Room is the most talked about room in the palace. It is beautiful, however the amber that is currently in the room is not the original amber that was placed in the room in the 18th Century. The room was looted during World War II. A restoration of the room began in 2003. Catherine's Palace has many interesting oil paintings and beautiful rooms. The Amber Room is the highlight of the tour. There is a very nice gift shop at the exit of the palace.

Truly spectacular. I visited the Palace at the end of a two-day tour, and it was the perfect way to end the trip. The first several rooms on the tour set the stage - gold everywhere, and gorgeous. The amber room was also impressive, albeit a bit crowded given all the competing tour groups. The pictures of the palace following WWII, compared with post-restoration, are fascinating. Definitely worth the visit!
Marvelous Tour. We had a private guide for three of us. It was marvelous. The palace is a bonus to our trip. After reading Catherine The Great, it was a must see and we were not disappointed!

Lots of history. It was very good to know this castle. Beautiful garden, the amazing âmbar rôom, the story of Elizabeth that reconstruct her castle's mother, the pictures of the castle on fire, its reconstruction. Worths the visit

Great palace!. Another "must see" attraction in St-Petersbourg. Tsarskoye Celo is located about 20km away from the downtown. You can get there by metro and city bus (it took us 45 minutes). The gardens are amazing but not as big as Peterhof. The palace is worth a visit, especially for its Amber room.

A must see. Even though this Palace was mostly destroyed during WW2, the reconstruction is incredible to see. Take your time to appreciate each room available to the public. If possible, secure the services of a local guide in St. Petersburg. The guides can get you in quickly and take you to places the general public doesn't see.

Busy and Packed. While it's a must see, it's packed and crowded. Very hard to take good pictures. Felt like I was part of a large assembly line, than a tourist. No pictures allowed in amber room which is ridiculous.

The blue and gold are staggering. The amber room is not to my taste but very clever. I loved the ballroom and the floor is incredible. We went with a private guide and as we got out of the Taxi the band struck up with the National Anthem and Jerusalem. Corny but wonderful and I hadt o stand by and sing along as they played-very corny.The grounds are also very well kept and beautiful
Too big for words.. This palace is too big for words. SOooo much gold! The amber room is fabulous as well. Definitely worth the time!

What Peter could do I can do better. No wonder eventually the subjects rebelled against the heavy burden of providing funding for these extraordinary palaces with the large amount of gold everywhere. Add to this the Amber room - you get the picture. Amazing are the floors, all inlaid wood and still in excellent condition after all these years. A must see on your visit to St. Petersburg. It helps being with SPB Travel in a small group early in the morning as there is no A/C in there!

Jaw dropping ! Stunning and beautiful. Leave out" oh my god " from your vocabulary and you will have very little else to explain the stunning beauty, elegance,gold,gold,gold and guilt. What an excessive life.again the history is amazing. Take pen and paper so you can keep track of who married who and who killed who !!!!

The gold dome dominates St Petersburg skyline. Parts under repair but still a dazzling sight on the St Petersburg skyline. Walk the stairs and around the top for a birds eye view of the passing parade below.

Spectacular Sight. We attended the Palace early on a Tuesday almost before the crowds. The exterior and grounds are stunning but the interior is reminiscent of that opulent bygone era. Hard to believe that the place was destroyed by fire but the Russians have restored the entire building and interior with an eye to detail.Because of the crowds, the ushers ensure that the groups keep moving along, difficult when there is so much to see and absorb.A very informative and eye catching morning.

Not Peterhof, but still impressive. The house interior is fabulous. All gold and opulence.The grounds are a lovely stroll on a sunny day. Some of the little pavilions are difficult to get into, but the concert hall is free and contains some beautiful mosaics.To get the best of the sights, arrive early so you can also visit the Alexander Park / Palace next door.The biggest problem is getting there. Our up to date guidebook was simply wrong, and we wasted a lot of time, and indeed only got there thanks to a car park attendant with no phone but good at gesticulating and showing us on his iPad. AS OF AUGUST 2013 this is how to get there.Go to Moskovskaya station. Follow the signs to the airport bus. Catch one of the minibuses, no. K545. There may be others, but that one definitely goes there! If your driver is unhelpful, the when you have gone through Pushkin, a small town which seems to be no more than a large number of low apartment blocks, the bus will turn left. On your right is a green park. Yell to be let off, and walk back to the entrance to the park on your left now.Coming back we simply flagged down a 545.
Must see in St. Petersburg. Individual tickets are often sold out in advance. Plan early so can get in. We took a group tour that started from Nevsky. It was 5 hours long.

Over the top gold decor.. This is an interesting place to visit and wonder how any one could have lived there. Gold , gold and more gold everywhere. Interesting wood floors and fireplaces. But the gold is over the top. Excellently restored. If you are in the area it is a must see attraction.

Catherine's Palace. It was just gorgeous. If you like gold, this is the place too see. Walls, ceilings, belongings etc etc. If I recall this is where there was a private theatre. It was great to see. I wish I had one too.

Another Amazing Sight. Brilliant palace with the ultimate in luxurious wall decoration - gold amid other rich colors as well as entirely different (no gold) sections. Some call this mainly Baroque or Roccoco. Catherine The Great certainly built herself a resplendent palace.

Viatour: misleading and deceptive conduct. We were to have gone to the Catherine Palace. At 9:30pm the night before a note was delivered telling us to be ready by 9:45am. We were ready and waiting 5 minutes before then and then we waited for half an hour. We had booked this tour through Qantas on the basis that it was represented as having car or minivan transport. When the car arrived at 10:05 we were informed by the (pleasant) guide that the trip would be by bus. We had assumed this to be a minibus. The car took us to Nevskiy Prospekt and there the guide said she would get tickets and that there would be a bus at 11am. So we walked around for 25 minutes waiting for a bus. When it arrived at 11:10, instead of being a minivan type bus, it was a large tour bus complete with a loud Russian guide. We enquired how long the travel to the palace would take and our guide said it would take an hour (via Pushkin) this was the last straw: Viatour had represented that the travel time was 25 minutes by car or by mini-van and that it would be a small group. This would mean that we would arrive at around 12:30 and would only have a short time to look around before having to return. A bus-load of Russian tourists smelling strongly of cigarettes was not what was represented, so we terminated our tour forthwith. I would suggest that persons taking an English-language tour may wish to get their hotel to arrange the tour: for $400 AUD for three people this tour was expensive and should have been as represented.

Amazing palace!!!. Visited the palace as part of our cruise excursion tour. Spent about 2 hours there and was blown away by the beauty of the palace and how the Tzars spent their money!Awesome place to visit and learn some Russian history!!

Magnificent. The drive to the Palace was interesting and we parked nearbye. We have already been before but it loses nothing on a second visit. The rooms are superb even though mostly restored and it is well worth a visit.

Do Not Miss the Catherine Palace. This is an incredibly beautiful palace that was restored after the war. During the war, the Nazis used the Catherine Palace as a headquarters. When they left, being chased by the Russians, they threw bombs in the palace rooms for the sole purpose of destruction. The various rooms have photos of the way they looked before they were restored. The Catherine Palace exterior is a stunning shade of blue, with gold and white trim, and is phenomenal. The interior rooms are magnificent, having been restored as perfectly as possible.

Beautiful Room. The rooms were phenominal!! The Russians used alot of gold leaf on their decorations. The amber room was simply beautiful. The only thing about it I did not like was that no photogray was permited. I did it anyhow with my iPad and got hollered at.
Catherines Palace. The grounds and fountains around the palace are almost as impressive as the inside of the palace. A wonderful place to tour.

Catherine was Great. Amazing place to visit, but, all the more so when you learn how much of it has been restored. The opulence and wealth of the Russian Royals is truly amazing and fortunately the country realises what an amazing commodity it has here in promoting tourism. You are given overshoes to wear to protect the floors and photography is allowed everywhere except in the Amber Room. Really words to describe it can not do it justice, just go and soak it up !

Insane in all ways. Catherine's Palace is just something to see. It is crazy the amount of money and time that went into this lavish home. So much details, you could spend all day here. The story of how the Nazi's destroyed it and the pictures of the burned out palace are interesting from a historical point of view. So glad that the Amber room was open so that we could see it. Loved everything about it (except the crowds) but we had a private tour for just us two so that helped. Such a wonderful place. The grounds are immense as well and quite gorgeous, well maintained.

summer palace - light, airy and vast. Many reviewers and friends had advised us to skip this one as it is generally combined with Peterhof Palace as it would make a long day trip. After ignoring their advices and seeing the place, we felt that it was worth doing that. Unlike Winter palace, this one is airy, lights everywhere, equally opulent interiors and rather well-maintained. I believe a lot of this is a marvelous restoration since this palace was on the german side of the line during siege of stalingard (st. Petersburg) and was quite badly damaged. go is our advice if the day is sunny and not overcast.

A Gem in Russian History. Yes, Catherine's Palace is like a beautiful "Gem" & an interesting part in Russian history. While many parts have been restored & rebuilt through the years, it indeed is magnificent. I suggest using a private guide who knows the tricks to avoid the long lined of tourists. However long the lines are, the wait is worth it in order to view this amazing place !

Dont miss it if you have time. The Catherine palace is pretty so depending on your time, our trip took about 2.5hrs around the palace and park and 1 hr to go back and forth by car. Beautiful historical place about the queen's life and her family

A gem of a palace. Probably the prettiest palace in SPB. Room after beautiful room. It is overpowering.I was disappointed that it was so warm and there were no windows open for ventilation. Also when we were there 12 years earlier we were allowed to take photos in the Amber Room. Not anymore.

Wow. When you think extravagant, you think of Catherine Palace. I've never seen so much gold and stones confined in one incredible palace in my life. Very crowded and busy. They don't allow you to take pictures in the Amber room, which is unfortunate because its pretty neat, however you can always shoot a picture through the doorway from the next room! Another must see while in St. Petersburg.

A truly magnificent experience in Tsarskoye Selo. A visit to the Catherine Palace is a truly memorable experience and it just keeps getting better all the time as more and more rooms are restored to their original finery as masterpieces of the great architects who were commission to design them. I especially like the most recent of them - a tribute to Charles Cameron who also designed and built the Cameron Gallery in the palace grounds. The Amber Room has been hailed as one of the wonders of the world and is a must for any visitor to Pushkin. After years of painstaking restoration by Turkish and Russian craftsmen, the Amber Room was finally reopened to the pubic in 2003, on the 300th anniversary of Tsarkoye Selo by President Vladimir Putin, accompanied by then German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and the 40 heads of State who were invited to St. Petersburg to celebrate its 300th birthday - in St. Petersburg, Tsarkoye Selo (Pushkin), Pavlovsk and Peterdvorets or Peterhof. Don't miss the grounds, the park and all that it also has to offer!

The lavishness is spectacular. I'm running out of superlatives for the sights in St. Petersburg. Go see this palace for the beautiful interiors and the amazing amber room recreation (the original was stolen by the Nazis). This was another place we went with Anya, our Alla Tours guide.
long and time consuming queue. 2 hours waiting to get in and make 40 minutes interior tour.Opening hours for individual visitors up from noon...

Too many people. Certainly a spectacular palace but the visit was spoiled by the hordes of people that were here when we visited. Obviously we were a member of the horde (and our tour group) and were forced to move with the masses through the palace which certainly put a damper on appreciating the property.

Use a tour guide. Even with a tour excursion through our cruise line, we still waited 45 minuts to enter. Luckily it was early in the day and the line up was shaded. For me, it was definitely worth the wait. I think Russia, will be one of those "once in a lifetime visits" so 45 minutes to see this famed Summer Palace was worth the wait for me. The efforts to ressurect this palace have been painstakingly detailed since it was destroyed by Nazi Soldiers in WWII. The Amber room is breathtaking as are many of the other rooms. True, the Russians don't roll out the red carpet for tourists...don't take them too seriously and let them ruin your trip--life is a difficult grind for these people--this palace is worth the wait.
Amazing!. We walked trough this magnificent Palace in aura of our surroundings and how magnificent the place is. The crowds again can be too much to bear.

Picture perfect palace. Expect entrance queues – much better than the Hermitage though and once you are in the movement between rooms is controlled to avoid overcrowding. There are two interior routes – a main for groups plus another quieter one which covers almost all the same rooms but with fewer people! You can take photos inside with the exception of the Amber Room which is AMAZING. Even though restoration work continues, the rooms that are available open to the public seriously rival Versailles and Schronbrunn. Fantastic use of gold leaf and range of wall textures, colours and other artistry. Some really interesting photos so you can compare the before and after restoration work. Bags larger than 20 x 30 inches reed to be checked in.

Worth a Trip to Pushkin. This palace was totally looted and destroyed by the Nazis in WWII. However, the palace was totally reconstructed from pre-war photos and is remarkably rebuilt to all its splendor. The day we went there were tour groups before and after us, but the pace was still good for us to hear out excellent tour guide and take many, many pictures.
Russian History here!. Catherine's Palace and Park is a must see when in St. Petersburg. Take the palace tour and spend time in the gardens! Fabulous!
