You have got to see this palace. We were the second group in early in the morning and thankfully had chance to linger in the great hall and slowly stroll through the rooms. As we left to do the grounds the hoards arrived. This place is a must see and the renovation is outstanding. Don't miss the photos of the damage post WW2. The gardens and the lake are also brilliant.
Overwhelming. This place is a "must see". Why else come to Russia if you don't see this? Too much to see and comment on so just go see it all.

A fine example of restoration. The most fascinating thing about this is the fact that the entire palace has been re-created, including the amber room... If you are looking for recent history, you will find a tale of how opulence was destroyed. It most certainly is beautiful, and the artefacts within the Catherine Palace are originals - take note of the fine craftsmanship of the mosaic tables and the peacock clock. A goods history lesson.

Don't go on a rainy day.... On this day in July it rained all day with heavy showers. This made it difficult to stroll in the vast romantic park. We paid 250 R per person to be taken around in the park in an electric golf car. Good option if problems with walking a lot. We didn't see the palace from the inside as the queue was too long and it was raining. We went there by public transport, it was very cheap. Duration: 1h 30 min from metro station Nevsky Prospekt. If you're only going to see the park and not the palace, opt for Petershof instead because of its fountains and location by the sea.

Worth seeing, hire a guide. Fascinating place. Completely luxurious. It is a good way to see how tzars lived in Russia. We went there with a guide and it was well worth it because we could skip the queue and hear the stories in a more personalized way. There were people outside waiting for hours to come in, you avoid this if you hire a guide. Come here but with a guide

Recreated spendour. A visit here gives you an opportunity to leave the city, seeing many landmark buildings on the way.Crowded once inside but staff control the flow of groups well so you can see the rooms - all magnificent (but all new copies as destroyed by the Nazis during the siege of St Petersburg).Extensive grounds but not enough time allowed to see much of these. We were entertained by musicians on arriving, in the courtyard and in a pavilion in the gardens which was a bonus.

You will wish you were Catherine's child!. If you were Catherine's child, you would be able to have a full court soccer match with your friends in one of its large halls. Joke aside, the sheer magnitude and size of this palace is mind boggling, the interior decorations are impressive and the amber room is just spell-binding.

An impressive palace to say the least. After seeing Peterhof Palace we came here a was impressed again. The grounds are beautiful but does not compare to Peterhof Palace. Still the interior of Catherine Palace was unbelievable. Walking from room to room was so stimulating to the eyes. With all the colors, the gold trim, the high ceilings with all the decorations and paintings on them and some of the historic pieces it is a lot to take in. It was so beautiful and realistic you can imagine yourself living back in the day.I highly recommend this to see if in SPb.

A beautiful palace...you can not miss the amber room. One of many spectacular palaces in St Petersburg. The best attraction is the amber room, which is a masterpiece that you can only see in this palace... you have to see it to believe it.

Amazing. This is one lady who knew how to live. The building and furnishings are almost beyond belief. And it's so big the crowds aren't really an issue especially if you have a good guide like TJ Travel who know when the best times are to visit.

Catherine Palace in Pushkin - amazing !!!. We had an organised tour of Catherine's Palace and were not disappointed. This palace is a one hour drive from St.Petersburg. On arrival, it was amazing to see the buildings restoration after the war. It is a wonderful building, the blue colouring is to match the sky colour. Inside, ensure you visit a washroom before your tour. The only room not permitted for pictures is the Amber Room. It is truly amazing. It was definitely worth the visit, to make you get a glimpse of the summer palace that Catherine The Great resided in during the summer. When visiting if not on an organised tour, make sure to go early as it can get congested when local's visit.

Great restoration after suffering severe damage during WW2. Cannot miss this one when visiting St. Pb. Awe inspiring. Have to see it to believe it. A royal palace. Beautiful choral group performed for us tourists while there. Don't even think about missing this one!
Just another beauty. Words cannot really describe the sites that you see, the riches that are there is hard to comprehend, truly amazing.

makes Versaille look like the poor cousin's house. Every room outdoes the last, it is truly opulent. In some ways it makes Versaille look like the poor cousin's house. Luckily we had a very skilled tour guide so we were able to line jump. The line seemed quite long. the history of the palace is interesting, including it being used as a Nazi headquarters,and then, of course, they destroyed it before leaving. there are some photos of how it looked The amber room is crazy, it is rebuilt and no one knows where the original is. No pictures allowed in there. booties provided to protect the floor. It is about 45 minutes from St Petersburg, I would recommend going with a guide, we really liked SPB tours.

Incredible. This is not all original but the craftsmanship in the restoration will leave you dumbstruck. Leave plenty of time to visit and if you can get a local guide to take you (Tourslocal I can highly recommend) to get the best out of this and Peterhof.

Lovely Palace A Must See. Last time we were here we toured Peterhof. This palace is equally impressive even though the grounds are different. Be prepared to spend up to two hours to take in the rooms and the gardens. We especially enjoyed the amber room - it is impressive so plan to spend a few extra minutes here. There are toilets in the entrance and at the exit. There are a number of gift shops as you exit. They sell food and refreshments at various kiosks throughout the garden so you don't need to carry water. They take Euros and Rubles.

Enjoyed every minute.. Love the Palace ! Its very pretty and rich. Garden is so big and nice that you can spend a day of walking just there. Its has a lake where you can sit and enjoy a view of palace. Very relaxing atmosphere.

Not to be missed!. This is a must see for your trip to St. Petersburg. "Opulence for opulence sake" is the only way I can think to describe it. I fell in love with the delft stoves, the Ballroom and the Amber room, which is just amazing. Warning: Do not attempt to photograph the Amber Room. The museum proctors are very serious about this. Seeing so much gold-leaf, along with the cherubs and mirrors in the Ballroom will put you in sensory overload, so be prepared. Parts of the palace are not as ornate and the story behind this is quite interesting.

Palace in Puskin. In nearby Pushkin, which is now a popular place for the wealthy to buy dachas. This is an amazing palace with tremendous gardens and lake on the grounds. Our tour guide indicated that individuals come at 6am to line up to get in and for those coming in tour groups there is a separate entrance. There is art from many of the great European masters throughout history, not just Russian artists. One needs to devote a number of hours as the palace is just tremendous.
Far to travel but worth it. Sad that this spalace was bombed and destroyed but restored. The grand dame really lived an opulent life and it is clearly evident.

Worth a visit.. We travelled out early morning to try to beat the crowds, but I think a lot of tours do this. So it was crowded but we got through. Some rooms are slower than others. The park is wonderful and they have people playing music which really adds to the whole experience. You are required to put on cloth shoes over your own shoes, which are provided free. This protect the lovely floors. The amber room is so unusual. All in all a great experience.

Gold and white splendour!. My wife and I took the tour via our cruise ship operator and enjoyed the drive out to Pushkin where the palace is situated south of St.Petersburg.We strolled around the gardens in the early morning prior to entering the palace and thereafter were enthralled by the gold and white splendour of the palace.Considering that the whole building was left in ruins by the Nazis in 1945 the restoration undertaken by the Soviets is truly impressive.The grand ballroom is completely magical..even better than the amber room which,whilst impressive,just doesn't look real???Well worth a visit.

Stunning. We loved our visit to the palace and park. The park is beautiful and well worth a walk around. While we visited the different buildings, four tenors sang in the 'tea room', and several weddings took place in the grounds.The palace is truly opulent, from the ceilings to floors.

Tsarskoye Selo.... the great Russian ripoff. Waited an eternity in a long queue in the boiling sun with no shade.Paid for some overpriced tickets, only to find you can only see a tiny portion of the building. You can photograph most rooms... except the room you want to photograph, i.e. the amber room.I would suggest forget the building itself, just walk around the park instead !

If I could go to only one attraction in St. P.. This would be the one. Like Versailles, it is guilded to the nth degree, bit it works. The Ruskis are renovating the exterior nd it's getting prettier all the time. You will need transportation here from St. P as it is about an hour's ride. Make sure you have a good guide. The amber room is an amazing story in itself.

To think this was destroyed.. The work that has gone into rebuilding this Palace is incredible and a credit to Russia. You just cannot describe the history and artefacts that are stored here. Great to see the clothing etc of the people who actually lived there.

Skip the Palace and tour the grounds. We waited, and waited and waited in 30 degree c heat in a line up. Finally 2 members of our group had had enough. It took some convincing of our private tour guide to leave and just do the grounds. Finally he admitted that once you had seen the Hermitage, everything else was over gilded! As well much of St Catherine's Palace is reproductions. We went to the building by the lake and listened to a men's choir, it was beautiful . They had Cd's for sale at half the price of the St Petersburg men's choir we saw the day before. The walk around the lake was magical. We all really enjoyed it. Lots of birds and the grounds are well maintained. There is another building on the grounds (blue and yellow) that is quite remarkable that is open on occasion to the public, that shows a form of dumb waiter that served large banquets.

Breathtaking.. This palace was a huge ruin after the Nazi occupation and was rebuilt to its former splendor. The treasures had been packed away before the occupation, for the most part. Interesting that the communist authorities would back this resurrection of opulence. My favorite site on the entire tour.
talk about gilt and gold. This was an amazing place to visit. Raw luxury in a palatial location on display. Gold, silver, amber, malachite, just stunning

St Petersburg's Catherine Palace. If you have been to Versailles in France, prepare yourself to be even more amazed when you visit Catherine's Palace and Park in St Petersburg. The gold sparkles everywhere you turn. The Amber Room is an unforgettable experience. The Grand Hall has so much gold, you need sunglasses to lessen the glare.

A Royal Experience. Astonishing. This palace is a must for all history enthusiasts and those with an appreciation of gorgeous design. The hall of mirrors makes you want to linger to appreciate how the light reflects in the mirrored walls. I only we could have lingered and toured more of the gardens. We were with a tour guide and had a limited amount of time, but the rooms in Catherine's palace are truly breathtaking. You are not permitted to photograph inside the reconstructed Amber Room, but some of the guides will allow you to turn around as you exit to take a photograph. Be prepared to don paper booties to protect the floors during your tour. Sometimes I felt a bit rushed as we moved from room to room, and there are two walkways where you must walk through and not pause at all because they are very narrow. Otherwise, just be prepared to be astonished.

Unbelievable Palace!. The palace and grounds are beautiful. It is about an hour drive from St Petersburg but it is worth the drive. We were lucky to see it in the evening after closing time for a tour and concert in the ballroom. It was spectacular!

Hall of mirrors a must. Of course the entire palace is beautiful. All the rooms have exquisite art and decorations. But the best is the Hall of Mirrors where all the balls were held. You can picture them all waltzing around the room - very romantic.
lovely day trip. we took a guide for the day and visited.beautiful palace with delightful interiors--art,furniture,paintings.interesting to hear about what happened dur ing and after wwII

Monsoon rains and gold covered everything. After seeing the Peterhof Gardens, we went to Catherine Palace. There were mobs of people and pouring rain. But once we got inside, we were able to go through the first few rooms with just our tour guide and the two of us. It is overwhelming. Class consciousness goes out the window as you look at the grandeur that is around you. The first few rooms are redolent in gold. As I told someone when we got back, "Everything in St. Petersburg is on steroids and covered with gold." And Catherine Palace most of all. The Amber Room is beautiful. You will want to buy a book or post cards since you can't take pictures in that room. But sometimes memories are better than pictures.

Beautiful!. The palace is beautiful! Definitely rent headphones to learn more about this incredible place. As the last residence of the last czar, I wish they would have at least mentioned Nicolas and his wife, Alexandra, and family, though, who were murdered here (or at least nearby). Who knows exactly where since the tour completely ignored the topic!

Beautiful Palace. The grounds were particularly striking with the fountains and gardens looking magnificent. There were large crowds, but this place is so big that was never a problem. The interior tour was also spectacular. It was a nice change to get out into the countryside.

Palatial Beyond Description. It is hard to believe that this palace and park were established so long ago. Seeing is believing. The master work put into everything from ceilings to floors must be seen to be believed.

A must-see!!. I still get confused at all the Catherines and Alexanders,and who married whom, and who got killed, etc. But even not understanding very much of Russian history, one really does need to visit these palaces to see how the elite lived. No wonder there was a revolution!
Extravagant. Astonishing how one person could want all this just for a few weeks of use per year. If you like luxury and exquisite art work this is the place to see.

"Another beautiful place to visit and a must if in St. Petersburg". After the tour of the palace, go outside and just sit and "drink" it all in. The gardens are just as wonderful as the palace. Just prepare yourself for long lines and more long lines. It is my understanding that there is a hotel adjacent to the palace and park. If you have time, I suggest you do this so that you can take your time and enjoy, especially is you are into the history of pre-revolutionary Russia.

don't forget to visit it. you will regret how such beautiful palace destroyed in 2nd world war . But thanks to people that through that disaster don't forget this palace and send precious items to safe place . they deserve for respect to save this majestic items.Amber room is a unique palace inside Catherine palace and I wish that can see the original room before war...

Catherine Palace. Fortunatly our guide was wise and took us there during lunch time. so we could take our time viewing the wondeful architecture with out the crush of the crowds. The amount of gold anf the treasure displayed there was beautiful to see.

The “Amber room Palace”. Great baroque Catherine Palace with the English-style-park are taking the breath away. Have to admit, that even the palace was almost totally destroyed during World War II, reconstruction teams made the great job and it is hardly recognizable.

Opulent. This palace is named after Peter the Great's wife, not the Catherine the Great most people are more familiar with. It can get very crowded in the summer, despite its huge size. The restored rooms are beautiful, and make you marvel at the luxury and opulence the fortunate few enjoyed. Many areas are not fully restored, but when you see pictures of the state the Nazis left the place in, it's a wonder anything survived. The Amber Room is quite a sight even if it is just a reconstruction and not the original, which was looted by the Nazis. Unfortunately, photography is forbidden in this room, though permitted elsewhere. If you have the time, the gardens are beautiful.
OMG. Gold, gold, gold! You really get a feel of how narcissistic life was for the imperials. Very nice, good walk through the park to the mini hermitage.... very representative.
Wonderful interiors. We loved the interior (the outside was great too) of this palace. The porcelain stoves were beautiful and impressive.

Beautifully restored summer palace. This is another "must see" palace in St Petersburg, but be prepared for crowds and some queuing.The interior of the palace has been beautifully restored and is exquisite. The gardens too are impressive.With the exception of the Amber room where photography is strictly prohibited, photos may be taken inside the palace and in the gardens.Would recommend females wear flat shoes because disposable 'slippers' have to be worn over footwear to protect the wooden floors.

See How the Tsars Lived...During the Summer. This blue palace was another one destroyed during the Great Patriotic War/World War II, and here it stands today nearly restored (there are some rooms which the public does not see that are not yet restored). The hallway between the last stairwell and the end of tour gift shop show the pictures of the destroyed palace, one of which shows an unexploded ordnance in one of the rooms.All visitors must wear booties so not to scuff up the floors. Yet take a look in one of the grand rooms where the pianos are - the wooden floor is pockmarked because when they hold huge expensive parties, they do not force the women to wear booties over their high heels or put a protective floor covering down. Tour groups follow one path and see rooms individuals do not see; I am not certain if the same can be said vice versa as I have always been with a tour the times I've seen this palace.The Amber Room - no photos whatsoever! The security make sure to tell people when they see cameras out (which is fine for the rest of the palace). Some of the Amber Room is still not fully restored, and according to my guide, it might not ever be. The original room is still missing, and there are treasure hunters trying to find it. There are books about it in the souvenir shops at the end of the tour.There are bathrooms near the shops and cafe. If you go outside, you might be allowed inside by the guard. Just mention WC, and he should let you in. Otherwise, make sure you use the facilities if you must before leaving. They are free. The ride back to Saint Petersburg is 40-60 minutes, traffic pending.The gardens are immaculate, but they lack the fountains of Peterhof. The gardens are divided into sections based on the landscape design. There is a little cafe in the garden near the line for the palace. There is a souvenir place off the grounds with some vendors. One of the shops used to be free for its bathroom but now either charge 50 rubles (over $1 at the time) or allow merchandise paying customers to use it for free.There is a book about this palace, Peterhof, and other nearby palaces when they were destroyed by the Nazis during WWII. It is called "Saving the Tsars' Palaces." I found it in a bookstore on Nevsky Prospect. Keep an eye out for it if you are interested in that sort of history as I did not see any books of its kind at the palaces themselves.

Wonderful, must see place in St. Petersburg. This was a wonderful visit that really is a must see location if you visit St. Petersburg.It's quite a ride from the town itself (upwards of 90 minutes in traffic), but it's well worth the visit. The palace itself has been fully restored and is camera friendly in all but a couple of rooms. The artifacts, antiques, guilting and restoration is amazing. The artwork is pristine and if you would like to see how the Russian Czars lived and entertained, this is a perfect place to get a taste of their world.The gardens are beautiful also, and a stroll through the greenery is a perfect end to this attraction.If you are in St. Petersburg, this is a must see.

The Second Best Palace in St. Petersberg. Catherine the Great was noted for her firm rule and oversized tastes in many things. Her palace fits the latter category. While not as tasteful and elegant as her father's (Peter the Great), it was designed to impress and surely does. Wikth 70% of the Russian peasant's footing the bill, the Csars kept builing palaces and this was surely the most ambitious. If you have time, it is well with a visit, but if you can see only one, go to Peterhoff
Alla Tour with Marina. Again our tour guide did a fantastic job of providing historic information, highlights of various aspects of decor, paintings, grounds, restoration.

Well worth seeing. Very opulent on the inside. You can see it fairly quickly if you don't try to stop in each room. There are nice grounds to be explored which we did not get to see, i would recommend you make sure that you have time for the palace and the grounds if you decide to go.

Beautiful grounds, pleasant way to spend a few hours. As we struggled a bit with the lack of English in St Petersburg, we were lucky to have the services of our apartment owner to show us which subway trains and bus to take to get to Catherine Palace for a very cheap price, the bus was only 30 roubles each.It was a very hot day, and like with Peterhof, we did not go inside the Palace as the queues were very long, we spent all our time outside in the very extensive gardens, there was plenty to look at, the gardens were quite stunning, the Palace itself looked beautiful from the outside. We had a drink at the cafe, not cheap but pleasant place to sit for a while out of the sun.Would recommend this place to visit.

Opulent and overwhelming!. I had to rely on my pictures to remind me all that I had seen. The gold and opulence caused my eyes to glaze over and my brain to freeze. So much beauty to take in. Do go, and take lots of pictures. You will be surprised at all you see and glad you did!
A palace fit for an Empress.. I liked the whole thing. A palace is not like a castle, it looks like many of the other large buildings from the outside, but the opulence inside is mind blowing.

It's good to be the Queen. Everyone was enchanted with the famous Amber room. You are captivated by the wealth and warmth of the golden tones. The palace is so huge, the grounds seem to go on for miles. Gorgeous!!

A Blue Extravagance. Catherine Palace was built by Tsarina Elizabeth, daughter of Peter the Great. She was a spoiled brat and spent much of the Romanov fortune on her extravagant whims. They say she died with 15,000 dresses in her closets -- she never wore the same one twice. The Catherine Palace was an exercise in this extravagance. It is loaded with pounds and pounds of gold-leaf.
Beautiful Palace and grounds. This was a beautiful palace, gorgeous gardens and unbelievable gold and opulence. It is a shame that the Amber room was destroyed but the restored room is beautiful.

True Splendor. We made the 1 hour trip to catherine's Palace by car with our tour guide. It was a fantastic sunny afternoon. The entrance to the Palace grounds lets you view the main house and the staff quarters. The tour of the house takes a minium of 1 hour The main ball room is spectacualer. The ceiling paintings as well as the gold trim and mirrors. The amber room is quite interesting but actually is less impressive than other parts of the palace. After the tour you can leave the Palace and walk through the gardens to the lake. There we went into the Grotto where a quartet was singing. The accustics were superb and their voices magnificient. The walk through the gardens back to the entrance of the park was quite nice. Being there in late May with the wisteria in bloom outstanding.
Amazing restoration. I thought I was seeing the original....till on my way out I saw the black & white post war photographs. Anyway...a spectacular bit of restoration. Beautiful lake and gardens.
Stunning. Evening visit to Catherine's palace was magical. Stunning rooms on view ending up with a performance by a chamber orchestra. Amber room is amazing .

Reagal Strength and Nature's Beauty. Seeing the Palace reminded me of how much Catherine influenced Russian culture - so many artifacts of grace and strength. At the same time, I was struck by the tranquil beauty of the Park. Bring your camera, you will want to remember this!

History alive. Read a biography of Peter the Great before you go and there will be more meaning to this amazing attraction. You get a very real sense of the original history and the post WWII restoration.

Beautiful and over the top.. I was expecting a lot before arriving, and I was not let down. The palace looks gorgeous inside and out. The lines are long, and the AC is non-existent in the summer, so be prepared. But it is an incredible place to see- inside and out.

too much gold. i was amused by its majesty, the amount of rooms and their design. i wouldn't want to go there back again i just didn't like the idea of covering almost everything with gold. didn't impress me. but the soveniers are very cheap there, don't buy them in st petersburg, go either here or to Peterhof (another astonishing spot) and you'll see the price difference!
A PERFECT HISTORICAL SITE. You should definitely go there if you are in St.Pete. Everything is wonderful there - the gardens are impressive, the palace is superb, the work of restorers is amazing.

One of the Great palaces to visit in your life. The Hermitage, catherine's palace at Pushkin, and Peterhof are the three must sees in St. P. Hard to say which of the three out shines the other. See them all, and decide for yourself.

An Architectural Confection. At first glance, this stunning and wonderful delight of a beautiful palace in blue appears and a most welcoming sight it is. The first sighting is of the amazing facade and imposing entrance, set in well laid out and lovingly tended gardens. The palace appears to have been newly built, and I was amazed to hear that it had been all but destroyed during the second world war. All that is history however, the important issue is how wonderful the restoration has been and how it captures the essence of how the palace must have appeared in its heyday. i loved the way each room presented new and fresh delights, the heating systems being especially impressive as would be expected in a Russian winter. The Amber Room was astonishing, how could you begin to estimate the cost of that, and the incredible reception and ballrooms were equally astonishing. Again, without going into too much detail, I can only recommend a visit if you are in St Petersburg
Wow!. Go see this place if you love palaces and looking into the past. Very beautiful and an interesting part of history. The area is also very nice in the forest. Lots of greenery.

Beautiful palace and gardens - but oh, the crowds!. The palace and gardens are well worth a visit, but the crowds and queues do detract from the visit. We had limited opportunities to go on our short trip to St Petersburg as we were using the 72-hour visa-free rule, and unfortunately the palace had also unusually been closed for the 2 days before our visit, so there were 3-days worth of tour groups vying for space as we went through the palace. We avoided the outside queues as someone from the Guide-guru office had arrived early and stood outside to save a place for us at the head of the queue (amazing service they give) but we still had to contend with a queue for the cloakroom and the sheer volume of visitors who were allowed in. Before you plan your trip, do check dates and avoid the first open day following public holidays or other additional closures; also give yourselves plenty of time to wander in the grounds, they also deserve a good couple of hours to make the most of the additional buildings and the gardens/parkland.

Unmitigated Opulence. Working one's way through and past tour groups is like a rugby scrum. The palace, almost totally destroyed during WWII, has been renovated to the nth degree. Rooms are perfect and glitter with brand new gold leaf. The parquetry is also intricate and perfect creating the impression that it is a new palace which it is even to the Amber Room, the original having been stolen during the war. What it lacks is patina and ambience. The total experience is almost overpowering.
Now this really is a Palace. I cannot describe the interior , it is too grand and only your pictures and your mind will remind you of this beautiful place.
Fantastic. Its hard to believe anyone could have enough money to build something like this. The rooms defy description, yet another must see in St Petersburg

More Magnificent Than Photo's Indicate. This is a must see attraction when in St. Petersburg. The Palace is amazingly large and the details of the design and finishes inside are almost beyond belief. The preservation and restoration work that has been done is truly impressive. The captures the essence of the Russian Royalty of the period.I would suggest a guide and particularly one that could get you early access if possible. This attraction is attended by all tours, ship shore excursions and the like and can be very very crowded during th tourist season.
fabulous. beautiful gardens, spectacular interiors, the restoration is so good. We went in the evening and there were very few other visitors, the best time to go if you can

A Little Too Much Gold.... Apparently, Catherine never spent a night in this incredible blue palace with room after room of chandeliers and mirrors dripping with gold. It's like a long rectangle and you proceed from start to finish with each room showing more glitz than the last. A must see, but I was more impressed by the workers outside cutting weeds in a line formation.
Must see. Very interesting to see this, learn the history and see the real Russia every day. Definitely recommend this.
Catherine Palace. Was on a tour with Smartours. Very impressive. A great experience. The palace especially the Amber Room was worth the tour.

Gold, gold, gold!. Ostentatious in the extreme, the palace shows the extent to which the rulers of Russia could satisfy their fantasies.The ballroom is a fantastic structure of mirrors, gilt and white.Unfortunately their had been a major function in the grounds so the presence of the marquees detracted from seeing the grounds at the rear.

Opulent. A wonderful day, similar to palace of Versailles, opulent, visually stunning, amber room a masterpiece, breathtaking. Gardens beautiful and the day finished with a lovely Russian meal in the grounds. Great day out.

Catherine Palace and Park. This gave a wonderful photo opportunity of what a palace should look like. The rooms were just fabulous and decorated in gold leaf. The paintings, furniture, flooring, etc. A memory forever. The Amber Room - WOW - just can't describe the feeling.

Must see attraction.. Unbelievable the amount of money this must have cost to construct and furnish initially. Really enjoyed the tour we had, would get there as early as possible as it gets very busy. Didn't get as long in the grounds as we would have liked as they looked fabulous.

UNBELIEVABLE PALACE. Try to get there early. Crowds can be quite large and you might have to wait in line. Absolutely beautiful inside. No photos allowed in the amber room which is now open, but all others are OK.

How the other half lived.. The Palace is situated in The Tsars Village which at one time musthave been very beautiful,a lot of the beautiful houses have falleninto disrepair.The Palace has been beautifully restored as it wasalmost destroyed by Germany during the War. It has lovely large rooms with lovely views over the Park.The Amber Room is amazing,once again restored ,as it was looted.You will not be disappointed with a visit to this most beautiful Palace.

Awesome grounds. I really liked the location of this palace as it was kind of out of the way in a quite area. It was a little tough to find as I don't speak any Russian and went at it on my own, but it all worked out. Never went in the palace because in my opinion, when saving time on a vacation, go inside one Russian palace, and most others look the same (had already done Peterhof.) The palace grounds at Catherine's are amazing. The little buildings and houses are painted perfectly and laid out well. A walk around the lake on a nice summer day is a good way to relax from the business of St. Petes. Good place for a slow half or full day to just unwind and enjoy the scenery.

first day in St Petersburg. We took a tour here organised by our cruise ship and after leaving St Petersburg we drove to Pushkin. As we left the coach a group of musicians asked what country we were from and when I said "England" they placed "Rule Britannia" which was an excellent start to a wonderful visit. The sheer opulence of the palace is amazing and very beautiful. The Amber Room which was looted during the Second World War by the Germans has been recreated, and it is spectacular if smaller than I thought it would be. The gardens were lovely and very peaceful despite a lot of people.

Fantastic introduction to Russian history. We came here with a English tour guide, who took us through the facility and explained everything. I would not want to do it any other way, otherwise you are just looking at stuff with no understanding of the context and history.We have been to Versailles and other palaces, but were still blown away from Catherine's Palace. The opulance was amazing and beautifully restored. Highly recommended.Note that photography is allowed, just remember to keep the flash off. Be sure you know how to operate your camera with flash off before you arrive.

Absolutely Fabulous!. Not much to say that hasn't already been said - yes it's gorgeous, crowded, and you really should not leave SPB without seeing it! Hiring a private guide is really the way to go - there are just so many tour buses dropping folks off, you could wait in line for hours, but a good guide can get you to the front of the line! There is a nice gift shop, but take cash tbecause the credit card machine was offline today. Also lots of kiosks selling jewelry and other souvenirs, as well as drinks and ice cream stands just outside the palace. Leave your bottles of water in the car because they will confiscate them at the door!

Worth a visit!. We took the tour to Catherine Palace and it was really worth it.Cost was about $53per person.It was 5 hours long inclusive of travel.Our guide Irina had lots of information to share.The gardens are beautiful.The Palace was crowded so there were delays as well as some very impatient tour guides.Remember the sunblock as it was very hot in June.

Breathtaking!!. Once you enter on the second floor the gold is a marvelous monument. I was awe-struck the entire time. It was the most extravagant palace I have ever seen. The amber room (a room where the walls are covered in amber) is splendid. I suggest going later in the day on Monday, as I did. No line and no crowds. Since the summer sets later during the spring and summer, you can walk around the palace grounds well into the night.

Beautiful Palace in gorgeous surroundings. We booked onto an English speaking tour recommended by our hotel which departed from mid-way down Nevsky Street. The driver drove at high speed through the city which most drivers appear to do, however the seatbelts didn’t work so we didn’t feel particularly safe. If safety is a concern for you, I would suggest you check the seatbelts before departure as the trip takes about 45 mins. The tour itself was very good and the guide informative. The grounds are vast and take at least an hour to get round. Some parts are very well maintained whilst others have been allowed to grow wild. There are many interesting buildings in the grounds and in one of them we were treated to a live performance of opera by three male singers. The inside of the palace is stunning and each room is more opulent that the last. Although there are signs that say that photography is not allowed, we were advised that we could take photographs everywhere, except for the Amber room. I would definitely recommend a visit.

Golden Excess. Although rebuilt the work has been done sympathetically and you can only marvel at the grandeur and opulence not to mention extravagance of gold and other precious items! You can spend a whole day here and never see the same thing twice.

Amazing!. The grounds, the gardens, and every room...a must see. Yes the Amber room is special, but so is everything about this place. The work and effort to restore is nothing short of incredible. Detail is everywhere. A short 45 minute ride from St. Petersburg but worth the trip!

A Must to visit!. Wonderful Palace with excellent surrounding gardens. The rooms are amazing and even more so when you consider the damage caused during WW II. They have been extensively restored and are beautiful. The highlight was the Amber Room - followed by a visit to the Amber Workshop where we were instructed into the methods and mysteries of how the wonderful panels had been constructed. A recommended place to visit.

A monument to royal excess. Every square inch seems to be decorated to the hilt with gold and other expensive materials. The reconstructed amber room was less-impressive than we expected. Very crowded. A good example of why Russia had a revolution in 1917.

Interesting history. Again another tsarina's palace that has been beautifully restored. The floors are amazing and much of the art had been sent to Siberia during the was and thus preserved.The real mystery of this palace is where is the Amber Room. This would make a great Dan Brown novel as sometime during the was the walls of amber were dismantled and have never been found. Some claim the Germans took it while others think it is still hidden in a warehouse in Russia ; some of this amber had appeared on Sotheby auctions and cannot be traced. Very interesting story. Also the actual building that Tsarina Catherine loved in was designed and built by a man named Cameron; how did a Scot get here?

A Must See in St. Petersburg. The grounds are spectacular - you need about three hours to get a feeling for the palace and the park. Amazing statutes, fountains, flower gardens all integrated into an over the top location.

Catherine's Palace. Amazing site to see! Highlight of the palace is the Amber Room. Truly an exceptional work of art the entire room is. Have to see it to believe it. A shame we could not take pictures. One of those sites you have to commit to memory, I guess. Our Alla-Tours tour guide was amazing in navigating us around this and many of the other sites in SPB.

Nice Palace.. Was very pretty. Used public transit to arrive and it took the better part of the day. The interior contained more rooms than Peterhof. The Amber room was very interesting. Worth the effort!

Nice from the outside. It was raining when I was there and the line to get in was really long, so we didn't go inside. However, looking from the outside, this palace was quite charming. I wish I could go inside.

oppulent. Fascinating history and you can really feel what the balls/dances looked might have felt like. Crabby Russian women in each room - policing people so don't even try to sneak any photos (not allowed).

St. Petersburg - Day 1. Today I toured the Catherine and Peterhof palaces and gardens. After the Catherine Palace I thought I had seen the very most elaborate palace of all time. Then we went to the Peterhof Palace … I wouldn’t have believed you could outdo the Catherine Palace, but I’ve seen it now with my own two eyes. You should not miss either one, both were summer palaces of the Tsars, or Czars or however you want to spell it. Tomorrow I go to the Hermitage, part of which was once the winter palace. There is so much gold leaf that I have a new name for this tour – The Gilt Trip.All kidding aside, the work that has been done here is astounding. Even more astounding than the original work, to me, is the reconstruction that has been accomplished since WWII. There are photos of the palaces after the war (I should say the shells of the palaces) and when you juxtapose those with the way they look today, the comparison is staggering. I will try to put side by side photos up another day, am running low on internet minutes … so no searching on line for post-war photos at the moment. The re-creation of these world heritage sites is breathtaking. On the one hand I can understand that the people would revolt against such extreme lavishness, so the Tsarist regime had to be overcome, on the other hand I can appreciate the beauty that remains now for all of us to enjoy. One of the very cool things about being here in St. Petersburg this time of year are the “white nights”. It’s 9:00 PM now and still broad daylight. The guide told us that from the end of May until the middle of July the sun doesn’t really go down, it’s bright enough to read all night long if the weather is clear - that’s why they call them “white nights”. My Florida magic is working and today was another clear and perfect day, weather wise. If I could bottle this weather and sell it I would be buying one of the summer palaces. Of course I would then magnanimously open the doors wide to all of my clients, but that would not be a problem; they could all take me up on my offer and there would still be rooms available.  It would take me a week just to begin to describe the manicured gardens and majestic fountains – in addition to the majestic buildings. I believe there are over a thousand fountains in the gardens just at Peterhof palace. Then there are the lush meadows, artificial lakes, miles of pathways, bronze statues … it’s a tribute to imagination and beauty. It’s also a LOT walking. You will be bursting with pride to hear that yes, I did my 45 minutes in the gym, even after all that walking. My feet are not bursting with pride, they are just plain bursting.We stopped for lunch and I tried borscht, and it’s not bad – beet soup – but it’s not going to replace Chicken Noodle-O’s for me. One more thing I learned today was how to say thank you, “spasiva”. Sounds like “spa” – where you go to relax and be treated, “sea”- near the ocean and “va” – while drinking vodka. Just another day at the beach!Getting close to 10 PM, sun is still up! What a magnificent trip this is.For more about this cruise please see my complete blog http://sailorscruisenews.blogspot.com.

Grand opulence. The Palace in blue and white is huge. The interior displays the opulence and grandeur of this bygone age where there was such a gap between the rich and the poor.The photos showing the Palace burnt compared to what has been restored today is worth noting. The question is also raised as to whether it was restored as originally completed.A tour of the Palace is quite lively as groups are moved through the rooms at a reasonable pace to maintain the level of visitors.Peace is restored with time spent in the Gardens.

Beautiful exterior. The exterior of the palace is not to be missed. The inside was crowded with tour groups. We were disappointed to know that it is a recent rebuild, post WWII. To some degree it loses its luster for me. Additionally, the Amber Room is just a replica so again I was a little disappointed. The rest of the palace looks similar to many other palaces in Europe.

True slendour. The ballroom of gold is really beautiful and huge and the palace has many stunning rooms but the Amber Room is amazing. It is not the original as it was stolen by the Nazis and is believed to be buried in Berlin.Our guide kept talking about the stolen panels so I was expecting to see a room with a few painting sized panels as I had seen an amber necklace on sale for £6000.I was shocked to find that the only part of the Amber room NOT amber was the floor! I found it reminiscent of a shell grotto but made of roughly oval pieces of amber in varying shades of orange.To me the room was ugly but all I could think of was "How much must all this be worth?" The gardens are pleasant but nothing special but we were welcomed by a band when we got off the bus and again at the Palace door.

Nice place, Must see, but a lot of walking. each room is unique and it really gives you an insight into how the upper, upper Nobility lived. Nicely restored and presented. But in the end, it is an Old Palace.

A beauty. This rivals the Peterhof, and for me this barely tops it. The interior is more stunning then the exterior. Over the top everything makes this place stand out. Pretty much destroyed in WWII, this palace has overcome the pile of rubble it was. Make sure you go inside and see the incredible amber room and great hall. Just absolutely magnificent.

You've want believe the beauty. This palace was almost destroyed during WWII and when you are here you see the love the Russians have for their antiquities. This palace was spectacular and the Amber Room......truly amazing.

Over the Top. Think opulent, beautiful and breath-taking. Think gold, alabaster, marble, parquet, porcelain and more. Layer on religious symbolism in art and artistry. Add cabinetry in its finest tradition. Peek around the corner and you're greeted by the set table in the huge dining room, replete with fireplace fronted by molded plaster screens. Walk through as slowly as you're able/allowed amidst the huge crowds and focus on the details as well as the big picture. Catherine loved her beauty, opulence and image. This is a palace designed to impress guests, from the entrance at the far end that forces them to look and admire on the way in, to the larger than life dimensions and planned aggrandizing perspective..
Don't Miss This!. Another great Russian Palace.... nothing exceeds like excess! And all those window canopies were covered in gold during Elizabeth's day!

Interesting display of wealth and power. Well, I personally enjoyed Peterhof more, but Catherine Palace is an impressive display of wealth and power and it rounds out the fascinating history of the Russian Royals.

Worth the effort. It takes some effort to get to the palace and park if you're on your own but it's worth it. To be able to see the Amber Room up close was worth the price of admission. The park offers a lot of surprises and one could easily spend several hours exploring every corner.
The best of all. I think that we enjoyed this most, but my wife picked up heaps of decorating ideas. Spend as much time as possible in the garden.

If You Have to Choose Only One, Pick Peterhof. One of Catherine the Great’s palaces, Pushkin is the home of the notorious Amber Room: a room covered virtually floor to ceiling with amber decorations. The Amber Room was looted during the WW2 German occupation and the original decorations have never been found, making it one of the most mysterious lost artifacts of the modern era. The room has been recreated and is a nice room, but after all of the hype, perhaps I had built it up to impossible expectations.Otherwise, the palace is similar to other royal palaces. I think it’s unfair to say that if you’ve seen one Russian palace, you’ve seen them all. Each of them has their own mind-boggling hubristic aspects that need to be seen to be believed. Still, if I had to choose between seeing Pushkin and Peterhof because I didn’t have time for both, I think Peterhof gets the nod due to its ocean-side setting and its interesting fountains and gardens.

Wonderful!. We visited the palace and grounds as part of a 4 day visit and managed to travel by public transport from St Petersburg which was really cheap! The palace and gardens are really wonderul. Considering the palace was ruined at the end of the war they have made the most wonderful job restorating the rooms which is ongoing. It can get really crowded however and the cafe is not at all big enough to cope with the crowds we encountered but this is a minor point. The gardens are as impressive as the palace and time needs to be devoted to these as well. Beautiful cool paths and walkways lead to pavilions and other buildings which are as just as impressive as the main palace.

Not Just a Palace. Everyone has seen the pictures of Cathrine's Palace and the amazing amber room but don't miss a walk thru the extensive gardens. One could spend the entire day just in the gardens alone.
Magnificent. Grand palace lacated in beautiful country side with lush green parks and grand interior very well maintained

Gardens alone are wonderful.... You needn't even enter the palace... just strolling the bucolic gardens and admiring the views is heavenly enough. Gardens are open all year... in dead of winter cross-country skiers are common sights.

Amber room is stunning!. We visited in a small group with a guide as a part of a grand tour of St. Petersburg. The palace is located geographically in the same area as the Peterof. We easily did both sights on the same day. Our guide purchased our tickets...We did not wait in line to enter. We were able to move from room to room with commentary by our guide (We used individual audio devices, so hearing her was not a problem.) Although it was crowded with other groups, our guide managed our group so that we could get a good look at each room...the crowds were not a problem. The interior of the palace was stunning...all glitter and gold (and plenty of mirrors!). NB: This palace has been rebuilt. It was destroyed at the end of WWII. The most incredible room was the amber room...well worth the visit by itself! The palace is definitely a DNM (Do Not Miss) sight! Going with a guide will facilitate your entry (saving hours in line) and enhance your visit.

Crowded with groups - not too hard on your own. We came on our own with a combo of metro and bus and the trip was pretty easy. We arrived before the opening time for individuals so we spent some time in the garden before getting into the palace. We heard lots of people who were in the palace before noon complaining that it was so crowded inside that they could not see. We got in at noon and there was not a great crowd then so we felt lucky. The audio guide was good but sometimes gave too much detail. We spent much more time than the few tour groups that were there with us and we still cut off the audio at times.

Huge and Magnificent. If you like the baroque style and lots of gilt, then this is the place for you ... the reception / ball room rivals that of Versailles. Is it better than Versaille? Not in my opinion but it is just as important and a visit is totally worth while IMO

Decadence reached a peak here. This place rivals or even exceeds Versailles (outside Paris). The opulence inside is amazing, and the grounds are equally impressive. You wear paper booties to walk through the place (to protect the floor). Again, no tours in English. The Amber room is an amazing (can't take picture there, which makes no sense) re-construction

Worth the day trip. The decadence of this palace and its gardens is overwhelming. You might have to pay through the nose for an organised tour or queue outside the palace for a while if you are a independent traveller but it is worth it. If you aren't on an organised tour you get lumped in with a group when you arrive for a tour in Russian. The audio guides are also only in Russian so if you want to know a bit more then you can get a guide book from the shop opposite the ticket booth before you enter. Once inside just make your own way around. As long as you aren't doing anything stupid or getting in the way, the staff don't seem to mind that you have 'lost' your tour!Make some time to see the gardens, some of the other buildings are almost palaces in their own right. If you have time, it's also worth getting over to the Alexander place but note that you'll have to pay again to get back into the Catherine palace gardens. The Alexander palace is in the process of being restored so you can see what the restorers have to work from. If you get the train out from St Petersburg, take a wander around the Vitebsky train station if you have time. And if you are wondering where to get tickets, head out towards the platforms and go along the right until you get to some modern ticket barriers - the ticket booth for suburban trains is here.

Lavish Living. Catherine lived a very lavish and rich life. I had read about them in history but never knew how they lived. They lived too rich for me. They seemed to have lived to impress. All the granduer, gold, amber it's too much and over the top, but you must see. It's unbelievable that people lived this way.

Go to the Park, avoid the Palace!. The park is huge and really beautiful, with different architectural objects like pyramid for example. The entrance fee is only 100/50R and you can enjoy it all day. On the other hand there is the Catherine Palace, well first you have to wait in the queue to enter the building, then you have to wait to buy the tickers. Another 10 minutes to go through the entrance, then in each room you have to wait and wait and wait. It was really annoying! Only two rooms are interesting, the gold one and the amber chamber. But I don't think it was really worth. Better enjoy the silence in the park :)

The Empress knew how to live. I was fortunate to have a private tour of Catherine's Palace while in St. Petersburg/Pushkin. It was worth every penny. The Palace is gorgeous, along with its stunning gardens, and the furnishings & rooms have been restored to their former glory. I coveted everything I saw, including the door handles! LOLBe sure you book your tour of the Palace well in advance. You have to be cleared and receive permission from the Russian government. You cannot just show up!

Great Day trip. We took the day excursion on Holland America and really enjoyed Catherines Palace. Its nicely restored since the Nazis destroyed Leningrad (now Saint Petersburg). The best part of tour is the garden.

Beautiful place altogether. Huge but elegant; more impressive than Versailles or Sans Souci. Amazing restoration since WWII damage. Gardens beautiful and peaceful. A must for a visit from St Petersburg.
Over The Top. Loved all the guilding and the amber room was incredible. All the rooms were different and it was hard to know where to look.
Stunning Restoration. Wonderful restoration. Each room a treasure to enjoy and the 25 year re-creation of the Amber room just stunning.

If a building could be a Faberge Egg...inside and out!. This is a beautiful place! Very delicate and feminine for the most part. They have restored if beautifully from the destruction of the Nazis...with the help of funds from the German government! Of course the Amber room is the highlight, as so it should be. The craftsmanship and attention to detail in ALL the rooms was amazing. If you are with a tour guide, they will explain everything and show you what is original (lucky enough to be saved from the war) and what was restored. This place really gives Versailles a run for its money as far as beauty and opulence are concerned. A MUST SEE if in SPB!!!

NO PHOTOS ALLOWED IN THE " Amber Room". Amazing. We visited with Globus escorted tour with a local guide. Photos allowed except for the Amber Room.While worth the visit.Lots of gift shops and bathrooms at the entrance.Enjoy

Opulence!. It's almost hard to believe that this palace was so badly damaged in World War II! It has been reconstructed and maintained beautifully since. Maintenance work is ongoing, but doesn't affect the experience. The Amber Room must be seen first hand, because no pictures are allowed in there. Walking through the palace and the gardens, you can only imagine what life was like for Russian royals!

Just Excellence. beautiful gardens, a very popular place. A lot of walking and crowds of visitors. The fountains in the gardens are magnificient.A cafe before the entrance gates and prices not over pricey.

Speachless. The only negative point : too many tourists at a time, we had to wait to get in. But this aside, it simply takes our breathe away. Gold everywhere, except the amber room that is not less amazing. Definetely worth a visit.
Pectacular. Beautiful palace with loads of cold on everything, wonderful art and history. Watch out for the "Babushkas" they are watching you. Definately a place to see.

Don't miss the basement!. While the gardens here are not as impressive as the Peterhof, the restored rooms are a sight to behold....the amber room is not as mind boggling as anticipated, but the rest of the place is just incredible...If you are lucky you may hear an a cappella group singing in the Boathouse! The pictures in the basement gave context to how the Russians restored this place following the destruction by the Nazis---unfortunately they did not have an English audio guide...or English placards in the rooms so a good guide book is a must!

Blingtastic. Raised to rubble in WW2 this palace was carefully rebuilt. If you are a fan of gold leaf - this will be your 'palace of choice'. After 6 days in StP I was really wanting to see something less 'in your face' - but had come to the wrong destination! This palace really is a 'glory of gold leaf'
It takes your breath away!!. Absolutely gorgeous palace and grounds. A must see for St. Petersburg. I don't think I've everseen a place with so much gold on the walls and ceilings. Just stunning.

Rivals Versaille. What an amazing place! We had a guided tour of both the inside and outside gardens. The Great Hall of gilded gold gives Versaille's Hall of Mirrors a run for its money. The Amber Room is very unique and the remaining rooms are plush with furnishings, silks, velvet, and beautiful flooring. The outside gardens are a mixture of French manicured lawns with English overgrowth. A beautiful place that we could wander forever. Definitely a must see!

An exotic palace with an interesting history. It is easy to visit this palace on your way back from Peterhof as it is outside St Petersburg. Go with a good guide so you can learn the intriguing history of this magnificent palace and Catherine's place in Russian history.

Beautiful!. Gorgeous palace & grounds, so lovely, could go back again and again! The palace itself is so beautiful, it is stunning and the grounds are lovely to wander around, no one could fail to be impressed with a visit here.

Stunning, and huge.. Massive palace which seems to go on for ever. The inside is richly decorated with one of the largest rooms I've ever been in.Gold seems to be the favourite material. Fully renovated after the Nazis left it a roofless shell . Well worth the trip to Pushkin.
Awesome palace!. This palace was bulit using classical and extravagant barroco styles, resulting in a fascinating construction

Catherine Palace Pushkin. Driving from St Petersburg Pushkin can be reached in less than an hour (25km /SE), and you feel out in the countryside. The Palace is just as impressive as the Winter Palace in St Petersburg with similar styling and colours. Built in 1756 it has a flamboyant Rococo style facade but the interior is simply bedazzling and lavish to the nth degree. Whereas the Winter Palace is more of a museum for works of art, this palace is great big empty ballrooms etc set up just as the lifestyle of the mid-18th century. They needed to be big to fit the dresses of the ladies of the day. One sees gold and reflections of gold in huge mirrors in most rooms. Then there's the bedchambers, dining rooms all set with displays of the finest porcelain, and the throne room plus so much more. Expect to walk for a couple of hours and continue to be in awe of just how much money and what a lavish lifestyle was held here in days gone by. Outside the gardens are in layers, with a summer house and pool, and wonderful trees. Going there with a Guide makes all the difference in the world as history is explained and you come to understand why Russia was and is the way it is, and why revolutions took place within their own country. We were lucky the place was not filled with tourists so good photos could be taken without people reflected in all the mirrors, but it was also cold and not quite the sunlight I would have liked on the exterior. I guess you get one or the other! But a "not to be missed" experience!

Worthwhile trip. A very entertaining and educational trip which takes about 5hours do travel there and walk around palace and grounds. The restoration work that had been completed is a credit to the Russian people - great selection of artwork and artifcacts to look at and great history lesson

Nice house Catherine!!. It took us about 50 minutes by coach to arrive at the palace from central St P. We were welcomed by a brass band where we parked and by another at the entrance to the palace. There were a number of tour coaches when we arrived, but it is such a huge palace, that it can easily cope with swarms of visitors. First impressions were wow this place is huge. It just seems to go on and on - I think they got rather carried away on this one. Of course it is completely over the top both inside and out, but that was the how it was done if you were a Russian Emperor. The rooms we visited were incredibly ornate and possibly even more than Versailles. The famous amber room exemplifies the opulence. They obviously did not know what to do with their money and it's hardly surprising that the common people revolted. The expenditure to build this palace must have been astronomical. It then had to be fully rebuilt after WW2, as it was almost completely destroyed. There are photos of the destruction.We also wandered around the nice understated gardens. It is a wonderful palace, a world treasure and a must visit place in St P.

what more can one say, it is fantastic. We were there as part of our Baltic Cruise and was overwhelmed with the gardens and palace. As previous comments about all the gold are so correct. Such wealth and such proverty all in the same city.

Nice palace with lots of Gold!. The palace takes about an hour to see. It has been restored completely as it was nearly completely destroyed during WWII. They have exhibits showing lots of before and after photos. Besides gold rooms they have an Amber room that is incredible.

Wonderful Wretched Excess. This place is totally over the top! Gold everywhere, a sprawling ballroom that dwarfs Versailles' Hall of Mirrors, the famous Amber Room, which is panelled entirely in the precious stone -- it's good to be the Tsar!We had booked a private tour so that we could get to both the Catherine Palace and Peterhof in one day. Expensive, but worth it. We made a point of starting from our hotel at 9 am and arrived at Catherine Palace just before it opened at 10. (The tour company wanted to pick us up at 10) Although we entered behind a busload tour group, we zipped past them as they tried to get organized just inside, and we were first -- and alone -- through the whole palace. It was wonderful!The Park attached to the Palace is very nice, but not memorable.
Impressive. Very impressive from the outside. Cloakrooms and queues a bit of a farce. Once you have seen one curly wurly golden room you have seen them all.
Very Grand Palace. Worth the trip to see this gorgeous former palace of Catherine the Great. Many beautiful things to see inside.

Go with a guide. This is a beautifully restored palace with equally beautiful gardens,best visited with a guide on a pre booked tour as individuals are only admitted at certain times and queues are long.the famous amber room is amazing.
Lovely Buildings & Architecture. Lovely Buildings & Architecture the opulence is amazing, just stroll around the gardens and enjoy the views and the size of the Cameron Gallery

Wow!. Just when you think you've seen all the opulence of St Petersburg's palaces and churches, you go to Catherine's Palace and you have to re-think! Not only is the palace itself huge but the park is immense. With all the pavilions dotted around the 250 acres, you need as much of a full day here as you can. Make sure you have a guide or you will miss/not understand too much.
Spoilt by the queuing. I have to admit we visited during a Bank Holiday but you have to pay to enter the gardens to be able to queue for entrance to the Palace and it took over two hours!

Wonderfull sunny day in Catherine Palace. Before every comment: if you want to get in this museum BOOK A GUIDE in advance! If you go by yourself you will face around 2 hours of waiting in the front door!The palace you'll see is a brand new palace because it was completely restored after the 2nd world war. The think is thanks to the will of a small group of person they convinced Soviet Union that the place needs to be preserved for future generation.The result is just fantastic because the 18th century 1st floor is perfectly restored. Pay attention on very rare Chinese pottery in the main hall. Yes the amber room is fantastic and unique but also the blue faience stove! You'll see a lot of gold, the facade is restore every 3 year because of hard weather condition so choose the right year if you want to see it shining.Don’t forget to visit the garden it's MANDATORY take a walk near the lake an Chinese pagoda, and walk in French garden.2 or 3 hours is necessary to visit garden and museum.Enjoy ;-)
Nice Museum. If Peterhof Palace and Garden has beatuy outdoors this one is beautiful from inside. Requires some amount of walking. Keep aside about 1.5/2 hours

Same as Peterhof - don't go in bad weather. If you want a great day out, make sure it's sunny and head to Catherine park and take the long walk around the lake with the various beautiful pavillions around it. Unfortunately, my own experience of it was marred with bad weather and unfriendly souvenir hawkers on the way back... But still, weather is the crucial factor here

Tour with Eclectica Tours. We went on a tour with Eclectica Tours to St Catherine's Palace which started at 2pm and said it would end at 7.10 pm. We arrived there very promptly as there was little traffic and we completed our very interesting tour promptly too as there weren't too many visitors. We were then told to explore the gardens for 45 minutes. It was a beautiful afternoon, so this was lovely. However 45 mins really isn't enough, especially if you want to have some tea or just sit and relax. Our bus journey back to the city was equally quick, so we were then taken to a tourist shop!!!! It was just by St Nicholas's church, so we decided to duck out of this part of the "tour" and go and see the church!!! I was quite cross about this........... We could easily have spent longer at the Palace in the gardens or we could have been shown the church instead!!!! Cheeky.......

Better to visit in winter. In summer season there are a lot of people in queue outside and inside. And they have special schedule for individual visitors and groups, so check it on website before. Don't try to go on Russian holidays (first 2 weeks in May) or weekend, because it is more crowdy with locals.The entrance ticket to the palace is 320 rub. (and before you also have to buy ticket to the park - 100 rub.) and you can't pay by card ( but there is ATM). You have to leave any backpack in cloakroom. The entrance ticket also includes excursion and special equipment to listen but it is only for Russian speaking people. In other case you could take audio-guide before to go to entrance after tickets purchase. if you come in summer to the park I really recommend to enjoy park and be outside. Or in september-october it is also nice in the park. But remember that it is less crowdy inside the palace in winter season.

A must go and worth the wait. The Catherine Palace is surrounded by a beautiful park which is worth a stroll in. The only issue is that individual visitors (not travelling in tour groups) can only access the palace between 12 and 2pm and between 4 and 5 pm. This means that you'll have to line up early since plenty of people want to visit the palace at those times. We arrived at 11h50 am and we had to queue for al;most 1,5 hours before we could enter. Better to come around 11h15 or 11h30am and get in immediately at 12. But the palace is worth the wait: very rich and beautiful interior. You need to follow a tour group inside the palace officially, but you can slip away from these very easily. Don't miss the amber room which is splendid!

Pushkin in the snow. We visited this site about half an hour by train from St Petersburg. We did the trip alone without guides (not willing to pay £100/head) and can thoroughly recommend the experience. The local train (from the upper level of the station in St P.) is slow and uncomfortable but warm: the local bus is cheap but one needs to be aware of when to get off - a local told us. The return journey is not straightforward as the bus takes a slightly different route but it is not difficult to find.The Palace is wonderful and would take too long to describe - not many visitors in March with no queues - I strongly recommend an audio guide (one is enough) and one should plan your route as there is so much to see.We used Metro back in St P and apart from some alphabet problems identifying stations it is well worth seeing the system - very clean and efficient - but the doors close quickly without warning as my wife who was left on platform will testify!!

Jaw dropping splendour. Was astounded the the splendour and luxury this palace oozed. Just stunning! Really beautiful rooms. My jaw just dropped in nearly every room I went in.Thought the brown pixi shoes were a bit out of place pink would have been better, nevertheless floors were protected. Really worth the money to visit here. A must. The gardens are lovely to walk around.

Not to be missed. This is one of those places that will never fade from the memory. The beauty of the palace and its contents is incredible. It is a wonderful tribute to the people of St Petersburg that the restoration has been done so accurately. Every room in the palace has its own unique story and character. From original paintings by the masters thought to chandlers that are exquisite. This is one place I will return to as it is hard to take it all in on one visit.

A wonderful restoration job. We went here over the Russian Easter weekend so expected the crowds but went early with our guide so didn't have to queue. Leave your coat and large bags, put on your overshoes and off you go.Yes it's very impressive and it's hard to believe people lived in such lavish surroundings but what impressed us more was the standard of workmanship in restoring this ruin to it's former glory. There are photos and drawings near the end of the tour which really bring home what a mess the place was after the war. The craftsmanship really is excellent and that was our lasting impression of this palace.It was a beautiful sunny day so we walked in the grounds and were lucky enough to hit the first seasonal performance of a local choir of four men who make a wonderful sound in one of the small buildings in the grounds. The acoustics are very good and we bought one of their CDs to bring home as a souvenir. There was a flautist playing near the palace too.The whole place had a lovely, relaxed atmosphere. A nice morning out.

Summer Palace. The ground belonged to Catherine the first, the wife of Peter the Great. And the interiors were redecorated during the times of Elisabeth (their daughter). The carving and guilding are amasing! You feel youself in history although many items were lost during the Second World War.The palace is situated in the city named after russian poet Alexander Pushkin so it is better to read something about his life and poems. By the way when living in this city he ended the Onegin's letter to Tatiana (from Eugene Onegin):…every moment seeing you,And following where’er you go,Your lips that smile, your eyes that move,To catch with eyes in love, aglow.To hear and hear you, understandWith all my soul your sweet perfection,In agonies before you stand,Turn pale and swoon! What bliss! What blessing!(the translation is taken from the Internet)So, a wonderful romantic place especially in nice weather!

Splendid restoration. Similar to the Peterhof in gilding, gold walls and ornate Baroque embellishment. It is staggering to see the magnitude and obvious cost of restoring this palace to its pre 1941 (ie. Nazi occupation) glory. I suspect Catherine the Great would be amazed
Luxury!. After visit this former Palace you totally understand why Russians had that revolution! The Czars lived like...like...well, like Czars!! So much luxury!

STUNNING CATHERINE PALACE. Don't miss seeing this magnificent building, it's jaw droppingly beautiful. The Amber Room is worth waiting to see. Be patient while your tour is being organised and tickets bought, coats put in a cloakroom and you have to put paper pixie like shoes on to protect the floor (or polish it free of charge!). On entering the Great Hall you will be speechless at the splendour of it all and to know that it had been practically completely destroyed by the Germans yet painstakingly reconstructed by the Russians is amazing.Don't try and visit independently of a tour, very strict hours for doing that and massive queues.The gardens are an added bonus, for us unfortunately spring is five weeks late and the leaves were still in bud but when they are out the gardens will be magnificent too.
Once seen never forgotten. Now you will understand why there was a Bolshevic uprising - the wealth and splendour is amazing, almost obscene.

Restored opulence. A magnificent Palace, beautifully restored and furnished, mainly in the Baroque style. I particularly liked the parquet floors of so many designs.The gardeners were working in the Park to prepare it for the summer season, and so the outdoor statues etc, were still covered by their winter boxes. However, it was warm enough to sit outside to wait for our fellow travellers to emerge. We watched the sparrows gathering bits and pieces (including a large white feather) with which to build their nests, tucked in behind the beautiful baroque decorations to the front of the building.It was a lovely trip and we were so pleased we had decided to go in April - I think it would have been much less enjoyable with the large crowds in the summer months.

Grand Palace. Magnificent work in gold and marble. Awesome setting. The halls in the palace was huge, quite easily amongst the largest that we have seen. The anterooms to this great hall in itself are larger than the main rooms in other castle. The lawns are brilliant . The water bodies in the grounds were still frozen lending them a special appeal. The grounds were just amazing and one could literally feel the vastness and quiet in the old times. A must visit place, both in summer or winter

Breathtaking but touchingly personal. Everyone visits the Hermitage in St Petersburg - and rightly so. We wrongly assumed we were 'palaced out" after seeing so many richly decorated residences. However Catherine Palace is of a size and layout that gives the wow factor but also portrays how the families actually lived there. The personal dining rooms are as interesting as the magnificent ballrooms. The amber room is a must - interestingly this whole building has been restored from a shell and the amber room had to be completely recreated with fresh amber as the original was lost - at what cost! Note you are not allowed to take photos in the amber room so have to buy the postcards Outside the gardens - even now in icy cold April - are worth a visit - and the little hermitage/garden retreat will I am sure be open to visitors one day A short drive outside St Petersburg this is definitely worth making time for.

Always amazing, no matter how many times I visit!. It is good to get away from the city's rush and noise and come to the Catherine's Palace to see its magnificent interior and treasuries or stroll along the park's alleys and paths. The Amber Room, a Russian treasure of legendary significance, is one of the highlights. The Great Hall with a spectacular painted ceiling, the Dining Room and The Portrait Hall are also very impressive. Approximately 100 kilograms of gold were used to gild the exterior and interior ornaments!On our last visit to the palace we took a small group guided tour which helped to skip the long queue and gave a more personal experience.
Beautiful palace and grounds. The palace is a little outside the city, but well worth the trip. It is breathtaking, and the amber room should not be missed.

Beautiful estate - stunning interior. Really easy to get to by ourselves: we got the 545 minibus from just outside the Metro Moskovskaya which took us straight to the bottom of the road of the palace at Pushkin for 35rubles, with entrance fee of 320rubles plus 150rubles for an audio guide. So quite a bit cheaper than the 1800rubles we were quoted for an excursion from Nevsky Prospekt.It was still low season so the grounds had only just thawed from the snow, and the lake was still frozen, however, on the plus side it was really quiet and we had the rooms to ourselves for most of the time which made enjoying the palace so much more possible. I would definitely recommend this as a must see place for anyone visiting st Petersburg.
Worth visiting. Definitely make a trip to Pushkin to see this marvellous place. Especially the reconstructed Amber room is a real beauty to see. Large amd impressive, along with the park.

Russian empire at its grandest. A powerful experience for the senses at the Catherine Palace. The whole palace was totally destroyed by the German army. Luckily, before the German army came, the palace staff took pain to hide the treasures away, some in St Issac. The Russians did an AMAZING job restoring the Catherine's palace. The palace showed the Russian empire at its grandest. When we arrived, there was this small brass band, band members dressed up as royal guards, welcoming the visitors. How lovely!Each room was in a different style, with decor materials from different parts of the globe. Every one was so beautiful. The amber room, though a re-creation (the original was taken down before the German army came but lost after the war) based on old sketches, was stunning. WOW!!!!
