What a sight!Our guide, from TJ Travel, took us through the palace and shared with us the stories and highlights of the exhibits. The palace could get very crowded with tour groups. We couldn't really take a lot of time to study each room in detail before being rushed forward by the group behind us. Be sure to arrive early. Compared to the Peterhof, the Catherine Park was ok. Nice but not impressive per se.

An amazing work of restoration. A beautiful and breathtaking building set in extensive parkland.The interior of the building was stripped by the German occupying forces during the seige during World War 2, but has now been restored to much of its former glory.Very popular venue with significant queues ( suggest you go as part of an organised trip, which appear to be given priority access )

Beautiful Catherine's Palace. Really should be a wonder of the world. Amazing! Words cannot describe it and neither photos give it the full WOW! factor. The gold room where Elton John played and so so much more. The Amber room, All the rooms. Especially beautiful because it was snowing. Plus not as crowded as would have been in the summer.

Nice short trip out of city. We enjoyed our visit here very much. One of the highlights for me were the photos on display taken before the bombings and after. The depict the packing and unpacking of thousands of art works removed from the palace for safekeeping. Also many photos of the restoration process and the people who dedicated themselves to seeing it finished. It is amazing what was accomplished.
Gaudiness to the extreme. Go early and beat the crowds--otherwise you will wait an hour or more in line to enter the palace. Don't miss going in the Garden House. I found the elevators fascinating.

Catherine Palace. This magnificent palace was more than I expected. I can't believe that it was destroyed during the siege and we are so lucky that the Russians decided to rebuild it. The furnishings, floors and everything in it was beyond belief.

Beautiful Palace and surrounds. Only a small part of the whole complex was open to the public, but it was incredible! Stunning architecture and a must see attraction when in St Petersburg. We were there in Winter and there was plenty of snow which added to the magic of the setting. Outside of the Palace is just as beautiful with big parks and other beautiful buildings.

Catherine Palace in March. The Catherine Palace (Tsarkoye Selo or "Tsar's Palace") is a prime example of Russian baroque. The great architects Rastrelli and Cameron's showplace is full of over the top large rooms with ceiling frescos and gold work galore. Also not to be missed is the recreation of the famed Amber Room that had disappeared during WWII. In 2003 they reopened it and you would not know that it is not the original as it sits in this most amazing and lovely place. We were winter visitors so did not take advantage of the garden tour in the 10 degree weather but I could see that is was large and very French in feel. The drive out is pleasant and allows you to see some upscale neighborhoods along the way with a final drive by the famous Alexander Palace (the yellow one to the right before Catherine's). A guided tour of the property would be a wise investment as there is some amazing history associated with it.

Very Impressive. We had a guided visit in February. Winter is a good time to visit as there are more rooms open to the public, and fewer visitors allowing a comfortable and leisurely visit. We had good weather on the day we visited and the gardens were particularly picturesque with the clear blue skies and sunshine. If you go, take a little time to look at some of the photographs which show the state that the palace was left in after the Second World War, and give you an appreciation of the amount of painstaking work that has gone into making Catherine Palace the impressive place that it is today.

It's worth the trip out of town. It's not too far out: take the metro 2 to Kupchino, then go to the bus station outside - simply ask any driver for "Puschkin", that's the name of the village, and he will show you the right bus. Then ask that driver for Katharina Palace and he should drop you off at the right stop, probably along with a lot of other visitors anyway. The palace is worth the trip - I'd recommend an audio guide, which tells you a lot about the history of each room.

Tsarskoye Selo, or Catherine Palace. We took a private guide and driver , the guide was very good, It must be wonderful in Summer but in Winter it was stunning, More rooms are open to visitors in Winter so it is a good time to visit.

Palace's garden. It is a beautiful place but I would recommend a walk in the garden on a sunny day instead of too crowded palace with a long line to get in. The palace is nice but it would not be a big loss to skip it and do something else instead.

beautiful. . .. beautiful palace!!! what i love the most is the beautiful paintings on the ceilings ;-)
it will take some efforts to go there (if you don't take any tour) but it's worth though...

Amazing place. We arrived with our private guide from Anastasia tours to see a huge long line of people waiting to get in! Not us we skipped right to the front of the line and in minutes were putting on our protective blue booties!What a place! Words cannot describe the jaw dropping amazement at the opulence of this place, it's stunningly beautiful, the recreation of the Amber room is stunning. Our guide made it all the better explaining to us little details that made the palace come alive. A must see when in SPB

Amber, gold and decadence. Catherine's Summer Palace, aka Tsarskoe Selo is an amazing palace complex. It boasts lavish and well renovated rooms that show the opulence of the Tsars, while a temporary exhibit showed the devastation it experienced during WWII. If you like gold, you'll love Catherine's Summer Palace. Most of the rooms are covered in it. It also just shows how much of a Diva Tsarina Elizabeth was - her parties, obsession with gold and habit of never dining in the same room two days in a row. While she had to constantly look over her shoulder at who might be scheming, she certainly made of the most of being a Tsar. I highly recommend a visit in winter. We went in February and had the palace to ourselves.

winter magic. I used to visit this place in the past always in summer, but this time it was a great surprise to discover all this beauty of the winter landscape! Add to this that there are not so many people at this time of year, seems like a perfect moment to feel the true spirit of Russia.

A restored wonder. This palace was just incredible! It has been heavily restored after WW2, and there are photos showing before and after, which are astonishing. The decor is outstanding - gold, mirrors, more gold, more mirrors, and it is fantastic that so much time has been put into reconstructing it. Definitely worth a visit!

Gardens, beautiful. Palace, interesting. Getting there, an adventure.. Recommending the Park and Palave in that order. I would've spent two hours quietly walking around the park and returned home content. Everything else was a bonus and possibly a distraction from a lovely walk. Getting there. Chose to talk the train and catch a bus from the station. Recommendation: have the name in Cyrillic, know how to pronounce in Cyrillic and recognize when spoken. Be patient. Use the three person rule. The rule: you need to ask three people to obtain the answer to one question. For us, this included finding the track, boarding the right train, and deboarding at the right station. It's an exhausting rule and a good one to remember. Park: Loved the Park. Could've walked in the snowy landscape for two hours.Palace: If you can, see this before the Hermitage because the art is not as good. Not a fair comparison, but there you have it. Next, there are very few explanations in English. in some ways, that's nice. We opted to wander through and just enjoy and use the guide book. Freeing to not have to study every last detail. Truly, the most amazing part is that the all the interiors are restorations.

Opulent but crowded. It took me 1.5 hours to queue up for ticket to see the palace & got shuffled in with a jam packed crowd through the inside. While opulent & spectacular, I'm not sure if it was worth the time & the effort.To me, the park & court gardens were more interesting & enjoyable. Beautiful hedges & landscape, satellite pavilions & bridges plus spectacular flowers under a clear blue sky in August was quite fascinating. The park was expansive & a quiet stroll was thoroughly enjoyable.

Tsar's Ball. What can you say about attending the Tsar's Ball in the beautiful blue Catherine Palace, and standing at the same windows the Tsar and his family looked out. Listening to the harpsichord in the Amber Room. Fireworks at midnight. Dancing. Caviar. Champagne. Incredible service. International guests at the ball. Incredible.

Visited in the snow. We visited the Catherine Palace in February and it was snowing when we arrived so was very atmostpheric. The Palace is very grand and the Amber Room is exceptional. Afterwards we strolled in the gardens in the snow! Well worth a visit and at this time of the year much less crowded.

Nice but beware of tourist traps. It is a fantastic place, and the town is just very beautiful. The Amber room, is quite worth seeing, and wandering around the garden is quite an experience. Just be careful of the tour operators that take you there. We went through a tour operator that we hired on Nevsky Prospect, and it was so bad that we ended up returning on our own. They told us that the bus would leave 10.20 but we waited until about 12 because they were just gathering more cattle... i mean tourists. In the meantime we suffered an hour and a half of pitches about whatever random DVD's and calendars for sale. They only allowed us 40 minutes in the palace, and of course we just decided to stay longer.At the end we returned by quite decent public transport at a fraction of the cost. The palace is nice, the town is really cool, but the tour operators are substandard.

Really amazing!!!! You must go and see!!!!. Just walking along the palace to the entrance is in itself an experience. The snow added a certain charm. Inside you are supplied with over-shoes to protect the floors. The rooms are just overwhelming. From floor to ceiling the rooms are spectacular! The 'Great Hall' is really enormous and very impressive. The Amber Room is beautiful! This is something NOT to be missed. Can't recommend it enough!!!!

Stunning....even in winter. If you're going in off season you really feel lost in this wonderful dream castle... It was a special feeling to share this huge golden ball room with no one... A unique experience. A beautiful palace with art and of course the AMber Room (it's just a copy but a great copy..)

Over the top, Go!. Every room had so much detail and made my jaw drop. Lots and lots of gold. But as you go through you see how things went out of style and new designs and concepts to architecture were put into place. When I hear now about luxury, wealth, distribution of wealth, etc Catherine's Palace will probably always come to my mind. The history and stories behind everything was great.If you are strapped for time in St. Petersburg, you can save yourself a little extra time by either walking quickly through the park or just skipping it.PRIVATE TOUR! The best thing we splurged on for our Baltic cruise. I can't emphasize this enough. If you can...DO IT. Our guide was so intelligent and always had everything organized so well. We always had a car waiting, no lines, no waiting for slow people in other groups. We didn't need headphones because our guide was always narrating. LOVED IT!
Interesting. Except for the fact that it was so far removed from the reality of the time, the Palace was quite interesting. The expense for these grounds while people were starving was dificult.

This place took my breath away!. Catherine Palace blew me away from the moment I caught a glimpse of it. It's grandeur and opulence are unbelievable. The palace is beautiful both inside and outside. The ballroom and the Amber room are incredible. The palace is a masterpiece. It recounts Russian history and czarism through its architecture, artwork and abundance of gold. It is definitely worth a visit when in St-Petersburg.

So much gold. This is less a palace than a gold exhibition hall. The restoration has been recently completed following the damage during the war. set in stunning grounds this palace goes on and on. Inside the gilt and gold leaf work is quite stunning but nothing prepares you for the amber room. Wow quite magnificent and paid for by a German Company in recognition of the damage done so many years ago now. It is one of the two must visit palaces in St Peterburg

Amazing. Visited in the winter, a handful of visitors so we seemed to have the Palace to ourselves. It is a beautiful palace, the Amber room is just one of the highlights and is the only room you cannot take a photo. There is a park (although as it was winter and it was snowing we didn't walk around as the statues were all protected). Do not miss it.

Amazing palace. it is one of the most beautiful and amazing places that St Petersburg offers to its guests. When getting closer to it you see just a side part of the building and then when you get right on the Platz infront of it and see the majestic Golden Gates and the enormous ensemble you can appreciate the talant of its designer. Inside it is like a palace from a fairy tale - gold carvings, beautiful statues and of course breathtaking Amber room! I still remember the warmth of it's precious decoration.It is unbelievabe beautiful! I am so happy we were there during our trip. No problems by the entrance, in fact our group was entering ( I was with Tj Travel) while the others from other companies were lining up in queue. Truly speaking they really made a miracle every time when there was a line to enter - they bit all of them. So no waiting and only the most pleasant memories from this fairy tale place. it is here you believe that Russia is a land of the Fire bird!
Amazing. A must see really. Very busy in season. Be prepared for lone lines and a 3 to 4 hour tour. But, to see the opulence is beyond belief.

If Peterhof is too crowded.... ...a terrific back up option. Or as a comparative study. Catherine was a German who killed her ineffectual husband (or had him killed at least), took control of Russia for a bit and beget us the Hermitage and this little country estate. Supposedly, even she felt it was "a bit much", but she was a harsh critic of architecture (she leveled her Tsaritsina in Moscow and demanded it to be rebuilt from scratch) and, like me, you might find it a decent place to call home. Great walking around the estate, even (or especially) in winter. The Amber Room lives up to its hype. If you're game, get there Russian style: Metro and Marshrutka. Cheap ($2) and easy!

Impressive.. A forty minute taxi from SPB. Grand palace with a decent English language audio tour. The Amber room is worth the trip. When the guard saw that I was on my own she allowed me to take a private side tour into some rooms the general Russian tours didn't see. Make sure you arrange return transportation in advance. I had difficulty finding a taxi after the tour.

Amber Room Unique. The Catherine Palace is in a village originally called Tsarskoe Selo and then changed to Pushkin because the famous Russian author went to school there. Both names seem to be used. All the rooms are beautiful and the routes through the palace are designed so room to see everything properly. But I have never seen anything in any palace in Vienna, etc. like the Amber Room. The walls are covered with amber, mirrors are trimmed with amber, and it is stunning. Of course the beautiful parquet floors and china and furniture in other rooms are beautiful too, but the Amber Room is amazing. Not all the rooms have been restored, but what has been restored is worth it.The cafeteria is not what you would expect in a palace but it is fine for a cafeteria.We took a minibus from St. Petersburg (first the subway, then the minibus). We went back the palace and had to walk back (as did a couple of other tourists). So if you take the subway/minibus route, much cheaper than going by tour, see if some person on the bus can tell you where to get out for Catherine Palace. There is a line-up for Palace, but it moves along. Grounds are pleasant too.

A unique place you should not miss. This restored palace was one of the first stops on our tour of the city, and was very worthwhile. Russia has done a great job restoring this building, and it has some rather unique things to see, namely the Amber Room. You have to fight the crowds, but that is expected, so just roll with it and enjoy the palace and the surrounding grounds.

Royal Review. The Restoration is valuable not only for its aesthetic value but for recalling the war history that made it necessary. Loss of life can not be restored. Across the road in Alexander's Park a sleigh ride through the forest can provides a reflective memorial to the loss of lives which can not be restored

Excellent palace!. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit here in December 2012. Would recommend anyone visiting in the winter - it was so quiet we almost had it to ourselves. All the rooms were available to us, which is not usually the case. The decor is fascinating and astonishing to see. Pity you cannot take photos in the amber room, but I suppose they have to make money selling you a picture (10RUB - which was not that expensive for a post card). Would recommend as a must see attraction on a St Petersburg visit.

A number one attraction. Must see to compare with the world's other grand palaces. The furnishings are great and timeless. Remarkable achievement given its time in history. It will be crowded though and you have to keep moving but worth it.
fabulous palace. Another fabulous palace on the must see list. There was a small wait to get in but the tour was fantastic once we got going.

A must see. We were overwhelmed by the beauty of the Catherine Palace. As soon as you see it, your breath is taken away by just how spectacular it is. The rooms that have been renovated are just beautiful and your attention is constantly caught by something new. I got a real sense of what it must have been like during the time of the Tsars. The Amber room is just wonderful. The grounds are also truly beautiful and surprisingly serene considering the amount of visitors. Anyone visiting Saint Petersburg needs to see the Catherine Palace.

Wow - what a place. You will be amazed when you learn that the Germans tried to destroy this amazing palace during WWII - and when you see what it looks like now. Imagine you are Catherine hosting a beautiful ball. Wish I had a time machine and was a guest their during her reign. Every room is more beautiful than the one before. Such a beautiful palace - don't miss seeing it.

Very impressive. The queues were huge but we somehow avoided all and squeezed inside thanks to our guide Inna, interiors surpassed our expectations, especially amber room. The park was nice, but we liked the one in Petershof more, anyway both sights are worth seeing.

Opulence. Another absolutely gorgeous palace. These monarchs didn't stint on their comfort. The Baroque throne room, the State Dining Room, the artwork -all just outstanding. This trip was taken after lunch which seems to be standard as we had the similar meals for two days. As a side note, a shot of vodka and Russian champagne was served at both meals. Different but thats why you travel to other places.

Marvellous Palace and lovely park. Althought the visit was in November, the palace was reasonably filled with tourists. It is one of the most beautifully decorated palaces I've been to. The most famous part of it is the Amber room, which is decorated with several tons of this precious stones. The tickets include free Russian speaking guide. From the park you can see the whole beauty of the Catherine Palace and have a walk in a very lovely decorated park.

Long lines. Buy a guided bus tour to escape waiting in line. Long lines to enter for individual visitors. I recommend to buy an escorted bus tour to get in fast and have a guided tour throughout the complex

Simply remarkable. I didn't get much time inside but I did visit the newly opened Amber room which was simply fantastic. I did however get time to walk all over the park, which was fantastic... so many sights to see, from monuments to houses to tree lined paths... each step and corner turned seemed to reveal a new breath taking scene. I was lucky to visit in November and could count on one hand the amount of people I came across... to feel like your all alone in such a beautiful and historical site was amazing.  If you get a chance to go, I would suggest staying in Pushkin overnight so that you can take in all the city has to offer. There are some nice shops, restaurants & a few hotels in the town... I'd highly suggest spending a full day here. If you opt to go back and forth from St. Pete, the train is very reliable, quick and cheap.

No time for park but beautiful palace. Took a bus tour of this palace so I couldn't see the park but I got to see the interior which was beautiful. Even though there are signs about not being able to take photos, they didn't enforce it except in the amber room.

Catherines amazing wonderland. This palace is a major highlight when visiting St Petersburg. The rooms are breathtaking and the detail is incredible. A key to enjoying this experience is to have your own private guide and not be part of a large group. This is becuase the guide will provide you with extensive detail on the history of the palace, ensure you don't need to queue up for admission tickets and funnel you past large tour groups. The grounds at Catherine's palace are beautifully manicured and you need to spend time in the garden to see how it has been beautiful planned around getting views of the palace from the garden and from the palace to the garden. The palace has been maintained to the highest standard and is the equal of any palace you would visit in the world. The Amber room which has been restored is simply brilliant and this palace is a very imporatant piece of Russian history. You must see it when in St Petersburg

Greatest Insult Ever: Catherine's Summer Palace-St Petersberg. Catherine's Summer Palace in St. Petersberg: While enjoying this Must See attraction, the Costumed Characters gave us a huge insult by turning their back and literally walking away when I turned my camera toward them. Recognizing it was customary to tip those in Costume, I was prepared and had a tip in my pocket. Obviously, their custom is to receive the tip first before providing the photo opportunity. In this instance, they lost and we lost. This really dampened our appreciation of the Russian people and all the effort put into the restoration and maintenance of this incredible historic and beautiful palace. This attitude alone knocked the Overall Rating down one point to a four. All of the other people were gracious and helpful. With that being said, Catherine's Summer Palace is a MUST SEE when visiting St. Petersberg, Russia. The extensive and outrageous use of gold covering is just stunning. The craftsmanship of all the ornamentation is all of the rooms is something to behold. Clearly a fantastic example of the difference between the Have's and the Have-Nots, at least the Have's did pay the artisans and craftspersons and provided work for the Have-Not's.Great care is taken to preserve this restoration. We attended on a rainy day and had to put on clean room footwear to protect the wood floors from deterioration due to the water tracked in.Security is very high-tech. Photography is not permitted in one of the rooms. When sensors detect a flash, or security sees a person using a camera, they are very quick to respond. We heard stories of the violator having to delete ALL images on their camera. That's a pretty high price to pay for not observing the rules.Bottom line: An excellent attraction to experience. We had our 8 & 18 yr old grandkids with us. The tour was short enough that they enjoyed it.Very educational.

Can't see why it is still popular after all that they've done this summer!!!!. The reason I give only one point is because of a terrible management. They are not interested in tourists at all. They treat you like a cattle. Two hours in line outside, a battle in the wardrobe, and a tour which is given on a level of a schoolchild repeating a boring lesson. If you are coming with a group - be ready that they'll show you the door, telling you have no appointment!!!! That's the only management effort they take. Something has to be done about it.

Awesome to behold -Catherine Palace and Park. Catherine's Summer Palace and Park, in St. Petersburg, Russia - is Rococo in style, from it's lavish exterior, to dominating main staircase, but my favorite was the magnificent golden mirrored ballroom. Having a personal, knowledgeable guide made our experience smooth and delightful. She was a jewel at getting us in quickly, to helping us navigate the crowds and explore the interior in detail.
Absolutely stunning. splendour on splendour. A stunning palace in an incredible estate. Amazing what can be done with a few thousand peasants and half an army. Trip was too short

Huge Ornate Palace with gold gilded rooms. This is a huge palace. So much history. Each room is full of gold gilded trim, detailed wall designs, and formal ornate furniture. Before entering you have to put brown booties over your shoes. We toured with palace while on a tour with TJ Tours. We arrived on a cruise ship.

Not to be missed. If you wish to visit this most interesting palace, with the beautiful Amber Room, I would suggest hiring a guide and going by car so you can see things at your own pace. We were able to see the palace in the morning, but due to the number of summer tourists there were 2 paths, and we could only see one path with our ticket, so we could not see everything. Sort of a lotteryfor which path you are given. But at least we were not shuttled through as fast as the groups. We also enjoyed a stroll through the park, and used the audio guide for a visit to the beautiful Turkish Baths (separate admission ticket). There were many souvenir stalls outside, but our guide Sergei advised against buying from them. Overpriced. He did take us to a cafe where we could buy blinis ( russian pancakes) for a cheap and quick lunch as we walked the 10-15 minutes over to Alexander Palace. This was more interesting to me as it is less formal and fascinating to see where the last Tsar and his family lived. Also a chance to walk over to the lovely chapel that Nicholas had built nearby. Don't miss going underneath to the private room where Alexandra went to pray everyday. Then we still had time to drive to Pavlovsk to see Paul's palace.

a true beauty. this palace brings you back to the "good old days" of Catherine the Great and gives a pretty good idea of what kind of person she was. Take also the time to walk around in the parc surrounding the palace

No wonder the peasants revolted. Wow and double wow is about the best I can do to describe Catherine Palace. This place, commissioned by Empress Elizabeth, was so lavish that it even took Catherine the Great aback when she ascended to the throne (by maybe icing her husband) and had a look at the books.The royal gilders were in the process of covering the statues and exterior in gold when Catherine the Great said, "Nyet!" but not before whole ballrooms were clad in gold. The grand Gold Ballroom has enough bling for the entire NBA roster.No wonder the Russians revolted against the perceived excesses of the Romanovs, who truly were the 1%. Or probably more like 1% of the 1%. But 21st-century tourists are the beneficiaries of this aristocratic excess. Catherine Palace, with its beautiful collections, is stunning in its details.The Nazis had headquarters here during their 872-day siege of Leningrad during World War II. When they left, the palace was in shambles and 70,000 trees in the surrounding park had been cut. Almost immediately after the war, the Russians set about restoring the palace, meticulously putting back together the pieces and re-creating from photographs such spaces as the Amber Room (the Germans dismantled the room and the original amber mosaics have never been found). As we were part of a Seabourn cruise tour group, we were able to go into the palace early, which was fantastic. We had the place to ourselves for a while. And our tour guide Marina was simply the most remarkable tour guide. She looked right out of Central Casting but her knowledge was voluminous and her English spotless.Even the drive out to Tsarskoye Selo from St. Petersburg is interesting and often beautiful. I don't know exactly what I was expecting from Russia but I know it wasn't anything as spectacular as this.

100% great!. The Catherine Palace and park is wonderful. Beautiful approach and wonderful building lines. The restored buildings (WW2 damaged) are a pastel blue shade and dominate the landscape.A very busy tourist destination and the best exhibit ( the Amber Room) amazing. This historic room once gifted to Peter the Great from Prussia( 1716), was stolen by the Nazis in WW2. The room we visit today is a recreation completed in 2003, with again, -assistance from Germany. The original Amber room contents remain missing, perhaps still buried in Europe.As you walk through the rooms, pictures are on display of that rooms conditionat the end of the war. How lucky we are to have had influental people to make Palaces and collections such as this and how fortunate we are to have saved them for all civilisations.

A highlight of St Petersburg. Recently re-furbished and re-gilded, this Palace loses nothing but size in comparison with Versailles. The rooms and artworks are stunning, and can be seen in an hour or so. Don't miss it.

Stunning. Enormous. Just Wow.. This palace is still being renovated since I first saw it in 1990! Gold leaf is being applied to exterior trims but the inside is beautifully restored. You need to get tickets in advance to save time, and plan to spend a lot of time to see the large park.

We saw some squirrels. This was definitely the highlight of St P. for me. The building was amazing, and so were the ground but the most amazing part of this place was that the Nazis destroyed over 90% of if when they left and the Russian government is spending a fortune to get it restored to its previous grandeur. The care and national pride that is being restored here was so lovely to see. This museum had stricter rules than previous museums, we had to have plastic cover slips over our shoes and there was no photography at all. We had to be in a state of motion the whole time, we weren't meant to stop and spend a lot of time in front of one exhibition. The grounds to the palace were immense, there was so much to see. A lot of birds and squirrels were all around and the amount of fun water features could have provided entertainment for hours. There are parts of the ground where if you stepped on the wrong stone water would spurt out at you, or to get to the only seats you had to run through a waterfall. A lot of humour went into the gardens. The gardeners tool shed is bigger than my 4 bedroom house too!

Amazing reconstruction. A wonderful day out from the city. Amazing to realise that the fairy tale palace and stunning interior have been totally reconstructed after virtual destruction during WW2. The photographs of restoration work were fascinating. The palace itself is very busy with tour groups but we did not feel rushed.The park is a delight. We were there on a beautiful day with the trees just changing colour. The 'toytown' band at the entrance is a hoot!
Must be seen!!!. Amazing palace and grounds that sought to outdo the best in Europe and succeeds in many ways - book ahead to ensure access

easily doable on your own. from ploshcahd vosstaniya metro station, we got down at the 2nd station on the red line..pushkinskaya... crossed over to vietbisky station... we went up to the 1st floor, passed through many halls and got on to the platform to get to the counter to buy the ticket... this was the difficult part.. we bought obratno.. return ticket to Pushkin... detskoe selo is the real name of the station and the town is tsarskoe selo but pushkin can get us through... we had printed out some schedules from the www. tutu.ru site links...so it was easy too get down at the right station... then bus 371, 382 or minibus taxi 371, 377, 382 were our options to the Catherine Palace and Park... a lady guided us to get down at the correct stop... yekaterinisky dvorets... individual visitors time to visit the palace is from 12 noon to 2, then 4--6...we had though of buying the tickets and going on to Pavlosk before returning here but the officials were issuing tickets only at 12.... bad waste of time but we stood in the queue as we did not want to lose our early bird advantage...loved the palace, toured inside for 2 hours, then roamed the gardens for another hour before deciding to go on to Pavlosk... the paid toilets were a relief to use after our peterhof experience of stinky portatoiletsall in all a fantastic experience, not to be missed... the tour groups were hurrying through the sights... it was great to do it at our own pace relishing it all
Beyond Belief. The Amber Room was fabulous, the other rooms in the palace were highly decorated and very opulent. The Ball Room's ceiling was an enormous work of art.

Another beautiful palace. St Petersburg has no shortage of amazing palaces that they have so impressively preserved and this is no exception. The grounds at this location are also extraordinarily beautiful

The most spectacular. This has to be the best palace to visit in Russia - gorgeous in blour Bucket listue, white and gold with the beautifully laid out gardens, beautiful interiors and the wonderful Amber Room.This should be on y
Breathtaking. Nicely restored, gold was almost blinding, history and culture well presented by local guides, go early to avoid some of the crush of the crowds,

That is a lot of gold!. An amazing restoration, completed in such a short time. The rooms on show were very impressive. Quite a lot of tour groups as it is a popular attraction. Would be easy to spend an entire day here as there is a lot to see.

Touring splender in the rain. What a wonderful experience in touring Catherine's splendor. Loved it. Great photo opportunities. The only Amber Room I have ever seen. Even the picture frames are of Amber.
Incredible Opulence. Beautiful, opulent and incredibly rich palace. Beautiful grounds and Tchaikovsky's original Swan Lake. The Amber Room is a must see.

Unbelievable. This was unbelievable and one of the #1 attraction in Russia. (there are many #1 attractions in this unbelievable country.)Take the metro to Moskovskaya and then take the bus that says Puskin, Catherines Palace across the top. It leaves every 10 minutes and takes 30 minutes to get there.. A great day trip.

Part of a Day Tour. We went to the Catherine Palace as part of a full day tour from a cruise ship. It was spectacular arriving and seeing the Palace and a band was playing near the steps as we entered. We had to wear overshoes which they supplied. It was raining the day we were there so the walks around the gardens weren't as pleasant as they should have been. The inside of the Palace was amazing BUT after you have seen the 10th room all decorated in gold and white the novelty wears off a bit! It just seemed to highlight the excesses of the time when some people had too much and others not nerly enough. We found each group was only allowed a few minutes in each room then the Russian attendants would growl at the guide and we would have to leave. We had lunch in the restaurant on the premises which was a very crowded room and very ordinary food was supplied. We were glad we saw it but we made the mistake of doing Catherine Palace and Peterhof on the same day and it was too much. Maybe just choose one!

excellent. I am writing to give you an update on out trip. My wife and I enjoyed the trip to Europe and the cruise. The cruise was perfect. The off-shore trips in Tallinn, St. Petersburg, and Helsinki were all perfect, in terms of length and also for all the amenities and services. THe tour guides were very knowledgeable. The best was a young man in St. Petersburg, called Dimitri. This person is extremely well prepared and very good in meeting the needs of the clients. My wife and I, he two of us, had him with a minivan and driver for ourselves. The day was planned brilliantly. Others who took the ship's tours had to wait for as much as 45 minutes to get on the coach with 30 people. We took 5 minutes to clear the port and on our way. WE will recommend to anyone.So, thank you very much for everything.

Not too far from metro station, worth a day trip. I was contemplating to visit Peterhof but I heard that the fountains may have stopped and with the lack of time (it's a slightly longer and more expensive trip to get there), I chose to visit Catherine Palace @ Tsarskoe Selo/Pushkin instead. It was not difficult to catch a minibus/marshrutka from the Moskovskaya (Моско́вская) metro station and similarly to get back as the buses run quite regularly. To go there, I took K545 @ 35rubles and it took about 20min.. to make sure, you can simply ask the driver if he goes to Tsarskoe Selo (or point a picture of the palace!). I was lucky I had a passenger who helped remind me to get off at the next main stop and the bus driver equally waved me to the front to get off at the right stop. You can't see the palace outright, you have to take a right turn and then you will see it. It's about a 7minute walk or so towards it. Going back is easier as the buses put big signs of the station that they will be driving to, at their windows. **Tip is, the marshrutka can be in the form of a passenger van or a big bus and although they have designated bus stops, they will still stop if flagged by the street.. and when that happens, you can't really depend to count the number of stops as a measure to know when to get off.You have to pay 100rubles entrance fee which gives you access to the park grounds and an additional 320rubles to enter the interior palace itself to visit the rooms. Anyway, I arrived in time to join a group who was going to be brought into the palace so I didn't have to wait. We had to slip on these sleeves around our shoes to protect the floors and do note that the audio guides given free over the counter are only in Russian. Slipping away from the group once inside, I could go around at my own pace and overheard a few personal guides explaining to small groups and couples in English.. so I believe you can request for their services if required.Apparently no photography is allowed in the Amber Room. All the other rooms are still ornate and interesting enough to keep your finger trigger-happy on your camera though esp if it was your first time visiting this type of palace... and since I am still experiencing the beautiful fall weather, the walk around the palace and park grounds was simply amazing. It was easy to lapse into a daydream-like mode like a royalty strolling along the streams, beautiful autumn-hued trees and passing by various smaller structures scattered around the area (it's a huge area btw)To me it was worth the trip if you have a day to spare and a lovely complement to the Hermitage (which in true St Petersburg fashion, is another grand building as well, packed with more goodies of course)

Catherine's. Also elegant and lovely. This woman had exquisite taste. Loved everything. It is amazing the colors, the size of it all. We were constantly wondering how they got all of these beautiful things there.

Only amber room. Only Amber room is something awesome. The rest of Palace is really boring. Gold... gold... gold... gold... gold... Park is really nice and it is worthy to spend some time just walking around :)
Amazing. The grounds are beautiful. The palace is beautiful. The interior is wildly extravagant and worth seeing. The Amber Room is breathtaking and the Green Dining Room is particularly interesting.

Even more Beautiful than the Hermitage. Extraordinary rooms full of magnificent furnishings. Beautiful grounds. Everything about it is a must see. Unfortunately, most tours take you through too quickly but it was wonderful.

From German princess of a small area to one tough empress.. Did not like knowing all this gold came from the labor of 100's of thousands of serfs. Did love seeing the magnificence of her choices. Wouldn't want her for a mother either, having had her son build his house next door. Worth a trip to both palaces. Mother and son.

The size of this Palace is unbelievable. We made our way out to the Palace on the undergound to Moskovskaya ploschad & then a minibus - as described on the official website. Its the cheapest option and takes about an hour in total. It also means you can see the Victory Monument just near the station too (well worth it).The Palace is huge and has to be seen to be believed. The grounds are beautiful too and there are many outbuildings to see. As with Peterhof you have to pay to go in the grounds, palace and all other building seperately so it can get expensive. Its worth walking to Alexandra Palace in the grounds too.

How to get to Catherine Palace without a tour. We found it quite daunting trying to work out how to get to Catherine Palace using public transport, from St Petersburg without joining a tour group that would get us there as well as being out of season.We went on the 12 October 2012. We just went as a couple. First we went to the Vitebsk Station in St Petersburg. You buy your ticket from Platform 3 which is upstairs in the main station. It is a very small ticket booth, tucked away behind the fast food outlet just before you go through the gates to the platform. It appears the ticket sellers are used to English speaking tourist - they hold up an english written set of instructions (e.g. go up the stairs) so don't be afraid to ask. Ask for a return ticket (they will offer it). It was 140R return for both of us. Walk through the scanning gates using your ticket. Platform 2 and 3 should get you there - ask general public (just show your ticket). You need to count the stations off - or like we did - time it 30 minutes as you can't understand the train announcements and there is no signage on the train. If you are observant there are kilometre signs at each train station. You get off at the 23/24th (?) kilometre mark. There is a stop at 21 km - get off at the next one. Be aware that there will be street sellars on the train. They are no problem - they don't bother you. They do there sell to the cabin and move on. The trains are old and clunky but get you there!Get off. You have an option of catching a bus. That costs about 50 R a couple. We got on one that said Palace and Parks and ended up in the middle of nowhere - Alexander Palace. Drivers and general public whilst being more friendly than the city are less confident with thier English. On the way back after our visit we just skipped the bus part, and walked to the train station. It takes roughly 30 minutes walk. You walk through the town of Pushkin which is a lovely little town. To walk FROM the train station - Walk out of train station. There is a round-about there. Take 2nd right which is Leningrad Skaya Ulitsa. Walk down it for 500 m. At 1st set of lights turn left. Walk up Oranshereynaya Ul ('up' the hill) on great footpaths - about 1.5 km. You will the park of the Catherine Palace and you can't go any further. Turn right and walk about 200 m to buy your tickets to the park (you have to pay to get into the park before you pay to get into the palace). The Palace is definately worth the trip. Similiar to Peterholf in size - beautifully restored. You can enter as an individual between 12 and 2pm. You go in as a group with a tour guide that speaks Russian - once in go on your merry way and explore as you wish. The gardens are magnificent and quite large. The cafe was very basic. If it was Summer I would strongly suggest a picnic in the gorgeous grounds. All up we spent about 1 hour in the palace and an hour looking through the gardens. Costs about 320 R each to get into the palace.It is worthwhile making the effort. Good luck!!
Fantastic. This was just so well worth the vist. All those rooms with just amazing different furniture and decorations. And the Amber Room was just spectacular.

More local than Peterhof. The last beautiful weekend of the year and the park was flooded with locals - taking pictures, collecting multicoloured autumn leaves, walking around the ponds.Very few tourists to be seen, not even in the palace. But lots of very big Russian tourgroups did spoil the view in the palace every once in a while. Luckily, one no longer has to join a tourgroup to view the palace. The audio guide gives sufficient info to enjoy the rooms on your own. The money spent on the audio guides was well spent, too well as the narration went on and on and on and on with all the details of a room.

Grand & Extravagant!. Loacted outside Saint Petrsburg, in Pushkin - the palace, park and water bodies are a study of things Grand and Opulent! It certainly gives a good idea of the extravagant life-style of the Russian rulers. A must visit with a time frame of 3 to 6 hours.
Highlight of my trip. I just loved this palace, so much history behind it! Everything about it was breathtaking from the gardens to the mirrored rooms.

FROM ASHES. Try not to miss the photograph collection of how this building was left by the Nazis after the WWII seige, and perhaps wonder as we did, that the magnificent restoration was planned and executed by the Soviet authorities.

Magnificent Palace and Grounds. You must go by hydrofoil !! Arrive at the pier and immediately your looking at the palace in background. So easy on the eye, golds and blues and excellent gardens. The main feature fountains are splendid and these work at differing pressures over about a 10 minute period. They are purely pressure driven by water taken from the resevoir at rear of palace.....no pumps!Interior of palace rich and colourful.....and the pictures in garden of how the Germans left the Palace after the war are pretty unbelievable. Renovations was really worth it...a memorable day.

Lots of glitz. Loved it all. It's a little way out of the city but well worth the trip. We managed to do this and Peterhof in a morning on a private guided tour; the cruise excursion took most of the day

Interesting palace. Superb exterior - similar in style to the Hermitage - not surprising, since designed by the same architects. Wonderful mirrored hall. And Delpht inspired stoves in the corners of may of the rooms.

JUST GO...PERIOD!!!. We visited Catherine's Palace as part of a customized 3 day DenRus tour...(you might want to see my review on DenRus as well...great experience and cheaper than ship excursions) Since we were on a tour of 3 people, we went straight to the head of the line and bypassed the crowds...even in middle September. Once we were inside, the crowds spread out. I have never seen such opulence! So much gold leaf! She really knew how to decorate! ;-)The history of the palace is also interesting. The Nazis basically lived here and destroyed it during WW2. They removed the amber, and to date, no one knows where it is. The Amber Room, which was unbelivable, was completely restored...every square inch of amber covered the walls.The photos of the times during WW2 were interesting as well.Take time to visit this place...we found it much more interesting than her husband's Peterhof Palace.

Another MUST-SEE attraction.. Bearing in mind the total devastation left by the German army in World War 2, the restoration of this palace beggars belief. Words cannot describe the sheer magic of the place. No visit to St. petersburg would be complete without a visit to the palace
A really nice park. We sat and had some ice cream in the park but Catherine was too busy posing to join us. A lovely place to sit and relax in the sun.

wonderful palace. very different and very interesting from Peterhof and the Hermitage. every Czar had different things they liked and disliked and with a good guide, the stories are excellent as well.

The World's Bling in one building. All that glitters really is gold in this palace, plus amber and painted Chinese silk and Wedgewood...and every excess that money and power could buy, now a museum for everyone to savour.
Great place to sit & relax. This is a small well kept park where you can sit & relax; do 'people watching' both day and night as the opera theater. is situated near one end of the park

A flamboyant Rococo style Palace.. Apparently more than 100 kilograms of gold were used to gild the sophisticated stucco façade and numerous statues erected on the roof. It was even rumoured that the palace's roof was constructed entirely of gold.It was mostly destroyed in WW II and is been vastly restored in 2003. You don't notice but the palace is not as glorious as originally was. However, this is a must go place.

Well worth a visit. The grounds and building are stunning to look at. Inside the detail, gold and art are breath taking. I was surprised it was all reconstructed having been destroyed in WW2. The amber room was underwhelming in comparison to the huge rooms elsewhere in the palace. I confess here that I'm not a fan of amber which just looks like hard toffee to me. Prehaps because the room is covered in amber my brain just doesn't take it in. The down side is the queues, which were huge and you shuffled through the palace tour after tour. Well worth it though.
Amazing place, never seen one like this place.. I have travelled in a lot of palaces, but this one top it all. So So amazing the way they build and decorate during that time.

Catherine's Palace. Another beautiful palace. Though it is still in a restoration mode--third floor--there is plenty to see and imagine people living in this beauty. The gardens are not as intense as Peterhof, but they are very nice.

Amazing. I have been amazed at the opulance showing how these palaces have been restored. One room in this palace the gold room, cost $129 million dollars and has 15tons of 22crt gold leaf. The whole palace is enormous, but only the middle part has been restored. The whole palace is amazing.

Evening at Catherine's Palace. We had the choice of attending an evening at Catherine's Palace from our cruise ship. We considered it for a while as it was quite expensive but we are so glad we decided to do it. There were 100 -150 people in total and we were divided into small groups to do a tour of the palace after we had been greeted by band and given vodka and canapes. To be able to take time and visit all the rooms in a small group was wonderful -we were even allowed photographs in the Amber Room. Then it was into the Great Hall for champagne and to listen to a small orchestra and watch some period dancing. Afterwards we went outside where the band was playing and more dancing then we had a tour of the Carriage House which my husband really enjoyed. Would recommend you do this if you can

Catherine really is great. The palace is still being restored from damage in WWII. The 40 state rooms that have been restored are stunningly beautiful. The Amber Room has been recreated and is a highlight of the tour. Be sure to include the park around the palace with many pavilions and spaces to see.

The maddest place I have ever seen. Compared to this place, Versailles is a poor people's place! This is the utmost example of human madness once you have lost all sense of perspective. I have never seen anything so magnificent in my life (you may include Versailles, Madrid, Rome, Florence, the Taj Mahal, Beijing...) but this beats everything.One can only feel anger at this extreme juxtaposition of richness and poorness: the extremely rich spending enormous amounts of money on their palaces, while on the other hand the poor literally starved. No wonder they had a bloody revolutation over there

a close 2nd to Peterhof, another must see. the gardens are amazing, the palace is even more amazing. you can be over-loaded in SP but these are all must see and must experience. spent 5 days in SP and that wasn't enough.

Wow!!!!. We had about an hours ride to Catherine's Summer Palace.It reminded me of Versailles. Make sure you have a private guide to go straight in and avoid the crowds. Maria from SPB tours was wonderful and she talked about the history of each room. She took us in a side door and very few people were around. The ball room and the Amber room were amazing. I never knew there was so many different colors of Amber. We also walked the gardens. They were beautiful but not as impressive as Peterhof gardens.

Must see, Amazing, Breath Taking. The Most Beautiful Palace I ever saw, recommend the most Amber room, magnificent work of art. I am glad Amber room has been returned back to Catherine Palace, the place it has its origins, after World War II, that dark period of Russian history. The pictures are prohibited in the Amber room due to obvious reasons. Loved the garden, gorgeous. If you planning to visit St. Petersburg, the Catherine Palace is absolutely top of the list.There is that pancake place right after you pass the market, there are no much space but pancakes are one of the best I ever tried.
Stunning. What a beautiful place, go with a guide who can tell you about the history.The colour and the gold finish on the outside of the palace is so well kept.

Best one day trip from Saint-Petersburg.. I grew up in Pushkin, so I am very well familiar with the area. In my opinion Catherine Palace is one of the most worthwile places to visit. Also have a stroll in the town afterwards to Gostinii Dvor and to newly rebuilt Saint. Catherine Cathedral.

A beautiful place with an unusual memory. We were able to visit Peterhof on a Sunday. We stayed a day longer than our tour provided to see the Catherine Palace and Pavlovsk (on a Monday with Marina Wilson tours). There were similarities among the three places. Each was spectacular in their own way. If one had unlimited time one could and probably should devote a day to the buildings and grounds. The amber room was somewhat different than one might expect. Ironically my most vivid memory of our visit occurred in the Grotto. There was a small, six man a cappella choir performing as a way to sell there CDs. There is no way to describe adequately how their voices sounded in the building. They literally made the building ring with their voices. The acoustics were truly phenomenal. I bought a CD recorded elsewhere, it is good but nothing could match their performance in the Grotto building.

A breath taking , gilded palace and grounds that are unparalleled.. One may read about the opulence of this Tsar complex of Palace and park, but one has to see it to be believed. The trip out on the metro and then bus to the park and palace in Pushkin is easy and inexpensive. Once there , it is only a short walk to the corner of the incredible palace. One can not believe the opulence of those times and the gilded, ornate exterior and then the interior rooms. The grand ball room is beyond description. This is truy a Must See if one visits the St Petersburg area and a one day side trip to remember.

Absolutely beautiful!. Very interesting and nice place! It is not easy to reach however. You must know that you to take the train and then a bus or you can walk but it is far from the train station. It is one hour from Saint Petersburg. Tours and independent visitors can only go at sometimes. You need to have your tickets reserve. They are not easy to get. This palace is better to do it with a tour. You cannot spent more than tow houes inside the palace. You can take pictures but not in amber room. The palace is stunning. The gardens are also very nice!

Don't Miss It. What a special morning. The ride from St. Petersburg was interesting and the palace and grounds are so beautiful. To think that the German completely destroyed this palace at the end of the war and the people have lovingly restored it. A true tribute to the people of Russia.

Unmissable. The interior of the Catherine Palace is just mind blowing in its opulence (and the vast size of the palace). The golden rooms seem to stretch forever. The gardens are ok but no where near the size and quality of the Peterhof. A map /guide of what the various buildings are will prove helpful.We did an English language tour through Electica - Departing from outside the Gostiny Dvor on Nevsky Prospect and would certainly recommend them for this tour.

Inside the palace. Well they do like to make you queue in dear old Russia. They also have a weird system of one person queues while the others sit in the cafe. They then turn up and just walk in front of you. Every one accepts this as 'normal'.Got there by tube, train and bus- total cost about £3.00. Loved the journey as we went from the deepest underground to a very CCCP style train and then a normal commuter bus. No one spoke English but a lot of people tried to help by pointing where we needed to go and telling us when to get off. They all seemed to know why we where there.The mad rush for tickets is bizarre as everyone gets in. You are only allowed in as part of a guided tour. The place is huge and stunningly beautiful. We just kept swapping tour groups as it was all in Russian so it didn't matter to us. No one was bothered so we had a leisurely look at everything. Loved it.

One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. This palace looks to be several hundred yards long. To think it was built for a few weeks visit in the summer. Gold leaf everywhere and words cannot describe it. Unfortunately on an excursion you only get to stay for little over an hour. I thought it was actually more impressive than The Hermitage. It is in the country and the grounds were really something. Please know that if you are on a cruise, Catherines palace,Summer palace, and trip to Pushkin are all the same. Pictures--they charge you $4 but everyone was taking them at will and nobody was checking--It was much too crowded to do so. The matrons in each room looked like they were asleep anyway. A must see if you are in port.

Amber room is a must to visit. Catherine's Palace is another great example of Russian history and heritage. It was amazing to walk through all the rooms and corridors and listen to all the historical events that took place. Amber room is definitely a draw card to all. Make sure you visit with a tour guide; you really need someone knowledgeable to point out key things to see and explain, otherwise there is way too much to take in.
Visited as part of a tour with Alla. Once again our guide got us through the queues and straight in. An opulent palace, really stunning the amber room was amazing

the summer residence of the Russian tsars. Just 20-25 km away from St. Petersburg, this palace is the summer residence of the Russian tsars, located in the Pushkin's town. The palace with the town deserves a half day visit with its major highlights as; the ballroom, the Palace Chapel, the agate rooms of Catherine II and definitely the famous amber room. After finishing the Palace, you can enjoy a peaceful walk in the scenic Pushkin's town.

Vision of Delight. We went on a brief afternoon tour of this palace and park, it is beautiful...of course, when you think about it you can begin to understand the vast difference between the haves and have nots, but all the same, one cannot help but be amazed at how wealthy some of the population was. It was amazing....

Reconstructed Grandeur in a Quaint Town. I was able to visit the Palace as part of a small tour group.The times and place of entrance to the palace is different for a tour than for the general admission, so I cannot offer advice on how to enter independently. The beautiful blue/white building is stunning to view, even before you walk through the entrance gate.There was a band playing "where the Volga flows", and "The Viennese Waltz" to keep us entertained prior to us being admitted.I was there the first week of September and it was packed with guided tours . Kind of felt like being herded like cattle. We were permitted to take photos, unlike at Peterhof. The Amber room was not permitted to be photographed.The Palace is a recreation of the original, as the Germans had destroyed it during the occupation. Some of the items are original, but many are copied replacements.You may see a lot of gold when you look at the rooms, but we were told that the gold gilded decorations were actually carvings made from local lime trees and then covered with gold dust. Only 1.5 kg of gold per room. That's kind of amazing in itself.The drive to this Palace is just past the airport. The area looked beautiful to stroll around in, but we only went to the Palace as part of the tour.We saw 23 rooms during the tour, each decorated in a unique fashion.I highly recommend visiting, even though it isn't the original building, just to get a taste for how the aristocracy of Russia lived in the 1700's.

Worth the drive!. It is fascinating to hear and see how Russia's royalty lived. This palace is quite different than many we've seen, esp. the Amber Room. Interesting though to realize that we didn't see any washrooms in the private areas!

Another Must See!. If your are in St Petersburg, take this 30 km trip outside the city to see a country palace. Largely decorated by Elizabeth II, daughter of Peter the Great, in Baroque style at its best. The palace is amazing and the gardens are endless. Take your time with this visit if you can.

A bit off the beaten track but don't miss!. Another fabulous must do when in St Petersburg but not easy to get to as it is out of town. Only organized tours are allowed in so don't waste your time trying to get in on your own. The walk up to the Palace is really tacky with a band greeting you playing Yellow Submarine! The walk back from the Palace is equally tacky with a market selling tat. However, don't let this put you off. The Palace is stunning, I have never seen as much gold in my life!

The History, The Palace, a Must See. We were fortunate to have a guide to walk us through (in cute little shoe covers) It is stunning the excess displayed in this palace. The dutch ceramic stoves, the recreations of how the rooms once looked. When you see the photos of how this looked after WWII and compare it to how it was restored, you have true appreciation of the efforts made to protect this national treasure. What was most interesting is that our guide credits the Soviets for making this and many of the other palaces available to the general public.

Amazing Palace!. This palace is absolutely beautiful and well restored! I would say that it was the highlight of our trip to St. Petersburg! There are about 280 acres of parks around the grounds, so you would need at least a day to se it all. You can see just the palace in about an hour though.

Local guide Explains about Catherine. Well obviously we visited many places on our 2 day comprehensive tour of St Petersburg. This one is a definite must see. We entered the palace grounds by gates to the left of the main building and at once were amazed at the size and opulance.Once we entered the main Palace we had a guided tour thru it room by room with detailed explainations. Catherine was some lady with over 42 known Lovers, What an appetite she had.

Another stunning Palace. The size and scale of this building is stunning, gold leaf, amber, dutch ceramic stoves, beautiful wooden floors and marble staircases. The quiet little garden in the centre for Catherine to be alone in. Tsarskoye Selo has to be seen.
Gold, gold, gold. Beautiful, never seen so much gold . Enjoyed the trip to the Paclace- it take you back in time - unbelievable l

GORGEOUS!. This was one of the most magnificent palaces I've ever visited. Tastefully decorated and a "poor cousin" to the palace at Versailles. The Amber room was incredible ... and the only place you couldn't take pictures.

Amber spectacular!. I've seen palaces all over the world, and Catherine's Palace is now one of my favorites. For sheer beauty the AmberRoom dazzles. I loved the delft room heaters and other room decos. Must visit for St. Pete travelers.

The Summer Palace. I always like to see how the super rich lived. This palace was extensively damaged in the Great War. The Russians have been restoring it ever since. I was fasinated by the pictures of the destruction and the efforts by volunteers to restore the palce. It shines with all the gold leaf. The Amber room was recreated from photographs. The original Amber panels have not been found. The palace was crowded and you had to keep moving to get through it.

Beautiful, a must see. This is definitely worth a visit, absolutely Beautiful gardens and stunning Palace. Gold leaf and bling everywhere, amazing how they lived. It's worth the trip out there, allow plenty of time though as the Palace and gardens are Huge.

Rebuilt. This palace was destroyed, burnt to the ground after the Nazis left in defeat after WWII, but with painstaking resolve and determination it was recreated to showcase the amazing wealth of Imperial Russia. The Amber room is a complete recreation, that stuns the mind!

A Russian Versailles. Having visited the Versailles of King Louis near Paris, I couldn't help noticing the similarities of these two palaces. I know that Peter the Great was jealous of King Louis and wanted to "outdo" him....and I'd say he succeeded.
MUST GO. words cant explain how indulgent this building is, if this is the only thing you do in St Petersburg, do it, you will not believe your eyes

Glamour Amber Room. My trip was done in May 2012, but just got the chance to write the review now. The place is stunning and the amber room is amazing. We're using a tour-guide (local one, his name is Alexander, very helpful, knowledgeable, and friendly for Russian standard) so we don't really have to queue much (of which by the way save us a lot of time, since the queue for individual visitor is LONG, esp in the summer time). Overall, it is typical Russian Palace with its splendor, and nice tour to do. Really recommend to do if you're visiting St Pete, and if you're up for some "real Russian transportation mode", better use the public transport to reach the place (with the guide).

Wow, a must see.. Kind of funny the way some of these places have been restored! This is full of gold and more gold leaf, but really stunning. We had a guide which I think is a must for most of these places. We drove in a car and of course did not stand in any lines.
great interior. the tour through the palace was great...lots of lovely furnishings and the rooms themselves were awesome amber room was interesting and very special

Cheapest way to get there: 67R, 1hr 35min. Don't bother with a tour, go there yourself! The easiest way to get there is to take the metro to Moskovskaya (blue line towards Kupchino). Get out of any exit, and then you see a big square with a Lenin statue in the middle. Cross over the square and on the other side there are many minibus taxis. Take number 545 and after about 40min you are at the stop near the palace (ask the driver or an English speaking passanger to tell you when to get off). You just walk for about 3min up the hill and then you are at the "Catherine Park" ticket office. You need to buy a park ticket (100R) to be able to go to the Palace entrance for the palace ticket (320R, audioguide 150R). The entrance/ ticket office for individual tourists is open from 12-14hrs and 16-18hrs only. I arrived early and had to wait (with many others) for over an hour in the pooring rain.I would recommend arrive at/ after 12.20hrs and you can walk straight in- no que! Buy a ticket for an audioguide at the same time as the entrance ticket, and pick it up at the office on the opposite side of the corridor (ask). They take visitors only in groups of 25 people through the palace (with a guide & earpiece- in Russian!). So use your audioguide instead of the earpice and you'll be fine. The park and lakes around the palace are also worth a visit!

Cannot be missed attraction. the beauty of this palace is intoxicating.You cannot look at the ceiling for long as you cannot take in all the designs,carvings paintings and frescoes.A guide is essential to guide you through the palace at your required pace.One has to depute limited time to certain exhibit and the guide makes the right selections.

Worth the trip. We went on our own which is a bit of an adventure using public transportation and requires planning as there are only two times per day that individuals (not part of group tours) are allowed in. I didn;t give it five stars as the crowds are huge and it doesn not handle then as well as the Hermitage does due to the size of the area you are allowed to tour. Also keep in mind that virtually everything you see is a painstakingly recreated reproduction as the Nazis destroyed the original. The gardens and grounds are also spectacular and one should be sure to leave time to walk them.

this place goes on forever. all the rooms were done so beautifully it is hard to think how long and how hard it was back then to build this place. A must is to hire a guide co to take you. there are long lines if you go by yourself.

Beautiful Palace and grounds. This is a must see place in St Petersburg. It is close to Peterhof and you can do both in a day. The grounds are really beautiful with lakes, canals bridges and ponds. Lots of photo ops. The palace itself is really beautiful. Our guide got us to the head of the line as it was quite crowded the day we were there. Inside was really neat and our guide took a lot of time explaining the history of the place. Lots of good photo ops inside as well.

Home of the Amber Room. This is a beautiful palace and the Home of the Amber Room. The tour is filled with room after beautiful room and was skillfully rebuilt after almost being destroyed by the German's in WWII.

Catherine's Palace, Pushkin, Russia. When tourists like myself plop down excessive wads of cash to catch a glimpse of Russia today, the country likes to put its best foot forward. The Hermitage notwithstanding, Catherine the Great had some pretty great digs. Even if you've seen pictures and have a fair idea what to expect, the effect of "way too much" and "over the top" is eye-popping. If you like gold leaf, if you like amber (the semi-precious stone, not the hue), if you like Russian Rococo, the 18th century architecture, turquoise (the hue, not the stone), and decadent ostentation, you're gonna love the summer home of Russia's Empress Catherine II. To appreciate her palace, you need to have some appreciation of Catherine. She was born in 1729 and lived to the ripe old age (for the time) of 67. Though born a commoner, and illiterate all her life, she took to empressing quite well. She ruled Russia with grace, charm, and most of all, enlightened intelligence for the next 34 years. Catherine's Palace, located in the Saint Petersburg suburb of Puskin, is an architectural portrait of Catherine II as vivid as Torrelli's painted posthumous coronation extravaganza. Remodeling and rebuilding upon the efforts of her mother-in-law, Elizabeth, the palace has a decidedly feminine aura, unlike the older Peterhof Palace which seems more masculine. This is especially notable inside both structures. Though the Peterhof Palace is sometimes referred to as the "Russian Versailles," the architectural influence of the French residential confection of Louis XIV is every bit as much evidenced in Catherine's version. Anything that didn't move was liable to receive a layer of gold leaf, an affectation Catherine seems to have acquired from Elizabeth. The palace, its lavish interiors, the well-ordered grounds, the fountains, the statuary, and the lovely shade of turquoise blue we see today is not that of Catherine II. It's all restoration. As with the Peterhof Palace, the Nazis, as they laid siege to Saint Petersburg (then Leningrad) during WW II were not kind to Catherine's creation. By the end of the war, both palaces were bombed out, burned out hulks. Some of their riches had been hidden, even buried on the palace grounds, but Hitler's hoard went out of their way to destroy that which they couldn't carry off. One example, the Amber Room, simply disappeared, never to be seen again. The Russians began restoration immediately after the war and have been working on the project ever since. The Amber Room today is a total, though fairly accurate, recreation. The Russians have lavished millions upon million of rubles upon their restroration efforts, probably as much or more than that which Catherine herself expended. The results are impressive, and along with the Peterhof and the Hermitage, no doubt largely responsible for Saint Petersburg being the number one tourist attraction in all Russia.

beautiful but to much restored. I must say the Russian Ministery of Cultural Heritage has a debatable way of make restoration of historical buildings.They paint with new painting and they often destroy what is under and rebuild as new (like in Summer Gardens).So unfortunatetly the effect sometimes is like Disneyland, like in this case with Catherine Palace, which is beautiful but sounds a bit like fake.

Beautiful Palace and amazing history. Vow, this is another beautiful Russian Palace worth the visit. Inside the palace is full of interesting decorations, beautiful setup etc. It is definitely worth the visit.

A beautiful palace!!!. this is such a beautiful palace both inside and out. I was delighted to see all the renovations taking place and would love to see it again once all the guilding is complete. The furnishing and art help bring you back to the days of the Russian royal family and all the grandure of it's time. it certainly rivals any palace I saw in Europe.

In the little town of Pushkin. This "small" summer palace is about a half-hour's ride out of the city. We were with a private guide; I don't know how the independent English-speaking tourist would manage otherwise. Beautiful rooms, furnishings, gardens and of course the famed Amber Room (no photos in there).

Amazing place. Tsarskoe Selo (Catherine Palace & Park) are even more beautiful in reality as they are in pictures. The restoration has been elaborate and the entire facility including, of course, the Amber Room, are stunning. Get there early and get out of the crowds to the park itself so you can enjoy the outdoors also. Save some time for the many souvenier stands as you head back to your bus, roughly on the north eastern end of the property past the exit gates.

More is More is More. In many ways the apotheosis of Russian Rococo, i.e. if they could gild it, they did.The park is huge (huge!) and lovely, worth a long stroll. Lots of photo ops.We were there in July and the crowds were crushing. But there were timed entries, so time spent waiting in the sweltering sun could be minimized.Many, many bloated tour groups, so be ready to slither through them in the narrow passage ways. Worth the trip outside of St. Petersburg.

Catherine Palace - St. Petersburg. Another must see in St. Petersburg. We arrived at Catherine Palace before it opened and there was already a line. We used Ulko Tours and were glad to have Mariana, our guide, help us negotiate the crushing crowd and purchase tickets. While waiting for the gates to open we used the nice restroom facilities -- they charged to use the restrooms. I didn't have any rubles on me but they were more than happy to accept Euros and US Dollars. When the palace opened the guards opened up one small gate and the huge crowd formed a funnel as we all tried to squeeze through one small gate. The crowd was civil, but no one wanted to give up their space as we literally inched toward the gate. Once through the gate you got in another line with your tour group. Depending on how many were in your tour group depended on where you got in line. There was a pecking order and the tour guides kept each other in check. Our guide told us that If you were a small group you end up getting absorbed into a bigger group for entrance. Then the groups split and travel at their own pace. Once again, being absorbed in to bigger groups going through security and from room to room in the palace. When I thought our line was bad I looked outside and saw everyone in the line on the other side of the palace that were individuals without tour groups. Mariana, our guide, was wonderful. She helped us check our bags and coats and find the restroom. Her commentary on the history of the palace, the art work and the people who had lived there was excellent. After the palace we enjoyed a walk the gardens. There were kiosks in the park selling drinks, ice cream and candy. There was one garden just outside of the palace where, if you stepped off the path on to the grass, there was a guard there that would blow his whistle. I felt this site was a must see and was worth the time, braving the crowds and the guard with the whistle to see.

Catherine Palace. The Catherine Palace is a large palace of staterooms, drawing rooms and living quarters. Its Grand Hall has a spectacular painted ceiling which gives the impression of endless space. One of the main features is the Amber Room which captivates one with the wealth and warmth of the tones. The gardens and parks of the palace are also beautiful.

Catherine Palace and Park. A most amazing interior to this building, so grand and sumptuous to behold. Lots of chandeliers, parquet floors, wall coverings, Gold everywhere, grand staircases etc. Just took your breath away.

Nice drive outside of the city. We enjoyed going outside the city to see more of the country. The location of Catherine Palace was right on the water. Bigger is better. The styles changes through the rooms were really interesting to see. Baroque in one room, China theme in another. The painting and furniture were still in there as well.
Had the bears there!. Nice park!! Had the bears of the world there. Nice green space in the city by the river. Well manicured and shaded

Truly a treasure!. You need to get to Catherine Palace as early as you can, because the lines become long. We were again really amazed at the grandeur. We purchased a book at the palace, and the pictures are such a keepsake.

If you've seen the Hermitage, this is a not anything special. Even the famed Amber Room isn't really anything special. First, there are far to many people wanting to get in. Then, they've changed the schedule so that individuals are allowed in from 12 to 2 and 4 to 6. Groups only from 10 to 12 and 2 to 4. We arrived just after 2 (14:00) and had to wait in line for 2 hours. Fortunately it was a beautiful day. Then they let people in in droves, batching them into groups each with a guide, who speaks into a microphone. Each member of the group, of about 40 people, has a little earset tuned to that group's guide. The guide only talks in Russian, if you only speak a different language, you're out of luck.
