Plus half the earsets in our group didn't work anyway.Luckily we had our own private guide whose headset did work so he could tell what was being said, which wasn't that interesting.The rooms are much smaller than those at the Hermitage, although the building is still HUGE, and strung together like pearls. One or two are splenderfous, the others just very pretty or even rather plain.Then there is the Amber Room. All the amber was stolen by the Germans when retreating in WW II. 10 years ago the German government paid $9 million to replace the stolen amber (the original's whereabouts is unknown) and the Russian government returned some artwork stolen from Germany. All to no great avail. No plans or photos exist of how the room originally looked so they just covered all the surfaces with slices of amber, and built up picture frames of amber, etc. The room is small and not nearly as grandiose as one would think.Coupled with the crushing masses of tourists and the long lines, Catherine's Palace isn't worth the time and hassle, particularly if you've seen The Hermitage, against which it pales in comparison.Actually the best thing about it are the gold cupolas at one end, over the chapel (which isn't on the tour). Not nearly as large as those on full size churches, on a sunny day they are gorgeous.
Catherine's lovers. Our guide told us that the 10-12 men under and around Catherine's statue in the Park where her preferred lovers. An interesting fact...

Wow, just wow!. We got there late in the day, after the tour groups off the cruise ships had left. We were one of the last groups in the door. It is an amazing palace. Perhaps one of the most beautiful I have ever been in. In some ways, I liked it even better than Versailles. Even though the Amber room was redone a few years ago, it is still pretty darn impressive.

Impeccable!. A gift to Catherine 1 from Peter the Great. Most of the credit goes to his daughter, Elizabeth of its magnificent s state of grandeur. It is the summer residence of the Russian Tsars. More than 100 kilograms of gold were used to gild the stucco facade and statues on the roof complimenting the blue and white color of the palace. Noticeable are the blue and white tiled stove in each corner of most rooms. It was once a venue of Elton John's concert and dinner hosted with famous statemen.The most impressive was the amber room. It was originally panelled with amber mosaics from Konigsberg Castle. It was presented to Peter the Great by Friedrich Wilhelm of Prussia as a gift. in 1941, German troops occupied Tsarskoe Selo and dismantled the amber room in 36 hrs. and shipped the amber back to Konigsberg. Restoration of the amber room started in 1982, costs 12M usd, took 20 years to finish.Worth mentioning also is the park. Our tour guide took us for a walk and we had a wonderful time.There is an outdoor cafe where you can stop for lunch or coffee break.Tips: Lines are long, an early start of a guided tour is a must.

Bling Bling. It is a trip out to the country to find this gem. Gold leaf on gold leaf on gold leaf. Sun glasses are recommended. Unlike in the French palaces where courtiers lived with the King, this palace was a family home. Some family. Some home!Worth the drive into the country to enjoy this treasure..

Wonderful building. If you are interested in architecture and opulence, then you must visit Catherine's Palace. Inside there are dozens of rooms. It's quite a way outside St. Petersburg so be prepared to travel about 22km. However, it's well worth the effort.

Beautiful palace and park full of sculptures and pavilions. 325 meters long facade of this palace was created by Rastrelli and is similar to the Winter Palace in nearby St. Petersburg. Entrance fee is charged for park entry and separately for the palace. Independent tourists are admitted only during limited time slots so you need to queue early or take organized tours from St. Petersburg. Excessively embellished amber room is one of the highlights of the palace, which has been painstakingly restored after heavy damage incurred during WWII.

Worth a wedding!. If this park and palace were good enough for the tzars, it's certainly perfect for me. My wife and I got married here, and according to everyone in attendance, this was the most spectacular wedding setup they've ever been to. The pavilion on an island is accessible via rope pulled ferry, and has the best and most romantic music concerts most of the year.
pure gold!!. This was amazing. We couldn't believe this palace, both inside and out. Pictures just don't do it justice. We got to go to the Grotto and hear 6 Russian singers performing folk songs.

Catherine's Palace. Magnificent, elegant palace with literally hundreds of opulent rooms - artwork, gold, and, of course, the amber room. We had to wait to get in, and it was very crowded, but it was spectacular - a must-see.

Magnificent splendor. When you first peer thru the gates at the entrance to this palace you see blue and gold with statues in a brilliant front garden. Enter the palace and there are gold adornments everywhere. A room base on amber. Dining rooms with crockery. Absolutely amazing. The gardens too. Catherine the Great was some smart lady in more ways than just being a leader.Her taste for luxury and the approach she took was remarkable.The palace is outside St. Petersburg, in a suburb now. Ideally do this with a driver and a registered tour guide ..so you get priority entrance otherwise you may have to wait and wait.Great value.

Go with a tour to save you time. After visiting the winter palace, you have to see this summer palace!There are 2 main tour companies offering a half day excursion to Tsarskoye Selo (Catherine Palace): Eclektika and Davranov, both tour kiosks are at the corner of Gostiny Dvor (the biggest shopping mall) on Nevsky Prospect. Tour groups get priority entrance to the palace over individual tourists, although you probably will still need to wait on line, it will be much faster with a tour group.

Palace of Catherine I. Another amazing structure from the time of Peter the Great, Catherine I, and Elizabeth. To see how these rulers lived is jaw dropping. The structures built during their time will simply amaze you.

Stunning property - amazing fountains.. The amazing number of fountains and the fact that they are all gravity-run (no motors or pumps anywhere in the system) make this tour incredible. The grounds are, of course, beautiful and we spent several hours watching the variety of fountains and pools - not to be missed!
unbelievably ornate. Worth the 25km trip. Exterior is gold & blue. Lots of amzing rooms to see inside. Huge grounds with plenty to see

Better than Versailles. This palace has been beautifully restored to all its glory, inside and out. Lots of gold, beautiful art, and the Amber room is just incredible--a whole room walled with different shades of amber.
I usually hate touring mansions and palaces, but this was truly something special and I'd highly recommend it.
Opulence done to the maximum. The grounds were so beautiful and peaceful. Inside you could just imagine the dances and important people of Catherine and Elizabeth's time.

Reconstruction at its best. Destroyed by the Nazis during their retreat in world war 2 a lot of work has gone in to reconstructing this palace. Although the work is ongoing so much has been completed that it leaves little to the imagination of the splendour of this palace. A knowledgeable guide helps explain the history and brings to life the rooms. The Amber room is fantastic and makes the visit. The change in styles as you progress through the building under different empresses is also very noticeable. Imagine what this building will be like when the renovation work is completed!Gardens, bland after the palace

Interesting Story!. It's a very beautiful palace, all the detail show that it was a Lady's palace. Going through different halls and rooms you can imagine its interesting story. The garden with the pools behind the palace is very beautiful too. Enjoyed it very much.

Wonderful History. We enjoyed visiting this palace, our guide had a great knowledge of the history and she escorted us to all the main rooms which were beautifully restored. Art work and original sculptures abound everywhere.The Amber room is a must and was our pick of the rooms.
Absolutely Stunning. This is an amazing palace and gardens. There is so much history and many, many paintings and artifacts. This is a must see when in the St. Petersburg area.Plan to spend the day.

"Just Amazingly Beautiful". The cost that went into this beautiful building! The inlaid flooring was amazing but the gold was everywhere as were beautiful lighting fixtures of all kinds. Interesting to see the very large blue and white heating units to keep the royals warm during the winter. The art work was lovely and interesting to see Catherine in all her glory. The furniture was beautiful to see with all the inlaids of different kinds of wood and other items. In the grand ballroom it was fun to imagine everyone of the time dancing away to the Russian music. The room with all it's mirror's, windows and gold just sparkled! The palace is a must to see.

Catherine Palace - Tsarskoe Selo. In need of an exterior face lift and the interior did not compare favourably with the winter palace at the hermitage where the architectural detail was superb. The Amber room and the Library were nice to look at

Very beautiful with huge queues. Once you get inside, Catherine Palace is simply stunning but the queue outside takes extra mental fortitude to survive. Also thought it was a little bit cheeky to charge for the park entrance when some areas were very clearly not being maintained! Bit of advice - take the gondola ride, it's very relaxing!

Do this before Peterhof and Hermitage. Out of all the sites we went to (including the Hermitage) in St Petersburg Catherine Palace had the longest lines. The restoration of the palace and the rooms are amazing, however a little dull next to the magnificent gardens of Peterhof and the interiors of the Hermitage. We joined a 2 day tour for St Petersburg and went to St Isaac's Cathedral and Catherine Palace on the first day, and the Hermitage and Peterhof on the second. Would recommend this order!

russian opulence. The palace was destroyed during the war and has been restored to grandeur. The photos in the basement detail the palace prior to destruction so, the artisans were able to recreate and restore very close to originality. The gold is as far as the eye can see. The amber room amazing and luxe. A must opportunity to see how "the other half lIved". The gardens are beautiful, not as extensive as Versailles, but still nice. A worthwhile attraction to see when traveling through St Petersburg..
Worth a visit. Had to wat in a queue for 11/2 hours to get in. Restoration very elaborate. those speaking English not well catered for OR are charged a premium for a conducted tour
great. was fantastic, loved the restoration done, make sure you see the before photos in the basement of what the palace looked like just after the war was over

Catherine liked variety. Just touring this Palace as a part of a shore excursion made me want to select my favorite stone and have art pieces created for an entire room. Such is the Amber Room of this Palace. Along with that dream factor, I would want to recreate a different room for dinner each night of the week with at minimum, 7 different sets of china, silverware and glassware. Catherine liked variety. I could go on and on about the inlaid parquet floors, the ceiling paintings, the allegorical sculptures, and etc,. etc., etc. I understand one of the rooms, with a grand piano, is used for selected events. I wonder what the rental fee is?

BAD. Another big mess and confronted with rude personnel. For my mother who tried to enter a palace for the 2nd time (first frustrated tentative was Peterhof) a big disappointment and having to enjoy the gardens only.....

Another can't miss sight in St Petersburg. The palace is fantastic...another can't miss sight. Everyone must see the Amber Room! Negatives...(1) audio tours were in Russian, so buy a detailed book about the palace before you enter; (2) the line is long, the line is not respected...people try to cut in all the time...and the hours for individuals is not very long...plan your trip accordingly.

Beyond belief. Catherine's Palace is the ultimate in royal grandeur and an absolute spectacular feast for the eyes. It's hard to imagine such opulence while people were starving but it is there in full glory. Best seen with a guide that can give you the history and nuances of the Romanovs place and time in history you will ooh and aah over the delft pottery stoves, the amber room and the sheer magic of it all.

Jaw dropping. Each place we visited on our trip to St Petersburg seemed to be more impressive than the next.Catherine's Palace is the place to go to see jaw dropping rooms, photos can be taken inside except for the Amber Room.Grounds are Ok but then if you want spectacular gardens go to Peterhof.

Tsarskoe Selo. It is nice Palace with beautiful gardens. Once again, not enough time to enjoy it. I had a tour to Catherine Palace and Pavlovsk, but decide against of going to Pavlovsk and spend those extra 45 minutes in the gardens. Still, it was not enough. I wish those tour operators (not just there, but all over the world) would give you a little time to enjoy the place
Its famous and you have to see it.. It is fantastic, just make sure you see this before Peterhof, otherwise you will be disappointed. Definately more spectacular from the outside than in.

A bit underwhelmed, but the long wait didn't help. The palace only opens at midday, unless you are there with a tour group. Expect to wait for at least an hour, no matter how early you arrive, because you'll be there with all the other poor unfortunates who turned up bright and early hoping to save time. If you've seen a lot of European palaces, you may find it a bit ho hum, and is it sacrelige to say the amber room is just kinda ugly and kitsch? The gardens are lovely and you could spend plenty of time wandering around, if I had a do-over I'd just take a picnic, wander the grounds, and admire the outside.

Fabulous palace. This palace is in a different setting to the Peterhof and Winter Palace. It has been partially restored so far - the state room enfilade is spectacular. There are only twenty rooms to view, but they are well worth a visit. The pink and green dining room and the amber rooms are particular highlights. The gardens are worth a visit in their own right. They are beautifully laid out, with various pavilions dotted around. We visited this palace courtesy of an excursion with Timofey/Tailored Tours St Petersburg, and would thoroughly recommend this way of visiting the palace.

Strange entry system. Well.... we enjoyed the park, but not the palace as w thought it is far too creazy to que up for hours.... the whole system to enter the palce is so complicated and artificially made difficult..... individuals can ented only between 12-14 and 16-17 ......... nonsense....at least one could buy a ticket on the internet, whey should we start quing at 3PM for a possible 4PM visit.... also the park lacks in cafes or restaurants... only open air places, not the best choice when it is raining.... the only restaurant at the lake was fully booked for groups and we were refused to get a table....... weird experience in Pushkin.....
Catherine Palace. Just opulent!! What a beautiful place! You couldnt even dream this if you wanted to! It makes you wonder if the habitants had any way of relating to the common man.

Catherine Palace and Park. Wonderfully renovated insided and outside. The Golden Hallway wonderful, Amber Room spectacular. What can I say? I was greatly impressed with the archectural details inside and outside. One of the best palaces we've seen,

Amber glory. What a Palace. Almost as good as Peterhof but not quite. Well worth the visit it is almost like the Palace of Versaille in Paris. The Amber room was brilliant and all in all well worth the time guided tour with SPB tours.
What a palace!!!. You will be surprised with the luxury of this Palace....the interior design and the decorations....its the most beautiful I have ever seen....

Gardens Excellent. The palace is really extensive and interesting to see. The gardens are beautiful and well worth the visit, but you have to pay an entry fee for every building you go in in the gardens as well as an entry fee for the gardens itself. It can therefore add up.
Another must see. The Summer Palace...another place you must see. Particularly the Amber room. The rooms will take your breath away with their beauty. Go early an avoid the majority of the crowds.
Wedding Cake Palace. Lots of history behind this powerful lady. Read up before.

A spectacular restoration. Looking at this palace, which eclipses Versailles, it is difficult to imagine that it was used as a Nazi military depot during the siege of Leningrad. The grounds of the palace are lovely as well however the interior is dazzling - acres of gold everywhere. Catherine certainly knew how to create rooms to impress her visitors! The drive to and from the palace offered yet another glimpse of how modern day Russia is lived - and it provided a chance to imagine what the siege must have been like over 900 days during the Second World War.

Word can't describe. How amazing this palace is. You should use a tour guide to get in otherwise you will have to wait hours! Tours skip the majority of the lines. The amber room is great and the center ballroom is out of this world. Gold leaf everywhere and shows how much wealth they had back in this time. A MUST DO!

Unbelievable opulence!. Looking over this vast palace, with it's gold, furnishings, art, sculptures etc, it is not hard to understand why there was a revolution. Unbelievable wealth on display - not to be missed even if you are on a 1-day St. Petersburg visit.

Impressive Palace. This palace, together with Peterhof and other venues of the Czars, are the epitome of examples of how out of touch they were with the common man. Stuuningly beautiful, the palace even has a complete room entirely fashioned in multi-colored amber, which has a value beyond imagination. Gold, paintings, chandeliers, woodwork, ceramics, art objects, furniture, antique clocks, and much more speak to the life-style of the czars. More than once I heard a visitor say what I, also, observed - it's no wonder the people revolted and threw them out.

Impressive!. This is the summer residence of the Russian tsars and the palace is huge and looks like something out of a fairy tale. There is also a huge park around the palace divided into a formal garden French style and a wllder English-style garden. Do take the time to stroll around in the park and look at all the smaller buildings and statues. There are plenty of benches to rest your feet if you get tired and you can also buy drinks, ice-cream etc. There is also a restaurant at the back of the palace which I never visited, though. You have to pay 100 rubles at the entrance of the park to get in and if you want to get into the palace you have to buy another ticket inside the palace. Usually there a long queues to get in! I had to queue for two hours on a weekday in July when I arrived at 10 in the morning (that's when they open the palace for visitors). After half an hour's waiting I learnt that guided groups go in first from another entrance at the back of the palace and visitors on their own have to wait until 12 to be let in. There might be information about this outside the park but the information there was only in Russian.All in all the staff around the park and the palace speak very little English, if any, and are not very helpful. When I finally got into the palace I saw a lot of audio guides but they were only in Russian so before visiting it is a good idea to get some background information about the palace - it will make the experience more interesting. The rooms are of course very beautiful and you are allowed to take pictures without paying anything extra except in the Amber Room where you are not allowed to take any pictures at all. As I visited in the summer there were a lot of guided groups crowding up the palace which made the experience less pleasant than it could have been but I definitely do not regret queuing those two long hours to get in.
Incredible!. We were there to see them turn on the fountains!!! a most memorable experience!! and such a gorgeous place to visit.
what a luxory!. What I saw in Catherine Palace was extremly effort to shaw off and in that manner, extrem loxury. It was destroed in Second World War and restaurators should be honerd for thay work.
Beautiful!. Wow to think you would build a palace like this while your people lived in poverty! This is out of the way but not too bad if you take the subway and a bus.

Wow. A must see. Best seen on an organised tour. Our guide explained to us the history of each room and well as how the palace was rebuilt after being razed by the Germans at the end of the war. Loved the main ballroom and the amber room.

An alternative to Peterhof. More difficult to get to and not quite as impressive but good none the less. Currently only open to individuals (not groups) between 12-14 and 16-17. Take the metro and then a bus.

They really need to install the air conditioner for this place. From outside, the palace looked amazing. Inside, there were a lot of interesting displays. However, tons and tons of tourists kept jamming into the palace and made it impossible to enjoy the details of these displays. The lack of air conditioner made the experience even worse; i was there when the temperature hit 32 degree outside, inside with so many tourist it felt like at least 40 degree and it was suffocating, seriously not fun. If you are going to visit this place during the summer time, maybe you should bring one of those mini electronic fans with you, and bring plenty of water.
CAtherine Palace is beautiful. Take this tour when you go to St. Petersburg, Is fantastic!!Get a good travel guide, not the White Nights Travel agency!!
Impressive. While the garden is not as impressive as Peterhof, the Palace is quite beautiful. Pushkin is a very nice town.

Amazing. After a while, with all the incredible palaces, churches and museums in St. Petersburg, you'd think you'd eventually get tired of it. But you'd be wrong when they're as amazing as the Catherine Palace.
Worth the trip. If you are on an organized tour it is usually included but if not it is worth the extra time it takes to visit. Spend time not just in the amazing palace but strolling the gardens

a bit dissappointing. it's really far away from st peter, took us almost 1.5hr with metro+bus (186) to get there. Luckily, bus station is just 2min away from park entrance. Park itself is large but not that impressive as summer palace. Catherine Palace itself is stunning from appearance, but it's overpriced and ticket queue took us more than 1hr under sun at noon. also, half of palace was blocked from visiting and was claimed to cover by another seperate ticket??? Overall, might skip if you visit summer palace.

Pushkin's place. My priority of visiting Catherine Palace and Park and Liceum was the fact that it was one of the Pushkin's place. Just make this visit before Peterhof, as afterwards it could seem a little simple.
Magnificant. One of the most stunning interiors anywhere. It should not be missed

CATHERINE PALACE IS MAGNIFICENT. Recently visited Versailles, Paris. We thought we would never see a palace quite like Versaille, well we were wrong! Catherine Palace was (in our opinion) far more interesting to explore!

Fabulous night with musical entertainment and dancing. We loved visiting Catherine Palace with the opportunity to get to the outskirts of St. Petersburg. We attended a special musical night when the Palace was closed to others. We enjoyed a tour of the rooms, performances by violinists, a military band, a harpsichordist, a flutist as we went through the amazing rooms. There was a dancing performance and a small orchestra performance in the ballroom. Enchanting. We finished off with a walk through the grounds to see the royal carriages. We are happy we took this tour and have lovely memories of the evening.
simply the best. can`t miss it. words can`t describe this palace. the best attraction at Saint Petersburg.

Seriously bling. Bling, busy, stressful, but quite amazing. This place has to be seen to be believed. It's not exactly tasteful. It's also VERY popular and you do get shunted along in a general panic. Backpacks aren't allowed so you need to use the cloakroom. Make sure you retrieve them from the cloakroom before proceeding to the grounds. I didn't realise this, which lead to great drama involving barefoot running (inappropriate sandals) and begging to retain my bag - trust me - it's not worth it - get your bag before going to the gardens. There was a group of singers performing in the gazebo. The bass ended on a very low G and it really gave us all goosebumps - a highlight of Russia for me.

Such a Wonder. We toured Catherine's Palace with a tour group called ECLECTICIA. The tour was to last 5-6 hrs but only lasted 3 and that included the transportation there. The only benefit with taking a tour is you walk right into the palace. The lineups are very long. A must to see is the amber room but every room is breathtaking. The corner stoves are fasinating. Lots of furniture, dishes, and pictures within the palace. Very large palace that has been restored. They even have pictures of the restoration. The park is certainly beautiful but not as magnificent as Peterof.
Overwhelming opulence. You must see this to understand how the Russian nobility lived
Fantastic Opulence. Every room was grander than the previous one and we agreed that it was impossible to explain this wonderful palace it simply has to be experienced.
Catherine Palace. Everyu site we visited seemed more amazing than the previous Loved this palace--provided by TJ Travel
Not my favorite. Catherine was quite a gal, and her place is well worth a visit. As others have noted, it gets crowded. There's a lot to see, but if you're short of time, go to Peterhof.
Peaceful and seren. We did not visit the palace, but the gardens are extensive and beautiful.

Wonderful tour including the Amber Room. I arrived with three others and my tour guide Marina Wilson (see review) at the gates just before 10:00 and throngs of people from cruise ship buses were clamoring to get through the gate. Marina was very adept to get us through and without damage to us or the gate. I strongly advise taking a tour guide because this and Paul's palace are in Pushkin - 30 km at least outside of the city. We spent a delightful time going through the various rooms that were of rococo influence. Since amber was a big fashion item back in the day an entire room (no photos allowed) was created with amazing detail However, as with Peterhof, much of the palace was damaged, pillaged, and artwork/furniture stolen by the Germans. The amber room is recreated.as is much of the palace but a masterful job none the less. We didn't see much of the gardens. because we saw the fabulous gardens at Peterhof and wanted to spend more time at Paul's Palace which I liked the best (see review)
Fabulous. A fabulous place with fabulous things but miserable staff. Go very early to avoid the crush. The gardens are well worth a wander round
Now I know why there was a revolution in 1917. This palace was as ornate and scrumptious as any I have seen in Europe. Remarkable artistry and detail in its interior.
Wonderful rooms. Don't get upset by the riches of the Emperors. Just be enthralled by the sheer beauty of it all and forget about ever living there.

The most crowded tourist attraction in Europe. This palace is unbelievably crowded with queues outside, inside, to get up the stairs ,to enter each room. As I commented at the time it is like Disneyland . Nothing though can prepare you for the absolute splendour which will take your breath away. It was worth the queue!!

Rich was surely better. This palace is vast. The grounds are groomed and huge with a variety of buildings about. Under Putin they have started to re-gilt all that was gold years ago. When this project is done sunglasses will be needed for sure. As you approach the entry gates shimmer to greet you. While we waited to enter a band played music, danced, and hawked their CD! Upon entering you must don booties to protect the ncredible wood floors from your shoes.Be prepared to stop and gasp when you get to the room with sconces and mirrors. Everyone did when we were there. The sheer opulence is staggering. This building alone may explan the Russian Revolution. Ask about Catherine telling her architect to stay within budget so you are aware of some of his clever tricks. She must have been quite a demanding client and got a masterpiece.

Beautiful palace and gardens - prepare to queue.. Once you get into he palace it is absolutely stunning especially the Amber room. However queuing here is a nightmare. If you are not with an organised group, individual visitors are admitted between 12-2 and 4-5. We joined the queue at 12.15 and only just got in before 2pm. The queue was shorter when we came out at 4. Once you get in turn left to purchase your entrance ticket, this was not clearly signed. Then you go to a separate queue to get your audio guide which you have to pay 150 roubles for and put down a 1000 rouble deposit. Then you just have to hope that the person is there to give you your money back and take the audio guide from you!

2 Day St. Petersburg Experience. This is definitely a highlight of any visit to St. Petersburg. I appreciated the ability to take photos inside (except amber room). Palace is very crowded, so plan ahead on your visit - preferably early.
She surpassed her husband. If you think men suffer from delusions of grandeur, you only just need to see this Palace for a re-think.

Palace and park are both outstanding. When we were last in St Petersburg in 1986 this palace was still being restored after the destruction if World War II, so it was a real treat to see the palace and the skill of the restorers. While the famous Amber Room is one of the real treats, there is much else to see and admire and the crowds were, unlike at the Hermitage, bearable. Room after room is stunning but do not miss the gardens. Gilding, plaster extravaganza, mirrors, paintings all embellish the history of grandeur and then destruction in war. Stunning.
A visit with Catherine.. We enjoyed every minute that we spent in Catharine Palace and Park largely due to the expertise of our guide, Dimitri.

Impressive, interesting and beautiful.. We visited on a warm late May morning as part of a tour organised from a cruise ship. Our guide was very knowledgable and spoke excellent English. As we walked up to the front of the palace the palace 'band' played, rather depleted compared to the poster beside them, in very tired uniforms that probably dated to when the palace foundations were dug! We entered and placed our shoe protectors on our feet and climbed the very impressive stair case to enter the ball room! WOW! We manged to carry a wheelchair up the stairs do a less able member of the party was able to enjoy the different rooms. The staff were very helpful. A note of caution! Shoe protectors and inlayed polished floors equal a serious slip hazard!! A must to visit! The restoration post WW2 is ongoing and a work of art!! You will be seeing Gold in front of your eyes for weeks!!

Great Place to Visit. Very impressive in every way--be sure to take a tour of the palace. Quite an art collection! Great architecture. Amazing grounds! Be sure to arrive as early as possible...long lines!

Amazing Palace. This was another must see while visiting St. Petersburg. The palace rooms were stunning. The only drawback was the lineups. They were 1 1/2 hours long. Perhaps it was because it was a Monday and the Hermitage and other places are closed on that day. So be prepared to wait but the wait is DEFINITELY worth it! For more info on St. Petersburg, I have done a review under the Hermitage section as our group of seven Canadians had some a wonderful time overall.
A place not to be missed. A wonderful Palace in fantastic gardens. The rooms are amazing with fabulous design and architecture. Such opulence it is hard to take it all in. Gold leaf everywhere!

The grandeur of it all!. Absolutely breathtaking as one approaches the palace from a tree-lined allee. We did queue for an hour and a half as all the tour groups were allowed entry first and then the Russian people and few foreigners were allowed in at 12. Unsure if it was worth the wait.

Gilded Glory. Hard to believe this was just one of the palaces - such opulence and splendor. The Delft tile fireplaces were mesmerizing, hard to imagine such works of art as functioning sources of heat. The inlaid floors, the gilding everywhere, an exhibit of beautiful decadence.

Catherine. I loved this palace. It went on and on and on. Would have liked more time here but one could never see it all. Each room was more opulant than the one before. I bought a small water color to remind me of this palace.
The only word is opulent!. Absolutely beautiful, especially the Amber room. A truly magnificent experience.
Beautiful palace. This is a beautiful palace with so much to see - do not miss it.

A rival to Versailles. Having seen this palace and Versailles within six months of each other, I felt quite knocked out by the Catherine Palace and Park.Interior rooms are shaped like Versailles but an overwelming dislay of baroque and roccoco until you get to the calmer style of James Cameron. However, I felt it lacked the delicacy of Versailles.The Gardens were quite woonderful - a small lake with pavillions and stables. More relaxed in shape and planting than the Versailes gardens. The best peonies I have ever seen.Give yourself lots of time.Good cloakroom, washroom, shop facilities.
Catherine Palace and Park. Lovely garden and fountains just as described in brochures. Stood on the stairway overlooking the fountains and saw those golden domes on the palace, Beautiful sight

Impressive Palalce and Gardens. Be sure to get your tickets in advance as there is limited capacity. Be sure to also honor your time arrival on your ticket. The massive fascade is sure to impress, especially when you see the pictures of the war and how the palace was left by the Germans. It is a lovely palace but pales in comparison to The Hermitage.

Worth the ride to see Catherine's palace. This has been restored and is another of the 6 top sights in St Petersburg. The ride out will help you understand how Russians are living in the area now. Several of the rooms reminded us of Versailles.
Catherine's Palace rivals any in Europe. The Russians have invested millions of rubles in restoring this massive palace complex. Hall of mirrors and Amber Room will knock your socks off.
One of the best places in St.P.. Great park, nice buildings.Limited possibilities for eating, to much tourists

Outstanding Palace. Catherine's Palace was one of the most spectacular royal palaces that we have ever seen (including Versaille). The ornamentation was dazzling and sumptuous. The highlight of our visit to St. Petersburg.

Enormous!. This palace is ENORMOUS, beautiful, lavish, and everything you'd hope from a royal place and more. The gardens are fantastic and well worth a long stroll. Just a note: beware of LOTS of crowds in the summertime (and just be vigilant about pick pockets).

Our number one attraction in ST P. The royal suite just goes from one staggering vista to the next. Absolutely stunning. Amber room very busy but I preferred the other furnished rooms anyway.. Worth the drive out to Pushkin

Impossibly extravagant. After the Grand Palace at Peterhof we didn't expect to be surprised, but we were wrong. It is easy to imagine the roots of the revolution as you stroll through this impossibly extravagant palace. We took a guided tour in English with Eclectica tours, and they were superb. At the height of tourist season we were just eight people in a mini-bus with guide (I guess that might have been luck). We heard a short, free, quality chamber music concert in one of the pavilions.
Go early to avoid the crowds. we were the first in and able to keep ahead of the tour groups. Not to the scale of Peterhof but the same quality and awesome decorations.
Stunning!. Speechless! Stunning! Gorgeous! Just wow! It is definitely worth your while. Take a tour, otherwise you won't be able to get into the Palace.

Similar to Godollo & Schonbrunn Palaces!. Except for its exterior light blue instead of light yellow, this palace reminds us very much of the Godollo Palace in Budapest and the Schonbrunn Palace in Vienna. Since this place is also out of the city center, one must have a complete half day to visit this place.

The Palace of Catherine the Great is not to be missed!. We travelled to St. Petersburg by cruise ship. Our 2 days there were filled with tours. One of our favorite tours was the tour to the palace of Catherine the Great in Pushkin. As everyone else has mentioned, it is very crowded!!! So definitely go early in the day. As you arrive, you must check your coat and umbrella. Yes, you will most likely encounter rain! If you are lucky as we were, you might be the first group allowed inside the palace. It was wonderful to see the rooms empty of visitors as you first enter. Then as you look back, the entire palace is filled with visitors as far as you can see! It's hard to find the right words to describe the palace. Unbelievable, spectacular, and impressive are a few that come to mind. You will take lots and lots of photos! The process of retrieving our coats and umbrellas was very efficient. Less than 2 minutes! The walk in the gardens was lovely, even if it was raining a bit. This is a very popular attraction and not to be missed! Go early and be prepared for crowds! Also, don't forget an umbrella on your visit to St. Petersburg.
Beautiful. Try to get with a smaller size tour group that will offer you early entrance to the building before the huge bus tours arrive. We recommend SPb Tours.
Very nice Park. Very nice Park, but the Interior Excursion was too short

Must visit for a day out of St Petes. Nothing much to add to the below observations re:rooms. I do recommend arriving at the grounds first thing in the morning like 9am and enjoy the beautiful Catherine Park before everyone lands at the venue. We were amongst the first to get in and did not have to be in line. Really amazed by the level of details and ornate-ness of all the rooms, especially after learning that the entire place was almost destroyed during the WWII and efforts taken to restore the place to its former glory, so definitely take the time to appreciate the photos at the basement– I was touched by the commitment as the German troops basically set the entire place in fire in 1944. Apparently, one loyal palace staff managed to bury and hide a large number of the artworks etc. I also enjoyed the porcelains for the various dining tables - very intricate. One more tip – as you walk to the back of the palace into gardens, there is white building near the lake. Try to get inside and check out if there is a small tenor performance of about 5min. The acoustic of the building was superb. I prefer the Catherine Palace to the Petrodvorets as the contents of the palace feel more personal and perhaps it was a more intimate atmosphere; both interior and external grounds.

Now this was something different. A long way out of town but the interior of this palace contains some of the most beautiful treasures of St Petersburg. However we were in a group of four and were able to by-pass the massive queues trying to get in and again inside there were so many people it was nearly impossible to enjoy the palace and its contents. The gardens on a sunny warm day were quite beautiful but very different from the gardens at the Petehof.
Wonderful to see. The buildings were amazing and it was nice to wonder around the grounds
Interesting - To Crowded. Rooms facsinating but no time to linger or admire because groups are hereded through like cattle

Was under construction. The park was under construction and refurbishing when I visited but the statue of Catherine the Great was easily in view and I got great pictures. It is the only statue of Catherine in the city and it is magnificent!
Catherine Palace. Opulent! With 150 palaces in teh St Peterburg area one can understand why there was a revolution
Not to be missed. I have never seen so much gold in my life. A facinating structure and the Amber room is a top attraction.

The ins and the outs. We found the exterior garden area less impressive than Peterhof ( but almost everything, anywhere would be ) but the interior was pretty special and if you read up a little about the intrigue surrounding the two Catherines, Elizabeth and Peter the Great it adds immesurably to the interest.

Worthwhile!. Arrive early as huge numbers visit, especially from cruise ships as we did. Nonetheless, one has enough time to appreciate the magnificence of Catherine the Great's summer home, and is allowed to take pictures except in the amber room. Our tour included a restaurant lunch as well.
The Amber Room is worth the long lines to get in!. The lines to get in are long, but the palace rooms are magnificent and the Amber Room alone is worth the wait.

Wow. We were fortunate enough to arrive at 10:00 pm for dinner (long story that involves lots of traffic jams) so were the only group there to tour the palace. Even though our group was 2 hours late the people were gracious; still poured champagne, vodka (of course), and had a military band playing as we crossed the courtyard. Our tour through the palace was not rushed and there were still characters in period dress here and there to explain how life was then. Finished in the ballroom. . .WOW. . .that's all I can say. There was a stringed quartet playing with people in period dress waltzing.Great opportunity. . .don't pass it up!

The historical Palace - The amber room. a Palace to be seen - If Versailles is nice, Catherine is great - fully furnish, historical Amber room , mirrors, paintings, history and you will be back to those time, If time get lunch by Patvory, not far and nice Russian food

Metro and MiniBus made it easy to go independently. The flowers were beautiful, the palace was glittered with gold. Read Anastasia's story before you go and imagine her living there and it being used as a hospital during the war. Be sure to see the photos of the reconstruction in the hallway....impressive work.
Catherine Palace and Park. Absolutely lovely all the gold, wooden floors Absolutely amazing!

The best palace. I have been many palaces around the world. Catherine Palace is definitely the best. The blue color stands out beautifully on a sunny day. The golden tops of the church attached to it are stunning! Of course, the Amber room is a must. As usual, there are a lot of people. So be patient. They also request you to use the shoe caps before entering the palace. Towards the end of the visit, you can see some old pictures taken after the palace was destroyed during war time. You will appreciate even more the restoration work that turn the ruins into such a gorgeous palace.

Best in St. Petersburg. After being so impressed by the Peterhof Palace and the Winter Garden Palace, We were not prepared for the best gem of all.... The Catherine the Great's Palace restored to her original glory. The Amber Room is truly so luxurious yet comfortable and warm. The Hermitage Pavillion in the grounds of the palace have mechanical devices that lower the tables so servants can refill them without seeing who are the guests on the main floor. The servants quarters and kitchens are several hundred meters away from the palace making it a real chore to bring these to the palace. Very beautiful grounds with a very peaceful lake. Really worth visiting. Should not be missed.
great. beautiful palace, especially the Amber room worth a visit
If you like Versaille you'll like this. Use a guide to best experience this Versaille-like attraction. It should be on the list when you visit St. Petersburg

Catherine Palace. Most people go to Peterof but our guide wanted us to see Catherine's Palace outside of St. Petersburg. What a palace.
This place has a Amber Room wow and very ornate and not bad grounds either. Peterof I heard has a more ornate park like Versailles in France. Catherine has a more ornate Palace.

Another extraordinary example of what you can do with money and power.. There are many reviews so just a short mention. Going in the spring makes more sense than the summer. The guide jokingly said the adjacent village of "Pushkin" was well named particularly the "push" part. The summers are chaos apparently. We were there on a day the buildings were closed ... however as "cruise" passengers we where allowed in which is great. Do check to make sure they are open ... to avoid disappointment. Truly on Verseille is more extrodinary of the royal palaces we have visited. I particularly wanted to see the Amber room ... magnificent ... but sadly we where not supposed to take pictures. Note that if you want to take pictures anywhere you are supposed to pay a little extra and get a sticker but no one seem to care ... If I had limited time would prefer this over the Hermitage. Lots of parkland to stroll on and think the gardens would be beautiful in the summer ... we were there too early so could only imagine.

Lovely Palace and Park. We spent several hours touring both the Palace and the Park. The Palace was especially impressive as you saw the rooms completely furnished, china, etc. The grounds were very nice as well. Donna N

Beautiful palace, very nice park. The main summer residence of the russian tsars! A true masterpiece! It has very interesting history and superb interiors. Make sure you walk around the park to Cameron's gallery and the Grotto and enjoy the nice view of the lake. Pushkin also has nice Cathedral of Sophia and also an old military town called Feodorovskii gorodok. In fact, there are so many places to visit in this small town.
Magnificent. Beautiful Palace fit for the queen but not as stunning as Peterhof...

Incredible. Beautiful palace and garden. You have to buy a ticket to the garden first and then stand in line to get into the palace. We didn't book in advance and ended up standing in the sun for more than 2 hours to get in. The palace takes about 30 min to see but when you get in but the garden if VERY big and you can easily spend 2-3 hours there.

WOW!. its not a wonder that the kingdom fell there... all these places are so megalomanic!! and no wonder they built it out the city so the people will not see the richness when they are starving... but, its a beautiful, outstanding palace! dont miss it!

A Golden Home. There is little more to say than what has already been said in most of the reviews. We were fortunate to have the sun peek out and project a brilliant view. The amount of gold that is in the place boggles your mind. The government has done an excellent job of restoring the palace.

Sophisticated architecture and lush..... Catherine's Palace is unbelievably stunningly beautiful, this huge building looks like the designs created on a cake.Bluish green, white trim, stucco head trim and gold with lots of statues erected on the roof. Lush green gardens sit in front of this summer palace.The inside simple depicts the wealth of Catherine the Great, various rooms adorned with gold, chinese silk, the chapel, the Agate room and so much more. Experience one day in the life of sophisticated luxury and please visit this palace and mingle throughout the grounds of the gardens
my favorite. the palace should not be missed. the amber room was beyond what i had imagined. the gardens were in bloom and beautiful. a truely breath taking morning.
Astounding. The much-touted amber room is not as good as billed. But the palace is beautiful inside and out. Ballroom is gigantic. Well worth the visit.

St. Catherine's Palace. We visited St. Catherine's Palace first thing in the morning and it was very crowded with huge groups from the various cruise ships. Although crowded we did enjoy seeing the different rooms and the artwork. The palace grounds are also very beautiful.

Confusing opening hours. The Palace is most impressive. But even though the opening hours are listed everywhere as 10 to 17, we were denied entry at 14 hours and told to come back at 16 hrs. A huge sign in front of the entrance probably said so as well, but is was only in Russian without just a single word in English. Poor service for tourists!We DID visit the Palace at 16 hrs, a mad rush through ticket office, security and loads of tourist groups before the closure at 17 hrs. But it was still worth it.A kind Russian advised us not to return to Saint Petersburg by train, but to take a bus instead (it was late Su8nday afternoon). He knew what he was talking about - it was the most crowded train I've ever been on. But it was all in all a funny experience to join the Russians having a weekend out of town.
Alla tours. This company made our dreams come true. they are good. so much to admire

Versailles in grand scale. We loved this palace especially the room resemble to the hall of mirrors in Versailles. The amber room is not as expected but the Chinese lacquer rooms between large rooms are to die for.
What a big blue house!,,. Catherine's summer palace is beautiful and worth visiting especially if you are a fan of Catherine the Great. The grounds are huge
Luxury , beautiful. Gold everywhere, nice fountains and park. Luxury. Guide neccesary.
Wow!!!. The amber room, the golden domes, the palace all wonderful
Not to be missed. Truly extraordinary Competes with Versailles.We visited before spring flowers and trees were in bloom. Can only imagine what it would be like with flora.

wonderful palace. Visiting St.-Petersburg - make up your schedule to visit Pushkin, this is a close satellite town located on the south from the city. There are several possibilities to go there and most of tourists use group tours to go there, but I do not recommend it. It is an easy trip to Pushkin from St.-Petersburg by "elektrichka" (Russian equivalent of German S-bahn). You take metro to Pushkinskaya station, get out and you are directly at the nice railway station called Vitebskiy which is a nice example of Jugendstil. By the way, there is a McDonallds just oposite to the railway station and you could enjoy some coffee and burger on the way to Pushkin. Take a train and after 25-30 minutes you will come to Pushkin railway station which is cosy, yellow and nice. Do not hesitate to take a taxi - town is really small and you woun't go out of budget. I recommend this way because you would be able to spend more time at the park around the palace which is nice itself. At the same time you can visit the palace without any rush and mess from the guide and other group members, moreover, if you like, you can visit Licey (the school where Russian most famous poet Pushkin studied) - it is close to the Catherine palace and for some people this visit could be attractive.I suppose that it is much more efficient to organize the trip to Pushkin yourself and plan your day.

Not to be missed!. Awesome palace and more of the astounding art collection. Even though we were there pre-summer, we saw the groundskeepers preparing the gardens and can imagine how beautiful it looks in season. Our guide, Timofey Kruglikov, assured us that it is also beautiful with the snow in winter.
Gorgeous Palace. Gorgoeus Palace also the gardens. Way too many people. They shoul limit the amount of people that enter the palace.

Wow - what a place. Only a short trip of about 20 miles from St. Petersburg at Tsarskoye Selo (Pushkin) , Catherine's Palace is often included with tour packages. While the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg is a fantastic art museum, the Summer Palace is more like a Tsar's palace would have been before the revolution. The palace and grounds are overwhelmingly beautiful. The amber room is worth a visit on it's own while the furnishings throughout give an idea of what life was like for the royal family.Yes, much has been restored and that is a good thing. In a basement corridor are wartime photos that show much of the damage that occurred here on the Leningrad front when the German army occupied the palace. Lots of fighting took place here and restoration was necessary to bring it back so visitors can see what life was like before the revolution.The visit here was one of my top experiences in Russia.

Borque and Glitzy. We visited both the Catherine Palace and the Alexandra Palace. Visit both. While the Catherine Palace is borque and glitzy the Alexandra Palace while not as restored was more interesting. The rooms of the Catherine Palace that were unglitzy showed the showed the Scottish architects influence. Looked more like Wedgewood.

Oh my goodness....a must see!!!!. This is definitely worth the trip outside of the city...We took the Metro and then a bus ....and when we saw the outside we were blown away...only to be more amazed by what was inside!!!

ok. It is beautiful, but what I didn't realize, is that it's been completely renovated fairly recently and some parts are still renovated. Even the amber room was completely redone as recently as 20 years ago. Very little original there, b/c it was pretty badly damaged during the war. Also very crowded with tourists - we were there at 10:30ish am.

Get the audio guide. We were very glad we paid for the audioguide for the Catherine Palace. Crazy ornate!We walked through the parks (getting a tad lost, but enjoying the walk) to the Alexander Palace. We paid for the Alexander Palace, then found out it was only 3 rooms (oops). At least it wasn't much. Then we went into the section (paid again, but very nominal fee) of the Alexander Palace where the ROmanov family exhibit was. This was very, very interesting. I wish we had rented the audioguide for this section, although there was reasonably good explanations in English. The Alexander Palace had very few visitors and was not clearly marked for where to enter for what. No one spoke English at the ticket booths here.In April, we were able to walk right up to both palaces and buy tickets for immediate entry and walk through at our own pace.

Too far and not worthwhile. It's so difficult to get to this place - and once you do you realize its a museum / palace with a lot of displays, but no story attached to any display. The building is pretty but, that's where it ends.Do it only if you have time and keep it low on your priority list.
It´s worth it. You have to see it. Catherine Palace is very nice and spectacular. One of the most famous places in St. Petersburg. Don´t miss the Amber room!
Stunning. Worth the trip and the rooms are beautifully restored. It's really worth the trip out of the city to see the palace and estate.

Catherine Palace during winters. I visited Cathering Palace in March 2012. I had earlier visited in July 2011 as well. I would say that Catherine Palace can be avoided during winters. The place is covered with snow and the interiors too are nothing as compared to the Hermitage. I would suggest to visit St Petersburg during summer only. I would also suggest to devote more time to the interiors of Hermitage and see Catherine Palace and Park from outside only. There is nothing outside of Hermitage to be seen and there is nothing much inside the Catherine Palace to be seen.
Dont miss this Palace. Just one of many in St Petersburgh , but one of the best . Good tip is spend 1 day in Moscow , then take your time in St Petersburgh , so much nicer and so much more to see .

A Lot of Gilding. Crowded, well-restored, but the gilding is overwhelming. The Amber Room is jaw-dropping & almost worth the visit.The adjacent Alexander Palace & Park, home of the last Tsar & Family, is more interesting & far less crowded. Both Palace Parks are adjacent, but the Alexander Park has more of the last Imperial Family, tho less manicured.
Water, water , everywhere. The fountains and water displays took our breath away.There was always room for viewing and photographing, despite the crowds.
wow!. the best time inside is winter (not to much people), small grups with guide. 2 hour max. ticket 300 RUB (guide incl)
Russian Tsars Residence. Besides it was a Residence of Russian Tsars, now it is worth of seeing the famous Amber room.

Exciting and stimulating. We made our way there by Metro and bus - very proud of ourselves as we neitherr speak nor read Russian! Outside the palace all was white, inside all was gold. After The Hermitage definitely the second most impressive sight and site in St.P

Catherine Palace at Pushkin. What a treat to see, the complete opulence of this is unbelievable. Very cold and covered in snow, walking through the gardens to the outside summer houses with no one around is a real treat. The palace is so grand, nothing that I have seen to compare the wealth, rooms covered in gold. No wonder they had a revolution.Take a taxi to the palace and then take the minibus down the road on the bus 342 which will take you to the train station taking you back to St Petersburg platform number 2. Cost is 30 rubles each for the bus and 25 rubles for the half hour train ride, well worth a trip.
Winter Wonderland. The Park was amazing, even in winter, when you simply walk to the island in the Great Lake. The Palace was beautiful, although more English signs would be great.
Great site. Although it was winter, we visited only the palace, but I can say, I did not regret a minute of the visit

Closed, but worth the trip for the view!. Even though we visited on the last Monday in the month, when the palace is evidently closed, it was worth the tube and bus ride from the centre to visit just for the views of the building. The best way of getting to Puskin was to catch the tube to Lenin square and catch the bus which are very regular. Information can be found on their website which is available in English. The parkland looked truly spellbinding in the snow.

What a country house !. All the rooms are unbelievable and layed out . Brides were even having their photos taken in ballroom of the palace. Again you do need to not forget to take an audio guide as no explanations are given.

Amazing!. This is an incredible place to visit. Although we went in the winter and could not really appreciate the gardens, which were under a couple of inches of snow, the Palace itself is incredible with an extraordinary selection of rooms decorated in different styles by top-class designers from all over Europe. We would love to go back in the summer and hope that one day we will get the chance to do so.
Another outstanding Palace. The Russian Nobles lived in the most lavious life style
Must see. Another superb palace which deserves a full day. Make sure you see the wonderful palace with a guide, and listen to the superb capella singers in the grotto beside the lake.

Stupendous. Firstly, if visiting St. Petersburg would strongly recommend using your own guide. We cruised here in September 2011 aboard Princess Cruises. You avoid long lines, can work out your own itinerary and spend more time at chosen venues. We were recommended to do so by someone we met on an earlier cruise in 2011. Catherine Palace has to be seen & absorbed if it is possible to take in so much beauty. The Russian people who spirited away so much of the contents in WWII saving them for the rest of the world to view & the artisans who have restored this palace have to be congratulated at the immense tenacity and skill that you can see today.

overwellming. Hope you have a wide angle lens to get a picture of this absolutely huge attraction. What you see is not the original but a restoration of the buildings that were damaged by the Germans during ww2. The work is amazing. Its an amazing attraction that shows a period of Russian history were all the great attractions were built,.

Beautiful Palace. We visited the grand palace with a private tour guide and enjoyed our visit. The rooms with their plaster work and gold are very impressive. It's also interesting learning the history of the building, and how so much of it has been lost/restored over the years. The grounds and gardens are also worth a visit.
Beautiful Palace. Architecture and furnishings are exquisite, was there in May so gardens were blooming and beautiful.
The most amazing palace. The incredible gilded halls and beautiful, beautiful rooms, each one different and equally spectacular.

Do not miss this. Also called the "Summer Palace", this is located about 20 miles outside of St. Petersburg, and this may lead you to decide against spending the time involved to take a tour. IMO, this would be a huge mistake. the palace interior rivals the Hermitage and Church of the Savior, and by itself is worth the time needed to travel, but the exterior and gardens are every bit as wonderful as the interior. If possible, try to arrive before 10am, which is when the fountains are activated. Outside the gates of the palace, vendors set up and hawk everything from soft drinks to matroshkas. I recommend the guy who sells fur hats from a stand in the center of the lane leading in. He was knowledgeable and had good prices after some haggling.took place. :)
A must see. Amber room really is the 8th wonder of the world. One of the highlights of this trip.

Not to be missed. One of the major palaces outside of St Petersburg, this is one not to be missed - we were told that there are in fact 1000 palaces in and around St Petersburg, many small and many unrestored from the war and ravages of the elements. This one is exceptional - restored to perfection and it is not to be missed on anyone's trip to St Petersburg. We were there at Christmas time, the palace and grounds were empty, we were quite fortunate in getting to see all of the palace rooms without many other visitors - in many rooms we were the only ones there! We had a private guide which is an integral part of appreciating St Petersburg and highly recommended.

The ineriors of the Catherine Palace are spectacular.. The Catherine Palace collection of Amberwork, Chinese pocelan, Gold, painted silk wallpaper and superb painted ceiling and much, much more, you will have to see yourself.

Great!!. It was very beautiful palace. Too bad that the amber room could not be allowed to be pictured. It was very stunning. However, it was not that organized as there was only audio guide in Russian so the foreigners could not understand the history of this palace. Also, many small buildings in the garden were closed during the renewal.

Catherine Palace in winter. The most agreable thing about traveling in winter is having the whole place for me. Of course there were other tourists at the same time, but we were so few people in a huge place that it was impossible to fill a room and there was no sense in making a queue.I took a bus from Saint Petersburg, at the stop located behing the Lenin monument. I arrived there by 11 AM and before the visit I went to the cafe, as I hadn't had breakfast. It was ok because I wasn't too hungry but I needed to eat, but I can't say "wow! I recommend this cafe".I don't remember if I payed extra or if the permission to take pictures was included in the entrance ticket. Well, I could take a lot of them in almost every room, except in the Amber Room. It is really fantastic! After the visit I bought a postcard collection of the Amber Room just to have the photos.The bad thing was not having an audioguide to explain the details during the visit, listening to some music in the background. I like this stuff and I missed it.It was possible to walk in the gardens, although there were no flowers to see and all the other buildings in Catherine complex were closed. The visit in winter can be made in half day.I uploaded some photos of my trip to help people who intend to go there in winter. I usually travel in winter, so I know how scarce is the information about the touristic sites for this time of the year. The air was pleasantly fresh and the snow made it beautifully russian!There is a tip that I'd like to share: at the touristic information office I was told that in winter it is worthier going to Catherine Palace rather than Peterhof, because the fontains in Peterhof don't work during the winter.
must see. nothing to tell. The palace and the park are beautiful. I love it. Just visit and enjoy!
A beauty!. Incredible and unique colors, loved the rooms with all the Russian Barocco

Took me back to my childhood. I grew up watching the cartoon Anastasia and pictured myself as her. I felt like I was Anastasia while walking through the grand rooms in Catherine's Palace. It was a dream come true!

Makes Versailles look tame. Another half day seeing history. Each room is a piece of art. Each doorway a stunning masterpiece. The place is wonderful and the grounds are not to be missed. Lots of pictures.

Magnificent example of tsarist architectural grandeur. We went independently using public transport, which wasin the end quite easy. We got on the underground at Nevsky Prospect paid 25 roubles each for a token from the desk and went to Moskovskaya. Once there you will need to follow the exit signs to Leninsky Prospect, this will bring you out opposit Lenin Square (big statue in the middle). Go behind the square and you will find numerous marshrukta minibuses, you can use K286, K287, K299 or K342. We paid a further 25 roubles each for the35 minute trip (did need to get the driver to let us know when to get of as was not obvious). The bus stopped at top of a road opposit the Park, the return stop was on the same road we came up approximatelly 100 yards on the other side, our return bus (same numbers) only went to 'Metro' which was shopping center so picked up the underground there, Kupchino. The Catherine Palace was fantastic, a stunning example of baroque architecture. We wanderred around the inside on our own admirring the the beautiful interior and furnishings, The Great Hall was particularlly inspirring (remanisant of the Hall of Mirrors at Versaille - sort of). The only downside was the lack of a guide book which would have enhanced our visit .  We went in December where the grounds although stunning were not at there best and the statues had been wrapped up for the winter in big galvanised boxes.
Gardens. It s a good one. The gardens are much prettier than the inside

Blinded by the gold gilding. There is so much gold gilding at this palace, it's almost blinding! The decoration inside of this palace is incredible, even more so than the Winter Palace. The amber room is very interesting too. I think the grounds would be lovely in spring or summer - but not when we visited in November (way too cold).

Oh, Oh, Oh!!! (:-). Be prepared to be astonished by the incredibly gorgeous palace, inside and out! Walk the beautiful large gardens and be surprised over and over again. Don't miss the amber treasure house way out there -- if it's open!
Away from it all in a realxing garden. The palace is very heavy with things..but has lots of history. The garden is lovely.

Beautiful Palace worth the visit. It totally worth it. The price with tours from Gostiny Dvor (mall on Nevsky Prospekt) is about 1500 rubles but because we took the tour on the same day which was about to start -2pm- and in Russian they gave us a price of 800 rubles which was a bonus - both transportation and entrance. We had an extra charge of 150rubles for audio guide in English inside the palace. It was beautiful, both interior and exterior of palace. The gardens seem to be nice in summer!
So Much History. Alot of History throughout, just mind boggling all the intricate carvings etc
Fantastic palace. A must do! Wonderful palace and exhibits and great garden. Well worth the approx. 40 minute trip out from St Petersburg.
BEAUTIFUL!. The Winter Palace/Hermitage are both quite awesome places, but Catherine Palace and Park are just as awesome. The park is so beautiful and so much fun to walk around.
Eye Candy. Marvellous place made all the better by our extremely knowledgable Russian guide, breathtaking decor & wonderfully restored, a must to see the Amber Room
Well worth it!. This place was absolutely breathtaking! The palace and the gardens were incredible.

rewards and challenges.... The Catherine Palace is definitely one of the artistic treasures of St. Petersburg, but it comes with the price. Located well outside the city, it can take a very long time to get there and back during periods of high traffic. Once there, the lines are spectacularly long in high season, the rooms are tightly crammed, and there is far less open to the public than one might think given the immense size of the palace. The grounds are very interesting as are some of the other buildings. Consider this a daytrip; and if your time in St. Petersburg is limited, visit other places in the city first.

Wonderful, Marina was a great guide.. We made reservation with insider-tour for a 2 day St Petersburg tour. At the port when we passed imigration, Marina (our guide) was waiting for us outside. That was the beginning of 2 wonderful days in Russia. She knows the history of St Petersburg very well, and at the different atractions...we did not wait in lines. Very efficient guide and Sergei a great driver. I recommend Insider-tour. Great service.

Loved the gardens. The place is really amazing, especially the gardens, where there are a lot of small pavillons. It worths to pay an extra tickets to visit each of them inside, they are all different and interesting, and all allow photography. The palace is very inetersting too, but you must visit with a guide and I got a Russian tour, which I could not understand. I had a light lunch at the cafeteria, which was nice, but employees a little uninterested. whatever..

Definitely include a visit on a trip to St Petersburg. A taxi here will cost about 1400 Rubles from the centre of St Petersburg. You can also take metro to Moskoskaya and then K286/K287/K299/K342/K545 taxi busEntrance is 320 Rubles. Individuals can only enter between 12 and 2 and 4-5 in peak season. Queues can be long.The Alexander Palace is 5 minutes walk away, but not that impressive.map: www.infoservices.com/stpete/pushkin/pushkin_map800e.htmPavlovsk Palace is 5km away and can be reached via taxi bus K286 and is worth a visit also

A vision into the life of the Tsars. Although Tsarskoye Selo is a bit of a trip outside of St Petersburg, it was well worth it. Unfortunately we only spent a half day here, as we could have easily kept busy the entire day. The palace and grounds are absolutely beautiful. The interior of the palace is like being in a movie. You truly get a sense of how lavish a lifestyle they lived when walking through the various rooms. Of course, when you also take into consideration the masses were starving, you also understand the fall of the Romanov's. Every room in the palace is like a piece of art, and the famous Amber Room is a piece of art. There is so much more to Tsarskoye Selo, and we regret we didn't have more time here.
Catherine Palace. Well worth the visit particualy the surrounding fountains and gardens

Gold rooms and stunning gardens. The Golden halls and Amber room are worth the visit. If you come to St Petersburg you must see a palace and this is a good one. Make time to walk the gardens if you can. Its an interesting palace with mixed decor and architecture. It wouldn't be my taste in many ways but it was a great way of seeing how they lived!If you are going to do this visit from St Peterburg my top tip would be to bring a guide. We had Sergei, he picked us up from our hotel, drove us there, had organised our tickets etc. We got to jump all the queues, see everything and were brought door to door. His knowledge of the palace really added to the trip. He is very good value as he is a guide and driver in one. Also he has been doing tours for years: sergeispb08@rambler.ru
Excellent. This is a little way out of SPb in a very nice town (We made our own way by train). As for the Palace it is beautiful in a park environment, reflecting the oppulence of the Czars.

It's B I G. The palace is huge, and you will cover a lot of ground without stepping outside, most of it in very close proximity to hundreds of fellow visitors. But it is jaw-droppingly beautiful (even if entirely recreated since 1945).Don't ignore the grounds, because the palace is, if anything, even more beautiful when seen from outside. But the grounds are on the same scale os the palace - enormous!Do not skimp on the time you allot to visiting the Catherine Palace. If you do not have much time, then stick to the Palace itself.
A more rational sized palace. Just go, but take the time to visit the gardens. Expect crowds.
Beautifull palace. We saw a ballet perfomrance arranged for tour groups; amateurish at best
Huge!. So much to see. We had a private guide who explained so much of the history. Truly amazing place to visit.
beautiful. totally worth the ride, i reccomend taking a bus one way if you have time for it..

Must be Seen. A sumptious palace which has been beautifully restored since its wrecking by the Nazis as they left during WW2. We particularly liked the original furniture and other items which had been hidden from the Nazis.

Magnificent!. Catherine Palace in Tsarskoye Selo, St. Petersburg is a fine place both for tourists and residents. They offer great excursions to explore the decor. Indeed, the grandiloquence of the interior strikes your imagination, especially the Great Hall. The guide told us that the original design of the Hall as well as ornamentation was done by Rastrelli. A huge amount of gold was used to gild the inner details and façade. In the Amber Room you admire dozens of shades of this natural material and craftsmanship of the creators and restorers.After the excursion you can have a rest in the beautiful park – take a boat or relax in the shady alleys. The territory is big and very well-kept. Tip: Instead of booking a guided bus tour from St. Petersburg go there by train. It takes as long as by bus and you you’ll have an unlimited time to explore the Palace. The more so because, the lyceum where Pushkin was educated is situated next to Catherine Palace.

Fabulous Russia...don't miss SPB attraction!. The most opulent and fantastic palace I have seen....anywhere...you think you know rich? You ain't seen nothing till you go visit this spectacular palace just 25 minutes outside St Petersburg. Spend at least half a day...the gardens, palace tour and gift shops are beyondyour imagination. If you have one optional tour on your visit, make sure this is the one you choose.

Extraordinary. The Nazis left this extraordinary palace almost completely in ruins at the end of the Second World War, but the Russians have rebuilt it the way it was at the time of Catherine the Great. Even the famous Amber Room is reconstructed. It took them years to do this and the craftsman ship is astonishing from the elaborate parquet floors to the gold leaf decorations both inside and out. It is well worth a trip there--about 3/4 of an hour's drive from St. Petersburg.

Over-whelming. Gold, Gold and more Gold. They out-did the Hall of Mirrors in Versailles. Absolutely beautiful. The Amber room is fascinating. Except for one wall, it has been completely restored after the damage caused by WWii.

Opulent to the Max, But Too Crowded. We visited the Palace on a weekday in August, so we did expect crowds, but I was still surprised at the number of people they let in at one time. The Palace is truly a sight to see, and it would have been much more interesting if they hadn't herded us all along like cattle. It was hot and no air was circulating, which made it unpleasant. They could have managed the crowds better and it would have been a much more enjoyable visit. Perhaps it is more palatable in the off-season.

most luxurious summer palace in the world. After having visited the most important royal palaces in Western Europe,I can say that Russia has the most beautiful and luxurious royal palaces and orthodox cathedrals in the world. No doubt about that ! Catherine's palace in Tsarskoye Selo is a breathtaking combination of abundant gold plated superb ornaments,mirrors,paintings and painted ceilings,shockingly beautiful Amber Room (amber,gold and mirrors) and magnificent Roman-style rooms. It's OVERWHELMING and ECSTATIC, and only by BEAUTY !It is an UNIQUE LIFE EXPERIENCE ! Just LIVE it and THEN die, to paraphrase an Italian say.Just VISIT St Petersburg and its environs and you will live the TRIP of your LIFE,in matters of breathtaking arts. Add here the breathtaking Russian classical ballet atMariinsky Theater - and you will have the full picture.

Amazing restoration. All but the shell of the original structure was completely destroyed by the retreating Nazis during WWII. The reconstruction is amazing. This palace is smaller, easier to take in than the Hermitage, a day visit is sufficient, but it is still a wonder of excess opulence. Unlike the Hermitage, you will be asked to put disposable booties (provided at no charge) over your shoes. No photography allowed in the Amber Room but flash-free photography is allowed everywhere else.
Must-see. Opulent, beautiful. Wear comfortable shoes. Long coats must be checked in coat room. No photography of amber room.

Spectacular experience. Spectacular palace and not to be missed. We were very impressed and even more impressive than Versailles which we had just visited a couple weeks early. Our guide got us to the palace before it opened and we had the place to ourselves for a couple of hours before the crowds showed up, even on a Saturday in August. The only negative was no pictures in the Amber Room, which was a little puzzling to me. Several of the other TA reviews give good insight about this palace, so I don't want to repeat them here, just don't miss this place if your in St. Petersburg.

Stunning - not to be missed. St Petersburg is the jewel in Russia and especially the Catherine Palace with the Amber Room and the Peterhof with its wonderful gardens and fountains. The Catherine Palace is nearly restored from WW2 but as you stop at each room you can see a photo of how it looked in 1945 - totally gutted. We were very lucky to be shown around these palaces and all the city by a very knowledgeable guide (with his own car) who spoke excellent English. He also took us to the Kirov Ballet and collected us after the show. We can highly reccmmend him. His name is Sergei - email sergeispb08@rambler.ru. We enjoyed these trips even more than the Hermitage which is overwhelmingly large - 5 palaces joined together. We saw it all in heavy snow and it was magic

So you think you've seen it all............ I don't think so!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Ok. So you are one of those travellers who has wondered in awe as you visited Windsor Castle, Hampton Court, Buckingham Palace, Chambord or Versailles in France. Well, my friend, if there is a must to add to your vast list of fascinating findings it is, without doubt,The Catherine Palace in the town of Pushkin, St. Petesburg. Refinement, magnificence, extravagance, splendour, this unique baroque palace has it all.
