Take my word for it, the summer residence of the Russian Tsars, with the impressive Amber Room, is a number one attraction which cannot be overlooked!!!

Beautiful but no English inside the palace. Great side trip just outside St. Petersburg. If you go alone as we did, there is no English guide inside the palace. The issue is that they take groups inside of about 50 each, have you put booties over your shoes (which is chaotic) then give you earphones for a tour in Russian. We don't understand Russian so we busted out of the bootie room on our own and strolled through past the groups listening (or trapped as the case may be) in each room. We have to wiggle through in the smaller rooms. The park is beautiful in August with lots of brides taking photos.

Tsarskoe Selo. Beautifull and magnificient Palace. It is very well conservated and restaured, the gardens are amazing. I think it could be more well organized, inseated of being groups of french, spanish, english at the sometime in a room, that is so confusion of languages, I think it could be better organize like Neuschwanstein, or Linderhof in Bavaria, Germany. That is an example that Tsarkoe Selo Curator/Director could think and adopt in this palace. Of course get also more money.

Woderful place, but too much crowded in August. Not too much to say. A wonderful Catherine palace rebuilt after WW2 bombs. Large decorated rooms, the ballroom full of gold.. paintings, beautiful inlaid wood floors, all is clean and shining. Wonderful gardens. The place one's expecting from the Tzars. Only one suggestion: do not visit it in August or you'll cue for the whole visit.

The ALLA Tour Company was wonderful in St. Petersburg. We just returned from a cruise on the Emerald Princess to Scandanavia and Russia. We spent two days in St. Petersburg and had booked ALLA Tours before going on our cruise. The tour was wonderful and our guide knowledgeble. There were 14 in our group and we saw more than the Princess Tour had scheduled. We did not pay for the tour until the second day of the tour. We recommend this tour company to those who want a reliable, extensive tour with a smaller group.

Very Impressive. I joined a local tour to Tsarkoye Selo. There's only Russian tour, no English tour! But the price is 5-6 times less expensive than English tour. I only paid for around US $ 30++ p.p. for Russian tour and English tour charges around US $150-180 p.p but English tour only operates as private tour. But the good thing of joining the local tour is you could avoid the hassles of travelling to Tsarskoye Selo through public transport. Apparently it's complicated. Also, you could avoid wasting time on queuing, there is only limited time session open for public (not in tour). I visit both Alexander Palace and Catherine Palace. They are walking distance to each other. Catherine Palace is really impressive!!!! Also, the AMBER ROOM is another must!!! If you have 2 full days in St Petersburg, spend one day at Hemitage and one day to Catherine's Palace

Anastasia Travel is Awesome - Use them for Private Tours in St. Petersburg, Russia!. Anastasia Travel picked us up at the pier in St. Petersburg, Russia just as promised. They are a very professional and excellent tour company if you are looking to take a private tour of anything in St. Petersburg, Russia. We had a wonderful guide, Svetlana - "Lana"! She truly made our tour special. She was warm, knowledgeable, professional, and above all a delight. She provided us with everything we wanted to know about Catherine Palace and Park and kept us on track without hurrying us. Her insights were great. It felt as if we were on a stroll in the park with a friend instead of a tour guide. I definitely recommend you use Anastasia Travel in Russia if you are looking for a private tour and make sure you request "Lana". We loved her!!

An Extravaganza of Artwork. A visit to Catherine's Palace is an all-day affair. As you wait for your time-slot after purchasing your tickets you will notice some groups going in directly; so if you can be part of a group which has purchased tickets ahead of time -otherwise you could be waiting an extra half-hour listening to the dancing marching band at the front steps.Inside it's handy to have a tour guide, not only for the information on the artwork and historical background you are seeing, but also to navigate the maze of rooms and passages in the most efficient way possible. We had to divert a couple of times to avoid over-crowded rooms that we saw later. People management is a major concern, so you definitely need a guide. Wear comfortable shoes and dress cooly since there is no air conditioning and lots of stairs to climb. Get a pick of tourists putting on booties to protect the floor - an interesting story, but once you see the wood & marble inlaid floors you'll see why that's necessary.One disappointment is that photos are not permitted in either the amber room - but see them at whatever extra cost since the contents are astounding. Another good photo tip is to set your digital camera to 'no flash' and stability/shake control. Natural light gives much better pictures, flash photography annoys everyone with little real advantage, and you can always adjust the pics later with software. It would also be handy to have a voice recorder to match up with the pics, since you will want to remember a lot of what you see when you get home. Having a bottle of water with you is also a good idea. Tip your tour guide generously because these knowledgeable people make very little for very hard work.

pickpocket. BEWARE of pickpocket!!!In general I find both Moscow and St. Petersburg very safe and there are many police force around the city. However, I was nearly pickpocketed in the Metro Station on the way back from Catherine Palace. There were two men in front of the entrace to the compartment and when the door was opened and they walked in before me and my friend but they instantly turned around and walked face to face making us step backward. In the meantime, two to three other pushed from behind trying to squeeze us in the middle. In a split of second, I covered my backpocket in which my wallet was and found half the wallet was already out. Then my friend and I made a big turn with our arms and hands driving those men away.I was lucky to keep my wallet but it is a lesson for me too as I should have never kept my wallet in a backpocket of my pants.I am a stocky man with a friend next to me; they still eyed on me as a target. I can't even say what could happen to a single or two ladies in this case!!!So keep your belonging safe in those busy subway stations.

Better than the Hermitage. We had a long debate and struggle between visiting Catherine IIs palace (Tsarskoye Selo) or the Peterhof. Both are summer palaces, both are supposed to be beautiful, but we were so glad we visited Catherine IIs because we are particularly interested in elegant INTERIORS. The Peterhof is better for the gardens/fountains.I'd consider the interior here just a touch short of Versaille. Versaille is so perfect, perfectly restored, high quality silks drapes/walltreatments, etc etc. Here the drapers were polyester, but the gold gilding, the paintains, the ornate floors, etc were all great. And the gardens were still very nice. I'd also say the interior here was notably better than the Hermitage - if you can do just 1, do this over the Hermitage.BTW - get a guide - I've written a review for guide gurus who set ours up. It saved us a lot of time (we didn't have to wait in any lines).Also be aware that entry times are limited - certain times for singles (non-guided) others for guided groups, so be sure to check that before you go.

Beautiful grounds and an impressive building interior. This building was gutted in the Second World War by a fire initiated by a bomb. Even though it was a monarchist site, the Stalin led communists restored the building to its previous glory, a process which took over 40 years. The result is a building of golden domes and richly adorned rooms plus the grounds with graveled walking areas. This palace is on a par with any I've seen elsewhere, including the Summer palace in Vienna. And the crowds are smaller so you can actually experience the palace.

Don't miss the Amber Room.... a Wonder of the world.. If I can only visit one palace in Russia, I will choose this palace. I think it is very representative of the flamboyance of the Russian palace, in particular, the overwhelming element of gold. The interior of the building is heavily gilded. Being a Chinese myself, I love gold (kind of Chinese tradition - means wealth) and I don't find it oppressive as the craftsmanship was really refined and delicate. It was only a bit dazzling to look at after you were led from one room to another. The chambers, however, are not all the same. They have themes and purposes and I was happy to see some Chinese elements in a few rooms. The highlight of the visit was the Amber room (NO photo only in this room). This is really a national treasure. The interior of the chamber was covered and decorated by amber stones of different colours. It was really sensational and mind-blowing to see the subtle lights radiating from different corners of the room and you feel like standing inside a box made of precious jewels. It was a pity to learn from our guide that the original Amber room (which was a gift from another country) was lost during WWII. The present Amber room is a replicate...yet the stones are all real. We were also told that the original Amber room was even more glamorous because of the high quality of stones available in the old days.You cannot stay too long in the room because of the heavy 'traffic' behind. Nevertheless, it really 'opened' my eyes and it is something that makes this visit unforgettable. I visited there in late May but there were already crowds of tourists. I am glad that I joined a group tour so that no time will be wasted queuing up for tickets or lining up to go inside. Remember that there were not much English signs (perhaps.. 'Exit' and 'Toilet" are the only frequently seen words in some but not all tourist spots) nor English explanatory notes on spots of interest. If you go by yourself + cannot speak Russian, you are going to waste a lot of time sorting out things. The soothing colour of light blue and white on the outside of Catherine Palace is merely a disguise to the hidden passion inside the gilded rooms. Catherine is really unforgettable.

Stunning palace and grounds. Catherine's palace is one of the most popular day trips out of St Petersburg, and with good reason -- the palace is beautiful, the various rooms, decorating in baroque and classical styles are perfectly restored. Considering the state of the palace after WWII, this is quite amazing. The state rooms and, of course, the famous Amber Room are beautiful--the ornaments and sumptuous fabrics on the walls, the furniture and gilt-work are very interesting. It's easy to get "palaced-out" if you visit a couple of the ornate palaces in St. Petersburg, so visit this one early--you don't want to be jaded as you walk around the state rooms. They can be a bit overwhelming...the amount of gilt-work and rococo swirls start to get oppressive after awhile.Fewer rooms are open during high season, to try to keep the crowds moving; visiting in Winter, our guide said, can be better since more of the living spaces are open. Be prepared for crowds, of course. This is a very popular place. Huge tour groups tend to dominate every space inside, and if you are in a smaller group, or trying to linger in a room to look around, it can be hard. It's worth hiring a guide or joining a day-trip tour in order to have the advantage of being "in a tour" -- being a solo visitor can mean long waits. Shoe covers are mandatory, and while photography is allowed inside in most other rooms, it is not allowed in the Amber Room. Getting pictures without crowds can be a problem, but it can be done if you're patient. (If you're like me, you don't like vacation pictures with hundreds of strangers in therm!) I mostly noticed the noise level, though -- tour guides talking loudly, people listening to audio headsets, etc. It's part and parcel of a very crowded tourist site, though.Having a local guide explain the history of the building and the restoration of the palace, and the significance of the art rooms and various differing styles that appear in the palace was absolutely worth it--and having a guide for just a couple, so we could ask questions and really focus on what interested us, was great.A visit to the palace should be included in any trip to St. Petersburg--it is one of the best examples around.

easy to get there on your own, not so easy to get in. The review by veresch on Jan 12 2011 is spot on. The only thing to add is advise on the ease of getting there from St Petersburg. Take the metro to Moskovskaya station on Line 2. Exit the station and look for the large soviet looking building (it stands out). You may be right next to the building or have a short walk depending on which exit you use at the station. There are buses and cabs (these are mini-vans). Look for K-342. This shared ride will take you there. It will make some stops in the local area and then on the highway before arriving in Pushkin. Look out the right side and when you pass Alexander palace you are seconds away from arriving at Catherine palace. The ride is 30 rubles. Do not follow the tour groups to the palace gate, go down the street with the kiosks, make a left, and buy a ticket to the park. Enter here and then queue for the palace on this side of the palace. Go back to the same street corner you were dropped off at, when you see K-342 stick out your hand and pay the driver another 30Rubles. After driving down the highway the cab stops at Kupchino metro station. You can get off here or wait until Moskovskaya. Kupchino is on the same line. If you visit Alexander palace, the cloak room is downstairs, next to the toilet. You must drop your bags and purse and then put on show covers before entering the palace. Cab 545 is also supposed to work as well, but we only used 342. It is easy and cheap.

very beautiful & worth the visit. we had the hotel [Radisson] contact a tour for us. We were lucky & had a english speaking guide & went via car. Just the 2 of us, the guide & the driver. was well worth the money. $7000 rubles. Tour was four hours. However, if you are visiting in the summer I would suggest an all day tour. the palace & gardens were a beautiful winter wonderland when I was there, so can only imagine how beautiful the gardens would look without snow. It was very beautiful covered in snow. One thing, be careful using your credit card. The souvenir shop at the palace was the only place I used mine on the whole trip to Russia & after I got home, 2 weeks later, the credit card coy advised me that my card had been compromised. Could have been a coincidence I guess.

Peculiarities of individual visiting. To get to this attraction of the world renown is not an easy task - commuter trains are not regular, there's no regular bus service of proper quality, there are only minibuses which can be found after reaching Moskovskaya metro station in the square behind a huge monument to Lenin and in front of a big official building with Soviet hammer and sickle at the top.The palace's working schedule is something quite irregular: in high season individuals enter from the garden side at 12-14 and 16-17 hours - but in case there are no groups coming from the other side (whom you do not see) - they may open doors earlier; they may not open doors for individuals at all in case too many prearranged groups are to come or a cruise ship being late or in case of a government event to take place or because of a preparation for a government event. The palace's official days off at any season - every Monday and last Tuesday of every month but for groups they may open the doors even in these days.In case you managed to enter - you get your tickets inside and then you are to leave at their check room (left of the individual entrance) your overcoats/raincoats/wet umbrellas/ bags bigger than 1 ft/ knapsacks. Before getting to a turnstile you are to pass through a frame like in the airport, in case you need to escape it due to health reasons (pacemakers etc) - it is possible to do but you should provide a sign to a security attendant near the frame.In a room where you are to put on protective bags on your shoes for the sake of parquets (after the turnstile) they form groups to go with Russian-speaking guides. No substitution for non-Russian speakers at this time, no audio guides, hardly any English-speaking guides with their tourists can be found to join them, no information (or almost no) in the halls - so, try to prepare yourself in advance. There are 2 routes - but usually only one is provided for individuals, through the Golden enfilade of rooms. Sometimes, in case of a big amount of individuals - they can divide them and to send part of the line to the second route where you see only 2 main iteriors - the Big hall and the Amber room while the rest of the barogue Golden enfilade you will not see.There have been no elevators for wheelchairs so far (though they have spoken about its installation) -but sometimes handicapped people can get to the main second floor being in a group ready to take them upstairs and then downstairs. I have participated in such events twice myself with my tourists eager to see the palace but not being able to get out of a wheelchair. Strollers can be taken upstairs as well - at your risk.The cafe at the palace is overpriced, its coffee is definitely not worth what they charge - and honestly speaking no good places in the surroundings can be found, water even outside the garden is almost triple regular price,so you are supposed to enjoy the beauty and splendour of the palace and the garden around coming filled in advance.But - putting aside all these possible problems - the place is definitely worth seeing.

Very beautiful place. Tsarskoye Selo is one of my favorite places around St. Petersburg. It is very quite and beautiful and it is so relaxing to walk through park's paths and feed squirrels. Beside the park itself there are also a lot of tourist attractions. For example, Catherine Palace that is on my mind one of the most luxurious palaces in the world. And the gem of this palace is world known Amber Room. It is impossible to describe the splendors of this room, it just must be visited. So, do not spare one day from your trip and visit Tsarskoye Selo; believe me it is worth visiting.

Very impressive and very crowded. The Catherine Palace is by far the most crowded sight in St Petersburg, so the best way to get there is with an organized tour, especially if you come in the summer time. This will save you time that otherwise you will have to spend lining up to enter the palace.If, however, you do decide to visit the palace on your own, remember that during the high season (May through September) individual visitors are admitted between 12 o’clock and 2:00 p.m. and then between 4:00 and 5:00 p.m. Although the palace opens at 10 o’clock, the rest of the entrance time is allocated to organized tours.The palace is actually in the countryside (about 20 km to the south of St Petersburg), so the drive there from the city center takes at least an hour. If you are determined to use public transport, take the subway to Moskovskaya station, and then a minibus (No. 342 or 545) to the palace. Using minibuses is a challenge in Russia unless you can speak some Russian because most drivers speak neither English nor any other language spoken in West Europe, so make sure you find out in advance exactly where to get on the bus and where to get off.The entrance for individual visitors is from the garden side of the palace. The booking offices are inside the palace. Before you go through the turnstiles, make sure you check your overcoats and bigger-sized bags in the cloakroom (no cloakroom charge) as these are not allowed in the palace rooms.There is an endless flow of tourist groups through the palace rooms, so if you want a tour, it is usually fairly easy to pick up a group that speaks your language and to listen in to the tour guide’s explanations.Because the palace tends to get overcrowded, they close up part of it during the high season to speed up the traffic, so if you come then, you are most likely to see just the famous “Golden Suite” of reception rooms designed by Rastrelli, which includes the unique Amber Room. The rest of the year, when the place is not as crowded, you might have a chance to see the living rooms as well.No flash photography is allowed in the palace, and there is a total ban on photography in the Amber Room (apparently introduced to prevent people from staying there for hours taking photographs). For those who want a picture of the Amber Room, there is a bookstore downstairs that sells separate booklets of this room as well as sets of postcards and books of the palace interiors.The Catherine Park around the palace has quite a few interesting and beautiful pavilions, so leave half an hour to walk around and admire the scenery. There is a small coffee shop inside the palace, and on a fine day, it is worthwhile to have a short rest in the open-air café in the garden in front of the palace.

The Amber Room is breathtaking. The Catherine Palace with it's blue and gold exterior is beautiful. The palace has been fully restored after the Nazi's destroyed it during WWII. All the rooms are furnished with exquisite decorations and furniture. The Great Hall with it's gold embellishments is something from a fairytale. But the highlight of the palace is the Amber Room with it's walls of amber. It's like nothing you have ever seen before. The walk around the palace grounds let's you see all the beautiful buildings and lakes on the property. Well worth the hour or so ride outside of St. Petersburg to visit.

Plan ahead for the unexpected.. When we first arrived here, in the mid-season, we were greeted by a poster in Russian saying "The palace is closed today and on Tuesday". And so it was. We checked the web page the day before and there was no warning abut that. So if you really want to see the Amber Room and the palace interiors, do call them ahead or plan for a second, back-up visit in Pushkin. Ordering a guided tour might help, too...The Museum's web page is really useful when planning your trip - it lists many options of travel, including the Marshrutka or bus from St. Petersburg. While the former (which is a privately-owned mini-bus) is a cheap and fast (and sometimes furious) option, the later is a bit tiring as the bus is usually full and drives around the town for about half an hour.In addition to the palace itself, there are two parks in the immediate surrounding. The one in front of the building is paid (a separate ticket is required), while the one behind the palace (containing chinese pagodas among other stuff) is free. It's a nice place for a walk if you have time - it may take from 30 mins to a couple of hours, you can also meet locals doing a BBQ or sunbathing in some areas.All in all, it's a days trip from St Petersburg but it's definitely worth it.

Gardens were a winter wonderland!. Was a little disappointed as the exterior was undergoing quite a bit of renovation when I visited in Jan 2010 (guess they are getting ready it ready for the summer). The palace was pretty much destroyed during the war, but the rooms have been beautifully restored – I didn't think they were as spectacular as the staterooms in the Hermitage and the amber room was a little weird (not to my taste). However, if you visit in Winter and have the good fortune to have had some snow – the gardens are magnificent – a true winter wonderland!

Catherine's Palace a must visit. We went with a tour group so it was nice to have transportation as the location is a bit far outside St Petersburg. The grounds are gorgeous and the palace is incredible, definitely recommend!

Very lavish. We joined an English speaking tour, next to Gostiny Dvor, on Nesvksy Prosect. They don't go everyday - I think it's closed on Tuesday- so check ahead. We travelled out on a mini bus which was fine. Our guide had perfeect English and was very informative. There is something odd going odd at this time (June 2009) between the locals, the police and the tours and we were told to be ready to leave the bus in a hurry when our driver got a parking spot. On gently pushing the guide as to what was going on he explained that Pushkin is a very upmarket area, the locals are not interested in their roads being clogged up with tourists and tour busses so they bribe the police to fine the drivers for parking etc. The tour groups in turn bribe the police to look the other way and so it goes on. When we were there the locals had upped the ante! We had to phone the driver and arrange a pick up spot etc on the way back too. Bizarre! Particularly given the many hundreds of acres available to create a car park witout even impinging on the palace.Anyhow the palace is extremely impressive outside with its 300 metre span and gold statues. Inside is equally impressive. It is trully very lavish, with gold everywhere. As it was destroyed during WWII they have done an incredible job on restoration. The famous Amber room is of course a copy as the original disappeared during the WWII German occupation. The whole palace is just amazing and very over the top in it's baroque style. One can't help thinking of the poor peasants starving while the tsars lived in such lavish palaces! No wonder they rose up! Catherines private rooms / wing is still under renovation. But you can see a lot of the rooms in the main run of the Palace. Well well worth a visit. If you can get around the gardens at all too they are pretty impressive though obviously not on a par with Peterhof.

Other Worldly. This was the highlight of my visit to St. Petersburg. A must see and pay attention to the floors a well as the walls and ceilings. A fairy tale palace. Take the dinner tour if possible where you receive champagne, caviar and entertainment along with a great meal, vodka and wine!!!

Join tours, or wait in the long lines. Through our hotel, we joined a day tour to visit the palace.The guide sure knows how to get into the palace and park, as well she gave a very detailed tour of the palace.The palace is meticulous, and deserves a close study.The park is very big and will take an entire afternoon to walk around.Travel time to the town is around one hour, depending on traffic condition.So the trip will easily take up a day.

Great palace, strange queue. First of all, this is a very nice place. We have been in the winter (around new year) and the place is not crowded and the scenery is great! We went on our own. First with the metro to metro station moskovskaya , from there you can pick a few minibuses (286, 287, 299, 342, 32 Rubles pp). But then we encountered a strange phenomenon. Before the palace was a queue of some 30-40 people. The door was closed and there was no ticket booth. We stood in line for some time, and we gradually came up front because some of the people moved out of the queue. Then we heard from some russians that the doors opened at 16:00, and it was just 14:15! It seems that the doors openend for individuals at 14:00 and 16:00 (in the morning 10:00 and 12:00 I believe). Then we walked around in the park en we got back in line at 15:30 at -10 degree celcius! At exactly 16:00 the doors opened and there was a rush of russian people heading forward, climbing the fence, pushing like there was some kind of disaster happening! Fortunately, we were in the second group to enter the palace, which was beautiful. You are assigned to a russian tour guide, which you can easily leave to go your own way. Tickets you can by in the palace for +/- 550 Rubles.

Makes Buckingham Palace look like a bugalow. We visited the palace in June 2008 on a Royal Caribbean tour. The palace is breathtaking, in fact, as our group walked up to the front of the palace, a British member of our tour group quipped, "It makes Buckingham Palace look like a bungalow". Each room is more captivating than the last one. The beauty of the palace must be seen to be believed. If you have an opportunity to visit the palace while in Russia, you should go, there is so much history and beauty which, again, must be experienced first hand to be believed.

If you have seen Palace of Versailles in Paris, skip Peterhof and go here. I was lucky enought to have the time to make two excursions outside of St. Petersburg and to see both Peterhof palace and Catherine Palace in Tsarskoye Selo. I have to say that I liked Tsarskoye Selo much better than the higher rated Peterhof.I was blown away by Catherine Palace and the parks surronding the palace. Just seeing the Amber room will make your visit worthwhile.Make sure to walk the grounds around the park! The park is beautiful.For those travelers that have to chose between Peterhof and Catherine Palace, I would suggest going to Catherine Palace if you have seen Palace of Versailles outside of Paris.I think Tsarskoye Selo give you much better feel for a "Russian" palace vs. the more eleborate Russian copy of the French Versailles - Peterhof. (The fountains and the gardens of Peterhoff are much more impressive then Versailles so don't get me wrong) Althought I was visiting St. Petersburg in the end of Septemer, Peterhof was crowded. Buses and buses of tourists. Tsarskoye Selo was not crowded at all. Mostly locals were visiting the park.Getting to the place was not hard at all. As other posts mention, taking the metro to Moskovskaya station and then marshrutka #299 (mini bus) will get you there. The cost was under $4 round trip.I think hotels can arrange a tour to Tsarskoye Selo if you are afraid to venture out on your own.

A true higlight of a trip to St Petersburg. The place is just awesome! A true counterpart to the famous Winter Palace - and not surprisingly, since this was the royal summer residence (while the Winter Palace was, naturally, the winter one). Especially recommended for those more interested in seeing the royal interiors then, say, the art displays. Although the palace itself is a masterpiece of art - I perfectly agree that the Amber Chamber alone is worth a visit! Such a pity the guide didn't let us to spend more time in it...

Worth the money to go see. Catherine's palace is 26 km outside St. Pertersburg and well worth the trip. It was destroyed by the Nazis and they painstakingly restored it to its prior state. They showed the before and after pictures which were amazing. Like most attractions in Russia, without a tour group they hard to get into. HOWEVER, this is one you can do solo if you prefer. To get there,you can take the metro to Moskovskaya and take a marshrukas(van/bus vehicle) just outside of the station (26Rtakes 30 min). Or take metro to Vitebsk Train Station. Take local train (go up to second floor, by pass first ticket booths go to ticket booth on the left side of the platform for local trains). After you have the ticket got to platform 1 and get off at the "DETSKOE SELO" stop or the "PAVLOVSK" stop (to see Catherine's son palace). Cost is 30R take 30 min. The stop is within walking distance (about 1mile walk) just go straight accross round-about to end of street then go right 3-4blocks and turn left until you run into it. Without a tour group you have to enter throught Catherine's park (130R). The queue for individuals starts at around 3:30pm (they left groups of 30 at a time starting at 4:00pm) the Palace costs (530R). You will be put in a group witha Russian speaking guide, you can just pass the guide an go on your own after you go upstairs.
Amber Room was worth the visit. The restoration of the Amber Room is truly magnificent. A true testament to the resolve of the Russian people to restore a treasure like that.

The most magnificent palace I've ever seen. The first time I came to Catherine's Palace, I was an impressionable 16 years old and arrived just as the snow fall shifted from a flurry to a steady pour. We had a few hours to kill before our tour started, so we took our time wandering around the grounds. It was almost empty because it was early March and the tourists hadn't really started coming out yet. It was that afternoon that I fell in love with Russia. Catherine's gardens and forests looked almost magical. This was a postcard perfect Russian setting right out of Dr. Zhivago. But most people come here in summer, when it is still breathtakingly beautiful, but you do have to contend with the throngs of tourists. This is good and bad--more tourists mean more chances that there will be a tour in English. If you don't speak Russian and have come on your own, ask if there's going to be a tour in English. If not, they'll quickly figure out that a Russian tour won't benefit you any, and will let you go in to walk around the palace by yourself. The inside of the palace is overwhelming in its opulence. The most impressive room is the recently restored Amber room--the entire room is an elegant (and expensive!) work of art. After the tour, you're allowed to stroll through the rooms again on your own--this gives you a chance to really look closely at the details and to take pictures in a quieter environment. And be sure to leave yourself time to walk through at least some of the outdoor paths. Most tourists don't do this, so you can usually have to path to yourself. It feels like discovering hidden treasure when you happen upon some elegant little statue or charming pagoda in the forest.Getting here on your own is a little tricky, but not impossible. The electric train to Pushkin from Petersburg barely costs anything, and it's a very Russian experience in itself. From there you can take any of the dozens of mini-buses outside the station with "Palace" written on the side. Coming on your own and not with a tour will also give you more time to explore the other sights in Pushkin, like the royal carriage house. These other attractions are also interesting, but are rarely visited by non-Russians. If you get hungry, the cafe in the Palace is actually quite good and fairly priced.
